site_title: China's CNOOC Q1 net income doubles, domestic output jumps
summary: China's state-owned oil company CNOOC reported a 132% increase in net income to 34.3 billion yuan (S$19 billion) in the first quarter of 2022, driven by a surge in global oil prices and domestic oil and gas production. Revenue rose 74% year-on-year to 90.9 billion yuan. The company's total net production increased by 10% to 151 million barrels of oil equivalent, with domestic output rising 15% and overseas output dipping 3%.

images.alt_text: China's CNOOC Ltd saw its stock surge as much as 44 per cent in its Shanghai debut on Thursday in defiance of overall market weakness, as investors sought safety in the oil giant amid lofty energy prices and quickening inflation.

site_title: Weibo shows user locations to combat 'bad behaviour'
summary: Weibo, China's equivalent of Twitter, has started publishing users' IP locations on their account pages and when posting comments to combat "bad behaviour" online. The move, which garnered over 200 million views, will display users' IP addresses under new settings that cannot be turned off. For users in China, the platform will display the province or municipality, while overseas users will see the country of their IP address. The goal is to reduce impersonation, malicious disinformation, and traffic scraping while ensuring content authenticity and transparency.

site_title: Taiwan Q1 preliminary GDP grows faster than expected
summary: Taiwan's economy grew at a slower pace in Q1 with 3.06% annual GDP growth, beating expectations of 2.9% but the slowest since 2020. Strong tech exports and global demand for chips supported growth, despite weaker consumer confidence and inflation. Total exports soared 23.5% from a year earlier, driven by continued international demand for tech products. Revised GDP figures, including full-year growth forecasts for 2022, will be released next month.

site_title: KKR to launch tender offer for Hitachi Transport in US$5.2b
summary: KKR & Co will launch a tender offer for logistics company Hitachi Transport System in a deal valued at over US$5 billion. The offer price is set at 8,913 yen (S$94.30) per share, a premium to Hitachi Transport's closing price of 8,540 yen on April 28. This deal will allow KKR to acquire a majority stake in Hitachi Transport, with parent Hitachi Ltd selling its approximately 40% stake and then acquiring 10% in the acquiring fund.

site_title: Singtel’s Australian unit enters A$1.4b sustainability-linked revolving credit facility
summary: Singtel's Australian subsidiary Optus Finance has secured a $1.4 billion sustainability-linked revolving credit facility. The loan is guaranteed by Singtel Optus and its subsidiaries, with interest rate discounts tied to Optus' 25% reduction in absolute greenhouse gas emissions by 2025 compared to a 2015 baseline. This marks the first revolving credit facility by an Australian telco.

site_title: S&P Global bumps up Pertamina, PLN and Astra ratings as Indonesia's credit outlook brightens
summary: S&P Global has revised its ratings on Indonesian companies Pertamina, Perusahaan Listrik Negara (PLN), and Astra International to "stable" from "negative", reflecting Indonesia's economic recovery from the pandemic and improved terms of trade. The ratings agency expects these companies to benefit from ongoing government support and maintain their financial flexibility during a period of sovereign stress. Indonesia's economic outlook has improved, with a 5.1% growth rate in 2022, compared to 3.7% in 2021.

images.alt_text: Indonesia clarified the embargo would include all exports of the oilseed and not only products intended for edible oils, as indicated a day earlier.

site_title: Indonesia palm oil shares, rupiah take hit from tougher export ban
summary: Indonesia's palm oil shares and rupiah currency fell after the government imposed a tougher export ban, including crude palm oil and refined products, effective immediately. The ban aims to cut high domestic cooking oil prices, but its impact on global markets and Indonesian earnings is uncertain. Shares in palm oil companies fell, with Astra Agro Lestari dropping 6.6%, while the rupiah currency hit its lowest since July 2021. The ban's duration and effects remain unpredictable, with the government planning to review it monthly.

site_title: CapitaLand Investment remains long-term positive on China
summary: CapitaLand Investment Limited (CLI) remains long-term positive on China, citing supportive government policies to steer economic growth. Despite internal and external pressures, CLI believes its extensive domestic presence and diversification of asset classes will enable it to navigate uncertainty and capitalize on emerging investment opportunities. The company's successful registration as a private equity fund manager and its ability to tap into Chinese domestic fund flow will further expand its fund raising channels and enhance portfolio resilience.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand Investment to issue S$400m worth of notes due 2027 at 3.33%

site_title: VW mulls expanding US plant to build ID.Buzz, electric pickup: source
summary: Volkswagen is considering an expansion of its Chattanooga plant in the US to produce an electric pickup and the ID.Buzz microbus, aiming to grow its market share in North America. The move is part of the company's plan to invest $7.1 billion in the region over 5 years and add 25 new electric vehicles by 2030. The Chattanooga plant, which already produces the Passat and Atlas, began pilot production of the ID.4 electric crossover in March, and the ID.Buzz may initially be imported before potential assembly in the US or Mexico.

site_title: Singapore startup UnaBiz emerges as white knight to troubled French tech giant
summary: A Singapore startup, UnaBiz, has emerged as the winning bidder for troubled French tech giant Sigfox, purchasing the company and its French subsidiary for 25 million euros (S$36.4 million). UnaBiz's co-founder and co-chief Henri Bong believes Sigfox's "fantastic" technology can be turned around with a new strategy, and the company plans to collaborate with other IoT communication technologies. UnaBiz has cash reserves to fund the acquisition and has previously raised over US$50 million in funding.

3,000 sensors at Temasek Poly can soon alert on frigid indoor sweater weather, energy waste

site_title: With Corsican reds, a case study of identity
summary: A case study of Corsican red wines explores how context and emotions influence taste. Corsican wines, made from grapes genetically identical to Tuscan varieties, are distinctive due to their terroir and cultural context. Producers capitalize on these connections, creating emotional ties with wine tourism. A three-wine tasting featuring Domaine Maestracci, Domaine Pinelli, and Domaine Comte Abbatucci showcases the unique characteristics of Corsican reds, including the Maestracci's 35% niellucciu blend and the Abbatucci's 70% sciaccarellu and 30% niellucciu combination. The wines' distinctiveness may be attributed to Corsican soils, climate, and cultural practices.

images.alt_text: Two bottles of the same wine can seem quite different depending on the context in which they are tasted or consumed. site_title: Taiwan's daily cases cross 10,000 after zero-Covid shift
summary: Taiwan has recorded over 10,000 new COVID-19 cases for the first time, following the government's shift away from its zero-Covid strategy. The health minister reported 11,353 local cases, 2 deaths, and 164 imported cases. This move marks a departure from China, which still adheres to a zero-tolerance policy. The shift is a result of Omicron's spread, forcing painful lockdowns in major economies.

images.alt_text: People line up at a testing centre for the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) in Keelung, Taiwan April 28, 2022. REUTERS/I-Hwa Cheng

site_title: Foreign workers to drive job growth in 2022 as Singapore economy reopens
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to drive job growth in 2022, with non-resident employment outpacing local employment gains. Despite a tight labour market, the Ministry of Manpower predicts modest growth in resident employment, driven by an ongoing economic recovery and border reopening. Non-resident employment, particularly in the construction sector, is expected to continue recovering, with 41,100 new jobs added in the first quarter. Experts warn that accommodating workers with higher expectations or skills may be a challenge, but overall, the labour market is expected to remain tight, with unemployment rates staying low.

Singapore National Employers Federation president Dr Robert Yap. In his May Day message on Thursday, Dr Yap said the tripartite partners are working together to address manpower issues to sustain growth.
The bulk of the increase in first-quarter non-resident employment stemmed from work permit holders in construction, according to the Ministry of Manpower.

site_title: The riddle of Russian money in Switzerland
summary: Switzerland, known for its banking secrecy, is believed to be a treasure house of Russian oligarchs' wealth, but a recent analysis found that only $8 billion of Russian assets have been frozen in the country, despite mirroring US and EU sanctions against 900 individuals. This low figure reflects the difficulty in tracing the effective control of assets, with many held indirectly through family members or trusts. Swiss banks have estimated that around $150-200 billion of Russian money is held, but the strict banking secrecy laws make it challenging for law enforcement to access this information.

images.alt_text: The Moscow Exchange, which closed after Russia’s Feb 24 invasion of Ukraine, partially re-opened on Mar 24 but only to local investors.

site_title: Eurozone government bond yields fall, focus on inflation data
summary: Eurozone government bond yields fell on Thursday, driven by investors focusing on inflation data, particularly Spain's slowdown in inflation to 8.1%, beating expectations of 9%. The uncertainty surrounding the economic impact of Russia halting gas supplies to Europe and lingering lockdowns in China also dampened risk sentiment. The European Central Bank's president Christine Lagarde hinted at a possible rate rise in July, while ECB vice-president Luis de Guindos emphasized the need to monitor inflation expectations.

images.alt_text: The ECB has been rolling back support at a glacial pace for months but a surge in inflation to nearly 4 times the ECB’s 2 per cent target is intensifying calls to finally end a nearly decade-long foray into ultra-easy monetary policy.

site_title: Your phone number on Google? Search giant now takes removal demands
summary: Google has begun accepting requests to remove search results containing users' home addresses, phone numbers, and email accounts, expanding its removal policies globally. The move follows growing demand from users and evolving norms about the threat posed by easy access to contact details. The company aims to preserve data in the public interest and will not remove information from government or official sources. Google typically processes requests within a few days, and users are encouraged to contact publishers to address the root of the issue.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares rise as BOJ keeps ultra-loose policy
summary: Japanese shares rose 1.75% to close at 26,847.90, the biggest daily gain since April 13, following the Bank of Japan's decision to maintain its ultra-loose monetary policy and unlimited government bond purchases. Investors were relieved by the lack of policy changes, boosting appetite for stocks. The Nikkei and Topix also rose, with Toyota Motor and Advantest among the top gainers.

images.alt_text: Tokyo shares opened slightly higher on Thursday.
Asian markets enjoyed some much-needed gains on Thursday.

site_title: Twitter scraps opening event at Singapore HQ day after Elon Musk buyout
summary: Twitter has cancelled a planned event to open its expanded office space in Singapore, its Asia-Pacific hub, following Elon Musk's proposed $44 billion buyout. The event was set to take place on April 28, but Twitter did not provide a reason for the change in plans. The company will instead focus on sharing initiatives with the Singapore government, including online safety, digital literacy, and tech talent. The planned event was attended by Singapore's Minister for Communications and Information, and its cancellation has raised concerns about the company's future and potential implications for the media landscape and politics.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk's US$44 billion bid to buy Twitter involves US$12.5 million in margin loans against his stake in electric-car maker Tesla, spooking investors in the latter.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end on healthy note
summary: Hong Kong shares closed with a 1.65% gain, following a positive lead from New York and an advance across Asia. The Hang Seng Index rose to 20,276.17, while the Shanghai Composite Index increased 0.58%. The move was seen as a welcome boost to the stuttering economy, following leaders' pledges to provide support.

site_title: Hermès new watch puts playful, innovative spin on  world timer complication
summary: Hermès unveiled the Arceau Le temps voyageur at Watches and Wonders Geneva 2022, a playful world timer complication featuring a fantasy equestrian map on the dial. Developed by Chronode, the watch displays 24 time zones using a unique "travelling time" complication module with 122 components, integrated into the H1837 mechanical self-winding movement. Available in platinum, matt black DLC-treated titanium, or steel, the watch features various finishes and textures on the dial, paying homage to Hermès' humble beginnings as a harness and saddle maker.

site_title: Thai workers' debt at 14-year high amid price rises, slow growth: survey
summary: Thai workers' debt has reached a 14-year high of 217,000 baht (S$8,723) per household, up 6% from last year, due to sluggish economic recovery and rising living costs. The debt is expected to reach 93-95% of GDP this year, further restricting domestic spending. The survey also found that a majority of service sector workers are worried about job losses, and Thailand's tourism sector may not return to pre-pandemic levels until 2026. This has raised concerns about the country's economic recovery and growth, which is forecasted to be just 3% this year.

site_title: Jardine C&C reports improved Q1 on the back of Astra earnings surge; shares jump 8.5%
summary: Jardine C&C reported improved Q1 2022 performance driven by higher earnings from its 50.1%-owned Astra International, with shares jumping 8.5% to S$29.10. Astra's earnings surged 84% in Q1, driven by domestic economic recovery and higher commodity prices. The company remains cautious about pandemic and geopolitical uncertainties for the rest of the year.

MAINBOARD listed Jardine Cycle & Carriage (Jardine C&C) said an off-market share purchase by its majority shareholder, Jardine Matheson Holdings, may be the reason behind unusual price movements in its shares on Thursday (Apr 21).

site_title: Carlsberg CEO sees more focus on Asia after Russian exit
summary: Carlsberg's CEO sees Asia as a key growth area after exiting the Russian market, citing countries like China, Vietnam, and India. The brewer reported a 24% organic sales increase to 14.9 billion kroner (S$2.9 billion) in the first quarter. Despite a US$1.4 billion writedown due to the Russian exit, Carlsberg plans to focus on growth in Asia and buy back up to 1 billion kroner worth of shares. The company's operating profit could decline by up to 5% or gain up to 2%, according to its revised forecast.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets jump at open
summary: European stock markets jumped at the start of trading on Thursday, April 28, extending a recovery from sharp losses earlier in the week. The FTSE 100 index rose 0.5% to 7,464.20 points, while the DAX index gained 0.9% to 13,916.33 points, and the Paris CAC 40 won 1.1% to 6,513.07 points. The recovery follows a decline earlier in the week, with investors remaining optimistic despite ongoing trade uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Unilever hikes prices as cost pressures build
summary: Unilever has raised prices by over 8% to offset higher supply chain and energy costs, exceeding forecasted sales volume decline of 1% in the first quarter. The company now expects full-year underlying sales growth to be towards the top end of its 4.5-6.5% guidance range, but its operating margin is expected to be towards the bottom end of its 16-17% range due to the Ukraine conflict. Unilever's forecast for cost inflation in the second half of the year is 2.7 billion euros, driven by raw material inflation.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB raises Frasers Centrepoint Trust target price to S$2.75
summary: CGS-CIMB has raised its target price for Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) to S$2.75 from S$2.73, maintaining an "add" rating. The new target price suggests a 13.2% upside from the current price of S$2.43. The trust's unit price rose 1.2% to S$2.46 following the announcement. The target price was derived from a dividend discount model and reflects the trust's distribution per unit (DPU) estimates for 2022 to 2024.

site_title: Biden’s high-stakes strategy in Ukraine poses challenges at home and abroad
summary: US President Joe Biden's strategy in Ukraine is shifting, with the administration now aiming to help Ukraine win the war and defeat Russia. This change in approach has been driven by a shift in public opinion, with many Americans now viewing Russia's actions as genocidal and wanting to support Ukraine's defense. The US has increased military and economic support for Ukraine, including providing advanced weaponry and billions of dollars in defense aid. The Biden administration aims to weaken Russia through a prolonged war, rather than seeking a direct military confrontation, and believes that a unified Western alliance will ensure Russia's defeat.

site_title: Visitor numbers to drive recovery at Marina Bay Sands Singapore
summary: Marina Bay Sands Singapore has reported positive earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (Ebitda) for the quarter ended March 31, driven by growing visitor numbers. Despite a 21.2% decline in net revenue to US$943 million, the company remains confident in the recovery of travel and tourism. Chairman and CEO Robert G Goldstein expressed enthusiasm for welcoming more guests back to properties in Macau and Singapore, with plans to invest in capacity expansion and enhancements. The company's net income for the quarter was US$2.53 billion, compared to a net loss of US$278 million in the same period last year.

site_title: Motor racing: Women's W Series sees Miami as a springboard to growth
summary: The W Series, an all-female single-seater championship, is set to gain significant growth with its upcoming Miami Grand Prix, its first major race. Founder Catherine Bond Muir sees Miami as a springboard for increased commercial and media interest. The series has partnered with Formula One and has secured a multi-year live coverage deal with Sky Sports. The season's expansion to 10 races aims to create role models for young women and promote positive change in society. Despite the challenges of breaking into Formula One, Bond Muir remains optimistic about the potential of her series.

site_title: Beyond risks such as Russia-Ukraine conflict, manpower is longer-term growth challenge: SNEF
summary: Singapore National Employers Federation president Dr Robert Yap emphasized that while the Russia-Ukraine conflict may inhibit economic growth in the near term, manpower is the longer-term challenge for the country. The tripartite partners are working together to address manpower issues through schemes like the Productivity Solutions Grant, encouraging employers to redesign jobs with technology and workers to upskill. The labour market needs to remain open to foreigners to address skills shortages, while employers should also develop and retain a Singaporean core. The goal is to create more progressive and inclusive workplaces for all workers.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS and RHB lower AA Reit TP on acquisition delays and financing costs
summary: Analysts from RHB and DBS have lowered their target prices for Aims Apac Reit (AA Reit) due to acquisition delays and financing costs. RHB revised its target price to S$1.66 from S$1.72, while DBS lowered its target price to S$1.55 from S$1.60. Despite this, both analysts maintain a "buy" call on the Reit, citing its strong positive rent reversion and potential for further rental growth.

site_title: Indonesia suspends all exports of palm oil
summary: Indonesia has imposed a complete ban on palm oil exports, citing a domestic shortage and soaring prices. The move aims to secure supplies of cooking oil, which has become scarce and expensive due to global market fluctuations. The country, the world's largest palm oil producer, aims to resume exports when local market prices fall to 14,000 rupiah per liter. The embargo affects all exports, including crude palm oil, and is seen as a last resort to prevent social tensions and stabilize the global vegetable oil market.

site_title: Prices of core construction materials in Singapore to remain high in next few quarters
summary: Singapore's core construction materials, including cement, steel, copper, and bricks, are expected to remain high in the next few quarters due to supply disruptions from the Russia-Ukraine war and ongoing supply chain issues. Cement prices are projected to rise 19.9% in the third and fourth quarters, while steel and copper prices are expected to increase 11.9% and 11.9% respectively. The construction industry's real output is forecast to grow 15.4% in 2022, but labour costs and material costs are expected to constrain growth, with brick prices rising 3.6% and diesel prices increasing 20.1%.

site_title: Fish tales at Poisson
summary: Poisson, a seafood restaurant in Singapore, has received mixed reviews for its nautical-themed dining experience. The restaurant's menu features a range of seafood dishes, including scallop ceviche, grey shrimp and tomato salad, and crab cakes, but critics argue that the dishes lack freshness and are overpriced. The restaurant's focus on seafood is commendable, but its execution falls short. While some dishes, such as the roasted French turbot, show promise, others, like the "hand-peeled" lump crab cakes, are disappointing. Overall, Poisson's rating is 6 out of 10, indicating a promising but flawed dining experience.

site_title: Singapore industrial space rents, prices continue to rise in Q1; occupancy falls: JTC
summary: Singapore's industrial space rents and prices continued to rise in Q1, with prices increasing 2.1% quarter-over-quarter and 5.6% year-over-year. Rents rose 1% quarter-over-quarter and 2.4% year-over-year, driven by strong demand for ramp-up facilities. Occupancy rates fell to 89.8% due to new completions and increased supply, but experts predict a rebound in coming quarters. Total available stock rose 333,000 sq m, while new industrial space is expected to hit the market, with JTC projecting 2.4 million sq m in the next 3 quarters.

site_title: Baidu leads years-long race for first driverless taxis in China
summary: Baidu has become the first company to deploy driverless taxis on Chinese roads, a milestone in its years-long quest to expand beyond internet advertising. Baidu and AI startup Pony.ai secured permits to operate autonomous cars without human intervention, a significant step towards fully autonomous vehicles. The approval marks a relaxation of Chinese rules and paves the way for Baidu to expand its self-driving services to 65 cities by 2025 and 100 cities by 2030.

site_title: Yangzijiang Financial fails to sparkle on trading debut; ComfortDelGro likely to remain on STI
summary: Yangzijiang Financial Holding (YZJFH) closed its first day of trading on the Singapore Exchange at S$0.62, a 43% discount to its net tangible asset (NTA) per share. The company's offshore investment is expected to reach 20% of its portfolio by 2023. As a component of Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, YZJFH will remain on the Straits Times Index (STI), while ComfortDelGro, the smallest STI component, is likely to be removed due to its market capitalization.

site_title: Pinterest posts strong quarter on ad spending boost
summary: Pinterest reported strong first-quarter revenue and profit, surpassing market estimates, driven by increased ad spending by businesses. Revenue rose 18% to $575 million, with strength in retail and international advertising. User growth declined 9% to 433 million, but mobile app users increased. The company cited the Ukraine crisis as a factor in its 11% revenue growth projection for the second quarter, which fell short of expectations. Pinterest's shares rose 9% in extended trading.

site_title: China Evergrande targets sales of 1b yuan in Golden Week holiday
summary: China Evergrande Group aims to sell 1 billion yuan (S$211 million) worth of apartments during China's Golden Week holiday, a 28-day period from April 25 to May 4. The target is spread across 413 projects nationwide, with a focus on the southwestern province of Sichuan. The company has offered special discounts on 10,000 apartments to boost sales, following a 95% resumption of construction work at its projects. This is the first reported sales target for 2022, after the company stopped disclosing monthly sales in September.

site_title: US bill to help Taiwan regain WHO status passes Congress, sent to Biden for signature
summary: The US House of Representatives unanimously passed a bill to help Taiwan regain its observer status at the World Health Organization, sending it to President Joe Biden for signature. The measure directs the Secretary of State to establish a strategy for obtaining observer status, which Taiwan lost in 2017 due to China's objections. Taiwan's leadership and response to the Covid-19 pandemic have been praised, with US Representative Gerry Connolly urging support for the bill, while China has already signaled it will not support Taiwan's participation at this year's assembly.

images.alt_text: Taiwan's strongest economic expansion in a decade likely cooled in the first quarter, and China's Covid lockdowns may pose challenges to growth in the months ahead.

site_title: Changi Airport mulls adding new flights amid manpower constraints
summary: Changi Airport is considering adding new flights amid manpower constraints. As border curbs are relaxed, travel demand is increasing, boosting passenger load factors on existing flights. However, ground-handlers are struggling to cope with a tight manpower situation, which may lead to poorer passenger service, including delays in baggage collection. Additional flights are expected to be launched in May, with most coming online this weekend, but approvals are only coming in progressively due to terminal constraints and manpower issues. The airport aims to accommodate slot applications as much as possible while ensuring a smooth airport experience.

site_title: Asia: Markets enjoy respite from heavy selling pressure
summary: Asian markets experienced gains on Thursday, lifted by bargain-buying, a positive lead from New York and Europe, and further economic support for China. Despite a troubled week, traders remain cautious due to the ongoing Ukraine war, surging inflation, and Chinese Covid-19 lockdowns. Analysts warn of high uncertainty and volatility, with the Federal Reserve's upcoming policy meeting expected to raise interest rates and signal further increases. Markets are also affected by the Russia-Ukraine conflict and the ongoing US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Societe Generale launches 4 new Nasdaq-100 DLCs in Singapore
summary: Societe Generale has launched four new 5x daily leverage certificates (DLCs) in Singapore, offering exposure to the Nasdaq-100 Index. The DLCs are available at two price points, S$2 and S$0.90, and provide 5x long and short exposure to the US tech-heavy index. The launch comes as the Nasdaq Composite index hits a 16-month low, and investors can use the DLCs to gain exposure to the US market during Asian hours.

site_title: StanChart Q1 profit beats estimates, gives bullish outlook
summary: Standard Chartered's Q1 pre-tax profit rose 6% to $1.5 billion, beating market estimates, driven by rising interest rates and a strong Asia-focused business. The lender now expects income growth to exceed its 5-7% range, aiming for a 10% return on tangible equity by 2024. However, the results also show potential challenges, including charges related to Sri Lanka's ratings downgrade and exposure to China's real estate sector.

site_title: Singapore AI startup Finbots.AI raises US$3m round from Accel
summary: Singapore-based AI startup Finbots.AI has raised US$3 million in a Series A funding round led by Accel. The funding will support product enhancement, marketing, and sales, and customer support. Finbots.AI develops an AI-powered credit scoring solution for banks and financial institutions, with plans to increase its headcount to 50 by the end of 2022. Accel's support will help Finbots.AI tap into the growing demand for AI-enabled solutions in the financial sector.

site_title: Gold hovers near 2-month low as dollar stays elevated
summary: Gold prices weakened on Thursday, hovering near a 2-month low, as the US dollar steadied near 5-year highs. Spot gold fell 0.1% to $1,885.20 per ounce, while the dollar index reached a 5-year top of 103.28. A stronger dollar makes gold less attractive for other currency holders, despite gold being seen as a safe store of value during economic crises. Global gold demand surged 34% year-on-year in the first quarter, driven by concerns over Russia's invasion of Ukraine and rising inflation.

site_title: A powerful dynasty bankrupted Sri Lanka in just 30 months
summary: Sri Lanka's Rajapaksa dynasty, which controlled the government for 12 of the last 20 years, has been bankrupted in just 30 months due to reckless tax cuts. After winning the 2019 election, Gotabaya Rajapaksa passed the tax cut immediately, restoring presidential powers held by his brother Mahinda. The move led to a collapse in revenue, forcing Sri Lanka to seek emergency funds from the IMF, World Bank, and China. The country's stock exchange is the world's worst performer this year, and the Rajapaksas are now in damage control mode, facing impeachment and human rights charges.

site_title: Samsung profit beats estimates on steady chip demand
summary: Samsung Electronics' first-quarter profit exceeded analysts' estimates at 11.13 trillion won (S$12.2 billion), driven by strong sales of memory chips and premium smartphones. Revenue reached a record high, despite slowing demand for electronic gadgets. The company's operating profit increased by about 50% and is expected to benefit from device manufacturers adopting new-generation chips. However, supply chain disruptions and global economic concerns are impacting consumer sentiment, leading to a 11% decline in global smartphone shipments.

site_title: Olivia Wilde served legal papers live on stage
summary: Olivia Wilde was served legal papers by her ex-partner Jason Sudeikis during her presentation at CinemaCon in Las Vegas. The papers, marked "Personal and Confidential," were handed to her on stage, but she continued with her presentation without missing a beat. The documents allegedly concern their 2 children, with Sudeikis stating he had no prior knowledge of the service and would never condone such an action. Wilde's representatives have not commented on the matter.

site_title: Moving against global tide, BOJ keeps ultra-low rates, dovish guidance
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its ultra-low interest rates and massive stimulus program, leaving guidance unchanged from the previous meeting in March. The central bank expects short- and long-term policy interest rates to remain at present or lower levels, and will offer unlimited 10-year government bond purchases to defend a 0.25% cap around its zero target. This move reinforces the BOJ's resolve to support a fragile economy amid rising raw material costs and inflation.

site_title: Bukalapak Q1 revenue rises 86% to 788b rupiah on growth from Mitra Bukalapak
summary: Bukalapak, an Indonesian e-commerce company, reported an 86% rise in revenue to 788 billion rupiah (S$75.4 million) for its first quarter ended March 31, 2022, driven by growth from its Mitra Bukalapak segment. Revenue from Mitra Bukalapak increased 227% to 472 billion rupiah, accounting for 60% of the company's overall revenue. The company also recorded a net profit of 14.5 trillion rupiah, up from a net loss of 324 billion rupiah in the same period last year.

site_title: S&P revises up Indonesia’s credit rating outlook to stable
summary: S&P Global Ratings revised Indonesia's credit rating outlook to "stable" due to the country's economic recovery from the pandemic and improved external position, including record high exports. The ratings agency cited Indonesia's fiscal consolidation efforts and the passage of the Job Creation law as positive factors. Despite geopolitical tensions and a slowing global economy, Indonesia's GDP growth is expected to accelerate to 5.1% in 2022. The revised outlook reflects confidence in Indonesia's economy, with the country's debt rated at BBB, on par with other major credit rating agencies.

site_title: New Zealand business confidence worsens in April: survey
summary: New Zealand business confidence decreased in April, with a net 42.0% of respondents expecting the economy to deteriorate over the year ahead, a slight worsening from March. Only 8.0% of respondents believed their businesses would grow in the next 12 months, down from 3.3% last month. The decline is attributed to ongoing inflation pressures and expectations of further rises.

site_title: Buffett-backed electric carmaker BYD sees 8,000% jump in net cash flow
summary: BYD, a Warren Buffett-backed electric carmaker, reported an 8,312% jump in net cash flow from operations in its first quarter, with 11.9 billion yuan generated from sales and services. This is the company's strongest first quarter in six years, driven by strong demand for its electric vehicles in China. Net income rose 241% to 808.4 million yuan, while sales increased 63% to 66.8 billion yuan. Analysts attribute the growth to soaring material prices for battery cells, setting a promising tone for the year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks kick off with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with gains on Thursday, rising 0.86% or 172.43 points to 20,118.79, following positive leads from Wall Street and Europe. This came after Chinese officials made commitments to support the country's economy. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index dipped 0.42% and 0.55%, respectively.

site_title: EU defies gas ‘blackmail’ as Russia pushes deeper into Ukraine
summary: Russia has cut off gas supplies to Bulgaria and Poland, two EU and NATO members supporting Ukraine, in a move described by the EU as "blackmail". The European Union warned Russia it will not bend to the "blackmail" and will respond immediately, united and coordinated. The move comes as UN chief Antonio Guterres met with Ukrainian leader Volodymyr Zelensky and Russian President Vladimir Putin, with Putin threatening a "lightning-fast" military response if Western forces intervene in Ukraine.

site_title: Singapore shares flat at Thursday’s open; STI edges up 0.01%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.01% or 0.22 points to 3,320.89 at 9:02 am on Thursday, tracking minor gains on Wall Street overnight. The index saw 49 gainers and 47 losers, with 188.9 million securities worth S$92.1 million changing hands. Key movers included Keppel Corp rising 2.4% and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding up 2.3%, while banking stocks fell, with DBS down 0.5% and UOB falling 1.4%. The US market also closed slightly higher on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.2%.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 8.02 points or 0.51% to 1,594.00, driven by a higher volume of 233.90 million lots worth RM110.60 million. The market saw 235 gains out of 99 losses.

site_title: Sinopec expects China's oil demand to recover in Q2, positive growth in 2022
summary: Sinopec Group, China's largest oil refiner, expects China's oil demand to recover in the second quarter as Covid-19 outbreaks are controlled. The company forecasts full-year oil consumption will reach positive growth despite a moderate recovery in the second quarter. Sinopec's refining runs have been cut since March, but the company maintains an "optimal" refinery operation ratio of around 85%. The firm also expects steady total liquefied natural gas imports in 2022, following a loss of 1.2 billion yuan in the first quarter due to high import costs.

site_title: QuantumScape bets on iron to ease battery supply chain squeeze
summary: QuantumScape, a solid-state battery startup backed by Volkswagen and Bill Gates, is exploring iron-based chemistries to mitigate soaring costs for raw materials. The company's ability to use iron instead of nickel could increase energy density by 50% and make its technology a viable alternative to lithium-ion batteries. QuantumScape is scaling production of its prototype cells, which could help boost electric-vehicle adoption by providing a safer and cheaper alternative to existing battery technologies.

site_title: Economic growth risks jolt inflation-obsessed markets
summary: Global economic growth is at risk of being jolted by inflation-obsessed markets, with financial analysts predicting an "outright" US recession by end-2023. The International Monetary Fund and World Bank cut global growth forecasts, and shipping groups and parcel services warn of falling container volumes and e-commerce growth slowdowns. Investors are shifting focus from inflation to recession, driving down oil prices and currency values. Central banks' aggressive policy tightening has heightened concerns, with the US Federal Reserve expected to tighten policy into an economic slowdown.

site_title: Singapore employment grows by 41,100 in Q1 2022 as construction workers return
summary: Singapore's employment levels grew by 41,100 in Q1 2022, with non-resident employment increasing significantly due to the easing of border restrictions. Construction workers, mainly on work permits, contributed to the growth. Resident employment rose modestly, while unemployment ticked up to 2.2% in March. Retrenchments fell to a record low of 1,300, and the labor market remains tight, with the risk of supply chain disruptions and economic growth factors weighing on sentiment.

site_title: Global inflation to stay stubbornly high as wrecked supply chains persist: poll
summary: Global inflation is expected to remain stubbornly high due to persistent supply chain disruptions. A Reuters poll found that forecasts for 46 economies have increased by 3.9 percentage points on average from 2020, with a further rise in 2023. Supply chain disruptions, particularly in the UK, euro zone, and US, are driving inflation, and economists warn that aggressive monetary policy tightening may not be enough to tame price pressures. The lag between supply chain disruptions and inflation peaks has made predicting inflation a challenge, with some experts predicting further rises in forecasts.

site_title: Major shipping firm sees signs of supply-chain bottlenecks easing
summary: A major shipping firm, Yang Ming Marine Transport, reports signs of easing supply-chain bottlenecks, with ship waiting times outside Los Angeles and Long Beach ports reduced to less than 40 from over 100 earlier this year. Chairman Cheng Cheng-mount expects port congestion to ease in the US, with Shanghai ports' waiting times decreasing to 2-3 days. He also predicts China's economy will rebound in the second half of the year, with global trade growth projected to slow to 5% this year.

site_title: Australia: Shares rebound on commodity push
summary: Australian shares rebounded 1% on Thursday, snapping a three-day losing streak, driven by gains in mining and energy stocks. Commodity prices rose after easing concerns over the global economic slowdown and China's Covid-19 outbreaks. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 7,335.10, with major miners BHP Group and Rio Tinto up 2.9% and 1.7%, respectively. Energy stocks also rose 1.5%, while financials and healthcare stocks edged up 0.7% and 0.5%, respectively.

site_title: Xi calls for ‘all out’ infrastructure push to boost economy
summary: China's President Xi Jinping has called for an "all-out" infrastructure push to boost the economy, a strategy that may prove less effective due to the country's hardline approach to controlling Covid outbreaks. Xi urged local authorities to bolster infrastructure construction and increase fiscal spending to ensure national security and expand domestic demand. However, experts warn that the government's efforts may be hindered by the lockdowns and the country's debt issues. The benchmark CSI 300 stock index has fallen to its lowest level in 2 years, and economists have downgraded their growth forecasts.

images.alt_text: China’s first-quarter retail sales lagged in key coastal economic regions with areas hit by Covid-19 outbreaks showing particular weakness, according to regional data, pointing to further sluggishness in consumption in the second quarter.

site_title: Great Eastern Q1 profit halved due to less favourable financial market conditions
summary: Great Eastern Holdings reported a 50% decline in its first-quarter profit to S$220 million, due to lower valuation of investments and mark-to-market losses. Despite this, its insurance business posted a 6% increase in operating profit to S$191.4 million. The company attributed the decline to less favourable financial market conditions and a 73% drop in non-operating profit. Operating profit from its insurance business was driven by a growth in in-force business, while new sales in Singapore increased by 32% to S$505.3 million.

site_title: Banks slash yuan forecasts as China's economy reels from Covid
summary: China's economy is reeling from the Covid-19 pandemic, leading banks to slash their forecasts for the yuan, with analysts predicting a 2% drop in the currency's value in 3 months. The yuan has plunged over 3% this month, with some predicting a further decline to 6.7 per dollar by the end of the second quarter. China's economic growth target has been reduced, and policymakers have pledged support, but markets are tumbling, raising concerns of accelerating capital outflows.

site_title: Musk's biggest ever gamble has divided Wall Street – but his instincts have been unerring
summary: Elon Musk's $44 billion bid to buy Twitter is his biggest gamble, involving $12.5 billion in margin loans against his Tesla stake, sparking concerns among investors. Musk's unorthodox approach, driven by instinct rather than traditional business thinking, has divided Wall Street. Critics argue the deal could lead to financial burdens and erosion of free speech, while others see it as a strategic move to position himself at the nexus of money and power. Musk's financial instincts have been unerring, but the outcome of the deal remains uncertain, with some predicting it could be a financial bonanza or disaster.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Corp, Sembmarine, Great Eastern, FEHT, Oxley
summary: Keppel Corp and Sembmarine announced a definitive agreement on a landmark transaction, with Keppel O&M becoming a wholly-owned subsidiary of the combined entity. Great Eastern Holdings reported a 50% decline in Q1 profit due to less favourable financial market conditions. FEHT's distributable income rose 17.2% to S$14.7 million, while Oxley Holdings sold two assets in Vietnam for S$84 million. Fortress Minerals' earnings plummeted 82.3% to US$1.1 million in Q4.

site_title: Amazon permanently lifts ban on mobile phones in warehouses
summary: Amazon permanently lifts ban on mobile phones in warehouses, allowing employees to keep their devices on the job worldwide. The decision comes after a 2-year trial period, following a December tornado that killed 6 Amazon workers, highlighting the need for real-time information during emergencies. The shift in policy is part of Amazon's labor unrest, with employees in several warehouses voting to join labor unions. The company cited the ability to safely keep phones on warehouse floors as the reason for the permanent change.

images.alt_text: US authorities urge Amazon to improve safety after tornado deaths in Illinois last year.

site_title: Boeing CEO knocks planemaker’s deal with Trump on Air Force One
summary: Boeing recorded a $660 million charge for its Air Force One program, citing higher supplier costs, technical requirements, and schedule delays. CEO Dave Calhoun questioned the deal, calling it a "unique moment, a unique negotiation, a unique set of risks" that Boeing probably shouldn't have taken. The company received a $3.9 billion contract for two 747-8 aircraft, but delivery is now unlikely to occur until 2026. Boeing faces another high-stakes battle to win certification of the 737 MAX, with a new safety standard taking effect at year-end.

site_title: Leading gauge of Japan consumer inflation to creep to near 2% in April: poll
summary: A Reuters poll suggests Japan's core consumer prices in Tokyo are likely to rise at the fastest pace in seven years in April, reaching near 2% due to global commodity inflation. This indicates the impact of rising raw material costs, with the Tokyo CPI expected to increase 1.8% from a year earlier. The data will likely keep the Bank of Japan under market scrutiny for potential policy changes. The government will release the April Tokyo CPI data on May 6.

site_title: Hot stocks: Sembmarine slides as much as 19.1% on O&M merger deal, Keppel Corp up 3.8%
summary: Keppel Corp and Sembmarine proposed a 56% Keppel-controlled merger deal, valued at S$8.7 billion. Sembmarine's shares plummeted 19.1% on the opening day, while Keppel Corp rose 3.8%. Analysts praise the deal, with Keppel expected to benefit from the divestment and Sembmarine to gain a stronger renewables focus. CGS-CIMB estimates a potential 5.1% upside for Keppel Corp and 18.2% downside for Sembmarine, while OCBC Investment Research is "positive" on the deal for Keppel.

site_title: Cryptoassets could be seized to stop crime: UK government
summary: The UK government plans to introduce legislation allowing the seizure of cryptoassets to combat economic crime. The move aims to mitigate the risk of those who cannot be prosecuted using their funds to further criminal activity. However, the proposal does not address a recommended single crime-busting agency. The government's multi-agency approach is seen as a missed opportunity by lawmakers, who criticized the lack of a unified strategy to tackle economic crime. The UK has already backed recommendations to require online platforms to tackle fraudulent advertising and support victims of online scams.

site_title: Ford confirms 2022 profit outlook despite lingering semiconductor crunch
summary: Ford confirmed its 2022 profit outlook despite lower quarterly auto sales due to strong vehicle pricing offsetting higher operating costs and the semiconductor chip shortage. The company reported a loss of $3.1 billion, but maintained its adjusted earnings forecast of $11.5 billion to $12.5 billion. Ford attributed the strong pricing to "pent-up" consumer demand, which is expected to continue in the second half of 2022 as more vehicles hit the market.

site_title: SoftBank, Arm move to retake control of China JV, oust CEO: sources
summary: SoftBank and Arm Ltd are nearing an agreement to regain control of Arm China's operations and oust CEO Allen Wu, who has refused to leave despite being fired in 2020 for alleged conflicts of interest. The companies are filing paperwork to have a new representative listed on a government database and will issue a new company stamp, allowing them to take control. The CEO job is likely to be split between two people, and the resolution is not yet finalized. This move aims to resolve uncertainty and pave the way for SoftBank's planned initial public offering of Arm, valued at at least $60 billion.

SoftBank is investing in AI Medical Service, which develops systems and software for gastrointestinal diagnostics.

site_title: Paypal cuts annual forecast as spending growth continues to slow
summary: PayPal reduced its annual forecast, citing slower volume growth on its platform in the first quarter. The company now expects total payments volume to rise 15-17% and revenue to grow 13%, down from earlier targets of 21-23% and 17%. Despite this, PayPal's transactions per active account jumped 11% and revenue jumped 8% in the quarter, beating analyst estimates. The company is shifting its focus to encouraging existing customers to use its app more frequently, rather than adding new users.

site_title: Singapore core inflation could peak at 4% in Q3 before easing in late 2022: MAS
summary: Singapore's core inflation is expected to peak at 4% in the third quarter before easing in late 2022, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). Core inflation, excluding accommodation and private transport, hit a decade high of 2.9% last month and is expected to remain significantly higher than the historical average. Rising energy prices, food shortages, and labor shortages are driving the inflation increase, with headline inflation potentially peaking at 5-6%. The MAS forecasts slower but "above-trend" growth in 2022 due to global supply-driven price shocks, but expects the economy to be underpinned by resilient domestic demand.

images.alt_text: Electronics, which was the star performer driving Singapore's economic growth last year, grew a muted 3.6 per cent in August on a year-on-year basis.

site_title: Russia coordinating cyberattacks with military strikes in Ukraine: Microsoft
summary: Russia has coordinated hundreds of cyberattacks with military strikes in Ukraine since Moscow's invasion, according to a report by Microsoft. The attacks, carried out by Russian-aligned hacker groups, have targeted Ukrainian government and critical infrastructure, including TV towers and government organizations. The cyberattacks often preceded military assaults, with some occurring on the same day. Microsoft has tracked almost 40 destructive cyberattacks, with many using phishing and unpatched vulnerabilities to gain access to systems. The attacks aim to disrupt or degrade Ukrainian functions and undermine public trust in institutions.

site_title: Far East Hospitality Trust's distributable income rises 17.2% in Q1
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust reported a 17.2% increase in distributable income to S$14.7 million for Q1 2022, driven by lower finance expenses and property tax. Gross revenue decreased 1.6% to S$21 million, mainly due to a 9.6% decline in commercial premises segment revenue. Hotel occupancy rates fell 8.4 percentage points to 67.7%, but average daily rate increased 31.8% to S$87. The trust's debt stands at S$739.3 million, with an aggregate leverage of 33.4%.

site_title: US: Wall Street sees tepid gains after Tuesday’s big drop
summary: US indices rose slightly at the close of trading on Wednesday, regaining some ground lost in the prior session, amid anticipation of US growth data. Despite concerns over high inflation and the war in Ukraine, the Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.2%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index added 0.2% and ended flat, respectively. The market is awaiting the release of the first quarter GDP growth estimate, with some analysts predicting a weak expansion or contraction.

site_title: Stop relying on Russia, Ukraine warns Europe after gas shutoff
summary: Ukraine has warned Europe to stop relying on Russia for trade after Moscow halted gas supplies to Bulgaria and Poland, citing non-payment in roubles as per a decree from President Vladimir Putin. The move, described as "blackmail," exposes the continent's weaknesses and divisions. European leaders have denounced the decision, and the European Commission is seeking clearer guidance on sanctions. The cut-off could cause havoc if it lasts for months or spreads to other countries, potentially tipping Germany into recession.

site_title: Oil prices dip as dollar soars, US crude stocks rise modestly
summary: Oil prices dropped on Wednesday as a soaring dollar made crude more expensive, with Brent crude futures falling 4 cents to $104.95 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures dropping 25 cents to $101.45. US crude stockpiles rose modestly last week, signaling ongoing tightness in the market. The dollar's rise, combined with coronavirus outbreaks in China and Russia's energy disruptions, created a "risk off" environment, according to analysts.

images.alt_text: RUSSIA'S oil production this year may drop by as much as 17 per cent amid international restrictions on buying the nation's crude, said Finance Minster Anton Siluanov.

site_title: Years of unhappiness culminate in 4-way fight for top post at Singapore Recreation Club
summary: The Singapore Recreation Club (SRC), a nearly 140-year-old social club, is holding its latest elections with a 4-way fight for its top job, marking the most heated election in its history. Unhappiness with the incumbent management committee's stewardship, particularly over the lease renewal of the club's site at the Padang, has led to a surge in candidates. This is the first time in the club's history that the top job is being contested by four candidates, with members finally waking up to address the financial and leadership problems that have plagued the club for years.

site_title: Taiwan economy likely slowed ahead of worsening China lockdowns
summary: Taiwan's economy is expected to have slowed in the first quarter, with a forecasted 2.8% growth rate, the slowest since the second quarter of 2020. The slowdown is attributed to widespread power outages and potential disruptions from China's Covid Zero strategy, which may impact Taiwanese manufacturing plants in China. Despite this, Taiwanese technology firms, major contributors to the economy, have reported being able to operate in China through closed-loop systems. The economy is also expected to face challenges from global inflation and supply chain disruptions.

site_title: PropertyBT: Investment opportunities post property cooling measures (Ep 6)
summary: Singapore property cooling measures have impacted investment opportunities. Analysts suggest considering commercial real estate or venturing overseas, such as Japan, due to structural drivers. Commercial property is seen as a viable alternative, while logistics has strong growth prospects. Experts advise property investors to reassess their strategies and consider new markets to maximize returns.

site_title: Sembmarine-Keppel O&M merger clears up a S$500 million mystery
summary: Sembcorp Marine's merger with Keppel Corp's offshore arm has cleared up a $500 million mystery. The combined entity will issue 39.9 billion new shares, diluting Sembcorp Marine's net tangible assets (NTA) per share. Shareholders of Sembcorp Marine will swap their 31.4 billion shares for new shares on a 1-for-1 basis. The merger aims to create a larger and more growth-oriented entity, but Sembcorp Marine shareholders who supported the company's discounted rights issues may question the value of their investment.

site_title: Qualcomm forecasts upbeat revenue as diversification bet pays off
summary: Qualcomm forecasts upbeat revenue for the third quarter, exceeding analyst expectations, driven by a growing non-handset business that cushions the impact of slowing smartphone demand. The company's shares rose 5% in after-hours trading. Lockdowns, war, and inflation have affected consumer spending on electronic gadgets, but Qualcomm has been less impacted. The robust earnings outlook suggests a positive outlook for the company's diversification strategy.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares edge up at Thursday's open
summary: Tokyo shares opened slightly higher on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.04% to 26,397.27 and the Topix index adding 0.25% to 1,865.37. The gains followed solid corporate earnings and relief from US indices avoiding further sharp falls. Investors also remained optimistic despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views, contributing to the rally.

site_title: Hyflux group takes legal action against former auditor KPMG over alleged contract breach
summary: Hyflux, a Singapore-listed water treatment company, has filed a lawsuit against its former auditor KPMG, alleging breach of contract and seeking compensation for over S$400 million in dividends paid out between 2010 and 2018. The lawsuit, filed in Singapore's High Court, claims KPMG failed to adequately audit Hyflux's financial statements, leading to the company's financial difficulties. KPMG has described the lawsuit as "protective" and has stated it will defend any claims.

site_title: Facebook parent Meta calms investors with strong profit
summary: Meta, the parent company of Facebook, reported a profit of $7.5 billion on revenue of $27.9 billion in the first quarter of 2022, calming investors' concerns about competition from TikTok and eased pandemic restrictions. The company's shares rose over 15% in after-market trading. Meta's average monthly Facebook users increased 3% to 2.94 billion, while 3.64 billion people used at least one of Meta's apps. The company's expenses rose 31% to $19.4 billion, and it ended the quarter with 77,805 employees, a 28% increase from last year.

site_title: Wellness in the corporate world
summary: Executives like Alex Mearns are leaving high-stress corporate careers to start holistic wellness centres, focusing on alternative solutions to medication. This trend is part of the growing wellness industry, which is on the rise. Mearns' experience is highlighted in an upcoming BTLifestyle issue, showcasing individuals who have successfully transitioned to wellness-related careers.

site_title: Europe: FTSE 100 rises on gains in miners, strong earnings; Aveva slumps
summary: The FTSE 100 rose 0.5% on Wednesday, driven by gains in miners like Anglo American, and strong corporate updates from Metro Bank and Go-Ahead. Aveva Group slumped 15.9% after warning of revenue hit from sanctions on Russia. Despite a subdued sentiment due to concerns over the global economic outlook, banks like Lloyds Banking Group rose 0.3% despite reporting upbeat profits.

site_title: HPL needs to articulate how it will use the SPH platform to bolster its performance
summary: Tycoon Ong Beng Seng, known as OBS, has led the consortium Cuscaden Peak to acquire Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) for S$3.9 billion. As part of the deal, HPL, OBS's company, will acquire a 40% stake in Cuscaden Peak, which holds a 30% stake in SPH. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move for HPL to pivot away from the hospitality sector and tap into SPH's retail and student-housing assets. However, HPL's recent performance has been struggling, and its shareholders may question the company's decision to make this acquisition.

site_title: Exxon declares force majeure on Russian Sakhalin-1 operations
summary: ExxonMobil's Russian unit, Exxon Neftegas, has declared force majeure for its Sakhalin-1 operations due to sanctions on Russia, making it difficult to ship crude. The Sakhalin-1 project, producing 273,000 barrels per day, is set to be discontinued following Exxon's decision to withdraw from its Russian operations. Insurers are wary of reputation risk, and chartering tankers is becoming increasingly challenging, leading to a curtailment of crude oil production. The exit could be concluded by June 24, with Exxon considering selling some assets.

site_title: Russian internet group Yandex reports 8.1 billion roubles net loss in Q1
summary: Russian internet group Yandex reported a net loss of 8.1 billion roubles (S$150 million) in Q1, citing geopolitical developments affecting operations. The company had withdrawn its 2022 financial guidance and scaled back investments, but will continue spending on core areas. Yandex experienced stable operations and growth in most businesses until February 23, when Russia invaded Ukraine, after which operations were adversely affected.

site_title: Oil prices edge up as worldwide supply concerns remain at the fore
summary: Oil prices rose modestly on Wednesday due to ongoing concerns about tight worldwide supply, with Brent crude futures settling up 33 cents to US$105.32 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude settling up 32 cents to US$102.02 a barrel. The US Energy Information Administration reported a drawdown in US distillate inventories, leading to a boost in US heating oil futures to an all-time closing record. Russia's move to cut off gas shipments to two European nations added to worries about tight energy supply, with European Commission Chief Ursula von der Leyen stating the era of Russian fossil fuels in Europe was coming to an end.

site_title: India’s biggest IPO attracts Norway’s wealth fund, GIC
summary: India's largest-ever IPO, valued at up to $3.78 billion, is set to attract investors including Norway's wealth fund and GIC, with the Indian government planning to sell 221.4 million shares at 902-949 rupees each. The offering opens for anchor investors on May 2, with LIC policyholders and retail investors also eligible to buy shares at a discount. Despite being less than half of last year's $3 billion, the IPO is expected to test the depth of India's capital market and surpass the largest-ever IPO by One97 Communications.

site_title: More NYC apartment renters are moving out instead of paying higher rates
summary: More NYC apartment renters are declining to renew leases due to post-pandemic rate increases. The renewal rate at Equity Residential's New York area buildings is around 60%, down 5 percentage points from the start of the year. Tenants who secured discounts during the pandemic are facing higher renewal prices, with net effective rent hikes of 21% for renewed leases and 29.7% for new agreements. Landlord Mark Parrell notes that the company can easily attract new residents at higher rates, and the drop in renewal rate is not a concern.

site_title: Fortuna Hotel to be sold for nearly S$86 million
summary: A 106-room freehold hotel in Singapore, Fortuna Hotel, is set to be sold for nearly S$86 million, working out to S$809,000 per room. The sale is expected to be finalized by an entity owned by JMD Holdings and an associate of TCRE Partners. The hotel, currently used for longer-term stays, has potential for redevelopment and could be repositioned as a boutique property. The sale price exceeds the site's maximum gross plot ratio, and the incoming owners may consider increasing the number of rooms to extract greater value from the asset.

site_title: Amazon signs deal to bring One Championship MMA fights to Prime
summary: Amazon has signed a 5-year deal with One Championship, a mixed-martial-arts fight promoter, to exclusively broadcast at least 12 of its events live in the US and Canada during prime time each year. The deal marks Amazon's push into live sports, following its exclusive rights deal with the NFL's Thursday Night Football. One Championship, one of the world's largest fight promoters, hopes to take on the UFC in its home market and build on its strong social media presence. The partnership is expected to give One Championship a significant boost, with CEO Chatri Sityodtong calling it a "real run" for the company.

site_title: Oxley to sell S$84 million worth of Vietnam assets
summary: Oxley Holdings, a Singapore-based property developer, has entered into memoranda of understanding (MOUs) to sell two assets in Vietnam for a combined S$84 million. The company will sell its 80% stake in Phu Thinh Land for S$63 million and a 30,981 sqm land in Ho Chi Minh City for S$21 million. The sale is subject to various conditions, including the signing of formal agreements, which may not be fulfilled. If completed, the proceeds will contribute positively to the group's cash flow.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher after tech selloff
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 210.7 points, or 0.63%, to 33,450.92, following a brutal selloff in the previous session. Strong earnings from Microsoft and Visa contributed to the gains, lifting the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite to fresh records. The tech-heavy Nasdaq had fallen to its lowest close since December 2020 in the previous session.

site_title: How e-scooter pioneer Neuron Mobility left South-east Asia and found its sweet spot
summary: Neuron Mobility, an e-scooter sharing startup, has shifted its focus to highly-regulated markets after facing challenges in South-east Asia. The company, founded in 2018, initially experienced rapid growth but was forced to exit Singapore, Malaysia, and Thailand due to accidents and public backlash. However, Neuron won a government tender in Brisbane, Australia, and has since expanded to 26 cities across Australia, New Zealand, the UK, Canada, and South Korea. With a recent $43.5 million Series B fundraise, Neuron plans to enter more cities this year, prioritizing markets with established infrastructure and clear regulatory frameworks.

site_title: US pending homes sales decline on rising rates, high prices
summary: US pending home sales declined 1.2% in March, marking a fifth consecutive month of decline, due to rising borrowing costs and high prices. The National Association of Realtors' index fell to 103.7, the lowest since May 2020. Economists had predicted a 1% drop. Rising mortgage rates, now at 5.37%, have made homes increasingly unaffordable, reducing buying activity. The Federal Reserve is expected to hike interest rates next month to combat inflation.

site_title: Ukraine president says Indonesian leader invited him to G20 summit
summary: Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskiy said Indonesian President Joko Widodo invited him to attend the G20 summit in Bali in November. Zelenskiy did not confirm whether he would accept the invitation, which comes as Russia's President Vladimir Putin plans to attend. The G20 has condemned Russia's invasion of Ukraine, and several members have called for Russia and Putin to be excluded from the summit. Indonesia's decision to invite Ukraine reflects its intention to secure participation from all G20 members, creating an opportunity for Russia and Ukraine to try to achieve peace.

site_title: Golden Mile Complex gets 80% mandate for collective sale at lower price of S$700m
summary: More than 80% of Golden Mile Complex owners have agreed to a collective sale at S$700 million, lower than the original S$800 million reserve price. The sale was made by a consortium comprising Far East Organization and Perennial Holdings via private-treaty negotiations. The 16-storey building, gazetted as a conserved building last year, has a gross floor area of 56,000 sq m. Buyers will not need to pay additional buyer's stamp duty due to its commercial zoning. The collective sale committee has until May 9 to exercise the option.

site_title: Archegos founder Bill Hwang hit with criminal charges
summary: Bill Hwang, founder of Archegos Capital Management, has been charged with 11 criminal counts, including racketeering conspiracy, market manipulation, and wire fraud. He allegedly inflated the fund's portfolio from $1.5 billion to $35 billion by using borrowed money and derivative securities, causing massive losses for banks and investors. Hwang and his CFO, Patrick Halligan, are accused of making false statements to investment banks and brokerages, and of concealing the true size of the fund's positions. Hwang's lawyer claims he is innocent and cooperative with investigations.

site_title: Carbon intensity fails to improve for the first time since 2010
summary: Carbon intensity of GDP, a measure of greenhouse gas emissions per unit of economic output, remained flat in 2021 for the first time since 2010, according to a report by Fitch Ratings. The carbon intensity of GDP grew at 6% last year, matching the global domestic product (GDP) growth rate. The report attributes the stagnation to a modest decline in energy efficiency and a slight increase in the carbon intensity of energy, mainly driven by China's growing reliance on coal. To achieve net-zero emissions by 2050, energy efficiency must rise by 4% annually over the next 20 years.

site_title: Small Indonesian palm oil planters already hit by new export ban
summary: Indonesia, the world's top palm oil producer, will ban exports of refined, bleached, and deodorised (RBD) palm olein starting April 28, in an effort to lower soaring domestic prices. Small palm oil planters in Indonesia, who have benefited from high global vegetable oil prices, fear they will be disproportionately affected by the ban. Prices of fresh palm fruit bunches have already plummeted, and farmers are worried about reduced sales and increased fertilizer costs due to the global price surge.

images.alt_text: Indonesia is prepared to widen a palm oil export ban, which currently only applies to refined palm olein, if local shortages of derivative products used in cooking oil occur.

site_title: Boeing reports US$1.2b loss on 777X delay, Russia costs
summary: Boeing reported a $1.2 billion first-quarter loss due to delays in the 777X program and costs associated with the Russia business, Air Force One, and the T-7 Red Hawk aircraft. The company now expects first 777X deliveries in 2025, resulting in a $1.5 billion hit to earnings. Revenues fell 8% to $14 billion, missing analyst estimates. This marks the latest disappointing result for the commercial jet maker, following production issues with the 787 jet.

site_title: Russia says its oil output may drop as much as 17% this year
summary: Russia's oil production may drop by as much as 17% this year due to international restrictions on buying the nation's crude, said Finance Minister Anton Siluanov. This would bring Russia's output to its lowest in almost 20 years, at around 8.74 million barrels per day. The decline is attributed to western nations' efforts to curb the Kremlin's military aggression by curbing key sources of revenue. Russia's oil industry has been under pressure since the invasion of Ukraine, with only the US and UK banning purchases of oil and petroleum products from the country.

site_title: Fortress Minerals posts 21% drop in FY2022 earnings to US$14.4 million
summary: Fortress Minerals reported a 21% drop in FY2022 earnings to US$14.4 million, down from US$18.3 million the previous year. Revenue fell 69.8% to US$5.2 million in Q4 and 9.1% to US$43.4 million for the full year. Lower iron ore sales volume contributed to the decline, but a 15% increase in average selling price helped mitigate the impact. The company recommended a final dividend of 0.008 S$ cents, down from 0.01 S$ cents last year, to conserve cash.

site_title: Revolut, Luno receive in-principle approval to provide crypto services in Singapore
summary: Revolut and Luno have received in-principle approval from the Monetary Authority of Singapore to operate fully regulated cryptocurrency services in the country, with only a few other MPI-licensed firms offering similar digital payment token services. This approval allows both companies to provide digital payment token services under the Major Payment Institution (MPI) license, marking a significant expansion of cryptocurrency services in Singapore.

site_title: Heeton appoints former MP Lee Bee Wah as independent director
summary: Heeton Holdings appoints former Member of Parliament Lee Bee Wah as its independent non-executive director, effective April 27, 2022. Independent directors Tan Tiong Cheng and Chia Kwok Ping stepped down after the annual general meeting. Lee, a former MP from 2006 to 2020, has been appointed chair of the nominating committee and member of the audit and remuneration committees. The company has also disclosed its remuneration policies and procedures, showcasing its commitment to board diversity and transparency.

site_title: India power minister tells states to step up coal imports for 3 years
summary: India's power minister has instructed states to increase coal imports for the next three years to address power demand shortfalls amid rising temperatures and industrial activity. This move contradicts the government's long-standing objective of reducing coal imports, but is seen as a temporary measure to address the crisis. The decision could significantly add to global demand and pose financial difficulties for debt-laden state utilities.
