site_title: Indonesia deploys navy as palm oil industry braces for export ban
summary: Indonesia deployed its navy and personnel to enforce an impending export ban on refined palm oil olein, set to take effect at midnight, amid rising cooking oil prices. The ban aims to curb surging prices, with futures surging 9.8% on the Malaysia exchange. Exporters face challenges in getting products onboard vessels in time, and the industry is bracing for a short-term halt, with prices potentially exceeding 19,000 rupiah per liter. The ban is expected to last less than a month due to limited infrastructure and pressure from buyers.

site_title: HKEx reports biggest quarterly drop in 6 years
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing (HKEx) reported its biggest quarterly drop in 6 years, with net income falling 31% to HK$2.67 billion, due to heightened scrutiny of mainland tech companies and market volatility. Despite this, HKEx CEO Nicolas Aguzin remains optimistic, citing the gradual relaxation of China's Covid-19 restrictions and the exchange's strong pipeline of initial public offers. Aguzin aims to leverage HKEx's China strength to become Asia's "marketplace of the future" and is focused on three strategic thrusts: connecting China with the world, connecting capital with opportunities, and supporting the creation of great companies.

images.alt_text: Regional exchanges revamp rule books in battle for S-E Asia's listing hopefuls

Hong Kong hasn’t hosted any IPO larger than US$1 billion so far this year. Overall proceeds in the Asian financial hub have slumped, with the vast majority of newcomers plunging below the listing price after they debuted.

site_title: Spending drive knocks Spotify shares after Q1 beat
summary: Spotify reported a 24% increase in first-quarter revenue to $2.82 billion, beating forecasts. Despite this, shares fell 11% due to an operating loss forecast of 197 million euros. The company's monthly active users rose 19% to a record 422 million, driven by podcast growth and a surge in advertising income. Spotify's CEO Daniel Ek attributed the strong results to the company's investments in podcasts and its position as a leading audio streaming platform, with a share of the market twice that of Apple Music.

images.alt_text: Joe Rogan's Spotify profile is seen in front of displayed Spotify logo in this photo illustration taken, February 7, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Keppel O&M and Sembmarine, Singapore's offshore and marine giants, are set to merge, creating a global offshore powerhouse valued at S$8.7 billion to tap the green energy boom. The deal aims to capitalize on the growing demand for offshore services in the renewable energy sector.

images.alt_text: Industrial production (IP) last month slowed to 3.4 per cent year on year dragged by the biomedical cluster, following a 17.5 per cent jump in February, according to data from the Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB) on Tuesday (Apr 26).

site_title: US mortgage interest rates rise further, loan demand ebbs
summary: US mortgage interest rates rose to 5.37% in the week ended Apr 22, the highest level since June 2009, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association. This increase of 220 basis points from a year ago is largely attributed to the US Federal Reserve's plans to raise interest rates to combat high inflation. Despite this, mortgage applications declined for the second week in a row, with the Purchase Composite Index falling 7.6% and the refinance index falling 9%. The housing market continues to show mixed signals due to low supply.

site_title: Malaysia to lift more Covid curbs, eases mask mandate
summary: Malaysia is easing COVID-19 curbs, lifting mask mandates for outdoor areas, and removing pre-flight and on-arrival testing requirements for fully vaccinated travelers and those who have recently recovered. The move comes as the country's vaccination rate is high, with nearly 82% of the population fully vaccinated. However, masks will remain mandatory for indoor activities and public transport. The decision aims to balance the need to control the spread of the virus with the economic benefits of reopening the country.

images.alt_text: The government has cut the private housing supply from its first-half 2019 land sales programme by 20 per cent from the current half, bringing it to the lowest level in 12 years.

site_title: Malaysia's Petronas sees higher demand as focus turns to energy security
summary: Malaysia's state energy firm Petronas is seeing higher demand for gas as countries prioritize energy security following Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Petronas, the world's fourth-largest LNG producer, has seen high demand from Europe, Japan, and South Korea since last year. The firm aims to raise production to 2.7 million barrels of oil equivalent per day by 2030, with most of the increase coming from Malaysia. Petronas is also investing in carbon capture and storage (CCS) technology to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050, with a planned CCS project set to capture over 3.5 million tonnes of CO2 annually.

site_title: Strong demand lets Mercedes-Benz hike prices to offset costs
summary: Mercedes-Benz expects strong demand for high-end cars to offset rising raw material and transport costs by hiking prices. The German automaker forecasts a pick-up in deliveries once chip shortages ease. Despite high pricing, demand remains strong, with luxury products being scarce, according to CFO Harald Wilhelm. Mercedes-Benz reported a rise in earnings before interest and taxes (Ebit) to 5.2 billion euros, with a 16.4% margin in the Cars division. The company confirmed its guidance for the year, but warned of potential production disruptions due to the war in Ukraine and extended Covid-19 lockdowns in China.

site_title: Singapore shares marginally down 0.04% in tandem with overnight US stock rout
summary: Singapore shares fell marginally, 0.04%, on Wednesday, in line with the US stock rout, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 1.38 points to 3,320.67 points. The decline was driven by concerns over expanding energy weaponisation by Russia and the ongoing pandemic in China. Key decliners included Apac Realty (-11.8%) and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding (-2.2%), while Pollux Properties was the top gainer, rising 34.6%.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi closed down 29.25 points, or 1.1 per cent, to 2,639.06, after falling nearly 2 per cent in early trade.
ESR-Reit posted a distribution per unit (DPU) of S$0.00723 for its first quarter ended Mar 31, 2022, 9.6 per cent lower than in Q1 last year.
Australian shares extended falls to a third session on Wednesday, weighed down by financial and tech stocks.
European shares extended losses for a third session on Tuesday.
Singapore stocks fell in early trade on Wednesday (Apr 27) tracking overnight losses on Wall Street amid ongoing concerns about sharp interest rates.

site_title: Russia withdraws from UN tourism body: UNWTO
summary: Russia has withdrawn from the United Nations World Tourism Organization (UNWTO) ahead of a vote to suspend its membership over its invasion of Ukraine. The decision, announced on April 27, comes after the UNWTO announced in March that it wanted to suspend Russia due to its invasion. The suspension is effective immediately and requires approval from 2/3 of the organization's 159 member states, which will be decided at a two-day extraordinary general assembly in Madrid.

site_title: Japan PM advisers urge improvement in current account as yen weakens
summary: Japan's current account surplus is expected to shrink further, potentially affecting the yen's value, as fuel import costs and slowing exports amid the Ukraine crisis create a trade deficit. Advisers to Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's top panel urged the government to prevent this decline to maintain financial and currency market stability. The panel proposed steps to improve the balance, including decarbonization efforts, exporting agricultural products, and promoting tourism. A resilient economic structure is needed to withstand external shocks, according to the advisers.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks edge up, Shanghai rallies
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended slightly higher, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.06% to 19,946.36, while Shanghai rallied 2.49% to 2,958.28 after Chinese President Xi Jinping announced a new infrastructure building drive. Traders remain cautious due to a Covid outbreak and lockdowns.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 10.70 points lower to 1,585.98 on Wednesday, with volume reaching 2.213 billion lots worth RM1.896 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 645 to 300.

images.alt_text: A man wearing a protective mask crosses a street in front of Petronas Twin Towers during a lockdown due to the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak, in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia June 1, 2021. REUTERS/Lim Huey Teng

site_title: China lockdowns raise earnings risk for chip firms, automakers, industrials
summary: China's strict "zero Covid" policy has led to widespread lockdowns, forcing factories to shut and disrupting global supply chains. Industrial firms, including chipmakers and automakers, warn of increased uncertainty and supply chain disruptions, raising concerns about the impact on the global economy. Companies such as General Electric, 3M, and Mercedes-Benz have raised prices to offset inflationary costs, while others like Asahi Group and SK Hynix have announced price hikes to cope with rising costs.

images.alt_text: China's stringent rules to curb Covid-19 are about to unleash another wave of summer chaos on supply chains between Asia, the US and Europe.

site_title: Keppel potentially the biggest winner from giant O&M merger
summary: Keppel Corp is poised to be the largest beneficiary of the merger between its loss-making offshore and marine (O&M) arm, Keppel O&M, and Sembcorp Marine, another struggling sector giant. The deal, valued at S$8.7 billion, will see Keppel receive S$500 million in cash and a 56% stake in the combined entity. Analysts praise the move, which aligns with Keppel's Vision 2030, as a major step towards transforming the group into a recurring earnings model. The merger is expected to be earnings accretive to Keppel and is subject to shareholder approvals.

images.alt_text: The proposed merger of Keppel's offshore & marine arm and Sembcorp Marine augurs well for Keppel's shift away from lumpy earnings to a more recurring earnings model

site_title: A 'da Vinci of violins' goes up for auction in France
summary: A near 3-century-old violin crafted by Italian luthier Giuseppe Guarneri in 1736 is set to be auctioned in France on June 3, with an estimated base price of 4-4.5 million euros. The instrument, considered a "Leonardo da Vinci of violins," has been owned by virtuoso Regis Pasquier since 2003 and has graced concert halls worldwide. Its exceptional sound and rarity make it comparable to a Rembrandt or Goya painting, with a potential sale price of up to 10 million euros, according to auction house Aguttes.

site_title: China Life profit slumps as stock market rout hurts returns
summary: China Life Insurance, the nation's largest life insurer, reported a 47% slump in profit for the first quarter due to a stock market rout and pandemic-related sales decline. Net income dropped to 15.2 billion yuan, from 28.6 billion yuan a year earlier. Investment income fell 27% and impairment losses more than doubled. The company's new business value also fell 14.3%. A probe into former Chairman Wang Bin has added to the company's headwinds, with some analysts predicting a 10% decline in insurance company profits.

site_title: Verdun House at Farrer Park sold to Fragrance boss James Koh for S$55.1m
summary: The Verdun House at Farrer Park in Singapore has been sold to Fragrance Group's CEO James Koh for S$55.1 million. The property, built in the 1980s, comprises 4 shops and eateries on the ground level and 12 apartments at its upper levels. Apartment owners will receive between S$2.1 million and S$2.8 million, while shop owners will receive between S$5.7 million and S$7.5 million. The sale price reflects S$1,793 per square foot, and the owners of 15 out of 16 strata-titled units have consented to the sale.

images.alt_text: Verdun House up for en-bloc sale again with S$55m reserve price

site_title: China Q1 consumption lags in key coastal provinces; Q2 off to weak start
summary: China's first-quarter retail sales lagged behind the nationwide growth of 3.3%, with key coastal provinces hit by Covid-19 outbreaks showing significant weakness. Retail sales in Shanghai dropped 3.8% and in Tianjin contracted 3.9%, while Guangdong and Jiangsu provinces posted growth of 1.7% and 0.5%, respectively. The sluggishness is attributed to tough restrictions and a prolonged lockdown in Shanghai, which is expected to impact the second quarter. China's GDP growth also slowed to 4.8% in the first quarter, below the government's target.

images.alt_text: China's stringent rules to curb Covid-19 are about to unleash another wave of summer chaos on supply chains between Asia, the US and Europe.

site_title: Singapore moves up to 8th position in Schroders Global Cities Index, emerges as top city in Asia
summary: Singapore has risen to 8th position in the Schroders Global Cities Index, overtaking Hong Kong to become the top city in Asia. The city scored well across all four metrics: economic dynamism, world-class universities, forward-thinking environmental policies, and excellent transport infrastructure. Singapore ranks in the top 5 globally for transport and top 10 for innovation. London holds the top spot for the second year, scoring well on all four metrics.

images.alt_text: HK falls off the map as aviation hub amid travel curbs
Hong Kong leader says city's brain drain 'unarguable'

site_title: Europe: Stocks steady at open
summary: European stock markets steadied at the open on April 27, 2022, following sharp losses on Wall Street and Tokyo overnight. London's FTSE 100 index rose 0.1% to 7,396.08 points, driven by gains in banks and miners. The eurozone's DAX and Paris CAC 40 indices were flat, with Frankfurt's DAX dipping 0.1% to 13,741.93 points.

site_title: Food security risks in Asia driven by climate change, worsened by Ukraine war
summary: Asia's food security is threatened by climate change, worsened by the Ukraine war, and exacerbated by existing domestic factors. Global food prices have risen 34% in the past year, with wheat, corn, and soybean prices increasing by 47%, 18%, and 9% respectively. The war has highlighted the vulnerability of Asia's food systems, particularly Indonesia's ban on palm oil exports. Climate change and environmental factors will have a greater long-term impact on food security, with Asia's deep-rooted problems including widespread hunger and food poverty affecting 375.8 million people in 2020.

images.alt_text: Yellen to push institutions to scale up response to war-fueled food security crisis

site_title: Bangkok's e-ferry fleet grows with money from development banks
summary: Bangkok's e-ferry fleet is growing, with Chao Phraya Express Boat planning to purchase 30 electric boats and phase out its diesel ferries. International Finance will assist in buying and operating the new vehicles and developing environmental standards. This move aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and improve air quality in the city, which has struggled with poor air quality and traffic congestion. The new electric ferries are expected to reduce carbon dioxide emissions by 18,900 tons annually, and also alleviate traffic congestion, saving commuters an estimated 114 hours in 2021.

site_title: Robot barista lends a helping hand, rather than displacing staff
summary: A Singaporean start-up, Ross Digital, has developed a robot barista called The Super Manual that can serve specialty coffee without displacing human staff. The robot is leased to companies like Singtel's Comcentre and Razer's headquarters on a monthly basis and is equipped with cloud software that tracks orders and customer preferences. The robot's automation aims to enable human staff to focus on service, with Ross Digital's CEO Gavin Pathross stating that the technology is not meant to displace employees but to "partner" them. The company plans to expand its services to other settings, such as offices and airline lounges.

images.alt_text: E-commerce brand Hook Coffee gets physical with first cafe, expands workshops
FoodPlant's general processing room, with the multi-function jacketed cooker.

site_title: Lloyds lifts profits forecasts even as inflation looms
summary: Lloyds, the UK's largest mortgage lender, reported better-than-expected first quarter profits of £1.6 billion, despite a worsening cost of living crisis and looming inflation. The bank raised its forecasts, citing confidence in its performance. Lloyds' pretax profits fell from £1.9 billion a year earlier, but exceeded analysts' forecast. The bank warned of potential impairments for bad loans and increased costs, but its underlying performance suggests it can increase its forecast for return on tangible equity and net interest margin.

images.alt_text: Lloyd's sees major claims this year from Ukraine conflict

site_title: SMEs in expansionary mode for fifth straight quarter: OCBC
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are expected to remain positive in the second quarter of 2022, with the OCBC SME Index indicating expansion for the fifth consecutive quarter. The index, which measures activity relative to the same period a year ago, came in at 50.5. While the index is expected to remain slightly expansionary, it is subject to downside risks, including monetary policy tightening and the emergence of new Covid-19 variants. The F&B industry is expected to see a boost in activity due to eased restrictions, while other industries such as wholesale trade, transport, and logistics, and manufacturing are expected to continue growing.

images.alt_text: Above: Tan See Leng, Minister of Manpower. Singapore businesses and workers must find progressive new ways to reimagine the way they work to emerge stronger from Covid-19, Tan said in his May Day message.
How much digitalisation must the F&B industry go through to be 'future-ready'?
SMEs must commit to digital innovation, upskilling and R&D collaboration to maintain growth

site_title: Sinopec Q1 net income jumps 25% on high oil prices
summary: Sinopec, China's top oil refiner, reported a 25% surge in Q1 net income to 22.61 billion yuan (S$4.75 billion) due to high oil prices. Refinery throughput increased 2.7% to 64.19 million tonnes, while crude oil production rose 1% to 69.07 million barrels. Sales of refined products dipped 1.8%, but capital spending increased 10.3% to 25.38 billion yuan. The company attributed the growth to rising global oil prices and domestic demand for natural gas and chemical products.

images.alt_text: China's CNOOC Ltd saw its stock surge as much as 44 per cent in its Shanghai debut on Thursday in defiance of overall market weakness, as investors sought safety in the oil giant amid lofty energy prices and quickening inflation.

site_title: The world's first ETP betting on both Bitcoin and gold is here
summary: The world's first exchange-traded product (ETP) combining Bitcoin and gold has launched in Europe, offering long-term returns and inflation protection. The 21Shares ByteTree BOLD ETP, a physically backed index product, combines the portfolio hedging power of gold with the strong returns of Bitcoin, aiming to bring together the old and new worlds of finance. Issued by Swiss crypto ETP provider 21Shares and UK alternative investment provider ByteTree Asset Management, the product is designed to provide investors with a unique asset allocation opportunity.

site_title: Ukraine war dents London Stock Exchange revenue, shares fall
summary: The London Stock Exchange (LSEG) reported a 6.3% increase in first-quarter total income, driven by good growth across all divisions. The exchange suspended products and services for customers in Russia and halted news distribution in the country due to the Ukraine war. Analysts estimated £60 million in revenue attrition from Russia/Ukraine, mostly from data and analytics. LSEG remains on track to meet financial targets, with £25 million in "run rate" revenue synergies achieved by the end of March.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong hasn’t hosted any IPO larger than US$1 billion so far this year. Overall proceeds in the Asian financial hub have slumped, with the vast majority of newcomers plunging below the listing price after they debuted.

site_title: Toyota exceeds annual sales goal with second-highest total ever
summary: Toyota Motor exceeded its annual sales goal with 9.5 million units sold in the business year through March, its second-highest annual figure ever. The company produced 8.6 million vehicles, narrowly missing its forecast. Strong sales in Asia and North America, particularly of the RAV 4 SUV, contributed to the success. Despite a challenging year ahead due to supply obstacles and a potential slowdown in global economic growth, Toyota's earnings announcement on May 11 is expected to provide insight into the company's performance.

site_title: Shares in Japanese beermaker Asahi jump after it announces price hikes
summary: Asahi Group Holdings, Japan's largest beer maker, announced its first price hikes in 14 years, with 162 items, mostly beer products, to rise between 6-10% from October 1. The price increases are aimed at coping with rising costs for materials, energy, and transportation. Asahi's stock surged 4.3%, outperforming the benchmark Nikkei index, which dropped 1.2%. Rivals Kirin Holdings and Sapporo Holdings are also considering price increases but have not made a decision yet.

images.alt_text: Japan's beloved 'Super Dry' beer to get first-ever recipe change

CARLSBERG, the Western brewer most exposed to the Russian market, expects its decision to sell its business there to result in a writedown of about 9.5 billion Danish crowns (US$1.4 billion), it said on Thursday (Apr 21).
Heineken sells more beer than expected as Europe reopens

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end over 1% lower after Wall Street slump; won drops
summary: South Korea's benchmark Kospi index closed down 29.25 points, or 1.1%, to 2,639.06 on Wednesday, marking its lowest close since March 15. The index fell nearly 2% in early trade, following Wall Street's overnight slump. The Korean won dropped to a more than 2-year low, while the benchmark bond yield fell. Technology giant Samsung Electronics and peer SK Hynix lost 1.66% and 2.25% respectively, despite Samsung's softer-than-expected first-quarter profit. Foreigners were net sellers of 677.2 billion won worth of shares.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi rose 11.18 points, or 0.42 per cent, to 2,668.31, after hitting a 6-week low in the previous session.

site_title: Reopening's boost to demand, sentiment could help avert stagflation fear for Singapore
summary: Singapore's further border reopening and loosened domestic curbs are expected to boost demand and sentiment, potentially averting stagflation fears. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has already moved to tighten monetary policy, but economists warn that more fiscal and monetary action may be needed to control inflation. Despite the threat of high inflation, Singapore's economic recovery is expected to continue, driven by services-led growth and "revenge spending" from the reopening. The MAS is expected to continue tightening policy at its next meeting in October, or sooner if needed.

site_title: Is it time to try speed dating?
summary: A new speed dating company, Ambyr Club, has been launched in New York, aiming to counter the current dating app culture. Founded by Lily Montasser and Victoria Van Ness, the company hosts events with a focus on in-person connections and vetted participants. The events, which cost $60 for application and $150 for entry, have been inspired by the success of speed dating in the 1990s. With a goal of promoting diversity and inclusivity, Ambyr Club is seeking to fill the gap left by the decline of traditional speed dating companies, such as HurryDate, which shut down due to the rise of dating apps.

site_title: Renault silent after media report of Avtovaz stake transfer
summary: Renault declined to comment on a report that it would transfer its majority stake in Avtovaz, Russia's biggest national automaker, to a Russian science institute for one symbolic rouble. The move follows Renault's decision to suspend operations at its Moscow plant amid pressure over its presence in Russia since the Ukraine conflict. Renault will retain the right to buy back its 68% stake within 5-6 years. The French state's 15% stake in Renault also declined to comment on the report, which sent Renault shares down 1.6% to 21.77 euros.

site_title: US bank stocks unravel in worst rout since 2020
summary: US bank stocks are experiencing their worst monthly performance in over 2 years, with the S&P 500 Banks Index falling 9.2% in April, erasing about $120 billion in market value. Despite solid first-quarter earnings, shares of major financial institutions have lagged broader markets due to concerns about a potential recession. The disconnect between earnings and share performance is attributed to rising fears of an economic slowdown, with interest rates and inflation also playing a significant role. The Federal Reserve's efforts to cool inflation will be a key driver for bank shares in the coming year.

site_title: Ad group WPP raises outlook on booming digital demand
summary: WPP, the world's largest advertising group, raised its full-year sales outlook due to strong client demand despite a gloomy global economy. The company attributed the increase to customers not cutting back on ad spend despite growing pressure on consumer budgets. Notable clients such as Coca-Cola provided a significant impact on sales, with the company expecting a positive year-end performance.

site_title: Deutsche Bank extends quarterly profit streak but Ukraine clouds outlook
summary: Deutsche Bank reported a 17% rise in first-quarter profit, exceeding analyst expectations, with a net profit of 1.06 billion euros. Despite the positive earnings, the bank's share price fell due to concerns about the impact of the Russia-Ukraine conflict on annual earnings. CEO Christian Sewing warned that the conflict could hurt full-year results, highlighting the challenges ahead for the bank's 2019 overhaul.

images.alt_text: The combination of higher inflation and higher rates has caught up with bank stocks, now on course for their worst monthly performance in more than 2 years.

site_title: Freehold hotel site at Devonshire Road up for sale with S$50m indicative price
summary: A freehold hotel site in District 9, Singapore, is up for sale with an indicative price of S$50 million. The 6-storey hotel development, with 44 guest rooms, has been approved by the Urban Redevelopment Authority and is located near Somerset MRT station and major shopping belts. The site, spanning 498.9 square meters, was previously a condominium project that was abandoned and sold by liquidators for S$25.9 million in 2016. ERA Realty expects "keen interest" from property developers, hospitality operators, and institutional funds, with an Expression of Interest exercise set to begin on April 28.

images.alt_text: The Chinatown shophouses (left) are located along 20 Trengganu Street, while the freehold site (right) is located at 118 Killiney Road.

site_title: Competing notions of the metaverse point to different futures
summary: The metaverse, expected to reach a $13 trillion market by 2030, is being conflated with virtual reality, despite Citi's report indicating VR's limited adoption rate of 900-1 billion users by 2030. Phil Chen, a founding partner of Race Capital, defines the metaverse as a "point in time" when people value digital assets as much as physical ones. In contrast, Web 3 and blockchain innovations have a natural alignment with the metaverse, particularly in decentralized economic systems and digital asset tracking. The focus on VR is seen as a distraction, and the defining innovation should be to free digital assets from walled gardens and allow them to be used across multiple platforms.

images.alt_text: Untold opportunities and risks in the metaverse

site_title: Asia: Markets sink as traders fret over global outlook
summary: Asian markets declined on Wednesday as traders fret over a perfect storm of crises, including China's Covid-linked economic woes, US interest rate hikes, soaring inflation, and the Ukraine war. Weak earnings from major companies and lack of support from Beijing further dampened sentiment. Tech firms led the decline, fearing sharp rate increases to tame inflation. The global economic outlook remains uncertain, with analysts warning that corporate earnings may not be enough to overcome economic headwinds.

site_title: Next-gen leaders are essential for family businesses to thrive in the new economy
summary: Next-generation leaders are crucial for family-run businesses to thrive in the new economy, particularly in South-east Asia where digitalization is transforming the business landscape. Despite 80% of family businesses prioritizing digitalization, only 19% have completed their transformation, highlighting a significant gap between awareness and action. The next generation, being digital natives, is better equipped to drive digitalization and innovation, but requires greater trust and support from their parents to succeed. To bridge this gap, family businesses should nurture transgenerational entrepreneurship, explore new business models, and leverage their private banking relationships to access resources and expertise.

site_title: Why China, not Russia, may be key for UN's future post-Ukraine
summary: The UN faces criticism for its handling of the Ukraine crisis, with over 12 million people in need of humanitarian assistance, despite the UN providing 2.5 million people with aid. The UN General Assembly has voted to suspend Russia from the UN Human Rights Council, but the UN Security Council has failed to pass any resolutions condemning the war. The UN's reliance on the veto power of permanent members, particularly Russia and China, hinders its ability to effectively address the crisis. Meanwhile, the relationship between China and the US, two of the most powerful members of the Security Council, may hold potential for fruitful partnership at the UN and beyond, potentially enabling more effective ways of resolving hard power disputes.

images.alt_text: Why China and Russia are transforming Nato's fortunes

site_title: Myanmar's Suu Kyi handed 5 year jail term for corruption: source
summary: Myanmar's deposed leader Aung San Suu Kyi was sentenced to 5 years in jail for corruption, a verdict that effectively ends her chance of a political comeback. She is charged with at least 18 offenses carrying combined maximum jail terms of nearly 190 years. Suu Kyi denies all charges, calling the allegations "absurd." The international community has imposed sanctions on the military and dismissed the trial as farcical, with many calling the verdict a "kangaroo court." The military has ruled Myanmar for 5 of the past 6 decades, and the country remains in turmoil after a coup in 2021.

images.alt_text: MYANMAR'S central bank has announced a broad exemption of foreign entities from a controversial new policy requiring foreign exchange to be converted into local currency, a rule that triggered panic among business groups and residents.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close lower
summary: Tokyo shares closed lower on April 27, 2022, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 1.17% or 313.48 points to 26,386.63. The decline followed a global economic slowdown, with US stocks also experiencing a rout. The Topix index fell 0.94% or 17.75 points to 1,860.76. The decline was part of a broader market trend, with US stocks and the Singapore Stock Exchange Index (STI) experiencing recent gains.

site_title: Air New Zealand to centralise Auckland ops, eyes 20% cost-cut over 15 yrs
summary: Air New Zealand plans to centralise its operations in Auckland and relocate its workforce to a refurbished airport campus by 2024. The move aims to reduce costs by 20% over 15 years, primarily due to rising building costs and expiring CBD leases. The airline will also build a new aircraft hangar at Auckland airport, anticipating a rebound in demand for long-haul flights as Covid-19 curbs ease.

site_title: Asia braces for LNG price surge as Russia cuts some supply to EU
summary: Russia is cutting off gas supply to Poland and Bulgaria, escalating tensions with the European Union over energy supplies. This move is expected to further tighten the global market, leading to higher spot prices for liquefied natural gas (LNG) in Asia. Asian LNG importers are bracing for higher prices as Russia's reduced supply is expected to lead to increased competition for limited cargoes, with some buyers already inquiring about available shipments. The EU's reliance on Russian gas is expected to increase, putting pressure on the global market.

site_title: Falls in Hong Kong home prices slow in March
summary: Hong Kong's private home prices slowed their decline in March, falling 0.7% from the previous month, as a Covid wave stabilized and the government eased social restrictions. This marks a reversal from a revised 2% fall in February. Despite a 3.2% year-to-date decline, realtors believe the market has bottomed, with prices and transactions expected to rise. Property developers are launching new sales, and some projects have received high demand, indicating a potential recovery in the housing market.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks drop at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks dropped 1.06% at the start of trading on April 27, 2022, following a Wall Street rout fueled by concerns over China's Covid lockdowns and US interest rate hikes. The Hang Seng Index fell 211.25 points to 19,723.46, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. The decline was attributed to global economic uncertainty and the impact of the lockdowns on China's economic outlook.

site_title: Ford juices production of Lightning F-150 electric truck to meet demand
summary: Ford has accelerated production of its F-150 Lightning electric truck, increasing annual production from 40,000 to 150,000 units. The company has started regular manufacturing and aims to hit showrooms in a couple of days, ahead of competitors like Rivian and GM. The F-150 Lightning boasts a lower price point than rivals, with CEO Jim Farley claiming it will be "thousands of dollars less" than competitors' trucks. Ford is also investing in battery materials production to ensure an American supply base for electric vehicles.

site_title: Australian inflation hits 20-year high
summary: Australia's annual inflation rate surged to 5.1% in the March quarter, the highest recorded since 2001, according to official data. The increase, driven by fuel and housing costs, exceeded analyst expectations and may prompt the Reserve Bank of Australia to raise interest rates as early as next week. This move would be a bold step, especially during the country's election campaign, and follows similar rate hikes in the US, New Zealand, and Canada. The rising cost of living has been a key issue in the election campaign, with the government handing out a one-off payment to millions of Australians.

site_title: Hot stock: Dyna-Mac hits 2-year high on Keppel O&M, Sembmarine proposed merger
summary: Dyna-Mac Holdings' shares hit a 2-year-3-month high following the proposed merger of Keppel Offshore & Marine (Keppel O&M) and Sembcorp Marine. Keppel O&M's KS Investments owns a 24.43% stake in Dyna-Mac, driving the surge. The merger is expected to realize S$9.4 billion in value. Dyna-Mac also announced new contracts worth S$90.3 million, bringing its net order book to S$461.1 million.

site_title: Businesses, workers need to find new ways to emerge stronger from pandemic: Tan See Leng
summary: Singapore businesses and workers must adapt to the post-pandemic era by embracing progressive changes, such as upskilling workers and expanding progressive wages, to emerge stronger. Minister of Manpower Tan See Leng emphasized the importance of strengthening protection for workers, improving employment protections for platform workers, and enshrining fair employment practices in law. The government aims to raise the adoption of flexible work arrangements to at least 4 in 10 workers by the end of 2022, building on Singapore's successful tripartite approach to managing the pandemic's impact.

images.alt_text: Manpower Minister Tan See Leng at Tanjong Beach Club in Sentosa, 20 Oct 2021.

site_title: The West's energy policy can be geopolitical and green
summary: Western countries' energy policies must balance national-security and environmental concerns amid Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Governments can adopt measures such as reducing fossil fuel subsidies, regulating natural gas, and increasing nuclear power to achieve this balance. Tapping existing stockpiles, like the US Strategic Petroleum Reserve, can also help offset supply shortfalls. Additionally, raising taxes on retail petroleum products and promoting renewable energy sources like wind and solar power can benefit both the environment and geopolitics. By taking these steps, governments can reduce demand for fossil fuels and mitigate the impact of Russia's invasion.

site_title: MAS aims to reach conclusion on Noble Group matter by Q3; investigations into Hyflux, EHT still ongoing
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has provided updates on ongoing investigations, including a potential conclusion on Noble Group's case by the third quarter of 2022. MAS is also reviewing Hyflux's statements for potential offenses and investigating Eagle Hospitality Trust's default on a loan. The authority has imposed S$2.6 million in financial penalties and issued 20 prohibition orders in the past 18 months, with a focus on strengthening enforcement against financial institutions and individuals for breaches of laws and regulations. MAS plans to enhance investors' recourse for losses from securities market misconduct and hold senior managers accountable for breaches.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 11.09 points or 0.69% to 1,585.59 on Wednesday, with 439 losers beating 73 gainers. The index saw 209.80 million lots traded worth RM111.20 million.

site_title: Solomon Islands pact with China roils Australian PM Morrison’s election campaign
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison's Liberal government is facing criticism over its handling of China's security pact with the Solomon Islands, which has taken center stage in the country's election campaign. Morrison's party had previously touted its stance on China as an electoral strength, but now faces accusations of bungling diplomacy and making Australia "less secure." Labor Party leader Anthony Albanese has seized on the issue, highlighting the government's alleged neglect of Pacific diplomacy and the sale of the northern port of Darwin to a Chinese company.

site_title: Could key ingredients for life have arrived from space? Scientists say yes
summary: Scientists have discovered that meteorites may have delivered key ingredients for life to Earth early in its history. A study of three meteorites found in the US, Canada, and Australia identified two previously undetected nucleobases, cytosine and thymine, crucial for forming DNA and RNA. The findings support the theory that meteorites could have provided the necessary organic compounds for the emergence of life on Earth, with further research needed to understand the chemical steps that led to the origin of life.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ESR-Reit, Aims Apac Reit, FCT, MIT, Sheng Siong, Keppel Infrastructure Trust
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

Several companies reported financial results, with ESR-Reit and Aims Apac Reit posting lower distributions per unit due to increased unit bases. Frasers Centrepoint Trust rose 2.3% on improved operating performance, while Mapletree Industrial Trust posted a 5.8% increase in DPU. Sheng Siong rose 13.9% on a 6% revenue increase. Keppel Corporation and Sembcorp Marine merged their offshore units, with trading halted. Sabana Industrial Reit's unitholders rejected the appointment of an independent director, and Keppel Infrastructure Trust proposed issuing S$250 million notes. Jardine Matheson Holdings' shareholders failed to convince a Bermuda court to strike out dissenting claims.

site_title: Australia: Shares extend falls as tech, financials drag
summary: Australia's shares fell for a third consecutive session, with the S&P/ASX 200 index down 1.1% at 7,241.00. Financials and tech stocks led the decline, with Commonwealth Bank of Australia and Block Inc. down 1.3% and 6.9%, respectively. Technology stocks experienced their worst session since March 11, while energy stocks rose 1%. The decline was attributed to concerns over aggressive rate hikes and tightened Covid-19 curbs in China.

site_title: Credit Suisse announces management reshuffle, Q1 loss
summary: Credit Suisse reported a 273 million Swiss franc (S$390.5 million) first-quarter loss, its fourth consecutive quarterly loss. The bank attributed the loss to increased litigation expenses and slowing business activity, following Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Top management departures include CFO David Mathers and group general counsel Romeo Cerutti, who will be replaced by Markus Diethelm and Edwin Low, respectively. The bank's embattled status continues, with a freewheeling culture and billions in losses from 2021.

site_title: Chinese drone maker DJI suspends business in Russia and Ukraine
summary: DJI, the world's largest drone maker, has suspended business operations in Russia and Ukraine due to internal compliance assessments. The move comes after the company denied accusations of leaking data on the Ukrainian military to Russia. Despite previous denials, a German retailer cited such information as a reason for removing DJI products from shelves. DJI's decision is seen as a rare move by a Chinese company to pull out of Russia amid the ongoing conflict.

site_title: Russia cuts off a major supply of natural gas to Poland and Bulgaria
summary: Russia has cut off natural gas supplies to Poland and Bulgaria, two NATO and EU member countries, marking the first direct energy attack on Europe. The move, made by Gazprom, aims to punish the West for its support of Ukraine. Poland gets 45% of its gas from Russia, while Bulgaria relies on 90%. The halt in supplies could severely impact both countries' ability to heat homes and businesses, but warming temperatures may mitigate the blow.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts mixed on Suntec Reit as Q1 DPU rises 16.9%
summary: Suntec Reit posted a 16.9% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.02391 for its first quarter, driven by new contributions from The Minster Building in London and higher contributions from Suntec City office and mall. Analysts are mixed on the Reit's performance, with Maybank raising its target price to S$2 and predicting stronger fundamentals for its retail and office assets in Singapore. However, CGS-CIMB downgraded the Reit's rating to "hold" citing potential downside risks and weak rental reversions in the near term.

images.alt_text: Suntec City is an integrated development comprising five Grade-A office towers, a mall and a convention and exhibition centre. It is linked to three MRT stations and the Marina Centre area.

site_title: Police reports filed against individuals from AGV's subsidiaries
summary: Police reports have been filed against individuals from AGV Group's subsidiaries in Singapore and Malaysia, alleging mismanagement and wrongdoings. The allegations have yet to be verified by the company. No further information was provided by AGV on the reports.

site_title: Best World to buy back 10% of its shares for S$1.36 each
summary: Best World International, an embattled beauty products distributor, is buying back up to 49 million shares, approximately 10% of its issued share capital, for S$1.36 each. This is the second time the company is buying back shares, following a previous offer in November 2021. The shares will be cancelled and have no financial value. The offer is open to all investors except a group of shareholders who control 57.3% of the company, and they are entitled to sell back approximately 23.4% of their shares.

images.alt_text: Best World International issues offer letter for 10% share buyback

site_title: France’s Thales charged over 2002 submarines deal with Malaysia
summary: A French judge has charged Thales, a defence group, with complicity in bribery over a 2002 sale of submarines to Malaysia. The case, which was opened in 2010, accuses Thales of paying kickbacks to former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak's associate, Abdul Razak Baginda. Najib was defence minister at the time and is also accused of receiving the bribes. Thales denies any wrongdoing, and the case will be reviewed by a French judge. The investigation was closed in January 2022, but prosecutors may still pursue further action.

site_title: mRNA platform company RVAC Medicines raises US$140m in Series B round
summary: RVAC Medicines, an mRNA platform company, has raised US$140 million in a Series B round, with investors including Temasek-linked Pavilion Capital, EDBI, and GS Holdings. The funds will be used to accelerate the development of novel vaccines and therapeutics, including a multivalent Covid vaccine, and establish a new R&D centre in Singapore. The company aims to address global healthcare needs and expand into emerging markets, creating over 100 jobs in Singapore. RVAC Medicines' Covid-19 vaccine candidates have progressed past preclinical studies, with clinical trials planned for Q3 2022.

site_title: BT's Top Stories from Last Week
summary: China port delays led to 441 fewer ships refueling in Singapore last month, a decline from the previous year. Expat bankers fleeing Hong Kong face bureaucratic hurdles in Singapore, limiting the influx. Singapore coal tycoon PT Bayan Resources' stock has more than doubled since Low's investment. Banks in Singapore have reduced fixed-rate home loans due to rising costs, advising customers to consider longer-term packages. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Global airline capacity hits 2022 high as China demand rebounds: OAG
summary: Global airline capacity reached its 2022 high this week, increasing by 3.3% to 88.6 million seats, despite extended lockdowns in China. This rebound is attributed to a surge in Chinese domestic demand. Despite this, total global capacity remains 20% lower than in 2019. OAG notes that planned capacity over the next three months is edging closer to 2019 levels, indicating confidence in the travel recovery. However, the data firm warns that a full recovery to 2019 levels may take time.

site_title: Chip startups using light instead of wires gaining speed and investments
summary: US chip startup Ayar Labs has raised $130 million from investors, including Nvidia, to develop silicon photonics technology, which uses light instead of wires to process information. This technology is gaining traction as the industry seeks new solutions to handle increasing AI computing needs. Other startups, such as PsiQuantum and Lightmatter, are also receiving significant funding, with total investments reaching over $1 billion. Industry experts predict silicon photonics will become common in data centers by 2025 and estimate the market will reach $3 billion by then.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, extending a rout on Wall Street, due to concerns over the impact of the Covid-19 outbreak in China on the global economy. The Nikkei 225 index fell 1.53% and the Topix index fell 1.35%.

images.alt_text: epa09895451 A passerby walks past a currency indicator board in Tokyo, Japan, 18 April 2022. The Nikkei Stock Average lost 496.53 points, or 1.83 per cent, during the morning session as the yen's hit a 20-year low against the US dollar.  EPA-EFE/FRANCK ROBICHON

site_title: Sustainability-linked loans trump other green finance for local property firms
summary: Singapore real estate companies and Reits raised S$75 billion in green and sustainability-linked financing in 2021, up from S$300 million in 2018. The real estate sector is expected to lead in sustainable financing due to established green building certification standards. Sustainability-linked loans dominated the market, with property firms and Reits accounting for nearly half of the green debt raised by Singapore companies. Higher oil prices, carbon taxes, and investment appetite for sustainable investments are expected to drive sustainable financing in the future.

site_title: Aims Apac Reit posts 4.8% fall in H2 DPU to S$0.0471
summary: AIMS Apac Reit posted a 4.8% decline in its second-half distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0471, due to a 3.8% year-on-year decrease in distributions to unitholders. Despite this, gross revenue rose 18.9% to S$77.1 million, and net property income (NPI) increased 16.6% to S$55.5 million. The full-year DPU was up 5.7% to S$0.0946. The manager attributes the performance to resilient operations and a continued recovery of the industrial sector.

site_title: 'On-demand salary' apps gain pace in South-east Asia, but questions loom
summary: On-demand salary apps, also known as earned wage access (EWA), are gaining popularity in South-east Asia, offering workers a way to track their earnings and withdraw a portion on a day-to-day basis before payday. Several startups, such as GetPaid, GajiGesa, and HariGaji, have launched in the region, with some employers absorbing the fees. While some see EWA as a useful resource, others worry about exploitative interest rates and over-reliance on the apps. Regulatory standards are needed to ensure fair practices and protect workers from exorbitant fees.

images.alt_text: Former Grab and Tokopedia executives raise US$5.6m for new fintech venture wagely
Fintech startup Paywatch raises US$5.3m seed round

site_title: South-east Asia could draw some investors away from China as virus lockdowns bite
summary: South-east Asian economies are expected to attract more foreign direct investment (FDI) as investors become wary of China's lockdowns and supply chain disruptions. Despite this, China remains the regional giant and is likely to maintain its status in the longer run. The Asia-Pacific region, including Asean, is the second-most attractive market for investors, according to a survey by consultancy Kearney. FDI flows into Asean are expected to be driven by the manufacturing sector, with countries like Vietnam, Malaysia, and Indonesia seeing investments in sectors such as electronics and basic metals. China's FDI prospects are not expected to be significantly impacted, despite a looming economic slowdown.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS lowers MIT target to S$3.05 after cutting earnings estimates
summary: DBS has lowered its target price on Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) to S$3.05 from S$3.35 due to higher cost assumptions. The new target implies a 4.8% yield and 9% potential upside from MIT's last trading price of S$2.64. The move is attributed to a negative impact of rising energy prices on margins in the coming quarter. DBS maintains a "buy" call on the real estate investment trust (Reit).

images.alt_text: The Mapletree Business City located on Pasir Panjang Road on 26 July 2019.

MIT's rise in gross revenue for Q4 2022 was largely due to the revenue contribution from the acquisition of 29 data centres in the US, and full quarter revenue from the data centre at Richmond, Virginia.

site_title: ‘Bleed us dry’: Why tech platforms are facing rebellions
summary: Tech platforms are facing rebellions as thousands of sellers rise up against fees hikes and restrictive policies. Etsy, with $5 billion in annual sales, drew fury for increasing fees from 5% to 6.5% after sellers felt they were "bleeding us dry" and being ignored. Similar price hikes and proposals have sparked outrage on platforms like Vimeo and OnlyFans, while Amazon and Uber face frequent unrest from sellers and drivers. Experts say the long-term outlook is uncertain, but cooperation among sellers or the establishment of alternative platforms may lead to change.

site_title: Visa allays slowdown fears as strong consumer spending lifts quarter
summary: Visa Inc reported a strong second quarter, with revenue accelerating past pre-pandemic levels, driven by a rebound in consumer spending. The company expects revenue to surpass pre-pandemic levels, reassuring investors. Despite challenging macroeconomic conditions, Visa's shares rose 5% in extended trading. The company reported net income of $3.6 billion and a 38% jump in cross-border travel volumes, but warned of a 4% hit to revenue due to the Ukraine conflict.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Wednesday’s open; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.3% or 9.79 points to 3,312.26 on Wednesday, tracking overnight losses on Wall Street amid concerns over sharp interest rates. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 2.4%, the S&P 500 dropped 2.8%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index sank 4% in the US. European shares also extended losses, with technology stocks down 2.3% at 6-week lows. Banking stocks in Singapore fell, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC down 0.2-0.3% each.

images.alt_text: ESR-Reit posted a distribution per unit (DPU) of S$0.00723 for its first quarter ended Mar 31, 2022, 9.6 per cent lower than in Q1 last year.

site_title: YouTube is starting to run ads on Shorts, its TikTok clone
summary: YouTube is testing ads on Shorts, its short-form video feature, as part of its effort to increase ad revenue. In its first-quarter earnings report, YouTube posted 14% ad-revenue growth, falling short of analyst expectations. The company has seen a drop in direct response ads, but is encouraged by initial advertiser feedback and results. With 30 billion daily views of Shorts, YouTube is exploring app-install ads and other promotions to monetize the feature, which competes with TikTok and Instagram.

site_title: SK Hynix Q1 profit jumps on server chip demand, but mobile chip demand eases
summary: SK Hynix reported a 116% jump in Q1 earnings to 2.9 trillion won ($3.2 billion), its highest first-quarter profit since 2018, driven by solid demand from server clients. Revenue rose 43% on-year to 12.2 trillion won. However, mobile chip demand eased due to China's Covid-19 lockdown and inflationary pressures, missing market expectations. The company's operating profit was below analysts' expected profit of 3.1 trillion won.

site_title: Netflix inks Japan studio deal in anime push
summary: Netflix has inked a multi-film deal with Japan's Studio Colorido to co-produce three feature films, including "Drifting Home", as part of its strategy to expand its anime offerings in the Asia-Pacific region. The deal aims to tap into Japan's 90% anime-watching population and globally, where half of users tuned in last year. The move is part of Netflix's efforts to win globally by winning locally first, according to Kaata Sakamoto, vice-president of content for Japan.

site_title: Apple slows hiring of Genius employees at some retail stores: sources
summary: Apple has slowed hiring for Genius technical-support jobs at some retail stores, according to sources, as part of a cost-cutting effort. This move has resulted in 5 or more positions going unfilled at individual stores. The slowdown is part of a broader shift in Apple's retail approach, with some locations eliminating the Genius Bar and outsourcing Mac product repairs. The decision has raised concerns among employees about customer service and wait times.

site_title: Tesla loses US$126b in value amid Musk Twitter deal funding concern
summary: Tesla's stock value plummeted by US$126 billion on Tuesday amid concerns that CEO Elon Musk may have to sell shares to fund his US$21 billion contribution to his US$44 billion Twitter acquisition. The 12.2% drop in Tesla shares equates to the same amount Musk committed to the Twitter deal, sparking worries about potential stock sales and Musk's ability to fund the acquisition. Analysts attribute the decline to investor concerns about Musk's financing and the possibility of a "cascade of margin calls" on his loans.

site_title: Kamala Harris tests positive for Covid-19: White House
summary: US Vice-President Kamala Harris tested positive for Covid-19 on Tuesday, April 26, 2022, but is asymptomatic and isolated at home. She is not considered a close contact of President Joe Biden and will continue to work from the vice-president's residence. Harris' press secretary stated she will return to the White House when she tests negative. This comes as multiple members of Congress and Washington elite have announced positive Covid-19 tests, including White House Press Secretary Jen Psaki.

site_title: FCT raises H1 DPU by 2.3% on improved operating, financial performance
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) posted a 2.3% rise in distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.06136 for its first half ended Mar 31, 2022, driven by improved operating and financial performance. Despite retaining S$4.8 million of taxable income, the Reit expects to distribute 90% of its taxable income annually. Gross revenue rose 1.5% to S$176.2 million, and net property income grew 3.8% to S$130.5 million. FCT's retail portfolio occupancy improved to 97.8% and shopper traffic increased to 65% in the January to March 2022 period.

site_title: Gold edges lower on dollar strength
summary: Gold prices eased 0.1% to $1,903.16 per ounce as the dollar held steady at its highest in over 2 years, pressuring demand for greenback-priced bullion. A stronger dollar makes gold less attractive for other currency holders. Spot silver gained 0.3%, platinum rose 0.2%, and palladium firmed 0.1%. The dollar's strength also weighed on US shares, with the Nasdaq posting its steepest 1-day rout since September 2020.

site_title: ESR-Reit posts 9.6% drop in Q1 DPU to S$0.00723; surge in utilities costs weighs down NPI
summary: ESR-Reit reported a 9.6% drop in its first-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.00723, mainly due to higher property expenses from surging utilities costs attributed to global energy price increases. Gross revenue decreased 1.2% to S$59.6 million, while net property income fell 10.4% to S$39.5 million. The Reit's merger with ARA Logos Logistics Trust is set to be completed on April 28, with the new entity expected to leverage its sponsor's integrated development and investment management platform to attract and retain value tenants.

images.alt_text: ESR-Reit undertakes S$38.5m redevelopment of Senoko Loop property

site_title: US authorities urge Amazon to improve safety after tornado deaths
summary: US authorities have urged Amazon to improve its safety protocols after six workers were killed in a tornado at a warehouse in Illinois last year. An investigation found that workers did not know where to seek shelter and a megaphone meant for communication was inaccessible. Amazon's safety protocols met minimal standards, and the company has been called upon to review and improve its procedures, including site-specific weather emergency plans. The incident has sparked discussions nationwide on the need for comprehensive workplace emergency plans.

site_title: Microsoft's cloud growth propels quarterly sales, earnings
summary: Microsoft reported strong quarterly sales and earnings, with revenue rising 18% to $49.4 billion and net income increasing to $16.7 billion. Cloud services demand drove growth, with Azure posting 46% growth, exceeding estimates. The company's overall cloud revenue rose 32%, and gross margin narrowed slightly to 70%. Microsoft's shares initially declined but later rose, driven by strong performance in Xbox hardware and commercial bookings for cloud products.

site_title: Oil settles up, rebounds on China’s plans to support economy
summary: Oil prices surged on Tuesday, rebounding from a 4% drop the previous day, as China's central bank announced plans to support its economy. Brent crude futures rose 2.6% to $104.99 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate contracts gained 3.2% to $101.70 a barrel. Analysts attribute the rebound to China's stimulus efforts, which are expected to boost oil demand. Additionally, Russia's threat to halt gas supplies to Poland and strong product prices are supporting crude futures.

site_title: General Motors lifts 2022 profit forecast after mixed Q1
summary: General Motors lifted its 2022 net income forecast to a range of $9.6 billion to $11.2 billion, citing strong consumer demand despite high vehicle prices and supply chain issues. The company's first-quarter net income decreased 3% to $2.9 billion, with revenue increasing 11% to $36 billion. GM's auto deliveries declined in all regions due to semiconductor shortages, but the company's pricing strategy enabled it to maintain profit margins. The company's earnings per share topped analyst expectations, and shares edged up 0.1% in after-hours trading.

site_title: Google-parent Alphabet see quarterly profit slip
summary: Alphabet, the parent company of Google, reported a quarterly profit of $16.4 billion, down from the previous year. Revenue rose 23% to $68 billion, driven by strong growth in search and cloud computing businesses. However, the company's cost of acquiring online traffic increased by $2 billion, and its employee ranks grew to nearly 164,000. Shares dropped 3% after the earnings report, despite the revenue growth. Alphabet continues to invest in products and services, with plans to label apps in the Play Store to provide users with more transparency about data collection.

site_title: Robinhood cutting 9% of full-time staff as 'hyper growth' ebbs
summary: Robinhood is laying off 9% of its 3,800-person workforce, citing "hyper growth" and duplicate roles. The move comes as the online brokerage struggles with declining trading activity and missed revenue estimates. Robinhood's stock has plummeted 74% since its IPO, and the company has racked up over $2 billion in losses. Lower retail participation in the stock market is contributing to the decline, with retail investors accounting for 17% of US equity trading volume in early March, down from a peak of 24% last year.

site_title: KKR sees ESG-friendly companies outperforming in the junk market
summary: KKR predicts that borrowers prioritizing environmental and social concerns will outperform in US corporate high-yield and leveraged loan markets. Highly rated ESG companies are expected to see tighter spreads, creating opportunities for those ahead of the trend. Conversely, companies with material ESG concerns trade at wider levels in the junk market, averaging 350 basis points more than the market. KKR expects the ESG premium to appear in the junk market as the industry evolves and ESG disclosure increases.

site_title: Crypto ETF roll out in Australia hits snag in inaugural push
summary: Australians may have to wait longer for the debut of the nation's first financial products offering direct exposure to cryptocurrencies. Cboe Australia and 21Shares, in partnership with ETF Securities, have delayed the launch of their respective crypto ETFs due to "standard checks" not being completed. The delay is attributed to the lack of infrastructure in Australia for crypto ETFs, with both providers stating they will launch the product once regulatory green light is obtained. The delay is expected to be minor, with some speculating it may be as short as 48 hours.

site_title: Canada stumbling in transition to low-carbon economy: watchdog
summary: Canada's environmental watchdog has criticized the government for its slow transition to a low-carbon economy, citing inadequate support for energy workers and overestimation of hydrogen fuel's potential to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The Climate Commissioner, Jerry DeMarco, stated that the government's approach is "unprepared and slow off the mark" and relies on existing programs, which are insufficient for displaced workers. The government's goal to reduce emissions by 45% by 2030 is also questioned, with varying estimates of hydrogen's emissions reduction potential.

site_title: Sabana Reit unitholders vote against appointment of director Chan Wai Kheong at AGM
summary: Sabana Industrial Reit's unitholders voted against the appointment of independent director Chan Wai Kheong at the annual general meeting (AGM), rejecting Resolution 3 with 77% of votes cast. Despite the manager's acceptance of the decision, Chan is stepping down from the board effective immediately. This marks the first time in Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) history that unitholders successfully voted against the endorsement of a director, with activist fund manager Quarz Capital Management leading the objection.

site_title: Nearly 60% of US population had Covid-19 by February
summary: By February, nearly 60% of the US population, or over 190 million people, had contracted Covid-19, according to a CDC antibody survey, exceeding the 80 million officially recorded cases. The majority of infections were undiagnosed, asymptomatic, or unreported. Vaccination remains crucial for long-term protection, with the US offering fourth shots to those 50 and over and third shots to those under 50. Pfizer is seeking FDA approval for a third Covid shot for children ages 5-11, while the Biden administration is doubling access to free Covid-19 therapeutic pills.

site_title: Sales of new US homes drop to lowest in four months
summary: US sales of new single-family homes dropped 8.6% in March to 763,000 annualized pace, the lowest in four months, due to high prices and surging borrowing costs. Mortgage rates rose to 5.11%, the highest since 2010, sidelining more prospective buyers. Nationally, home prices surged 19.8% and the median sales price of a new home increased 21.4% from last year, to $436,700.

site_title: Revolut CEO eyes expansion into mortgages, crypto wallets
summary: Revolut CEO Nik Storonsky is expanding the company's strategy to become a "superapp" by exploring decentralized cryptocurrency wallets and the mortgage sector. Revolut currently offers payments services, crypto trading, and savings accounts, and plans to launch a buy now, pay later product and expand remittance offerings. Storonsky believes Revolut can become a one-stop shop for financial services, citing the success of superapps in other parts of the world, such as China's WeChat.

site_title: US: Stocks routed amid fears over inflation, growth
summary: US stocks plummeted on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 2.4% and the S&P 500 dropping 2.8%. The tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index sank 4% amid investor fears over sharp interest rate increases and potential economic slowdown. Analysts cite concerns over the Federal Reserve's inflation-fighting measures and ongoing global tensions, including the war in Ukraine and Covid-related lockdowns in China. Despite positive corporate earnings, investors remain cautious, citing potential for companies to lower guidance and supply chain constraints.

site_title: Commodity traders thrust into the spotlight as war exposes risks
summary: The commodity trading industry, dominated by private companies, is under increased scrutiny following the Russia-Ukraine war, which has exposed risks and vulnerabilities in the market. The International Monetary Fund, Federal Reserve, and Financial Stability Board have highlighted concerns over traders' access to credit, liquidity, and the potential for margin calls to disrupt the financial system. Regulators are urging the industry to increase liquidity and improve risk management, while banks are reviewing their exposure to commodity markets. The increased scrutiny may lead to greater regulation, with regulators seeing an "opportune time" to examine the commodity markets.

site_title: India to trim mega insurer IPO size, issue opens next week
summary: India's largest initial public offering (IPO) of Life Insurance Corporation (LIC) will proceed with a 60% reduction in size, selling 221.3 million shares at 902-949 rupees each. The sale, which could raise up to 210 billion rupees, aims to bridge the budget deficit despite waning investor demand amid the war in Ukraine. The IPO will be India's largest, surpassing a 183 billion rupee sale by One97 Communications in November, and will test the depth of India's capital markets.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The global shipping market saw a mixed week, with some segments showing improvement in sentiment and others under pressure. The Capesize market, particularly in the Pacific region, showed a positive trend, with rates increasing for certain routes. The Atlantic market, however, experienced a decline in demand, leading to lower rates. The Ultramax and Supramax markets also saw increased activity, with demand returning from the US Gulf and Asia. In contrast, the Handysize market remained relatively flat, and the VLCC market saw a decline in rates due to reduced demand. The Suezmax and Aframax markets also experienced a decline in rates.

site_title: Sembmarine, Keppel O&M in giant merger to create offshore powerhouse
summary: Keppel O&M and Sembmarine, Singapore's offshore and marine giants, are merging to create a global offshore powerhouse valued at S$8.7 billion. The deal aims to tap the green energy boom and enhance engineering and operational capabilities. Sembmarine's chairman Hassan Marican and Keppel Corp's chief executive Loh Chin Hua have expressed optimism about the merger, calling it a historic moment for the O&M sector in Singapore. The combined entity will focus on the offshore and energy sectors with an enhanced focus on sustainability.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust proposes S$250 million 4.11% notes due 2027
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust is proposing the issuance of S$250 million 4.11% notes due 2027 under its S$2 billion debt issuance program. The notes will be issued at 100% of their principal amount and bear interest at 4.11% per annum. They are expected to be issued on May 5, 2022, and mature on May 5, 2027. The net proceeds will be used for refinancing, financing general working capital, and financing acquisitions.

site_title: Yangzijiang Financial listing creates battle among smallest constituents to remain in the index
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) is set for a shake-up as Yangzijiang Financial Holding (YZJFH) spins off its investment arm, YZJ Shipbuilding, into a separately listed entity. The smallest constituents, including ComfortDelGro Corp, Keppel DC Reit, and YZJ Shipbuilding, are at risk of deletion from the index. ComfortDelGro's market capitalization is under S$4 billion, while YZJ Shipbuilding's is around S$3.6 billion. Analysts expect the stock to re-rate following the restructuring exercise. The STI review is also expected to consider Olam Group's inclusion and potential secondary listing of Emperador in Singapore.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slide with eyes on US tech earning
summary: European shares extended losses for a third session on Tuesday, with the Stoxx 600 index closing lower despite earlier gains. Technology stocks plummeted 2.3% at six-week lows, while banks dropped 2.3%. The losses were fueled by concerns over economic growth and big tech earnings. Meanwhile, miners and energy stocks rose, buoying the FTSE 100. The US Federal Reserve meeting next week and European Central Bank comments also weighed on investor sentiment, with money markets pricing in more than 80 basis points of ECB interest rate hikes by year-end.

site_title: 3M cuts 2022 profit outlook amid decline in mask demand
summary: 3M trimmed its full-year profit outlook due to declining demand for its disposable N95 masks amid waning COVID-19 cases. The company also grapples with surging inflation, supply chain constraints, and semiconductor shortages. The revised profit outlook ranges from $9.89 to $10.39 per share, down from the previous expectation of $10.15 to $10.65. Net income fell to $1.29 billion in the first quarter, but adjusted earnings beat analyst estimates.

site_title: Jardine Strategic fails to strike out claims from dissenting shareholders seeking 'arbitrage profit'
summary: Jardine Strategic failed to persuade a Bermuda court to strike out claims from 87 dissenting shareholders seeking appraisal of the fair value of their shares after the company's amalgamation. The Chief Justice ruled that shareholders who bought shares after the announcement can apply for appraisal, despite Jardine Strategic arguing this would enable "arbitrage profit" by event-driven hedge funds. The court rejected Jardine Strategic's claim that acquiring more shares after an announcement of a merger was an abuse of the court process, instead noting that such transactions promote liquidity and market resetting.

site_title: Thai central bank ready to act if baht is too volatile
summary: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand, is closely monitoring the Thai baht and prepared to take action if the currency becomes too volatile. The baht has depreciated 2.5% against the dollar since the start of the year, mainly driven by external factors such as the US Federal Reserve's monetary policy and concerns about China's slowdown. The central bank advises the private sector to manage risks to reduce the impact of financial market volatility.

site_title: IMF's Gopinath says China needs open capital markets for yuan to be global currency
summary: IMF's No 2 official Gopinath states that for China's yuan to become a global currency, Beijing needs open capital markets and full currency convertibility. Unlike reserve currencies like the dollar and British pound, China's yuan has capital restrictions. Gopinath emphasized the need for fully mobile capital, full capital account liberalization, and full exchange rate convertibility, which are not currently in place in China. This would be a significant step towards making the yuan a globally used currency.

site_title: US consumer confidence eases as inflation surges
summary: US consumer confidence eased in April to 107.3, down from 107.6 in March, despite more optimistic future expectations. Inflation, the fastest since 1981, has reduced paychecks, but the job market remains strong, boosting wages. The current conditions index declined to 152.6, while the expectations index improved to 77.2. Economists warn that inflation and the ongoing war in Ukraine may curb consumer spending this year. Despite this, the US economy is expected to have another solid month of job growth in April.

images.alt_text: The property is within a five-minute walk to the Tanjong Pagar MRT Station and the upcoming Prince Edward MRT Station on the Circle Line. The latter is due to be completed by 2025.

site_title: Moscow cites risk of nuclear war as US, allies pledge more arms for Ukraine
summary: Russia has accused NATO of engaging in a proxy battle that poses a significant risk of nuclear war, following a US-led meeting of allies in Germany to pledge heavy weapons to Ukraine. US Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin stated that nations worldwide stand united in supporting Ukraine against Russia's aggression. Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov warned that the danger is real and that NATO's actions are equivalent to war. The US has approved a $165 million ammunition sale to Ukraine, and NATO officials emphasized the need for continued support to achieve a Ukrainian victory.

site_title: Ferragamo, Amazon say they helped China seize counterfeits in Zheijang
summary: Chinese authorities seized hundreds of counterfeit Ferragamo products, including the iconic Gancini belt and buckles, in a raid on a warehouse in Zhejiang province. The luxury group and Amazon, which had cooperated in a global investigation, said the products were sold on Amazon as originals. This follows lawsuits filed by Amazon and Ferragamo in the US against manufacturers who used Ferragamo's registered trademarks to deceive customers. The incident highlights the ongoing issue of counterfeit goods, estimated to be around US$464 billion globally in 2019.

site_title: Cash-strapped Sri Lanka to sell 'golden' visas
summary: Sri Lanka, facing severe financial crisis, has announced the sale of "golden" visas to attract foreign currency. Foreigners who deposit at least $100,000 locally will be granted 10-year residency and permission to work in the country. The government also approved 5-year visas for those spending $75,000 on an apartment. The move aims to alleviate acute shortages of food, fuel, and medicines, and has sparked protests demanding President Gotabaya Rajapaksa's resignation. The government is also considering constitutional reforms to pare back the president's authority.

images.alt_text: A food stall in front of commercial buildings in downtown Colombo, Sri Lanka, on Monday, April 18, 2022. Sri Lanka has been thrust into uncertainty as protesters angered by sky-high inflation and lengthy power cuts called for the resignation of President Gotabaya Rajapaksa and his brother, Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa. Photographer: Buddhika Weerasinghe/Bloomberg

site_title: Amara shareholders vote against re-election of independent director Tan Tiong Cheng, performance share plan
summary: Amara Holdings shareholders voted against the re-election of independent director Tan Tiong Cheng and a resolution granting directors authority to issue shares under the Amara Performance Share Plan. The company will not comply with listing manual requirements due to the loss of its lead independent director Foo Ko Hing's resignation. Tan cited unresolved differences with the board, while the board aims to appoint new independent directors. The vote results show a significant divide among shareholders, with Tan's re-election rejected by 77.7% and the performance share plan plan rejected by 35.5%.

site_title: Spain’s richest man buys Glasgow building for US$254m
summary: Spanish billionaire Amancio Ortega has purchased a commercial building in Glasgow, Scotland, for US$254 million. Ortega, the founder of Zara, has invested billions in global properties, including the Haughwout Building in Manhattan and Miami's tallest office tower. His investment firm, Pontegadea Inversiones, has a 15.2 billion euro real estate portfolio, with a focus on premium commercial properties. This acquisition marks Ortega's latest investment in the UK market.
