site_title: BlueRed Partners leads US$10m round in LED display repair startup InZiv
summary: BlueRed Partners led a US$10 million Series A funding round for Israeli tech startup InZiv, which focuses on LED display repair. The funding will be used to accelerate production development of automated lighting and visual solutions, expand into the US and Asia markets, and make new company appointments. InZiv's CEO David Lewis said the investment will help the company develop high-resolution tools for advanced display technologies, making them accessible and affordable to consumers. New board members Yishai Klein and Itzchak Edrei also joined the company.

images.alt_text: BlueRed Partners’ managing director Yishai Klein; business development head Laurence Harel; and Keng Ann Yap, vice president of operations.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust posts 5.8 % rise in Q4 FY22 DPU to 3.49 cents
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) reported a 5.8% increase in Q4 FY22 distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.49 Singapore cents, driven by revenue contributions from US data centre acquisitions and a full quarter from Richmond, Virginia. Gross revenue rose 35.5% to S$164.1 million, while net property income (NPI) grew 35.3% to S$124.2 million. MIT's full-year DPU increased 10% to 13.8 cents, and gross revenue rose 36.4% to S$610.1 million.

site_title: Top US officials set to visit Kyiv amid call for heavy arms
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin were set to visit Kyiv on April 24 to discuss Ukraine's call for more powerful weapons amid the ongoing conflict with Russia. The visit, announced by Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, comes two months after Russia's invasion began, with thousands killed and cities reduced to rubble. The US and NATO allies have shown growing readiness to supply heavier equipment and more advanced weapons systems, while Turkish President Tayyip Erdogan expressed readiness to assist in negotiations with Russia.

images.alt_text: epa09699836 US Secretary of State Antony Blinken speaks during a press conference following bilateral talks with Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov on soaring tensions over Ukraine, in Geneva, Switzerland, 21 January 2022. EPA-EFE/MARTIAL TREZZINI

site_title: Benedict Cumberbatch returns for 'riot' in multiverse 'Dr Strange'
summary: Benedict Cumberbatch reprises his role as Doctor Stephen Strange in the upcoming Marvel film 'Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness'. The movie allows for various versions of the character to exist, potentially leading to surprise appearances by other Marvel characters. The film, set to release on May 4, also stars Benedict Wong and Elizabeth Olsen. Cumberbatch expressed excitement about the film's exploration of the multiverse and its potential to create new opportunities for the Marvel Cinematic Universe. The movie has faced controversy over its depiction of LGBTQ+ characters, with reports suggesting it may have been banned in Saudi Arabia.

site_title: Musk's Twitter deal could test Tesla executive bench
summary: Elon Musk's $44 billion acquisition of Twitter has raised concerns about the executive talent at Tesla, his more valuable company. Musk's focus on Twitter may divert attention from Tesla's production issues, supply-chain snarls, and expansion plans. Investors worry that his energy levels may be limited, citing his past comments about working "crazy hours." Tesla has managed to outrun its problems, but a heavier pull of Musk's focus could be a distraction, leading to share price slumps.

site_title: US durable goods orders rise on resilient business spending
summary: US durable goods orders rose 0.8% in March, reversing a revised 1.7% decline in February, with core capital goods orders increasing 1% and bookings for motor vehicles rising 5%. The surge in durable goods spending suggests sustained business investment amid higher energy costs and supply chain disruptions. However, the report also noted unfilled orders for transportation equipment rose 0.4% and inventories climbed 0.7%. The figures come as the first quarter draws to a close and ahead of Thursday's GDP release, which may provide further insight into the US economy's momentum.

site_title: Sheng Siong's Q1 FY22 net profit up 13.9% year on year
summary: Sheng Siong, a supermarket operator, posted a 13.9% rise in net profit to S$35.1 million for its first quarter ended March 31, 2022. Revenue rose 6% to S$358 million, driven by a 4.7% increase in same-store sales in Singapore and 1% in China. Gross profit grew 9.8% year-on-year, with improved margins. The company plans to expand its store presence and enhance its e-commerce capabilities to maintain sales growth amid rising inflation.

site_title: Olive Rd GCB sold for S$50.2 million
summary: A 2-storey Good Class Bungalow (GCB) along Olive Road in Singapore has been sold for nearly S$50.24 million to Wee Hian Nam, the grandson of late property magnate Wee Thiam Siew. The buyer paid S$1,800 per square foot, making it one of the pricier deals in the GCB market this year, with 19 deals totaling S$511 million in GCB Areas so far. The sale comes amid a strong demand for GCB properties, with prices generally appreciated between last year and now.

site_title: Carnival names operations head Weinstein as next CEO of cruise operator
summary: Carnival, the world's largest cruise company, has named Josh Weinstein as its next CEO, replacing Arnold Donald. Weinstein, a 20-year veteran of Carnival, will take over on August 1 and become the company's vice chair. He oversees major operational functions, including maritime operations and auditing. Carnival forecasts a loss for a third straight year due to soaring fuel costs and expects its full fleets to start sailing again by the end of the year. The company's US-listed shares fell 1.6% amid broader declines on Wall Street.

site_title: World faces biggest energy shock since 1970s: World Bank
summary: The World Bank warns of the world's biggest energy shock since the 1970s, citing surging oil and gas prices due to the Russian invasion of Ukraine. Energy prices are expected to remain "historically high" through 2024, threatening economic growth. The World Bank predicts a 50% increase in energy prices this year, with Brent crude averaging $100 a barrel. Non-energy commodity prices, including agriculture and metals, are projected to jump 20% this year. The shock is exacerbated by trade restrictions and rising prices for food, fuel, and fertilizers.

site_title: Power shortages on the cards for coal-strapped Vietnam
summary: Vietnam's coal-fired power plants are facing power shortages due to a lack of coal, with the country's national electricity provider EVN warning of reduced capacity. The shortage is caused by a limited domestic supply of coking coal and surging demand, with Vietnam expected to burn almost twice as much coal by 2025. The country is considering importing more coal from Australia and other sources to meet its energy needs, but this may create problems for its carbon-neutral goals and impact other industries such as cement production.

site_title: GE sees 2022 earnings at lower end of forecast on supply chain, inflationary woes
summary: GE has revised its 2022 earnings forecast to the lower end of its previous range due to supply chain disruptions and rising costs. The company cited fresh Covid-19-related lockdowns in China and Russia's invasion of Ukraine as factors. GE's healthcare unit was impacted by lockdowns in China, while its power business has a bigger exposure to Russia. The company reported a higher-than-expected adjusted profit in the first quarter and expects to generate $5.5 billion to $6.5 billion in free cash flow.

site_title: PepsiCo raises revenue forecast on boost from price increases
summary: PepsiCo raised its full-year revenue forecast after beating quarterly estimates with a 9.3% increase in net revenue to $16.20 billion. The company attributed the boost to steady demand for its sodas and snacks despite several price increases due to pandemic-induced supply chain disruptions and inflation. Despite trimming its core earnings per share forecast, PepsiCo maintained its 8% organic revenue growth forecast for fiscal 2022.

site_title: Warner Bros Discovery revenue rises in first results since merger
summary: Warner Bros Discovery's quarterly revenue rose 13% to $3.16 billion, driven by a rebound in ad spending, the Beijing Olympics, and Discovery's lifestyle TV networks. Total paid streaming subscribers increased by 2 million, while net income rose to $456 million, or 69 cents per share. The results mark the first set of financials since the $43 billion merger between Discovery and AT&T's WarnerMedia assets. The performance highlights the challenges facing the streaming sector, with significant investments in content and uncertain long-term prospects.

site_title: Singapore and Zhejiang deepen collaboration with joint innovation call programme
summary: Singapore and Zhejiang province in China have launched a joint innovation call programme to fund co-innovation projects in areas such as digital economy, sustainability, and smart cities. The programme, open for application in the third quarter of 2022, aims to help Singapore companies capture new opportunities in the region. The move follows a roundtable discussion between government agencies and companies in early 2022, which led to the formation of a consortium for digital trade financing pilots. This expansion builds on an earlier pilot programme and aims to deepen collaboration and drive innovation between the two regions.

site_title: China will step up infrastructure construction to boost growth: President Xi
summary: China plans to boost domestic demand and drive economic growth by stepping up infrastructure construction, according to a top economics meeting chaired by President Xi Jinping. The country aims to focus on transportation, energy, and water resources, and bring forward investments for projects beneficial to industrial growth and national security. This move comes as China's economy faces a slowdown due to Covid-19 restrictions, a mired property market, and slowing exports.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's industrial production slowed to 3.4% year-on-year in March, following a 17.5% jump in February, according to the Singapore Economic Development Board. Despite this, the country's first-quarter GDP growth is expected to be upgraded due to better-than-expected March factory output. Food and beverage catering services have seen an uptick in business, and trust in the Singapore banking industry has increased by 7 points to 63, despite Covid-19 uncertainties.

site_title: Bank of Japan offers to buy unlimited JGBs for 2 more days
summary: The Bank of Japan extended its offer to buy unlimited 10-year Japanese government bonds at 0.25% for two more days, sending benchmark yields to their lowest in over a week. The 10-year JGB yield fell to 0.235%, its lowest since April 15, despite previous offers to purchase unlimited bonds. The central bank aims to keep yields below its 0% target, amid modest inflation and an economy still below pre-pandemic levels, as it prepares for a policy meeting on Wednesday and Thursday.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, on Monday, April 25, 2022. Governor Haruhiko Kuroda said the Bank of Japan must keep applying monetary stimulus given the more subdued inflation dynamics in the country compared with the U.S., in remarks on April 22 that omitted any reference to the yen's depreciation. Photographer: Toru Hanai/Bloomberg

site_title: Singapore stocks end lower amid outflow of institutional funds; STI down 0.5%
summary: Singapore shares closed lower on Tuesday, down 0.5% to 3,322.05, as institutional funds continued to withdraw from the Straits Times Index (STI) for the fourth consecutive week. The financial sector, particularly banking stocks, declined, with OCBC, UOB, and DBS falling 0.7%, 0.4%, and 1.1% respectively. Only 5 out of 30 STI constituents gained, while 25 lost value. This follows a global trend, with the Shanghai Composite Index and Australia's S&P/ASX 200 also ending lower due to pandemic lockdowns in Shanghai.

site_title: US: Wall St slips at open as investors focus on Big Tech earnings
summary: US stock indexes fell at the start of trading on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 142 points or 0.42% to 33,907.49. Investors are waiting for Big Tech earnings to see if they will provide support to a market concerned about high inflation and slowing global growth. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also fell, with the S&P 500 down 18 points or 0.42% and the Nasdaq down 86.8 points or 0.67%.

site_title: Thai March exports beat forecast, but shipments to Russia tumble
summary: Thai exports surged 19.5% in March, beating forecasts, driven by increased global production, lower freight rates, and a weaker baht. The export value reached a record $28.86 billion, boosted by gold and electronics shipments. However, exports to Russia plummeted 73% and to Ukraine by 66%, attributed to the Russia-Ukraine war. Overall, exports rose 14.9% from January-March, exceeding the ministry's target, with a trade surplus of $1.46 billion in March.

site_title: Maersk says shipping boom will stabilise in H2, revises up profit guidance
summary: Maersk, a leading container shipping company, expects the container market to normalize in the second half of 2022, despite high freight rates. The company raised its full-year profit guidance to $30 billion, citing an assumption of normalization in ocean shipping. Container volumes declined 7% between January and March, and global demand growth is expected to slow to 1-4% this year. Maersk's shares rose 8.3% after the update, but analyst Per Hansen remains cautious due to the risk of a US recession in 2023.

site_title: Kuok scion’s music creator platform BandLab bags US$65m
summary: Kuok Meng Ru's music creator platform BandLab has secured a US$65 million funding round led by Vulcan Capital, valuing the company at US$315 million. Founded in 2015, BandLab has over 40 million registered users and is gaining traction on TikTok, where users create original content. The funding comes amid the rise of the creator economy and aims to inspire collaboration and empower independent artists worldwide. BandLab is a subsidiary of Caldecott Music Group, which also includes heritage instrument retailer Swee Lee and British music publication NME.

site_title: Lifeboat safety is shipping's shameful secret
summary: Lifeboat safety in the shipping industry has been a "shameful secret" due to a high number of accidents and deaths during drills, despite being a safety measure. Since 1981, 419 people have died and 346 were seriously injured in such incidents. The main cause of these accidents is unintended hook releases, which can occur when a lifeboat is lowered from a great height. The International Maritime Organization (IMO) has made changes to regulations, including a 2009 amendment that allows lifeboats to be launched without the crew being on board, but this change is not universally enforced. The industry must focus on improving lifeboat safety to prevent further loss of life.

site_title: Amid growing outbreak, China's zero-Covid stance looks unsustainable
summary: China's zero-Covid policy is facing increasing scrutiny as the country struggles to contain a growing outbreak of the virus. Cities like Beijing and Shanghai are on high alert, with mass testing and lockdowns in place. The government, led by President Xi Jinping, remains committed to the policy despite concerns about its impact on the economy and competitiveness. The longer the restrictions drag on, the greater the risk that investors and companies will look elsewhere to do business, potentially exacerbating the economic hit.

images.alt_text: A health worker takes swab sample on a woman to be tested for Covid-19 coronavirus at a swab collection site along a street in Beijing on April 25, 2022. (Photo by Noel Celis / AFP)

site_title: Japan's relief package will deal with rising raw material costs
summary: Japan's government has prepared a 13.2 trillion yen ($141.8 billion) relief package to ease the impact of rising fuel and raw material costs on households and companies. The package, set to be finalized by Cabinet ministers, includes subsidies for gasoline wholesalers, cash payments to low-income households, and funding support for small firms. The government plans to spend 6.2 trillion yen, with some measures funded by tapping emergency budget reserves and private-sector lending. The package is a smaller measure than a previous 36 trillion yen package, as the government balances economic support with public finances.

site_title: Sri Lanka begins talks with China on refinancing debt
summary: Sri Lanka has begun talks with China to refinance its $51 billion in external debt, amid a severe financial crisis. The country's dwindling foreign currency reserves and shortages of fuel, food, and medicines have led to widespread protests. China, the joint-largest bilateral creditor, has offered to help restructure debt repayments, following President Gotabaya Rajapaksa's request in January. The IMF has also expressed willingness to engage with Sri Lanka, and other countries have pledged support, including the World Bank and India. Discussions with China are at an early stage.

site_title: US vows to move 'heaven and earth' on bolstering Ukraine
summary: The US has pledged to "move heaven and earth" to support Ukraine in its battle against Russia's invasion, with a meeting at the Ramstein airbase in Germany aimed at bolstering Kyiv's defenses. The US is the largest supplier of international military aid to Ukraine and will continue to meet Kyiv's needs, with Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin stating that Ukraine believes it can win and so does the international community. Germany has agreed to deliver used Gepard anti-aircraft tanks to Ukraine, and other countries are providing heavy artillery and tanks, including France and Britain.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end higher, Shanghai extends losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose slightly on Tuesday, April 26, after a previous day's losses, while mainland Chinese markets fell due to investor concerns over a Covid flare-up and lockdowns in major cities. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.33%, and the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 1.44%.

site_title: Nomura profit up as unit sale offsets US expenses
summary: Nomura Holdings posted a fourth consecutive quarter of profit, totaling 31 billion yen (S$333 million) in the 3 months ended March 31, as gains from a stake sale offset expenses related to a US legal case. The firm booked 42.8 billion yen from the sale of its holding in Nomura Research Institute Ltd. and plans to buy back up to 30 billion yen of its own stock. Revenue in Nomura's retail division dropped 27% due to market volatility, while fixed income revenue slipped 5%. The results follow a year marked by the collapse of Archegos Capital Management and litigation in the US.

site_title: South Korea's recovery eased last quarter amid Omicron wave
summary: South Korea's economy decelerated to a 0.7% growth in the last quarter, exceeding economists' estimates, amid an Omicron outbreak and rising commodity prices. The result is in line with a 3.1% annual gain, but poses challenges for policymakers as they navigate inflationary pressure and global economic uncertainty, including the impact of war in eastern Europe and lockdowns in China. Monetary policy is expected to tighten further.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 6.7 points to 1,596.68 on Tuesday, April 26. The stock market saw 2.25 billion lots traded worth RM1.923 billion, with 506 gainers and 393 losers.

site_title: UBS posts best Q1 profit in 15 years, bolstered by trading growth
summary: UBS posted its best Q1 profit in 15 years, with a 17% jump to $2.14 billion, driven by strong trading revenue that offset declines in capital markets and advisory revenue. The bank's investment banking business saw a 126% pre-tax profit increase. This beats expectations and contrasts with US peers, who reported double-digit profit drops due to uncertainties over the war in Ukraine. UBS's earnings also indicate the bank is on track to meet enhanced profit goals and highlight a widening gap between itself and smaller rival Credit Suisse.

site_title: Liverpool to face Crystal Palace in pre-season friendly in Singapore
summary: Liverpool will face Crystal Palace in a pre-season friendly match at the Singapore National Stadium on July 15, 3 days after playing Manchester United in Thailand. This marks Liverpool's return to Singapore for the first time since 2017, following successful games in 2001 and 2009.

site_title: Venturi Partners closes maiden fund with US$175m
summary: Venturi Partners, a Singapore-based Asia-focused venture capital firm, has closed its maiden fund with a $175 million investment. The firm typically invests in Series B to Series D rounds of high-growth Asian consumer companies, including those in the fast-moving consumer goods, education, and healthcare sectors. Founded in 2019, Venturi Partners has previously invested in companies such as Livspace and Believe, and may increase the fund size if demand for investments rises.

site_title: F&B catering's back, but not at a sprint yet
summary: Food and beverage catering services in Singapore are seeing an uptick in business following the easing of safe management measures, with a 50% increase in enquiries for staff-served buffets and a 20% boost in sales. However, sales remain a fraction of pre-pandemic levels due to curbs on events and a manpower shortage. Caterers are concerned about the continued suspension of self-service buffets and are calling for its resumption to boost sales. Despite this, many have pivoted to offering bento boxes and other options to stay afloat, with some expecting to reach 75-80% of pre-pandemic sales levels this year.

images.alt_text: Food preparation at Amici Events and Catering.

site_title: UK's Sunak faces new headache as borrowing figures overshoot forecast
summary: British finance minister Rishi Sunak faces a new challenge as government borrowing in the 2021/22 financial year exceeded forecast by almost 20%. The figures underscore the need for new help to households and businesses struggling with surging inflation. Sunak remains committed to fixing the public finances, despite the surge in debt, which has jumped to over £2 trillion. He reiterated his plan to tackle the debt while providing immediate relief to those facing cost of living pressures.

site_title: Singapore must act decisively to safeguard energy security
summary: Singapore must take decisive action to secure its energy security amid the global energy crisis sparked by Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The country needs to rapidly expand local renewable energy production, diversify its energy sources, and invest in technological research to compensate for its relative lack of resources. Aiming for 40% of its energy mix to be locally produced by 2035 and 30% of its electricity needs to be imported from clean energy sources by 2035 is considered an ambitious yet necessary goal.

site_title: What the current volatility means for energy-transition investing
summary: Investors navigating the current volatile market face a challenging cocktail of risks, including inflation, supply chain disruptions, and geopolitical tensions. However, energy-transition equities offer substantial long-term opportunities, with over $100 trillion expected to be spent on achieving a sustainable energy system over the next 30 years. Despite near-term risks, valuations have reset and the sector is now fairly priced. Investors willing to hold on through the short-term pain may find the longer-term returns projection appealing, with structurally growing markets and a strong potential for earnings growth.

site_title: The battle for sovereignty is now fought online
summary: The battle for sovereignty is shifting to the online realm as nation-state conflicts increasingly involve cyber attacks. Governments are struggling to defend their critical information infrastructure (CII) against sophisticated and impactful cyber-attacks, which can weaken governments, militaries, and businesses. A holistic and integrated approach to cybersecurity is needed, with Extended Detection and Response (XDR) and public-private partnerships to facilitate data sharing being key solutions. Governments must keep pace with the latest cyber-attack campaigns and vulnerabilities to effectively navigate the digital terrain and build a safer digital environment.

site_title: Wall Street Firms Make Crypto Push to Catch Up With ‘Cool Kids’
summary: Wall Street firms are expanding their services to catch up with the growing demand for cryptocurrencies. Financial heavyweights such as Jefferies, BlackRock, and Goldman Sachs are investing in crypto trading, prime brokerage, and wealth management. Despite initial resistance, the firms are recognizing the importance of staying competitive in the rapidly evolving industry. Institutional investors traded $1.14 trillion of cryptocurrencies last year, and banks are exploring wholesale lending to crypto firms and offering crypto services in trading and wealth management. Regulatory uncertainty and compliance remain a challenge, but the industry's growth is expected to continue.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rebound from 6-week low, automakers lead gains
summary: South Korea's Kospi index rose 0.42% to 2,668.31, rebounding from a 6-week low, driven by Wall Street's overnight gain and better-than-expected GDP data. Automakers Hyundai Motor and Kia led the gains, with LG Energy Solution falling 2.19%. The Korean won weakened, while the benchmark bond yield fell. Foreigners were net sellers of 250.2 billion won worth of shares.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi closed down 47.58 points, or 1.76 per cent, at 2,657.13.

site_title: JTC puts up 2 industrial land sites for sale in Tampines
summary: The Jurong Town Corporation (JTC) has launched two industrial land sites for sale in Tampines, Singapore. The sites, located near the Giant and Ikea cluster, are available for application through the reserve list system and confirmed list. The first site, Plot 10, spans 0.5 hectares and has a gross plot ratio of 2.5, while the second site, Plot 9, spans 0.49 hectares. Interested parties have until June 7 and June 21 to submit applications, respectively, with a minimum committed bid price of S$7 million for Plot 10.

site_title: Singapore Q1 GDP expected to be upgraded with better-than-expected March factory output
summary: Singapore's Q1 GDP is expected to be upgraded after better-than-expected March factory output, which slowed to 3.4% year-over-year despite a 17.5% jump in February. The industrial production index excluding the biomedical cluster grew 9.7% year-over-year. Economists predict an upgrade of 0.2-0.7 percentage points to the final print of Q1 GDP, which was initially estimated at 3.4%. This improvement is attributed to the resilience of the transport engineering sector, which saw a 20.7% year-over-year increase in output.

site_title: Twitter under Elon Musk will be a scary place
summary: Elon Musk's takeover of Twitter has sparked concerns over the platform's future. Twitter's board accepted a $54.20 per-share takeover bid from Musk, despite his history of using the platform to spread misinformation and harassment. Critics argue that Musk's vision for an "inclusive arena for free speech" would prioritize his own views over others, potentially leading to increased toxicity and censorship. Musk's track record of mishandling companies he owns, including allegations of racism and sexism, has also raised red flags. The move has left Twitter employees and users worried about the platform's direction under Musk's leadership.

site_title: WeWork rival IWG revenue rises but inflation in focus
summary: IWG, a global office rental company, reported a 18% increase in quarterly revenue to £613.7 million, driven by growing demand for flexible workspaces. Occupancy levels are nearing pre-pandemic levels, with 83% of Fortune 500 firms as customers. However, IWG warned of higher costs due to rising inflation and a slower-than-expected return to normal conditions in China, where current lockdowns are impacting business. The company has about 3,500 buildings in over 120 countries.

site_title: A joint push to ensure America Competes
summary: US President Joe Biden's administration is set to pass the America COMPETES Act of 2022, a bipartisan bill aimed at boosting US technological competitiveness with China. The $1.2 trillion infrastructure package, passed last November, was the first major legislative achievement of Biden's presidency, garnering support from both parties. The COMPETES Act, which includes subsidies for domestic semiconductor manufacturing and research, is expected to pass with even broader bipartisan support. This shift in industrial policy marks a turning point for the US approach, as the government takes a more activist role in overseeing the growth of the nation's industrial-technological base to compete with China.

site_title: Sumitomo Mitsui in talks for stake in Marathon Capital: sources
summary: Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group is in talks to acquire a minority stake in Marathon Capital, an independent investment bank specializing in clean power, infrastructure, and sustainable technology transactions. If a deal is reached, it may be announced in coming weeks. Marathon Capital was founded in 1999 by CEO Ted Brandt and has advised on transactions including investments by Carlyle Group and Manulife Investment Management. The move is part of a trend of foreign banks seeking to expand in the US, which has the deepest global fee pool.

site_title: Adapting to a hawkish Fed
summary: The US Federal Reserve has pivoted from its initial plan to keep interest rates at zero through 2022, instead indicating a desire to normalize the federal funds rate to neutral. This shift comes after recent meetings, marking a significant change in the Fed's stance on interest rates.

site_title: Shanghai stainless steel extends losses as raw material prices fall
summary: Shanghai stainless steel futures fell 1.4% to 19,225 yuan (S$4,030) a tonne, its lowest close since March 4, due to a drop in nickel prices and poor downstream consumption. The current market is characterized as "high cost, low profit, strong supply, and weak demand". Other steel products also extended falls, with construction material rebar and hot-rolled coils dropping 0.7% and 1.2% respectively. Chinese Premier Li Keqiang urged policy measures to stabilize prices and economic fundamentals amid economic impact from domestic and external factors.

site_title: China builder bonds diverge as offshore creditors lose most
summary: China's distressed developers are experiencing a record rout in dollar bonds, with Yuzhou Group and Shimao Group seeing their dollar notes decline sharply this year, while local creditors have received coupon payments or sweetened offers. In contrast, yuan bonds have fallen less or gained. This divergence highlights the subordination risk faced by offshore holders, with some cases showing better outcomes for onshore creditors. The Chinese government's policy support and domestic lenders' support may help mitigate the crisis, but offshore investors remain cautious.

site_title: Trust in banks in Singapore increases despite Covid-19 uncertainties: ABS study
summary: Trust in Singapore's banking industry has increased by 7 points to 63% due to the industry's focus on continual improvement, customer-centric solutions, and community contributions. 68% of respondents have high trust, 5% have low trust, and 27% have moderate views. The industry faces areas for improvement, including increased accountability and community contributions, as well as strengthening security measures to safeguard customer accounts. Experts emphasize the need for banks to continually invest in maintaining and building trust with customers, particularly in the increasingly digitalized financial sector.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares track Wall Street gains, China worries cap rise
summary: Japanese shares rose 0.41% to close at 26,700.11, tracking US Wall Street gains, but were capped by concerns over China's Covid-19 lockdown impact on domestic companies. The Shanghai lockdown entered its fourth week, while Beijing's mass testing orders sparked fears of a similar fate.

site_title: Victor and vacillator: Macron wins, Scholz hesitates
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron won re-election with a reduced margin over far-right rival Marine Le Pen, but faces a lacklustre support from his allies in the upcoming parliamentary elections. This may hinder his ability to govern. Macron's victory has raised expectations for Franco-German cooperation on Europe's international position, strained by Covid-19, inflation, and the Ukraine war. However, key differences remain, including energy security, European interest rates, and the future of Christine Lagarde, ECB president. The EU has also put on hold attempts to reform the fiscal rules of monetary union, and the ECB's bond portfolio is a matter of extreme political and legal sensitivity.

site_title: IPO drought places HKEX among world’s worst-performing bourses
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing (HKEX) is among the world's worst-performing bourses this year, with its shares declining 28% in 2022. The exchange's earnings are expected to slump 23% in the first quarter, attributed to China's corporate clampdown, pandemic-related woes, and fewer large IPOs. Hong Kong has not hosted any IPO larger than $1 billion this year, with most newcomers failing to meet the listing price. Analysts predict HKEX may benefit from a shift of US-listed Chinese companies to the city and mutual market access programs.

site_title: China's No 2 phone maker seeks new funding ahead of 2022 IPO: sources
summary: Honor Device, China's second-largest smartphone maker, is seeking new funding ahead of a potential initial public offering (IPO) as early as this year. The company is in talks with investors about a pre-IPO round of financing to boost its domestic retail and e-commerce operations and build a global presence. Honor is seeking foreign funding to distance itself from Huawei and potential China-related sanctions, but investors are wary of its valuation of over $45 billion. The company is likely to opt for a domestic listing in China, but a final decision has not been reached.

site_title: HSBC Q1 profit drops on credit charges, says more buybacks unlikely in 2022
summary: HSBC Holdings reported a 27% drop in quarterly profit to $4.2 billion, citing rising inflation and economic uncertainty due to the Russia-Ukraine conflict. The bank also nixed the possibility of more buybacks this year, blaming volatility in investment hedges. Despite a 12% gain in shares this year, HSBC's results beat analyst estimates, with higher lending and business growth in personal banking and trade finance expected to support future quarters.

site_title: Indonesia may widen palm oil export ban if local demand not met
summary: Indonesia may expand its palm oil export ban to include crude palm oil if domestic shortages occur. The current ban applies to refined palm olein and will be strictly monitored. If shortages are found, further export bans can be implemented. The ban aims to control soaring local prices, which have already risen due to adverse weather and Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Global edible oil prices have surged, and the rupiah has rebounded slightly on the news.

site_title: Investing post-pandemic: Start with these 3 sectors
summary: Singapore's post-pandemic recovery has opened up opportunities for investing in sectors such as travel, tourism, and hospitality. With borders reopening and economic growth, companies like Singapore Airlines, Royal Caribbean Cruises, and Disney are expected to benefit. Additionally, luxury spending is on the rise, with companies like Ralph Lauren, Prada, and Gucci seeing significant growth. Investors can also consider hospitality REITs, such as Ascott Residence Trust and CDL Hospitality Trusts, and online platforms like AirBnB.

site_title: Brokers' take: Offer price for Apac Realty low, takeover likely to fail
summary: Analysts predict Morgan Stanley Private Equity Asia's S$0.57 per-share takeover offer for Apac Realty is too low, undervaluing the company's long-term potential. RHB Group and CGS-CIMB maintain neutral and "add" ratings, respectively, with target prices of S$0.75 and S$0.93. Analysts believe the offer price is a 30.1% discount from the last traded share price and is unlikely to succeed, with potential weakness in the company's share price in the near term.

site_title: Novartis income edges higher on strong Sandoz, Entresto
summary: Novartis reported a 3% increase in core operating income to $4.08 billion in the first quarter, driven by a rebound at its generic drugs unit Sandoz and a surge in Entresto prescriptions for heart failure treatment. Sandoz's core operating income rose 21% to $538 million, and Entresto's revenue jumped 42% to $1.1 billion, beating market expectations. Novartis reiterated its full-year 2022 earnings forecast and confirmed plans to buy back up to $15 billion worth of shares, with CEO Vas Narasimhan targeting $2 billion in acquisitions.

site_title: SoftBank invests in Japanese startup that helps detect cancer
summary: SoftBank has invested in AI Medical Service, a Japanese startup that develops systems for gastrointestinal diagnostics using artificial intelligence to help clinicians identify potential stomach and intestine cancers. This is SoftBank's third investment in a Japanese startup, following Aculys Pharma and Soda Inc, both also backed by the Vision Fund 2. The investment aims to expand SoftBank's presence in Japan's biotech and frontier tech sectors, according to founder Masayoshi Son, who plans to increase staff and deal-making in the country.

site_title: What you need to know about Elon Musk's US$44 billion Twitter deal
summary: Elon Musk has reached an agreement to buy Twitter for $44 billion, his initial offer price of $54.20 per share. The deal, valued at $44 billion, is expected to close this year subject to shareholder and regulatory approvals. Musk aims to enhance Twitter's product with new features, including an edit button and open-source algorithms, and promote free speech. The acquisition has sparked concerns in China, where Twitter is banned, and analysts expect Musk to make significant changes to the business model. The deal has been unanimously approved by Twitter's board of directors.

site_title: Japan's jobless rate hits lowest in almost 2 years, economic outlook still shaky
summary: Japan's jobless rate fell to 2.6% in March, the lowest since April 2020, but the number of furloughed workers remained high due to the pandemic's effects. The seasonally-adjusted unemployment rate was lower than forecast, with 180,000 more workers and 90,000 fewer unemployed, compared to the previous month. The government sees the drop as a sign of recovery, but notes that the pandemic's impact continues to be felt, with 2.43 million workers on furlough. The country's economic outlook remains shaky due to ongoing risks, including the Ukraine war.

site_title: London beats Dubai as top city for foreign investment in finance
summary: London surpassed Dubai as the top city for foreign investment in finance firms in 2021, attracting £600 million in investment into 114 financial and professional services projects. The UK capital took second place globally, behind the US, which attracted 234 projects valued at £1.1 billion. The number of financial and professional services projects in the UK grew 8% in 2021, with fintech firms accounting for a third of the investments. The City of London Corporation's report highlights the enduring role of finance as a key export for the UK, with the sector needing to "future-proof" and remain globally competitive.

site_title: UBS posts surprise 17% Q1 profit rise
summary: UBS posted a 17% rise in first-quarter net profit, exceeding expectations of a decline amidst war uncertainties, thanks to strong trading. The Swiss bank's net profit reached US$2.136 billion, outpacing average analyst expectations of US$1.79 billion. CEO Ralph Hamers attributed the strong results to the bank's ability to execute its strategy and manage risk, despite the challenging backdrop. The earnings report provides a contrast to the profit declines reported by US peers this month.

site_title: JPMorgan sued after millions stolen from Ray-Ban maker’s account
summary: Essilor Manufacturing (Thailand) Co. has sued JPMorgan Chase Bank, alleging the bank ignored red flags as international cybercriminals drained $272 million from its New York bank account in 2019. Despite being aware of a "highly suspicious pattern of fraudulent transactions" as early as September 2019, JPMorgan failed to notify the company. The company is seeking compensatory damages for the stolen funds, which it recovered all but $100 million of.

site_title: ECB has room for 2-3 rate hikes this year: policymaker
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has room for 2-3 interest rate hikes this year, according to ECB policymaker Martins Kazaks, amid a surge in inflation to nearly 4 times the ECB's 2% target. Kazaks suggests a rate rise in July is possible and reasonable, with markets pricing in 2 or 3 25 basis point steps by the end of the year. The ECB aims to normalize interest rates to the neutral rate, around 1-1.5%, to prevent excessive growth.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The European Central Bank (ECB) logo in Frankfurt, Germany, January 23, 2020. REUTERS/Ralph Orlowski//File Photo

site_title: About 1 in 8 SME employees receive no medical benefits at work: Prudential survey
summary: About 1 in 8 small and medium-sized enterprise (SME) employees in Singapore receive no medical benefits at work, according to a Prudential survey of 1,029 employees. The main reasons cited were the small size of their companies and high costs of group insurance. Only 27% of SMEs with 10 or fewer employees receive any medical benefits. The majority of respondents, 9 in 10, want their employers to provide healthcare coverage, and 60% are more likely to join an SME that offers medical benefits.

site_title: Elon Musk and Twitter: What we know, what we don't about US$44b deal
summary: Elon Musk has agreed to buy Twitter for $44 billion, following weeks of speculation after he took a stake in the social media platform. Musk's original bid was $54.20 per share, but the price was adjusted to $44 billion. He has raised $25.5 billion in debt financing from 12 banks to back the bid. Twitter will become a privately held company, and Musk has agreed to buy the platform "wholly owned" by himself. The deal is subject to a shareholder vote, and Musk's plans for the platform include making it a haven for unfettered speech and removing ads for paid users.

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB lowers Parkway Life Reit to 'hold' on limited share price upside
summary: Brokerage firm CGS-CIMB downgraded its recommendation on Parkway Life Reit to "hold" from "add" due to limited near-term upside for the counter's unit price. Analyst Lock Mun Yee maintains a stable income structure and expects the Reit's distribution per unit to remain consistent. Despite a 1.9% on-year increase in net property income for the first quarter, the firm notes that the Reit's unit price has already outperformed in recent months, pricing in the stability.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed but China, Fed keep confidence in check
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Tuesday, recovering partially from the previous day's rout, but concerns over China's Covid-induced lockdowns and the Federal Reserve's plan to hike interest rates continue to drag on sentiment. China's lockdowns threaten the world's second-largest economy, while the Fed aims to control inflation at a 40-year high. Despite this, traders are less convinced that the situation will shift the Fed's plans to aggressively hike interest rates. Markets in Hong Kong and Shanghai edged up, while Tokyo, Seoul, and Jakarta also ticked higher, but losses in Sydney, Singapore, and others persisted.

site_title: CEO of sportswear firm Fila Philippines found dead in Singapore
summary: Philippines' CEO of Fila Philippines, Maricris Abad Santos Albert, was found dead in Singapore on April 23 at the age of 52. The investigation into her death is being treated as unnatural, and her business, Fila Philippines, confirmed her passing in a Facebook post. Albert was also the CEO of Isport Life, the sole distributor of Fila products in the Philippines. The cause of her death has not been disclosed.

site_title: Singapore March factory output eases to 3.4% amid steep fall in biomedical manufacturing
summary: Singapore's factory output eased to a 3.4% year-on-year increase in March, driven by a surge in the aerospace segment and electronics production. Excluding the volatile biomedical manufacturing sector, industrial output grew 9.7% year-on-year. The transport engineering sector saw a 20.7% year-on-year increase, while the aerospace segment surged 39.3%. Despite a decline in biomedical manufacturing, overall manufacturing output for the first quarter is expected to grow 7.1%, higher than initial estimates.

images.alt_text: Singapore exports grow by 7.7% in March as gold shipments lift trade

site_title: Australia: Shares slide over 2% as China lockdown fears hit commodities
summary: Australian shares fell 2.4% on Tuesday, hitting a five-week low, due to concerns over prolonged Covid-19 lockdowns in China and aggressive global interest rate hikes. Iron ore and industrial metals plummeted, with sector majors BHP Group, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue Metals Group experiencing their biggest intraday drops in nearly two years. The S&P/ASX 200 index also declined, with energy stocks recording their worst intraday drop since June 2020.

site_title: Kim will ‘strengthen’ North Korea’s nuclear weapons: state media
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has vowed to strengthen the country's nuclear weapons program, stating that the nation will "continue to take steps to strengthen and develop our nation's nuclear capabilities at the fastest pace." The declaration comes as the country faces biting international sanctions over its nuclear ambitions. Kim emphasized that the nuclear arsenal is a "symbol of national power" and should be diversified, with the potential for deployment in case of a threat to North Korea's "fundamental interests."

site_title: Fintech unicorn Nium to acquire alternative payments platform SoCash
summary: Fintech unicorn Nium has announced its acquisition of alternative payments platform SoCash, a Singapore-based company, for an undisclosed sum. SoCash allows customers to deposit, withdraw, and make payments with cash from over 30,000 local shops in Singapore, Malaysia, and Indonesia. The acquisition is expected to be completed in the third quarter of 2022 and will provide Nium with the ability to accept physical payment methods for e-commerce, saving up to 30% in commissions. Nium co-founder Pratik Gandhi stated that the acquisition will offer a lower-cost payment processing alternative for digital merchants.

site_title: Gold regains some ground as bond yields ease
summary: Gold prices firmed above a near 4-week low on Tuesday, driven by lower US Treasury yields and a slight dollar retreat. Spot gold rose 0.2% to $1,902.31 per ounce, while US gold futures increased 0.3%. The easing yields made gold more attractive, and the dollar's retreat offered support. Silver, platinum, and palladium also rose, with palladium advancing 1.2% to $2,170.42. The price gains come after concerns over nuclear war and rising interest rates had pressured gold prices in the previous session.

site_title: Classical music incorporated: The CEO also plays Chopin
summary: Kyohei Sorita, a 27-year-old pianist and aspiring conductor, has founded Japan's first orchestra operating as a stock-issuing company, the Japan National Orchestra (JNO). Backed by Japanese manufacturer DMG Mori, JNO aims to promote classical music and nurture talent through concerts, tours, and online platforms. Sorita's vision is to make the orchestra financially sustainable while fostering younger musical talent and eventually establishing a musical academy. The company has broken even and is planning to take the orchestra overseas later in 2022, with a subscription-style membership service and paid performances.

site_title: Funding Societies co-invests with Carro for a stake of Indonesian bank Bank Index
summary: Funding Societies, a small and medium-sized enterprise (SME) financing platform, has co-invested with used car marketplace Carro in Indonesian bank Bank Index Selindo (Bank Index). The move aims to support Funding Societies' neobanking ambitions and tap the unbanked population of Indonesian SMEs. The partnership is part of a recent US$249 million Series C funding round, with Softbank leading the round, and will focus on expanding services to target markets. This is the latest in a series of fintech investments in Indonesian banks by companies like Welab, Sea, and Grab.

site_title: 4 ways Twitter could change under Elon Musk
summary: Elon Musk, set to acquire Twitter, has expressed concerns about the platform's content moderation policies, suggesting he may change the way the platform handles user content. Musk has hinted at revising Twitter's approach to free speech, potentially reducing the role of content moderators. He may also introduce new features to promote transparency and accountability. However, the exact nature of his plans remains unclear. Musk has provided hints through interviews, regulatory filings, and his own Twitter account, but his vision for the platform's future is still subject to interpretation.

site_title: Olam’s OFI to acquire Canada’s Club Coffee at enterprise value of C$150m
summary: Olam's food ingredients unit, Olam Food Ingredients (OFI), is set to acquire Canada's Club Coffee for C$150 million (S$161.8 million), expanding its private label capabilities in North America. The acquisition is expected to complete in Q2 2022, pending regulatory approval. OFI's existing cash and debt facilities will fund the deal, which is expected to be accretive to current year earnings. The acquisition will expand OFI's presence in the private label and co-manufactured channel, a high-value and growing segment.

images.alt_text: Olam International's new office at Straits View, Marina One East Tower. It has an 18-metre long green wall, designed to capture the spirit of their business and create a living green space.

site_title: SIA, United Airlines expand codeshare agreement to 19 new destinations
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and United Airlines have expanded their codeshare agreement to 19 new destinations, including 10 in the US and 9 in South-east Asia. SIA customers can now connect to US destinations via Los Angeles, while United customers can connect to South-east Asian destinations. The agreement aims to boost business travel and passenger capacity, following Singapore's easing of pandemic curbs.

site_title: Global supply chain crisis flares up again where it all began
summary: China's strict COVID-19 measures are poised to disrupt global supply chains, exacerbating existing congestion at US and European ports. The lockdown in Shanghai, home to the world's largest container port, has led to a 35% increase in container ships waiting to offload. This is expected to cause a one-two punch, threatening to derail the global economy, which is already buffeted by inflation pressures and headwinds to growth. Companies are reassessing their global supply chains, with some opting for regionalization to reduce exposure to Asia, and policymakers are exploring "friend-shoring" strategies to promote more resilient trade linkages.

site_title: IMF warns Asia faces 'stagflationary' economic outlook
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned that Asia's economy faces a "stagflationary" outlook, with expected growth of 4.9% this year, down 0.5 percentage points from its previous projection. The region's economies will be affected by higher commodity prices and slower growth in European trading partners due to the ongoing crisis in Russia and Ukraine. IMF officials also cited risks from a faster-than-expected Fed rate hike trajectory, new Covid-19 waves, and prolonged lockdowns in China, highlighting significant uncertainty around the region's growth outlook.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CLCT, Suntec Reit, APAC Realty, F&N, Olam Group
summary: Singapore stocks saw significant developments on Tuesday, with CapitaLand China Trust (CLCT) posting a 30.4% rise in Q1 net property income to S$72.2 million, while Suntec Reit's distribution per unit rose 16.9% to S$0.02391. APAC Realty agreed to acquire a 59.8% stake for S$129.5 million, and Olam Group announced the acquisition of Canadian coffee roaster Club Coffee for S$161.8 million. Meanwhile, Fraser & Neave proposed to acquire Ladang Permai Damai for S$68.3 million.

site_title: Doge surges after memecoin advocate Musk agrees to buy Twitter
summary: Dogecoin surged 30% after Elon Musk agreed to buy Twitter, reaching 17 cents. Musk, a frequent supporter of Dogecoin, had previously hinted at using it to buy Tesla merchandise. The cryptocurrency's rally is due to speculation about potential integration plans, despite Musk's lack of confirmation. This move is reminiscent of Tesla's 2021 Bitcoin purchase, which also sparked a rally.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.59% to 26,746.37, and the Topix index gaining 0.36% to 1,884.09. Investors were boosted by gains on Wall Street, but remained cautious about Chinese shares.

site_title: Coal still top threat to global climate goals: report
summary: Coal remains a significant threat to global climate goals, with record CO2 emissions in 2021 despite a decline in new coal-fired power plants under construction or development. The operational fleet of coal-fired power plants grew by 18 GW, and 176 GW of new capacity is under construction, primarily in China and South and South-east Asia. The UN and IEA warn that capping global warming at liveable levels requires no new coal plants and a rapid phase-out of existing ones, with rich countries expected to achieve this by 2030 and most of the world by 2040.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Steam rises from the cooling towers of the coal power plant of RWE, one of Europe's biggest electricity and gas companies in Niederaussem, Germany,  March 3, 2016.    REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Tuesday's open; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.1% to 3,343.52 at Tuesday's open, tracking overnight gains on Wall Street. The STI gained 3.93 points, with 37.3 million securities worth S$42.9 million changing hands. Gainers outnumbered losers 73 to 36, with notable gainers including Jiutian Chemical, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, and Singapore Telecommunications. This follows a roller-coaster session on US markets, where the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.7% and the S&P 500 gained 0.6%.

site_title: Japan's Sumitomo Metal abandons Pomalaa nickel project in Indonesia
summary: Japan's Sumitomo Metal Mining Co. has abandoned its feasibility study on a nickel processing plant project in Pomalaa, Indonesia, due to a disagreement with partner PT Vale Indonesia. The project aimed to boost nickel output to 150,000 tonnes a year, but construction delays and differing views on costs and scheduling led to the decision. SMM cited the difficulty in maintaining its project team without a prospect for future progress. The project's future remains uncertain, with PT Vale Indonesia committing to its development.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 8.78 points or 0.55% to 1,598.76 on Tuesday, with 214.20 million lots traded at RM94.36 million. Gainers outpaced losers 333 to 89. The market opened higher despite global economic uncertainty, with stocks in the US and Europe also making gains. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records, while the STI rose 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open slightly higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly higher on Tuesday, April 26, 2022, after a 0.60% gain in the Hang Seng Index to 19,989.04. The gains came despite ongoing concerns over China's worsening Covid outbreak and lockdowns. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index edged up 0.07% and 0.10%, respectively.

site_title: Don't pop that crypto-cork just yet on wine NFTs
summary: Brad Pitt's wine house is set to release its first NFTs, with exclusive experiences and physical bottles of rare cuvées tied to unique QR codes on a blockchain. However, experts are skeptical about the long-term viability of NFTs in the wine industry, citing concerns over authenticity and value. While some wineries see NFTs as a way to connect with younger generations and add brand publicity, others view them as gimmicks. The market for NFT wine is expected to grow, but for now, investors should approach with caution, as the technology is still in its early stages.

site_title: Chinese stocks in the US whipsaw amid growing lockdown woes
summary: US-listed Chinese stocks experienced a whipsaw on Monday, closing 0.7% higher after falling as much as 4.1% in early trading, amid concerns over China's expanded Covid measures in major cities. The rebound followed a 4.9% slump in China's CSI 300 Index, which closed at its lowest level in 2 years. Investors weigh the economic ramifications of the country's lockdown woes, with China's central bank cutting foreign exchange reserve ratio to counter yuan weakness.

site_title: Softbank cuts back spending, leaving startups desperate for cash: sources
summary: SoftBank Group, the world's largest tech investor, is cutting back on spending, leaving its portfolio companies, including Light, struggling to raise funds. SoftBank's Vision Fund, which backed Light with a $121 million investment in 2018, is now offering only a token amount for the startup's next fundraising round. Light, which had been expanding into self-driving tech, is now exploring options, including winding down operations, as its purse strings are tight. This marks a significant shift from SoftBank's past freewheeling largess, with the company adopting prudence in its investment strategy amid plunging tech valuations.

site_title: South Korea's Q1 GDP growth slows but beats expectations
summary: South Korea's Q1 GDP growth slowed to 0.7% seasonally-adjusted, nearly halving from the previous quarter due to coronavirus curbs on private consumption and surging inflation. This beats economists' forecast of 0.6% growth, but still falls short of expectations. The economy grew 3.1% from a year earlier, surpassing the 2.8% forecast. The growth slowdown raises concerns over the recovery, but the Bank of Korea's data suggests the economy is still on track to meet its 2022 growth target.

site_title: Twitter CEO tells employees company is in the dark over future under Musk
summary: Twitter CEO Parag Agrawal told employees that the future of the company is uncertain after Elon Musk's deal to take the company private. Agrawal deferred many questions about Musk's plans, citing that they should be asked directly by Musk himself. A question-and-answer session with Musk is set to take place at a later date, but no specific details were provided. Agrawal's comments suggest that the company is in the dark about its future under Musk's leadership.

site_title: Bored Ape Instagram hack cost NFT owners US$3m
summary: Hackers gained unauthorized access to the Instagram account of the Bored Ape Yacht Club (BAYC) collection, resulting in the loss of approximately US$3 million worth of non-fungible tokens (NFTs). The hackers uploaded a phishing post, claiming free crypto tokens, and tricked users into authenticating their digital wallets to the fraudulent site, allowing the hackers to access and transfer their NFTs. Despite the account being protected with 2-factor authentication, the incident highlights the vulnerability of social engineering tactics in crypto scams.

site_title: Crew of first private flight to ISS return to Earth
summary: A crew of four, including a former NASA astronaut, safely splashed down in the Atlantic Ocean on April 25, 2022, after spending 17 days aboard the International Space Station. The Axiom Space Ax-1 mission, the first fully private mission to the ISS, marked a milestone for NASA's commercialization efforts. The crew, consisting of wealthy businessmen and the astronaut, carried out research projects, including experiments on cancer stem cells and robotic swarm technology. The successful mission paves the way for future private missions and Axiom's plans to build its own private space station.

site_title: Blackstone agrees to buy PS Business Parks for US$7.6b
summary: Blackstone has agreed to purchase PS Business Parks for approximately $7.6 billion, expanding its real estate portfolio in the US. The deal, valued at $187.50 per share, is a 12% premium to PS Business Parks' closing price. The acquisition includes around 27 million square feet of industrial, office, and rental housing properties in California, Miami, Texas, and Northern Virginia, with affiliates of Blackstone Real Estate taking over the assets.

site_title: China lockdown ramps up inflation scare for global markets
summary: China's potential lockdown of Beijing, a city of over 20 million people, has heightened concerns about supply stresses and inflation, sparking a global market downturn. European stocks fell the most since April 6, while US futures are expected to open lower. The inflation scare, combined with aggressive central bank responses, is taking a toll on demand, spending, and corporate earnings. The S&P 500 Index has slumped for three weeks, and some analysts predict a bear market, as monetary authorities rush to respond with interest rate hikes and emergency stimulus cuts.

site_title: Hong Kong looks to start trade in Yuan stocks in second half: sources
summary: Hong Kong is poised to launch yuan-denominated stock trading in the second half of the year, with final clearances from mainland China regulators expected. The move aims to build Hong Kong as a hub for offshore yuan trading and reduce currency risks for investors in the mainland. The initiative, which includes waiving stamp duty for market makers, is seen as a potential first financial achievement for new Hong Kong leader John Lee. However, experts question the impact on yuan internationalization, citing limited demand from Chinese firms.

site_title: UK hosts ‘world’s first’ hub for drones, future flying taxis
summary: The UK has launched the world's first fully operational vertiport for drones and future flying taxis, dubbed Air-One, in Coventry. The pop-up urban port, developed by Urban-Air Port, marked a significant milestone in the burgeoning industry, with a commercial drone taking off and landing vertically for the first time. The site aims to showcase integrated hubs for autonomous delivery drones and air taxis, with plans for over 200 similar sites worldwide, and has secured orders worth £65 million. The UK government's "future flight challenge" funded the project, with potential uses including emergency responders and logistics operators.

site_title: 'You Raise Me Up' copyright fight rejected by US Supreme Court
summary: The US Supreme Court has rejected Johannsongs-Publishing's request to review the Ninth Circuit's copyright standard in a lawsuit over the song "You Raise Me Up." Johannsongs sued Rolf Lovland, Universal Music Group Recordings, and Warner Records over the 2003 Josh Groban cover of Lovland's 2001 song, claiming substantial similarity. The Ninth Circuit upheld a lower court's decision that Johannsongs failed to provide enough evidence of substantial similarity, citing a flawed extrinsic test used to compare the songs. Johannsongs argued the test was "logically flawed" but the Supreme Court declined to review the case.

site_title: Trump rules out Twitter return as Musk announces US$44b purchase
summary: Former US President Donald Trump has ruled out returning to Twitter, citing concerns over the platform's moderation practices and the presence of bots and fake accounts. Trump stated he will continue using his own platform, Truth Social, after Elon Musk's $44 billion purchase of Twitter. Musk, a self-proclaimed "free-speech absolutist," is expected to take a less robust approach to regulating content, potentially reinstating accounts of Trump and allies who have been suspended.

site_title: Two-thirds of workers might seek new jobs if forced back to office: global survey
summary: A global survey of nearly 33,000 workers found that 2/3 would consider looking for a new job if forced back to office full-time. Worker demands for flexibility and security are growing due to the pandemic and tight labor market. Satisfaction with current jobs is low, with half of workers reporting they are only somewhat or not at all satisfied. The pandemic has led to increased stress in the workplace, driving workers to negotiate job terms or seek new employment.

site_title: Bitcoin touches six-week low as risk-off mood gathers momentum
summary: Bitcoin fell 3.3% to $38,223, its lowest since March 15, amid a risk-off mood and hawkish Federal Reserve policy outlook. The decline is part of a broader trend, with Ether also dropping 4.8%. Despite this, Bitcoin remains within its trading range of $35,000 to $45,000. Technical analysts predict further declines, with some expecting a retest of January lows. The decline is linked to the Fed's expected rate hikes to combat inflation, potentially leading investors to reallocate from Bitcoin to the dollar.

site_title: Twitter CEO tells employees company is in the dark over future under Musk
summary: Twitter CEO Parag Agrawal revealed that the company's future is uncertain after Elon Musk's planned takeover. In a town hall meeting, Agrawal deflected questions about Musk's plans, including whether former President Donald Trump would be allowed to return to the platform. Agrawal assured employees that there are no plans for layoffs, but acknowledged that the platform's direction is unclear until Musk joins for a Q&A session. Twitter's board chair, Bret Taylor, expressed confidence that the deal prioritizes operating continuity until the transaction is closed.

site_title: CLCT posts 30.4% increase in Q1 net property income to 344.5m yuan
summary: CapitaLand China Trust (CLCT) reported a 30.4% increase in net property income to 344.5 million yuan (S$72.2 million) for its first quarter ended March 2022, driven by full contributions from business parks and new contributions from logistics parks. Gross revenue rose 24% to 489.9 million yuan. Retail occupancy remained at 95.4% despite a 7.1% drop in shopper traffic. The company expects steady leasing demand for business parks and new demand for logistics parks amid positive business confidence and government support.

site_title: GM's Corvette is going electric
summary: General Motors has confirmed plans to offer an electrified version of its iconic Corvette sports car as early as next year, featuring a hybrid model with an electric motor and petrol engine. The hybrid Corvette will be followed by an all-electric version powered by GM's Ultium battery. This marks a significant shift towards an all-electric future for the Corvette line, which is also expected to include a crossover SUV.

site_title: Humanity stuck in ‘spiral of self-destruction’: UN
summary: The UN Office for Disaster Risk Reduction warns that humanity is suffering from a "broken perception of risk" leading to climate change and a surge in disasters globally. Between 350-500 medium- to large-scale disasters occur annually, a 5-fold increase from the previous three decades. By 2030, 560 disasters are expected annually, with devastating events like drought, extreme temperatures, and flooding becoming more frequent. This is attributed to a "broken perception of risk" leading to policy decisions that exacerbate vulnerabilities and put people in danger, setting humanity on a "spiral of self-destruction."

site_title: Europe: Stocks slide to 1-month low on China slowdown fears
summary: Europe's stocks slid to a 1-month low, dropping 1.8% due to concerns over China's economic slowdown and rapid US interest rate hikes. Commodity stocks fell 6% as China-exposed sectors such as miners and oil & gas declined. The STOXX 600 index closed at its lowest since mid-March, while France's CAC 40 dropped 2%. Investors sought safety in bonds amid fears of stagflation and weaker economic growth.

site_title: Inflation puts rate hike on table in Australia during election
summary: Australia's core inflation is expected to breach the Reserve Bank's 2-3% target for the first time since 2010, intensifying pressure on policymakers to raise interest rates amid an election campaign. Core inflation is forecast to reach 3.4% in the first quarter, while headline prices are seen soaring to 4.6% due to high energy costs. Despite the risk of alienating voters, economists expect the Reserve Bank of Australia to raise interest rates in June, with some predicting a 40 basis point hike.

site_title: Suntec Reit posts 16.9% rise in Q1 DPU amid higher contributions
summary: Suntec Reit reported a 16.9% year-on-year increase in Q1 distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.02391, driven by higher contributions from Suntec City Office and Suntec City Mall. Gross revenue rose 13.9% to S$99.2 million, with net property income growing 24.9% to S$74.3 million. The company's portfolio remains resilient, with positive rent reversion in Singapore and improved occupancy at Suntec City Mall. Capital distribution resumed after the pandemic, and the company is more optimistic about the recovery of retail and convention businesses.

images.alt_text: Suntec City is an integrated development comprising five Grade-A office towers, a mall and a convention and exhibition centre. It is linked to three MRT stations and the Marina Centre area.

site_title: Sri Lanka cut to selective default by S&P after missed payment
summary: Sri Lanka was downgraded to selective default by S&P Global Ratings after missing an interest payment on its dollar bonds, with the long-term foreign currency debt rating lowered to SD from CC. The government had halted payments on foreign debt to preserve its dwindling dollar stockpile for essential imports. This marks the first blemish on the nation's debt record since its independence in 1948, with Fitch Ratings and Moody's Investors Service also downgrading the country's debt.

site_title: US ships artillery to Ukraine to destroy Russian firepower
summary: The US is sending long-range howitzers to Ukraine to degrade Russian firepower and weaken Moscow's ability to sustain the conflict. The artillery shipment aims to help Ukraine blunt Russia's mounting offensive in the eastern Donbas region, where Ukrainian forces will use better air defense, attack drones, and Western intelligence to destroy Russian firepower. The goal is to force Russia to negotiate realistically, but experts predict a "war of attrition" that could wear down both sides, with Ukraine's superior artillery potentially giving it an advantage.

site_title: Indonesia's Pertamina aims to double geothermal capacity: CEO
summary: Indonesia's state energy firm PT Pertamina aims to double its geothermal capacity by 2027-2028, targeting 28 gigawatts of power, as the country seeks to reduce its fossil fuel dependency. The estimated cost of this project is around $4 billion. Pertamina plans to build 210 MW of new capacity using a Binary Organic Rankine Cycle (ORC) plant, which utilizes unused brine from existing geothermal wells. The company is open to partnering with investors and has an ongoing initial public offering plan for its geothermal development subsidiary.

site_title: Four in ten US small businesses plan to raise prices by at least 10%
summary: US small businesses plan to raise prices by at least 10% due to decades-high inflation, according to a survey by the National Federation of Independent Business (NFIB). Nearly 40% of businesses intend to increase prices by 10% or more, while two-thirds plan to raise prices in the next 3 months, with most increases ranging from 4-9%. This comes as national inflation reaches an 8.5% rate, surpassing the 1981 record.

site_title: US: Stocks end volatile day higher as Musk buys Twitter
summary: US stocks ended a volatile day higher as Twitter shares rose after Elon Musk agreed to buy the company for $44 billion. Twitter shares gained 5.7% after Musk announced a financing plan, including $21 billion from his personal fortune. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.7%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes also saw gains. Market volatility was attributed to concerns over China and the Federal Reserve's interest rate plan, but bargain hunting after the S&P 500's low also contributed to the rally.

site_title: OUE C-Reit prices S$100 million 4.2% notes due 2027
summary: OUE Commercial Real Estate Investment Trust (OUE C-Reit) has priced its S$100 million 4.2% notes due 2027 at 100% of their principal amount. The notes will bear interest at 4.2% per annum, with a stepped-down rate of 3.95% if a rating upgrade is achieved within 18 months. The net proceeds will be used for refinancing and general corporate funding. The notes will mature in 5 years and are guaranteed by DBS Trustee.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower on global slowdown fears
summary: Wall Street's main indexes fell on Monday due to concerns over China's Covid-19 outbreaks and aggressive US interest rate hikes. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.24% to 33,731.65, while the S&P 500 fell 0.38% to 4,255.34 and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.70% to 12,749.17. Investors are spooked by the potential for a global slowdown, which may impact US stocks.

site_title: F&NHB’s subsidiary proposes to acquire entire stake in Ladang Permai Damai for RM216.6m
summary: A unit of Fraser & Neave Holdings Bhd (F&NHB) has proposed to acquire Ladang Permai Damai for RM216.6 million (S$68.3 million) to expand its upstream fresh milk business. The acquisition, expected to be completed in the third quarter of 2022, will enable F&NHB to reduce its dependence on imported milk and promote the local agricultural industry. The deal is not expected to have a significant impact on F&NHB's earnings or share capital.

site_title: Russia’s Lavrov warns of ‘real’ danger of World War III
summary: Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov warned that a World War III is a "real" danger, despite continuing peace talks with Ukraine. Lavrov criticized Ukraine's approach, saying Kyiv's good will has limits, and accused Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky of "pretending" to negotiate. Lavrov expressed confidence that the conflict will end with a signed accord, but noted that its parameters will be determined by the state of fighting at the time of the accord.

site_title: UK government set to establish independent regulator
summary: The UK government plans to establish an independent regulator for English soccer to handle finances, club ownership, and corporate governance. The regulator will have statutory powers to license and sanction clubs, backed by primary legislation. The decision comes after a fan-led review, which aimed to address issues such as fan protests and club ownership controversies. The regulator will also apply enhanced owner and director tests, and have financial oversight powers. The move is expected to replace current tests administered by the Premier League and English Football League.

site_title: Twitter set to accept Musk's US$43b offer
summary: Twitter is poised to accept a $43 billion cash offer from Elon Musk, the CEO of Tesla, after his "best and final" proposal. Musk wants to take the social media company private to grow and promote free speech, while also combating trolls and proposing changes to the Twitter Blue premium subscription service. Twitter's board is expected to meet to recommend the deal to shareholders, with the company potentially announcing the agreement later. The sale would represent an admission that current CEO Parag Agrawal's leadership is not making the company more profitable.

site_title: Oil slumps 4% as Shanghai lockdowns stoke demand fears
summary: Oil prices plummeted 4% on Monday to their lowest in two weeks due to growing concerns over global energy demand amid prolonged Covid-19 lockdowns in Shanghai and potential US interest rate hikes. China, the world's largest oil importer, is heavily impacted by the lockdowns. Oil futures fell to $102.32 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude dropped to $98.54. The decline in prices has prompted US speculators to cut their long positions, and a strong US dollar is making oil more expensive for other currency holders.
