site_title: Morgan Stanley Private Equity to acquire 59.8% stake in APAC Realty for S$129.5m from Northstar
summary: Morgan Stanley Private Equity Asia (MSPEA) agreed to acquire a 59.8% stake in APAC Realty for S$129.5 million, with the offeror intending to make an unconditional mandatory general offer for all outstanding shares. The acquisition marks MSPEA's first investment in the real estate services sector in Southeast Asia. APAC Realty, a real estate service provider with over 20,000 advisors across 653 offices in Asia, will have a new majority shareholder. The offer price of S$0.57 per share represents a 30.1% discount to the last traded share price.

site_title: Zilingo's story a reminder of differing standards in the private markets
summary: Zilingo's CEO, Ankiti Bose, was suspended from her position after the startup failed to file audited annual financial statements since 2019. The incident highlights differing standards in the private markets, where startups are increasingly attracting retail investors through blockchain technologies and hybrid funds. The lack of standardized disclosure and governance raises concerns about potential fraud and hurting investors, particularly everyday working Americans. The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) commissioner Caroline Crenshaw has expressed concerns about the opacity of private markets, warning that the lack of transparency may harm investors.

images.alt_text: Ankiti Bose, co-founder and chief executive officer of Zilingo, in early 2019. The story of Zilingo's fall from grace is hardly unique. PHOTO: Ore Huiying/Bloomberg

site_title: Some Singapore firms want staff back at workplace, but experts warn against rushing into it
summary: Singapore companies are considering requiring staff to return to the workplace several times a week as part of the easing of Covid-19 measures. Some firms, like Randstad Singapore and Elxr, plan to have employees return twice and thrice a week, respectively, to promote collaboration and socialization. However, experts warn against rushing back to the office, citing the need for employees to adjust after two years of remote work, and companies to ensure a conducive working environment.

site_title: Huawei pumps US$22b into R&D to beat US sanctions
summary: Huawei has invested $22.1 billion in research and development in 2021, more than any company globally outside the US, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. The investment accounts for 22.4% of Huawei's sales, nearly double Amazon's and Google-owner Alphabet's proportions. The move is part of Huawei's efforts to develop chips, networking gear, and smartphones free from American technology, barred since 2019 due to US sanctions that wiped out nearly a third of its revenue in 2021.

site_title: Yangzijiang's largest shareholder sees spin-off helping shipbuilder, offshoot get fair valuations
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's largest shareholder, Ren Yuanlin, believes the spin-off of its investment segment will help both entities achieve fair valuations. The shipbuilder's investment segment, Yangzijiang Financial Holding (YZJFH), will debut on the Singapore Exchange mainboard by dividend in specie, with a total net asset value of S$4.3 billion. Ren plans to recommend a dividend payout ratio of at least 40% and may institute share buybacks if the counter dips below industry averages. The spin-off aims to diversify risks, increase product offerings, and attract S$1 billion in third-party capital within a year.

site_title: Activision Blizzard's quarterly adjusted sales misses estimates
summary: Activision Blizzard reported quarterly adjusted sales of $1.48 billion, missing estimates of $1.80 billion. The company's latest title "Call of Duty: Vanguard" contributed to the decline in sales. This marks a setback for the gaming publisher, which faces increasing competition and changing consumer preferences.

site_title: ByteDance hires Skadden lawyer as CFO while IPO remains in limbo
summary: ByteDance has hired Julie Gao, a Skadden lawyer, as its new chief financial officer, filling a vacant position. Gao, who has worked on IPOs for tech companies including JD.com and Baidu, will work out of ByteDance's offices in Hong Kong and Singapore. The hiring may revive speculation about the company's potential IPO, which remains uncertain despite the appointment. ByteDance has been streamlining its businesses after Beijing's crackdown on consumer internet, and regulatory uncertainties remain a major risk for the company.

site_title: Facebook-owner Meta to open first physical store in metaverse bet
summary: Meta Platforms is set to open its first physical store, the 1,550-sq ft Meta Store, at its Burlingame campus in California on May 9, offering demos and sales of its Quest 2 VR headset, Portal video calling device, and Ray-Ban's augmented reality glasses. The store marks the company's efforts to take its metaverse mainstream, with Meta also testing tools for selling digital assets and experiences within its virtual reality platform Horizon Worlds. The company's investment in the metaverse is seen as crucial for its future plans, with the next version of the Quest 2 VR headset expected to be released in the second quarter.

site_title: China lockdowns and US rate expectations hit metals
summary: China's ongoing lockdowns and economic slowdown have led to a sell-off in industrial metals, with benchmark aluminium falling to $3,061 a tonne, its lowest since February 4. The decline is also attributed to expectations of aggressive US interest rate increases and a soaring dollar. Weaker industrial production and fixed-asset investment in China have fueled concern over metals demand, and surveys of China's manufacturing sector are expected to show activity contracted in April. The US dollar's strength further exacerbates demand, with zinc prices reaching a premium of $51 a tonne.

site_title: World's oldest person dies in Japan at 119
summary: Kane Tanaka, the world's oldest person at 119, has died in Japan. Born on January 2, 1903, Tanaka was in relatively good health until recently and lived at a nursing home, enjoying board games and pastimes. She had a long life, running businesses and marrying with four children, and was recognized by Guinness World Records in 2019. Local officials and her family have expressed sadness over her passing, with the local governor praising her life and legacy.

site_title: US says diplomats to return to Kyiv, as 'Russia has already failed' in war aims
summary: US diplomats are set to return to Kyiv, Ukraine, as the US says Russia has already failed in its war aims. Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin and Secretary of State Antony Blinken visited Ukraine's capital, praising its success in repelling Russian forces. The US pledged new assistance worth $713 million to support Ukraine and other countries in the region. Despite Ukraine's success, the war is far from over, with Russia regrouping its forces and launching a massive assault in eastern Ukraine.

site_title: Oil falls below US$97 as China's lockdowns imperil demand outlook
summary: Oil prices dropped 6.2% as concerns over a spreading Covid-19 outbreak in China led to concerns about impact on demand. China's lockdowns, including in Beijing, sparked jitters about unprecedented demand destruction. The world's biggest crude importer is heading for the worst oil demand shock since the early days of the pandemic, with demand down 1.2 million barrels a day since Shanghai lockdowns began. This adds to bearish signs in the market, which is also affected by Russia's invasion of Ukraine and EU measures to restrict oil imports from Russia.

site_title: Short-term win for Malaysia's plantation sector from Indonesia's palm oil exports ban
summary: Malaysia's plantation sector may benefit from Indonesia's 4-week palm oil export ban, as the ban is expected to shift global attention to Malaysia as the next largest producer. Analysts predict the long-term impact will be minimal, with palm oil prices likely to return to normal levels after the ban is lifted. Indonesia aims to ensure domestic cooking oil supplies and may revise its policy to balance export revenue and local supply.

site_title: China's Xi congratulates Macron on re-election
summary: China's President Xi Jinping congratulated French President Emmanuel Macron on his re-election, praising their strategic and long-term relations. Macron won a second term, becoming the first French president in 20 years to do so, and vows to heal the nation's rifts. World leaders, including the US, EU, Australia, and India, have welcomed Macron's victory, as the far-right leader Marine Le Pen came closest to power in French history. Xi emphasized the importance of maintaining diplomatic relations based on mutual understanding and benefit.

site_title: S Africa's deadly floods shine spotlight on housing crisis
summary: Deadly floods in South Africa's eNkanini informal settlement have highlighted the country's severe housing crisis. The 2022 floods destroyed 87 shacks, home to nearly 500 people, and claimed 435 lives. Many residents, like Thulisile Ntobel, live in shacks due to unaffordable rent. South Africa's housing backlog has ballooned to 3.7 million homes, despite 3 million government houses being constructed since 1995. The government is beginning to clear land to erect temporary housing, but longer-term solutions are still being investigated.

site_title: A trapezoid? Office conference tables and rooms take new shape in hybrid-work era
summary: Companies are reevaluating office conference spaces as hybrid work becomes more prevalent. To accommodate both in-office and remote attendees, various table shapes are being experimented with, including triangles, trapezoids, and semi-circles. These shapes aim to optimize space for optimal camera views and collaboration. Meeting size and attendee numbers are key factors in determining the best table shape. Technology, such as interactive collaboration tools and camera systems, is also crucial for seamless hybrid meetings. Companies like Microsoft and Cisco are testing different layouts to create inclusive and effective virtual meeting spaces.

site_title: Chinese regulators urge more prudent IPO pricing after market debut flops
summary: Chinese regulators are urging underwriters to set initial public offerings (IPO) prices more reasonably after a third of over 100 new listings this year fell on their trading debut. The Shanghai Stock Exchange held a meeting with underwriting banks, asking them to set prices prudently. The regulators are also considering using newly listed shares to assess a bank's underwriting quality. This comes after a bearish investor sentiment and poor pricing skills led to significant declines in some IPOs, including a 36% drop in chipmaker Vanchip Tianjin Technology.

site_title: Nissan ending production of Datsun brand vehicles
summary: Nissan is ending production of Datsun brand vehicles, less than a decade after reviving the brand in 2013. The decision comes after disappointing sales and follows the cessation of production in Indonesia and Russia. The last facility, in Chennai, India, will continue to provide aftersales service and parts. Nissan cited a focus on core models and segments as the reason for the brand's demise. The Datsun brand, first introduced in 1931, had a significant global presence but struggled to regain its former success.

images.alt_text: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Renault-Nissan Alliance Carlos Ghosn speaks on a screen as the new Datsun on-DO car is displayed during its Russian presentation, at a news conference in Moscow April 4, 2014. REUTERS/Artur Bainozarov (RUSSIA - Tags: TRANSPORT BUSINESS)

site_title: Coca-Cola results exceed expectations on higher prices, stable demand
summary: Coca-Cola exceeded quarterly revenue and profit expectations, driven by higher prices and a rebound in demand for its sodas at theaters and restaurants. The company's net revenue rose 16% to $10.5 billion, while net income attributable to shareholders increased 24% to $2.78 billion. Despite higher costs due to the Ukraine war and Indonesia's palm oil ban, Coca-Cola left its annual profit forecast unchanged, citing a resilient demand. The company's suspension of Russian operations is expected to impact its annual profit by 4 cents per share.

site_title: Marine environment at risk as chemicals pollution grows
summary: Marine environment and revenues at risk due to growing chemical pollution, according to a report by Back to Blue. Thousands of new chemicals are introduced annually, with little known about their toxicity and harm to the environment. The report emphasizes the urgent need for coordinated action to reduce and eliminate chemical pollution risks across the entire value chain. Marine pollution is linked to climate change, and a knowledge gap exists in evaluating and monitoring new chemicals. The report recommends stricter rules, a circular economy, and greater public awareness to tackle the issue, which threatens trillions of dollars in ocean services and revenues.

site_title: US dollar hits more than 2-year high
summary: The US dollar surged to a more than 2-year high, reaching 101.33 on the dollar index, driven by Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell's comments on a possible half-point interest rate increase and consecutive rate hikes this year. This marks the largest daily percentage gain since mid-March and a 5.7% gain so far this year. The euro fell 0.4% and sterling dropped to its lowest since November 2020, while the yen lost more than 10% of its value against the dollar.

site_title: China halts auctions of wheat reserves before new harvest
summary: China has halted its weekly wheat auctions from state reserves before the new harvest, earlier than last year, amid tight supplies and record-high prices. The decision, made to cool down prices, follows Beijing's ban on feed producers buying wheat from the reserves. The country's wheat feeding fell sharply after prices of the grain rallied, losing its advantage over corn. China's new wheat crop, initially hit by poor conditions, has since improved, and the market is watching its production closely. This move bolsters prices, which have been exacerbated by the war in Ukraine.

site_title: Market uncertainties could hit CPO price, companies’ H2 earnings; gradual price decline expected
summary: Market uncertainties are expected to hit Crude Palm Oil (CPO) prices, with analysts anticipating a "gradual decline" in the commodity's prices in the second half of 2022. Despite year-to-date gains of around xx%, CPO prices may experience volatility due to factors such as the Russia-Ukraine war, tight supply, and rising costs. Analysts warn of potential headwinds including demand rationing, ESG issues, and changes to Indonesia's biodiesel mandate, which could impact prices and earnings for palm oil companies.

site_title: Europe runs risk of energy rationing if Russian gas supply is cut
summary: Europe is at risk of energy rationing if Russia cuts off its gas supply due to the Kremlin's demand for payment in roubles. The EU has rejected the payment terms, and payments are due in May, putting the region's energy market on edge. If supplies are cut, Europe would face a power shortage, with Germany most exposed, and could lead to rolling blackouts, increased pollution, and a deeper crisis. The EU aims to cut its gas dependency on Russia by two-thirds this year, but a sudden halt in gas deliveries could cost Germany's economy 220 billion euros.

site_title: Yen collapse, weakening yuan may add to South-east Asia economic uncertainty
summary: The Japanese yen and Chinese yuan are weakening against the US dollar, potentially exacerbating economic uncertainty in Southeast Asia, particularly Singapore. The weakening currencies may lead to increased export competition for the region, negatively affecting trade, investment, and financial flows. Economists predict that China may struggle to meet its 2022 growth target, with some downgrading forecasts to 4.8% growth. The US Federal Reserve's hawkish monetary policy and the Bank of Japan's yield curve control policy are driving the currency fluctuations.

site_title: Brokers' take: SIAEC, SingPost, Singtel among CGS-CIMB's top reopening picks
summary: Singapore-listed companies are expected to benefit from the easing of pandemic curbs, with retail and office landlords, transport and tourism-related counters leading the charge. CGS-CIMB has chosen SIA Engineering, Singtel, and Singapore Post as top reopening picks, while retail and hospitality trusts such as CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust and Ascott Residence Trust are also favored. The relaxation of domestic safe management measures and removal of mask-on event capacity limits are expected to boost foot traffic and ridership, benefiting companies like ComfortDelGro and SBS Transit.

site_title: Singapore hotel room rates set to rise as visitor arrivals continue to recover
summary: Singapore hotel room rates are expected to continue rising as visitor arrivals recover, albeit at a tempered pace due to restrictions in key source markets. Occupancy rates remained stable at 62.8% in March, with room rates increasing to S$198.32. Industry experts predict a continued shift to higher-rated business and leisure travel, driven by a shrinking discounted domestic market. Average room rates in luxury, upscale, and mid-tier segments are expected to improve further, with prices stabilizing the economy segment. Occupancy is expected to improve in 2022, but pre-pandemic levels may not be reached until 2024 or 2025.

site_title: Europe: Stocks sink at open in global selloff
summary: European stocks plummeted on Monday, April 25, following heavy Asian losses due to concerns over rising US interest rates. The CAC 40 index in France fell 2.0%, while the DAX in Germany dropped 1.9%. London's FTSE 100 also declined 1.7%. The re-election of French President Emmanuel Macron was overshadowed by the economic concerns.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's headline inflation jumped to 5.4% in March, a high not seen since 2012, driven by rising costs of food, services, private transport, and accommodation. The Monetary Authority of Singapore also tightened monetary policy settings. Meanwhile, the government announced plans to redevelop a 10-hectare site in Farrer Park into a new public housing estate with 1,600 HDB flats and sports facilities. Trade and Industry Minister Gan Kim Yong warned that decarbonization efforts will increase costs, while two former traders were fined and suspended for false trading related to an Indonesian tycoon.

site_title: Murdoch launches TalkTV channel with Trump trashing Harry and Meghan
summary: Rupert Murdoch's TalkTV launches in Britain, entering a crowded news market, with its star interviewer Piers Morgan interviewing former US President Donald Trump. The network will feature Trump trashing Harry and Meghan, and Morgan has previously clashed with them on-air. Trump claimed Morgan edited their interview, but Morgan said it will be shown unedited. TalkTV will air on regular TV, streaming platforms, and YouTube, targeting a similar audience to another right-wing newcomer, GB News.

site_title: Blinken says Russia is failing in its war aims, Ukraine succeeding
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken stated that Russia has failed in its war aims, while Ukraine has succeeded. This assessment came after Blinken met with Ukrainian officials in Kyiv, where the US announced a gradual return of diplomats and nominated a new ambassador. The US also pledged $713 million in new assistance to Ukraine and surrounding countries, amid concerns of further Russian aggression.

site_title: STI down 0.6% as Asia equities tumble on China lockdowns
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.6% on Monday as Asian markets declined amid China's tightening Covid-19 restrictions. The decline was attributed to North Asia heavyweights, while Southeast Asian countries like Singapore, Malaysia, and Indonesia showed resilience. Key losers included Yangzijiang Shipbuilding and HongkongLand, while Sats and Singtel were among the top gainers.

site_title: Wages rise at a record 70% of US companies: survey
summary: US wages rose at a record 70% of companies in the first quarter, according to a National Association for Business Economics survey. The majority of businesses passed on higher costs to consumers, with 45% reporting cost increases to consumers. Economists expect sales to remain strong and prices to rise in the next three months. However, nearly half of respondents anticipate recession odds in the coming year at 25% or less, with shortages improving and skilled labor shortages declining.

site_title: Strong indications of resurgent Aussie, in the very short term
summary: The Australian dollar is experiencing a resurgent trend in the short term, driven by the Russia-Ukraine war boosting alternative commodity sources and China's steel output cut, increasing demand for Australian coal. Despite a recent pullback due to the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike, the Aussie 10-year premium to US 10s has widened, suggesting further appreciation. However, in the medium to long term, the author favors a short AUDUSD position due to the Fed's hawkish rhetoric and potential interest rate differential favoring the greenback.

site_title: German-funded consortium to develop 'battery passport' for Europe
summary: A German-funded consortium, including BMW, Umicore, and BASF, will develop a "battery passport" to track the content and carbon footprint of batteries in Europe. The project, receiving 8.2 million euros in government funding, aims to meet European Union regulations requiring rechargeable electric vehicles and batteries to disclose their carbon footprint by 2024 and comply with CO2 emissions limits by 2027. The digital tool, which could become mandatory, will enable easier recycling of raw materials and reduce dependence on foreign suppliers controlling key resources.

site_title: Ascendas India Trust Q1 net property income up 4%
summary: Ascendas India Trust reported a 4% increase in net property income for its first quarter ended March 2022, with total property income rising 6% to S$49.7 million. The increase was attributed to income contributions from newly acquired properties and higher utilities income. The trust leased and renewed 0.5 million sq ft of leasable area and has a committed portfolio occupancy of 87%. The manager expects a recovery in the leasing environment and growth in the IT and logistics industries, with plans to diversify into new economy asset classes.

site_title: SMEs find niche role for crypto payments
summary: Singaporean health and wellness group A Wellness Holdings has started accepting cryptocurrencies as payment for services, with around 5% of customers opting for digital payments. The company plans to accumulate cryptocurrency assets to fund a million-dollar Web3 platform. Other SMEs, such as fashion retailer Charles & Keith and Korean fusion restaurant Joo Bar, are also embracing alternative payments, with some offering discounts and incentives for crypto transactions. However, experts caution that volatility and regulatory risks remain, and many merchants are hesitant to adopt crypto payments due to complexity and security concerns.

site_title: Deal momentum slows in en bloc market after cooling measures
summary: The en bloc residential market in Singapore has slowed down since December's cooling measures, with developers taking a cautious approach due to increased development risks and elevated costs. The Beaumont, a freehold development at Devonshire Road, saw its 10-week private treaty period expire without offers, while Thomson View Condominium's S$950 million tender closed without a successful bid. Market watchers attribute the slowdown to the gap between reserve prices and developer willingness to pay, as well as geopolitical tensions and rising interest rates. Some developers are turning to the Government Land Sales (GLS) programme, while others are restructuring their portfolios.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 11.99 points to 1,589.98. The market saw 3.133 billion lots worth RM2.636 billion, with 876 losers outnumbering 236 gainers.

site_title: China looks to sell spare LNG as virus lockdowns hit demand
summary: China, the world's largest LNG importer, is selling spare supplies amid deteriorating domestic demand due to virus lockdowns. Major buyers, including Cnooc, are offering at least five shipments for summer delivery on the spot market. The move aims to offload excess cargoes if Covid-19 restrictions worsen, potentially boosting international prices and providing relief for Asian and European utilities. China's high Covid-19 risk provinces account for around half of its gas consumption, and the country's strict Covid Zero approach is fuelling concerns about economic growth.

site_title: Sri Lanka stocks plunge, end trading 32 mins after reopening
summary: Sri Lanka's stock market plummeted, with the blue-chip index sinking 12.6% and the benchmark Colombo All-Share Index falling 6.7%, triggering a trading halt. The decline was attributed to the central bank's record interest rate hike, government debt payments, and a weakened economy. The stock exchange was halted for two weeks, with investors expressing concerns about the nation's economic crisis and foreign investor confidence.

site_title: Market uncertainties could hit CPO price, companies’ H2 earnings; gradual price decline expected
summary: Palm oil prices are expected to decline gradually in the second half of the year due to uncertainties in the industry. Despite a 53% year-to-date increase, analysts predict volatility and potential correction in prices due to factors such as the Russia-Ukraine war, tight supply, and geopolitical tensions. Companies in the sector, including South-east Asian firms, are expected to report strong earnings in the first half, but face headwinds from demand rationing, rising costs, and ESG issues. Analysts recommend "purer Malaysian plays" and Indonesian downstream companies as potential stock picks.

site_title: Huya cuts hundreds of staff, sources say, as Chinese tech retrenches
summary: Chinese video game streaming site Huya is laying off hundreds of staff amid a regulatory crackdown, according to 3 sources. The move is part of a broader trend of technology companies in China scaling back operations. Huya's Nimo TV unit is most heavily affected, with large staff cuts already implemented. The layoffs are seen as a response to China's regulatory crackdown, which has impacted the country's tech sector.

site_title: Japan's Mizuho plans to bulk up US M&A advisory, equity underwriting
summary: Mizuho Financial Group plans to expand its US operations for M&A advisory and equity underwriting, aiming to grab a larger share of the global investment banking fee pool. The move comes after bolstering debt underwriting capabilities in the US following the 2015 acquisition of Royal Bank of Scotland's North American corporate loan portfolio. Mizuho's CEO, Masahiro Kihara, is compiling a strategy to grow organically in these areas, focusing on industry sectors, analyst coverage, and collaboration with sales and trading teams.

images.alt_text: Mizuho Bank's signboard is pictured in Tokyo, Japan, January 25, 2017.  REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/File Photo

site_title: GIC buys £694m stake in London Paddington office campus
summary: Singaporean sovereign wealth fund GIC has agreed to buy a 75% stake in London's Paddington Central office campus from British Land Co for £694 million (S$1.2 billion). The deal, valued at about 1% below British Land's September book value, is expected to complete within the next 3 months. GIC will own the majority stake in the campus, which has long-leases and strong green credentials, attracting global investors despite the COVID-19 impact on office space demand.

site_title: China allows banks to ease financing for distressed developers
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, allowed major banks and asset-management firms to ease financing restrictions for distressed developers, including China Evergrande Group, to address a cash crunch. The move aims to support cash-strapped developers amid a slowdown in housing sales and increased consumer confidence concerns. The central bank relaxed requirements on loans for property acquisitions and extended maturities on debt, with 12 developers set to receive support in the first wave of the programme.

site_title: Virtual AGM vendor Azeus enters Malaysia market through KPMG partnership
summary: Azeus Systems Holdings, a Hong Kong-based virtual AGM vendor, has partnered with KPMG in Malaysia to introduce its electronic annual general meeting (AGM) product, ConveneAGM. ConveneAGM allows for virtual, physical, and hybrid meetings with features such as live Q&A and voting. Azeus has successfully conducted hundreds of electronic AGMs in Singapore, Australia, and the US, and has spearheaded large creditor and annual meetings in Malaysia. The partnership aims to bring the electronic AGM product to all Malaysian listed companies, expanding Azeus' presence in the Southeast Asian market.

site_title: Mortgagee auctions up 23.7% in Q1: Knight Frank
summary: Mortgagee auction listings in Singapore rose 23.7% in Q1 2022, with 47 properties sold, accounting for 58.8% of auctions. Residential mortgagee listings fell to 21 units, while owner sale listings more than halved to 28 listings. Despite the drop, a record 11.3% success rate was achieved, with 9 properties sold across all auction types. Knight Frank attributes the restraint in foreclosing residential properties to broad-based rental improvement and strong buyer demand.

site_title: This man married a fictional character. He’d like you to hear him out.
summary: A 38-year-old Japanese man, Akihiko Kondo, has been married to a fictional character, Hatsune Miku, for over a decade. Kondo, who has depression and was rejected by women, found love and solace in Miku, a computer-synthesized pop singer. He held an unofficial wedding ceremony in 2018 and considers Miku real because of the emotions she evokes. Kondo is part of a growing movement of "fictosexuals" who identify with fictional characters, and his story has sparked discussions about the power of love and relationships.

site_title: Going green : Don't ignore the economic costs
summary: Singapore has made significant strides in environmental sustainability, with 95% of its power generation coming from natural gas. However, a tradeoff between environmental sustainability and economic growth remains. The government has implemented policies such as eco-friendly buildings and green spaces, but concerns remain about the costs of transitioning to renewable energy and the impact on economic competitiveness. To balance these competing interests, the government should prioritize systematic and transparent quantification of costs and benefits, conduct social experiments to assess the efficacy of "nudges" towards reducing energy consumption, and develop a comprehensive national database of firm environmental, social, and governance (ESG) information.

site_title: China's yuan ends at 1-year low, with more downside seen
summary: China's yuan reached a one-year low against the US dollar, closing at 6.5544 per dollar, amid investor concerns over a worsening economic growth outlook and strict lockdown measures. The currency has posted its worst week since 2015, with some analysts warning of further falls. The People's Bank of China's apparent lack of intervention may signal a shift towards growth-oriented currency management, which could lead to continued selling pressure on the yuan. Economists will closely watch the politburo meeting later this week for clues on potential measures to prop up the economy.

site_title: EU, India to set up council to broaden ties amid Ukraine war
summary: The European Union and India agreed to establish a trade and technology council to enhance cooperation between the two nations amid the Ukraine war. EU President Ursula von der Leyen's visit to New Delhi, part of Western efforts to reduce India's ties with Russia, resulted in the joint statement. The council aims to promote joint in-depth strategic engagement, coordinate technical work, and report to the political level to ensure implementation and follow-up in areas important for the economies of both regions.

site_title: Innovative solutions can preserve water, our most precious resource
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Water scarcity affects 2 billion people worldwide, with 30% of Asia's population facing the issue. Companies are making a difference by minimizing water use and reusing water. Semiconductor manufacturer Taiwan aims to re-use 86.4% of water, while a solar power company in India uses robots to clean panels, reducing water consumption by 92%. Cement manufacturers are also adopting water-saving measures, such as water reuse and recycling. Investors can support these companies, which are not only sustainable but also providing innovative solutions to protect the world's most precious resource, clean water.

site_title: Decades of low rates, low inflation coming to an end: Gan Kim Yong
summary: Trade and Industry Minister Gan Kim Yong warns that the low interest rate and low inflation environment that has supported economic growth in recent decades may be coming to an end. As a result, governments will likely need to manage starker trade-offs between growth and inflation. Despite this, Gan sees opportunities for growth, particularly with the shift in global economic weight to Asia, and Singapore's investments in digital technology and sustainability. The country is also focusing on its "Singapore Economy 2030 vision," which aims to achieve deep industry and business transformation and build a strong bench of Singapore enterprises.

site_title: Million sq ft Farrer Park site to yield 1,600 HDB flats, sports and recreational facilities; analysts expect strong demand
summary: A 1,600 HDB flat project will be developed on a 10-hectare site in Farrer Park, Singapore, with 20% reserved for sports and recreational facilities. Analysts expect strong demand, particularly if the flats are launched under the Prime Location Public Housing (PLH) model, which could see prices ranging from S$550,000 to S$700,000 for 4-room units. The project's proximity to amenities, sports facilities, and the city fringe is expected to appeal to young couples and sports enthusiasts.

site_title: Accounting for longevity risk in retirement planning
summary: Singapore's aging population is facing unique financial challenges due to increasing longevity, which can lead to depleted retirement savings. Pre-retirees underestimate their life expectancy, planning for too short a period in retirement. To address this, experts recommend re-thinking the retirement age, allowing for phased retirements, and providing opportunities for older workers to continue working and earning an income. Employers can also adapt by offering re-employment programs and flexible work arrangements. Delaying retirement and utilizing CPF savings can help maintain financial security, and pre-retirees should create a strategy to review their personal situation and seek professional help to ensure a long, comfortable retirement.

site_title: Twitter, under shareholder pressure, begins deal talks with Musk: sources
summary: Twitter has initiated deal talks with Elon Musk, the CEO of Tesla, amid shareholder pressure. The talks do not guarantee a sale, but rather explore whether a sale is possible on attractive terms. Musk's $54.20 per-share bid faces hurdles, including a detailed financing plan and potential regulatory risks. Twitter is seeking more information on Musk's ability to complete the deal and may consider a break-up fee if a sale appears risky. The company's board aims to negotiate better terms while weighing the potential risks and benefits of a sale.

site_title: Hong Kong: Hong Kong, China stocks dive as lockdown fears bite
summary: Hong Kong and mainland China stocks plummeted on April 25, 2022, due to growing fears over the Chinese economy and the fast-spreading Covid-19 outbreak forcing lockdowns in major cities. The Hang Seng Index dropped 3.73%, the Shanghai Composite Index fell 5.13%, and the Shenzhen Composite Index declined 6.48%. Traders also worried about an expected sharp hike in US interest rates.

site_title: Two former traders fined, suspended for false trading related to Indonesian tycoon Kris Wiluan
summary: Two former trading representatives, Ngin Kim Choo and Yeo Jin Lui, have been fined and suspended by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) for false trading related to Indonesian tycoon Kris Wiluan. They executed orders to purchase shares of collapsed oil services firm KS Energy to create a false appearance for the counter's share price. Ngin paid a civil penalty of S$100,000 and was issued a 5-year prohibition order, while Yeo paid S$50,000 and was issued a 4-year prohibition order.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Maybank upgrades CP Foods to ‘buy’ ahead of Vietnam IPO
summary: Maybank Securities has upgraded its recommendation on Charoen Pokphand Foods (CP Foods) to "buy" ahead of the company's indirect subsidiary, CP Vietnam's, initial public offering (IPO) on the Ho Chi Minh Stock Exchange. Analyst Suttatip Peerasub expects the IPO to unlock value and give CP Foods more flexibility, driven by CP Vietnam's 9-year sales CAGR of 11%. Maybank's price target remains unchanged at 27.90 baht, with the stock trading flat at 23.90 baht.

site_title: AIA Singapore, EPL club Tottenham Hotspur team up to raise funds for disadvantaged children
summary: Tottenham Hotspur, an English Premier League club, has partnered with AIA Singapore to raise funds for disadvantaged children through a charity shirt initiative. On May 1, the team's players will wear jerseys with the "AIA Better Lives Fund" logo, with proceeds going towards supporting children from the Children's Wishing Well and VIVA Foundation for Children with Cancer. The funds will also benefit the Tottenham Hotspur Foundation. The partnership aims to "build an inclusive Singapore" for future generations.

site_title: Hyundai shares climb after quarterly earnings top forecasts
summary: Hyundai Motor Co. reported a 16% increase in quarterly operating income, beating analyst expectations, as a weaker Korean won offset supply-chain snags. Despite a 9.7% decline in sales, revenue rose 11% due to robust sales of SUVs and luxury models. The company expects a gradual recovery from the pandemic and chip shortage, but faces supply uncertainties due to lockdowns in Chinese cities and fluctuating raw material costs. Hyundai plans to invest $15 billion in battery-powered EVs and aims to introduce more EV models globally.

site_title: Abu Dhabi crude to head to Europe, replace Russian oil: sources
summary: A French shipping unit, CSSSA, has chartered a tanker to load 1 million barrels of Abu Dhabi crude in early May for Europe, marking the first such shipment in 2 years. The shipment will replace Russian oil imports to the EU, which have been reduced following Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The move is part of a global trade flow adjustment, with more Abu Dhabi crude grades expected to head to Europe in the coming months to meet the shortfall.

site_title: Japan readies US$48b package to help with fuel and materials cost spikes
summary: Japan's government is set to announce a $48 billion package to help mitigate the economic impact of rising fuel and raw material costs, primarily caused by the war in Ukraine. The package, which includes $1.5 trillion in fuel cost relief and $1.3 trillion in cash payouts to low-income households, aims to stabilize energy, raw materials, and food supplies. The spending, however, will add to Japan's already heavy public debt, which is over twice the size of the country's economy.

site_title: Higher pay may create inflation spiral: Bank of Korea study
summary: A Bank of Korea study suggests rising wages in South Korea could lead to a cycle of higher inflation, as inflationary pressures already impact labor costs with a lag of 4 quarters. The study, while not an official position, supports further interest rate hikes to combat inflation. Following a decade-high inflation rate in April, the central bank has already raised rates twice this year to target 2% inflation. The study's findings may influence the bank's decision at its May 26 policy meeting.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei sees worst day in 6 weeks, tracks Wall Street losses
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average plummeted 1.9% to 26,590.78, its largest decline in six weeks, as it tracked Wall Street's losses after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell hinted at near-term interest-rate hikes. The broader Topix also fell 1.5%. Heavyweights such as Fast Retailing, SoftBank Group, and Daikin Industries led the decline, with oil explorers and airlines also suffering losses. Market analysts await comments from Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda on the latest currency move.

site_title: Asia bonds lose US$155b as China woes add to rates pressure
summary: Asia's dollar-denominated bonds have lost $155 billion over the past 9 months due to China's economic woes and rising interest rates. A benchmark of government and corporate notes has plummeted 12.1% from its peak in July, the largest-ever drawdown since 2009. China's Covid-19 outbreak and concerns about a slowdown in economic momentum have contributed to the decline, with Asian high-yield dollar bonds dropping 2 cents on the dollar. Investors are seeking attractive entry points, but some analysts see the short-end of investment-grade credit as looking attractive.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won drop on Fed rate-hike bets, China slowdown fears
summary: South Korean stocks plummeted 1.76% on Monday, their largest drop in 7 weeks, due to concerns over the US Federal Reserve's aggressive monetary policy tightening and a slowdown in China's economy. The benchmark Kospi index fell 47.58 points to 2,657.13, while the Korean won dropped to its lowest level in over 2 years, reaching 1,249.9 per dollar. Foreigners sold 733.4 billion won worth of shares, and the central bank's GDP data for the first quarter is expected to show significant slowdown.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi closed down 23.5 points, or 0.86 per cent, to 2,704.71.

site_title: World order may fragment following Ukraine conflict
summary: The Russia-Ukraine war is likely to escalate, potentially ending with the use of nuclear weapons, which would have devastating consequences for Europe. The UN's credibility is at stake, and the international community's response to the crisis is inadequate. The war may lead to a fragmentation of the global order, with the emergence of a new cold war between the US-led NATO alliance and a China-led group of Russia, India, Brazil, and South Africa. This could result in a new global currency system, with the dollar, renminbi, gold, and cryptocurrencies playing intermediary roles, and a potential split in the World Trade Organization.

site_title: Malaysia's palm oil board urges countries to reconsider food versus fuel priorities
summary: Malaysia's palm oil board urges countries to reconsider using edible oil as biofuel, warning of a supply crisis following Indonesia's ban on palm oil exports. The ban, set to start on April 28, could lead to global food inflation and constrain supplies. The board advises countries to pause or slow down biofuel use to ensure adequate food supply. This move comes as global edible oil supplies are already low due to adverse weather and Russia's invasion of Ukraine, prompting consumers to pay top dollar for supplies.

site_title: Brussels prepares to hit Russia with 'smart sanctions' on oil imports
summary: The European Union is preparing "smart sanctions" against Russian oil imports, including a potential oil embargo, in response to Russia's actions in Ukraine. The EU spends around $450 million per day on Russian crude oil and refined products, $400 million on gas, and $25 million on coal. The sanctions package, which is expected to be the sixth, aims to maximize pressure on Russia while minimizing collateral damage. Some EU states, such as Poland and Lithuania, support a ban on Russian oil and gas, while others, like Germany and Hungary, oppose an immediate oil embargo.

site_title: Misguided to resurrect the South vs North divide over Ukraine
summary: The resurgence of the North-South divide concept is being misused to explain differing responses to Russia's invasion of Ukraine, despite the fact that the original economic divide between the two has become obsolete due to globalization and rising nations in the South. The differing responses are actually driven by national interests, with countries like China, India, and the Arab Gulf states resisting Western economic sanctions against Russia to protect their economies and international standing. The true threat is not the South vs North divide, but Russia's aggression posing a threat to the international order and sovereignty of nations worldwide.

site_title: Beijing Covid spike prompts mass testing, panic buying
summary: Panic buying and long queues formed in Beijing's Chaoyang district on April 25 as the Chinese authorities ordered mass testing in response to a spike in Covid-19 cases, sparking fears of a hard lockdown. The district, home to 3.5 million people, has seen residents stockpiling essentials and many businesses, including fitness studios and gyms, canceling classes or closing. China's zero-Covid policy, which includes strict lockdowns and travel restrictions, has taken a toll on businesses and public morale, with officials struggling to contain the outbreak.

site_title: Credit Suisse special audit backed by Norway’s wealth fund
summary: Credit Suisse will undergo a special audit, backed by Norway's sovereign wealth fund, following the collapse of its supply chain finance funds with Greensill Capital. The audit is in response to a proposal by the Ethos Foundation and 7 Swiss pension funds, which was initially rejected by Credit Suisse. The Norwegian fund's support adds momentum to the proposal, set to be voted on at the Credit Suisse shareholder meeting on April 29. The fund also voted against absolving the bank's leadership of their legal liability for the fiscal year 2020.
