site_title: China to boost coffee imports as young professionals drink more
summary: China is increasing its coffee imports by 5% this year as demand from young professionals in Shanghai and Beijing grows. The nation's coffee consumption has risen 45% over the past four years, driven by promotional efforts from companies like Luckin Coffee, Nestle, and Tim Hortons. However, local farmers are not satisfied with the profits they get from growing coffee, leading to a potential shift towards alternative crops. In response, Yunnan province, a major coffee-producing region, may consider programs to boost farmer incomes and make coffee production more appealing.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Corp, ST Engineering, Digital Core Reit, Wee Hur, Cromwell E-Reit, Jardine C&C
summary: Keppel Corp posted higher net profit for the first quarter, with group revenue growing 9% year-over-year. ST Engineering acquired TransCore, a US-based transportation solutions provider, which was met with concerns but saw a 0.7% increase in shares. Digital Core Reit beat its IPO forecast with $12.1 million in distributable income, while Wee Hur proposed a $113.3 million stake divestment. Cromwell E-Reit acquired industrial properties in Italy and Germany, and Jardine C&C saw a 5.4% increase in shares following an off-market share purchase by its majority shareholder.

site_title: Some banks in Singapore suspend fixed-rate home loans as cost of funds rises
summary: Some banks in Singapore have suspended fixed-rate home loan packages due to rising interest rates and increased volatility. Foreign banks, such as Maybank and Standard Chartered, have ceased offering fixed-rate home loans, while local banks like OCBC, DBS, and UOB continue to offer fixed-rate packages. Mortgage brokers attribute the suspensions to rising hedging costs and the desire for banks to offer floating-rate packages instead. As a result, consumers may face higher interest rates and less stability in their mortgage repayments.

site_title: Federal Reserve’s Powell, half-point hike in view, completes hawkish pivot
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell hinted at a series of half-point interest rate hikes in May, setting the stage for a hawkish pivot to combat rising inflation. With inflation running three times the Fed's 2% target, Powell said the Fed will consider a 50 basis point increase, pinning down an expected rate path steeper than previously projected. This move could lead to a recession, with economists warning that a one-in-three chance of a recession over the next 12 months.

site_title: US: Stocks fall following hawkish Federal Reserve comment
summary: US stocks tumbled on Thursday following hawkish comments from Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell, who signaled a half-point interest rate increase for next month's policy meeting to combat record US inflation. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1.1%, while the S&P 500 dropped 1.5% and the Nasdaq Composite Index fell 2.1%. Despite strong corporate earnings, including a record quarterly profit from Tesla, the market reversed course due to rising 10-year US Treasury yields above 2.9%.

site_title: Euro boosted by ECB rate hike bets, Macron debate
summary: The euro surged to a 1-week high, reaching $1.0936, amid expectations of a European Central Bank (ECB) interest rate hike in July, which would lift benchmark rates above zero for the first time since 2013. French President Emmanuel Macron's strong performance in a TV debate against far-right candidate Marine Le Pen also supported the euro's rise. Meanwhile, sterling fell to a 10-day low against the strengthening euro due to differing monetary policy paths from the Bank of England and other major central banks.

site_title: Goldman Sachs raises US$3.5b for global real estate bets
summary: Goldman Sachs' asset-management arm has raised US$3.5 billion for its global real estate fund, West Street Real Estate Investment Partners. The fund aims to make core-plus or value-add bets in resilient sectors with favorable growth trends. Executives oversee the fund, targeting gross annualized returns of 12-15% and an asset-level loan-to-value ratio of 65%. Goldman has invested over US$50 billion in real estate assets since 2012, with the global real estate market gathering US$29.5 billion in the first quarter, down from a record US$71.9 billion in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Gucci quarterly sales disappoint as lockdowns in China weigh
summary: Gucci's quarterly sales missed estimates, growing 13% on a comparable basis, weighed down by lockdowns in China. Total revenue at Kering, Gucci's parent company, rose 21% in the quarter, beating expectations. Analysts attribute the performance to strong demand in Europe and North America, but weaker sales in the Asia-Pacific region due to China's lockdowns. Kering faces "substantial headwinds" from the war in Ukraine and China's lockdowns, which may impact the luxury market.

images.alt_text: A pedestrian wearing a protective mask walks past a Guccio Gucci SpA store on Canton Road in the Tsim Sha Tsui district of Hong Kong, China, on Sunday, May 10, 2020. Hong Kong’s retailers will need to get creative to survive the deepening recession that’s enveloped the city as tourists from the mainland who fueled past rebounds are unlikely to come to the rescue this time. Photographer: Paul Yeung/Bloomberg

site_title: UK consumer morale plunges near all-time low in April: GfK
summary: British consumer sentiment plummeted to its second-lowest reading since records began in April, falling to -38 from -31 in March, as the worsening cost-of-living crisis hurt households' confidence. This is near an all-time low of -38 hit in July 2008, amid the global financial crisis. Consumer price inflation surged to a 30-year high of 7% in March, leading to a sharp decrease in consumers' intentions to make major purchases, and a separate survey showed around a third of consumers had cut back on spending this year.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on January 10, 2022 A customer shops for food items inside a Tesco supermarket store in east London . - Britain's biggest retailer Tesco on April 13, 2022,  warned that soaring inflation would bite into future profit, causing its share price to slide along with those of rival supermarkets. Tesco said underlying profit was expected to drop in its current financial year after it jumped by more than one third in 2021/22. (Photo by Daniel LEAL / AFP)

site_title: Russia slaps travel ban on Kamala Harris, Mark Zuckerberg
summary: Russia imposed travel bans on 29 US Americans and 61 Canadians, including Vice-President Kamala Harris, Facebook chief Mark Zuckerberg, and prominent officials, in retaliation for US sanctions over Ukraine. The list includes defence officials, business leaders, and journalists. The foreign ministry cited "Russophobic" policies as the reason for the restrictions, which will remain in effect indefinitely. The US has led international sanctions against Russia, including President Vladimir Putin and oligarchs. The travel bans were seen as an "honour" by some US officials, with Pentagon spokesman John Kirby calling it a "good group to belong to".

images.alt_text: epa09901667 Vice President Kamala Harris arrives in San Francisco, California, USA, 21 April 2022. Harris visited the EMBRACE program of prenatal and postnatal care for black women.  EPA-EFE/TERRY SCHMITT / POOL

site_title: Keppel Corp reports higher Q1 profit as 3 out of 4 key segments fare better
summary: Keppel Corp reported a higher Q1 profit, with group revenue growing 9% to S$2.07 billion, driven by the energy & environment segment. The property development arm, Keppel Land, saw a net profit dip due to lower contributions from China projects. CEO Loh Chin Hua remains optimistic about opportunities in China, citing continued economic growth and urbanization trends. The company also announced asset monetization efforts, including the sale of legacy rigs and associated receivables, as part of its asset-light strategy.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Digital Core Reit reported US$12.1 million in first-quarter distributable income, beating its IPO forecast of US$11.9 million by 1.9%. Gross revenue was 0.1% lower than forecast at US$26.5 million, while net property income increased by 6.9% to US$17.9 million. The Reit's portfolio value reached US$1.46 billion as of March 31. Sembcorp Industries announced the retirement of non-executive director Nicky Tan Ng Kuang, effective at its annual general meeting.

site_title: End of an era as Netflix faces stagnation challenges
summary: Netflix faces stagnation challenges after losing 200,000 subscribers for the first time in over a decade, with shares plummeting 30% on Wednesday. The company anticipates a larger drop in subscribers in the second quarter, with analysts predicting very low growth in 2022 and 2023. To combat this, Netflix plans to introduce cheaper subscriptions with advertising and increase prices. The company is also focusing on monetizing its 100 million free households and investing in local content creation and gaming. Billionaire investor William Ackman liquidated a $1.1 billion bet on Netflix due to concerns over the company's short-term predictability.

site_title: Eurozone consumer confidence rises to -16.9 in April
summary: Eurozone consumer confidence rose to -16.9 in April, a 1.8-point increase from March, beating economists' expectations of a decline to -20.0. In the EU, consumer sentiment rose to -17.6. These improvements suggest a stabilization in consumer morale, but the overall economic outlook remains uncertain.

site_title: 2022 Nissan Qashqai review: Is Qash still King?
summary: The 2022 Nissan Qashqai has been reviewed, with the new third-generation model boasting striking looks, latest tech, and a powerful engine shared with Mercedes. The Qashqai now features a larger touchscreen, wireless Apple CarPlay, and a head-up display system. The mild hybrid setup reduces fuel consumption and provides a boost to acceleration. While the car is not as fun to drive as some others, it impresses with its solid feel, rigidity, and quality interior. The Qashqai is available in two trim levels, with the Prestige version tested starting at S$162,800.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise for third straight day; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks rose for the third consecutive day, with the Straits Times Index (STI) increasing 0.4% to 3,348.46. Singtel and SATS were top gainers, while Dairy Farm International was the top decliner, falling 1.8%. The market saw a positive performance, with most Asian markets also rising, despite concerns over China's markets and US delisting fears in Hong Kong.

site_title: China calls YouTube 'tool' for blocking next Hong Kong leader
summary: China accused US companies, including YouTube and Meta Platforms, of using their platforms as "political tools" to interfere in Hong Kong's chief executive election. The move came after YouTube suspended the campaign channel of John Lee, a former policeman and front-runner for the position. China's Foreign Ministry spokesperson, Wang Wenbin, described the actions as a "vicious attempt to intervene in Hong Kong affairs" and warned Western forces to stop interfering in China's internal affairs. The incident has raised concerns about the erosion of freedoms in Hong Kong.

site_title: Red Dot Design Museum Singapore reopens
summary: The Red Dot Design Museum Singapore has reopened after a 6-month closure due to low footfall, primarily caused by the pandemic. The museum now features two new showcases: the 2021/2022 Red Dot Award: Design Concept winners and the Freitag Archive Exhibition. The Red Dot Award showcases innovative design concepts from around the world, while the Freitag exhibition takes visitors on a journey of the Swiss brand's history and design. The museum has seen a steady stream of visitors since its reopening, with the president of Red Dot Award in Asia stating that it's an early positive sign for Singapore's tourism recovery.

site_title: Oil edges higher on concerns over Russia, Libya supply disruption
summary: Oil prices rose on Thursday, driven by concerns over supply disruptions, including a potential EU ban on Russian oil imports and ongoing blockades in Libya, which has lost over 550,000 barrels of oil output. Brent crude futures closed at $108.33 a barrel, up 1.6%, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures rose 1.6% to $103.79. The market is also reacting to potential interest rate hikes and a tight supply-demand balance.

site_title: Tesla gains on Musk's optimism about overcoming supply issues
summary: Tesla shares rose 7.8% to $1,053 after the company reported better-than-expected earnings and predicted production will grow at a fast clip despite supply chain challenges. The automaker reported a record quarterly profit and warned of ongoing shortages of key materials. CEO Elon Musk predicted production will exceed 1.5 million vehicles this year, with a 60% growth rate, and production will be "substantially higher" in the third and fourth quarters.

images.alt_text: Netflix is becoming more interactive to keep its viewers from turning to video games.

site_title: Singapore to have world's largest sustainable aviation fuel plant
summary: Singapore will have the world's largest sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) production capacity when Finnish producer Neste's 1.5-billion-euro refinery in Tuas is completed in 2023, with an annual production capacity of 1 million metric tonnes. Currently, Neste produces 100,000 metric tonnes of SAF per annum in Finland. SAF is a renewable fuel produced from waste materials, meeting quality and performance requirements of conventional fossil fuels but costing 3-5 times more. This move is expected to help the aviation industry achieve emissions reduction goals.

site_title: In Venice, minimalist Singapore show speaks volumes
summary: The Singapore Pavilion at the Venice Biennale 2022 took a minimalist approach, focusing on the power of books and knowledge. The pavilion features a life-size paper maze, a film about the history of books, and a 400-page book titled "Pulp III: An Intimate Inventory Of The Banished Book." The book explores the importance of books as a symbol of knowledge, power, and activism, with a section on vanishing languages. The pavilion aims to promote the preservation of books and knowledge, and its success is seen as a milestone for Singapore's participation in the biennale, marking the first time an all-female artist and curator team represents the country.

site_title: Putin claims victory in Mariupol, even as 2,000 Ukrainian defenders remain holed up inside plant
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin declared victory in the Mariupol battle, claiming the port is "liberated" despite 2,000 Ukrainian defenders remaining inside a steel works. Putin called off a final storming, ordering instead a blockade of plant facilities. The declaration came after nearly 2 months of siege.

site_title: Six ways to win digital growth in South-east Asia
summary: Southeast Asia's digital economy is booming, with 350 million digital consumers expected to drive growth at a 1.6x rate. To succeed, brands must adopt six strategies: rewriting their digital agenda, rewiring their supply chain/business model, reimagining consumer engagement, refreshing product offerings, re-envisioning sustainability, and realigning to consumers' new hybrid lifestyle. Brands must prioritize digital maturity, supply chain resilience, and consumer intimacy to stay ahead. By implementing these strategies, brands can maximize their success in the region.

site_title: Why we admire Zelensky
summary: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky is admired for his courage and commitment to his country despite being outnumbered. He sets an example by showing honor and love for his nation, and his personal presence inspires others. Unlike many politicians, Zelensky is willing to tell the truth, even if it's difficult, and his words have led to actions that vindicate their meaning. This is rare in Western politics, where leaders often prioritize popularity over honesty. Zelensky's leadership is a refreshing change, reminding people of the importance of virtues like courage and integrity.

images.alt_text: China's envoy to the European Union warned that excluding Chinese tech group Huawei could hamper new 5G mobile networks, the Financial Times reported on Sunday.

site_title: Back to the office
summary: Companies are reinvigorating office spaces as the pandemic restrictions are lifted, with some arguing that a hybrid work model won't necessarily lead to a decrease in office space demand. Experts suggest that regulation and education are crucial for the crypto industry to thrive. Despite flexible working becoming the norm, offices still have a lot to offer, including face-to-face interactions and company culture. The shift towards hybrid work models may instead lead to a resurgence in office usage.

site_title: Biden announces new US$800m military package for Ukraine
summary: US President Joe Biden announced a new military aid package worth $800 million for Ukraine, aimed at supporting the country's fight against Russian forces in the Donbas region. The package includes 72 155mm howitzers, 72 armoured vehicles, and over 120 tactical drones. The aid is intended to help Ukraine meet the emerging Russian offensive and will be delivered by the weekend. This brings the total US military aid to Ukraine since 2021 to $4 billion. Biden also announced a ban on Russia-affiliated ships from US ports and additional funding for Ukraine's government.

images.alt_text: FILE — Ukrainian soldiers prepare to tow an intact but immobilized Russian armored fighting vehicle in Nova Basan, Ukraine, on April 4, 2022. Reflecting a renewed sense of urgency, President Joe Biden announced on Thursday, April 21, that the United States would send the Ukrainians $800 million more in military aid. (Ivor Prickett/The New York Times)

site_title: ST Engineering says TransCore acquisition complies with US regulations
summary: ST Engineering says its acquisition of TransCore complies with US regulations, including clearance from the Committee on Foreign Investment in the US. The company assured that customer data will remain in the US and be stored securely. Officials from the Ohio Turnpike and Infrastructure Commission expressed concern about TransCore's ownership, but ST Engineering has not received any further queries. The acquisition was completed last month after regulatory approvals.

site_title: Singapore businesses can tap on Nordic region with expanded GIA network
summary: Singapore businesses can now tap into the Nordic region through Enterprise Singapore's expanded Global Innovation Alliance (GIA) network, which includes Stockholm, Sweden. The 8-week-long GIA programme, launched in partnership with Epicenter, aims to support Singapore companies in areas like sustainability and tech innovation. The programme includes online coaching sessions, physical business matching sessions, and co-innovation initiatives through the Eureka Network. This expansion aims to strengthen innovation collaboration and expand overseas as borders reopen, with Enterprise Singapore chairman Peter Ong expecting Sweden to provide tech and innovation opportunities for Singapore companies.

site_title: As Malaysia reopens to the world, airlines see healthy pick-up in flight bookings
summary: Malaysia's aviation industry is experiencing a surge in flight bookings since the government reopened the country's borders to the world on April 1. AirAsia expects to return to 100% of pre-Covid capacity on key routes by the end of 2022, while Malaysian Airlines is seeing a load factor of over 80% on most of its upcoming flights. The airline's parent company aims to operate at 70% of its 2019 capacity by the end of 2022, with a gradual increase in flight frequency. The industry's growth is expected to be driven by demand for domestic and Asean routes, with air passenger traffic projected to increase by 525% in 2022.

site_title: IMF chief warns of risks from a prolonged China slowdown
summary: IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva warned of global spillovers if China's slowdown persists, but noted Beijing has room to adjust policy to support the economy. China's growth forecast was cut to 4.4% by the IMF, below the country's target of 5.5%. China's President Xi Jinping stated the economy is resilient, while foreign brokerages have downgraded their forecasts, with Barclays at 4.3%, BofA at 4.2%, and Nomura at 3.9%.

site_title: New 7 Series reveals BMW's changing mindset
summary: BMW unveiled its new 7 Series, the seventh generation of its flagship model, with a focus on luxury and technology. The new car features an all-electric version, the i7, which boasts 660 horsepower and a range of up to 600 km on a full charge. The 7 Series also introduces a new design language, with a large, upright grille and a 31.3-inch panoramic display, dubbed the "Theatre Screen". The car's interior features advanced materials, including crystal and cashmere upholstery. BMW forecasts that half its sales will come from electric vehicles by 2030, marking a shift in the company's approach to luxury cars.

images.alt_text: Thailand's booming property market is at risk of cooling this year as rampant construction threatens an oversupply of apartments amid increasing global economic headwinds.

The French government, which owns 15 per cent of Renault and 22 per cent of voting rights, has warned that it doesn't intend to let the former CEO walk away with the kind of lavish payouts that he is accustomed to.

site_title: BOE may need to raise interest rates 'a little bit', says policymaker
summary: Bank of England monetary policymaker Catherine Mann suggests interest rates may need to rise "a little bit" further to control inflation, potentially hinting at a stagflationary environment. The economy is already experiencing a slowdown, with high energy prices and slowing retail sales. Mann warns against premature comparisons to past economic downturns, emphasizing the need to monitor the situation in May.

site_title: A Napa favourite goes back to the future
summary: Stony Hill Vineyard, a pioneering California chardonnay producer, has undergone significant changes under new ownership. The winery, sold to Gaylon Lawrence Jr in 2020, has converted to organic viticulture and is replanting its vineyard with a new focus on red wines, including 14 acres of cabernet sauvignon. Winemaker Jaimee Motley, known for her fresh and savory wines, has brought a youthful energy to the historic estate. The cellar is being rebuilt, and the winery is adopting biodynamic and regenerative viticulture practices. While the style of the wines may change, Stony Hill will continue to produce its signature chardonnay.

site_title: HK reopens venues, extends dining hours as Covid-19 cases fall
summary: Hong Kong has reopened gyms, beauty parlours, theme parks, and cinemas after more than four months of Covid-19 restrictions, as authorities relax measures amid falling daily cases. Dining hours have been extended to 10pm, and group gatherings have been expanded to four people. Many residents are relieved, while businesses have already closed and tens of thousands have fled the city. The easing comes as the city's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate rose to 5% in the January-March quarter, its highest since 2021.

site_title: Warner Bros shutting down CNN+ streaming service: Variety
summary: Warner Bros Discovery is shutting down its CNN+ streaming news service, citing 2 people familiar with the matter. The media firm will provide details to employees on Thursday. CNN+ was launched last month to capitalize on the growth of digital subscriptions, offering live, on-demand, and interactive programming with original content. Warner Bros Discovery's shares fell 5.6% on the news. The decision comes as the company faces challenges in the streaming market.

site_title: Hooray for Hollywood
summary: Gucci's "Love Parade" collection, inspired by the Golden Age of Hollywood, was unveiled last November in Los Angeles with a spectacular show featuring hundreds of guests and movie stars on the catwalk. The collection, designed by Alessandro Michele, features 115 looks with a mix of retro and modern elements, including fur stoles, beaded headdresses, and opera-length gloves. The show was a tribute to Michele's mother's production company and featured a cast of diverse models, including Jared Leto, Jodie Turner-Smith, and Phoebe Bridgers. The collection also included a range of iconic Gucci handbags updated in silver leather.

site_title: UK parliament triggers contempt probe into PM Johnson
summary: The UK parliament has triggered an investigation into allegations that Prime Minister Boris Johnson misled Parliament regarding his staff's Covid-19 lockdown rule-breaking. Lawmakers approved a motion calling for a parliamentary committee to determine if Johnson's denials constitute contempt of the House of Commons, following his subsequent police fine for breaching regulations. The motion passed without opposition after the government abandoned its earlier attempt to delay the investigation.

site_title: Zero to neutral in 9 months marks a defining pivot for Fed, Powell
summary: The US Federal Reserve is poised for a swift policy shift, with officials aiming to reach a neutral interest rate by the end of the year to tame high inflation. Since March, policymakers have become increasingly hawkish, with Fed Chair Jerome Powell advocating for a "do-whatever-it-takes" approach to contain inflation. This shift could be the Fed's swiftest monetary policy change since the 1960s, with a potential half-point rate hike at upcoming meetings. The goal is to bring inflation back to the 2% target without highly restrictive rates, but economists warn that the current inflationary pressures may be more entrenched than expected.

site_title: In Venice, minimalist Singapore show speaks volumes
summary: The Singapore Pavilion at the Venice Biennale features a minimalist exhibit showcasing the country's cultural heritage, including a life-size paper maze and a collection of books. The exhibit explores the preservation of languages, such as kristang, and the importance of reading in a public space. Curator Thomas Bauer and artist Rao hope the pavilion serves as a "place of solace" amidst the ongoing war in Europe, reaffirming humanity's shared love of books and cultures.

site_title: Blackstone's first-quarter earnings surge 63%
summary: Blackstone's first-quarter earnings surged 63% due to strong performances from its real estate and credit businesses, offsetting a decline in its hedge funds unit. Distributable earnings rose to $1.9 billion, exceeding analyst estimates. The company generated $23.2 billion from asset divestments and spent $22.8 billion on new acquisitions, including the $6.4 billion takeover of Crown Resorts. Its hedge fund portfolio had a 1% net return, compared to a 0.3% decline in the benchmark index. Total assets under management reached a record $915 billion.

site_title: Nestle starts year with strongest price increases in decade
summary: Nestle has implemented its largest price increase in over a decade, with a 5.2% rise in the first quarter. This affects various products, including Nespresso capsules, Purina dog chow, and DiGiorno frozen pizzas. Other companies, such as Procter & Gamble and Danone, have also started the year with similar price increases of around 5%. This move aims to offset surging food inflation and higher expenses for consumers.

site_title: ECB rate at zero or more by year-end a 'no brainer'
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) may lift policy rates above zero by year-end to control surging inflation, according to ECB Governing Council member Pierre Wunsch. A severe economic shock or "restrictive" policy would be needed to address inflation concerns, but Wunsch considers a rate hike to zero or slightly positive territory a "no brainer" unless bad news from the war in Ukraine emerges.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines parent MAG turns the corner in FY21 with positive Ebitda of RM433m
summary: Malaysia Airlines parent Malaysia Aviation Group (MAG) posted a positive Ebitda of RM433 million in FY21, a turnaround from the RM1.76 billion loss in the previous year. The growth was mainly attributed to its air cargo logistics business MAB Kargo, which posted RM3 billion in revenue. MAG attributed the improvement to restructuring efforts, which reduced liabilities by over RM15 billion and eliminated RM10 billion in debt. However, the group is concerned about the impact of escalating fuel prices due to the Russia-Ukraine conflict on its profitability.

images.alt_text: Apple CEO Tim Cook at an event in Cupertino, California. Apple will report its latest quarterly earnings on Tuesday. For the upcoming results, it will no longer detail the exact number of iPhones sold in the quarter, leaving analysts to guess the mix of devices based on revenues.

site_title: Private homes in the OCR reap big percentage gains in  Q1 resale market
summary: In the Q1 2022 resale market, non-landed private homes in the Outside Central Region (OCR) saw significant gains, with prices increasing by over 36% in the last decade. Cushman & Wakefield analyzed caveats and found that the top 5 profit-making deals by percentage were all located in the OCR, with one seller netting a 79% profit in nearly 6 years. The OCR outperformed the Rest of Central Region (RCR) and Core Central Region (CCR), which saw lower price growth and higher losses.

site_title: Prudential, former top agency manager reach settlement, drop appeals
summary: Prudential Assurance Company Singapore and former top agency manager Peter Tan Shou Yi have reached a confidential settlement, dropping their appeals in a high-profile lawsuit. Tan was found liable for poaching over 220 Prudential agents for rival Aviva in 2016 and ordered to pay S$4.8 million in damages, S$1.2 million in interest, and S$2.5 million in legal costs. The settlement also discontinues Tan's claims against Prudential's former CEO and two agents.

site_title: Sabana Reit posts slightly lower portfolio occupancy of 85.2% in Q1
summary: Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) reported a portfolio occupancy of 85.2% for Q1 2022, slightly lower than the previous quarter. The company signed 11,786 sq ft of new leases and renewed 208,633 sq ft of leases, with 4% of renewed leases having higher rental rates. This marks the eighth consecutive quarter with positive rental reversion, and 44.1% of leases due to expire this year have been renewed.

site_title: Musk secures US$46.5b in funding for Twitter bid
summary: Elon Musk has secured US$46.5 billion in funding to buy Twitter, with himself committing US$33.5 billion. Banks, including Morgan Stanley, will provide US$13 billion in debt. This comes after Twitter's adoption of a "poison pill" to thwart Musk's US$43 billion offer. Musk aims to take Twitter private to promote free speech, and private equity firms such as Apollo Global Management and Thoma Bravo are considering financing options.

site_title: Non-landed private homes in the suburbs reap big percentage gains in resale market in Q1
summary: In the first quarter of 2022, non-landed private homes in Singapore's Outside Central Region (OCR) saw significant gains in the resale market, with prices rising 36% over the last decade. The top 5 profit-making deals by percentage were all located in the OCR, with one seller netting a 79% profit from a unit in Silahis Apartments in Telok Kurau. In contrast, the Core Central Region (CCR) saw significant losses, with prices decreasing 0.9% over the decade.

site_title: CDL, MCL launch this weekend to kick off batch of upcoming projects
summary: CDL and MCL will launch Piccadilly Grand, a 407-unit 99-year-leasehold condominium in Singapore's Farrer Park area, starting this weekend. The project, which includes 1- to 5-bedroom units, will be the first major private residential development since cooling measures were introduced four months ago. Prices range from S$1.058 million for a 1-bedroom unit to over S$3 million for a 5-bedroom unit. Other upcoming projects, including Liv @ MB and Atlassia, will also be launched in May, with some experts predicting a 40-50% take-up rate due to cooling measures and uncertainties.

site_title: KKR to buy most of Hitachi Transportation Unit, Nikkei says
summary: KKR plans to acquire about 90% of Hitachi Ltd's transportation unit, Hitachi Transport System, for over 600 billion yen (S$6.4 billion). The private equity firm has been named the preferred bidder and will launch a tender offer once an agreement is reached. Hitachi will reduce its stake to 10%. The companies aim to finalize the deal by April 28, when preferential bidding rights expire. This move comes as Hitachi reviews its portfolio assets, with other shortlisted bidders including Bain Capital and Baring Private Equity Asia.

site_title: Hooray for Hollywood
summary: Gucci's Love Parade collection, unveiled in Los Angeles, is a tribute to the Golden Age of Hollywood, blending classic glamour with modern eccentricity. The 115-look show featured Hollywood stars, including Jared Leto and Jodie Turner-Smith, on the catwalk, alongside over 100 models. Creative director Alessandro Michele drew inspiration from iconic Hollywood fashion, referencing Jean Harlow, Mae West, and Elizabeth Taylor. The collection also paid homage to Michele's mother, who worked in the film industry. To complement the show, Gucci launched a selection of updated iconic handbags, including the Jackie 1961, Gucci Diana, and Gucci Bamboo 1947.

site_title: China securities watchdog says it expects audit deal with US regulators soon
summary: China's securities watchdog, the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC), expects to reach an audit deal with US regulators soon, resolving a long-standing dispute that could lead to delistings of US-listed Chinese companies. Vice Chairman Fang Xinghai said negotiations are progressing smoothly, with talks held every 2 weeks via video link. The deal would allow the US Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (PCAOB) to conduct checks on Chinese accounting firms in China, removing uncertainty for Chinese stocks listed overseas. A deal is expected to bring an end to the standoff, which could affect around 270 Chinese companies.

site_title: Singapore to have world's largest sustainable aviation fuel output capacity
summary: Singapore is set to become the world's largest sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) production site when Neste's facility in Tuas is completed in 2023. The 1.5 billion euro Tuas refinery will produce up to 1 million metric tonnes of SAF annually, meeting all quality and performance requirements of conventional fossil fuels. This move is driven by growing demand from airlines and regulations, with SAF identified as a key factor in achieving aviation industry emissions-reduction goals.

site_title: US: Wall St rises at open on boost from Tesla, airlines
summary: US stocks rose at the open on Thursday, led by a surge in Tesla shares and airline stocks, with United Airlines and American Airlines forecasting a return to profitability in the current quarter. The Nasdaq Composite rose 1.27%, while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average also increased, with the Nasdaq leading the way.

site_title: Banks in Singapore put brakes on fixed-rate home loans amid surging cost of funds
summary: Some banks in Singapore have suspended fixed-rate home loan packages due to rising interest rates. This move is attributed to fixed-rate packages becoming less attractive for clients, as well as the rising cost of funds for foreign banks. Mortgage brokers previously recommended fixed-rate packages for clients concerned about rising rates, offering a flat interest rate for up to 3 years.

site_title: In Venice, minimalist Singapore show speaks volumes
summary: The Singapore Pavilion at the 59th Venice Biennale, titled Pulp III: A Short History Of The Banished Book, presents a minimalist show that speaks softly but persistently. Designed by Shubigi Rao, the pavilion features a life-size paper maze that leads visitors into a private space where they can pause and reflect. The accompanying book, Pulp III: An Intimate Inventory Of The Banished Book, recounts the history of Singapore and Venice as printing hubs and features stories about publishing, censorship, and preservation. The pavilion aims to promote the importance of books as symbols of knowledge, power, and activism, and invites visitors to take a free copy of the book to their destination cities.

site_title: Unesco meet in Russia on world heritage postponed indefinitely
summary: A meeting of the UN World Heritage Committee, scheduled to take place in Russia in June, has been postponed indefinitely due to diplomatic wrangling over Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The decision was made after weeks of pressure from Western nations, including the UK, which had called for the meeting to be held elsewhere. The indefinite deferral was formally agreed upon after no objections were forthcoming from committee member states. The meeting, which determines World Heritage status, was one of the few international events Russia was still hosting after the invasion.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines parent MAG turns the corner in FY21 with positive Ebitda of RM433m
summary: Malaysia Airlines parent Malaysia Aviation Group (MAG) achieved a positive Ebitda of RM433 million in FY21, up from a loss of RM1.76 billion in the previous year. The growth was attributed to its air cargo logistics business MAB Kargo, which posted RM3 billion in revenue, and restructuring efforts that reduced liabilities by over RM15 billion and eliminated RM10 billion in debt. Despite increasing passenger demand, the group is concerned about the impact of escalating fuel prices due to the Russia-Ukraine conflict on its profitability.

site_title: Serena Williams, Lewis Hamilton join Broughton's bid to buy Chelsea
summary: Former tennis world No. 1 Serena Williams and 7-time Formula One world champion Lewis Hamilton have joined Martin Broughton's bid to buy Premier League club Chelsea. Broughton's consortium includes World Athletics president Sebastian Coe and wealthy investors, aiming to maintain Chelsea's top status. Private equity veterans Josh Harris and David Blitzer, who own the Philadelphia 76ers, are also backing the bid.

site_title: China stocks plunge as Xi offers no respite from Covid lockdowns
summary: China's stocks plummeted 1.8% on Thursday, extending a fifth day of losses, amid concerns over the economic fallout from the nation's Covid-Zero strategy. President Xi Jinping's speech defending China's lockdown-dependent approach to fighting the pandemic did not offer respite. The CSI 300 Index is now near its closing level on March 15, and the onshore yuan has weakened to its lowest level since October. Investors are pulling money from mainland shares, and foreign investors have offloaded 45 billion yuan of shares in March, citing growth risks and a weakening yuan.

site_title: Russia's US$124b crypto market is pinched by Ukraine sanctions
summary: Russia's $124 billion cryptocurrency market is facing new restrictions due to sanctions imposed by the European Union in response to the country's invasion of Ukraine. Binance Holdings, the world's largest cryptocurrency exchange, will curb services to Russians with crypto assets exceeding 10,000 euros. US sanctions have also been imposed on BitRiver, a digital currency farm operator in Russia, citing "unfair competition." The move is seen as a response to Russia's economic isolation, with some warning that digital currencies could eventually help ease the pain of sanctions.

site_title: All eyes on CDL, MCL's launch of Piccadilly Grand this weekend
summary: City Developments Limited (CDL) and MCL Land have launched Piccadilly Grand, a 407-unit 99-year-leasehold condominium in the Farrer Park area, starting at S$1.058 million for a one-bedroom unit. The project is the first major private residential development since cooling measures were introduced in December 2021. Previews begin on April 23, and sales booking is scheduled for May 7. The project's prices are expected to gauge sentiment and demand from homebuyers, with guide prices ranging from S$2,200 to S$2,500 psf for 1- and 2-bedroom units.

site_title: Simple Italian at il Cielo
summary: Il Cielo, a rooftop restaurant in Singapore, has undergone a transformation from a fine-dining Italian establishment to a casual poolside cafe. The menu features simple Italian dishes, including pasta, pizzas, and seafood, with some standout options like Fritto Misto and Burrata Siciliana. While the food is homey and uncomplicated, it lacks excitement and has become predictable. The restaurant's atmosphere is functional, with a basic view of the hotel swimming pool. Prices range from S$28 for a 2-course set lunch to S$48 for a Wagyu striploin steak. Overall, il Cielo is in coasting mode, waiting for inspiration to elevate its offerings.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims decline moderately
summary: US initial jobless claims fell 2,000 to 184,000 for the week ended April 16, a moderate decline. Economists expected 180,000 applications. Strong job growth continues, with 11.3 million job openings at the end of February. Worker shortages are driving wage increases and inflation. The Federal Reserve raised interest rates in March and is expected to hike again next month. Claims data will be closely watched for signs of demand impact from rising borrowing costs.

(Photo by Frederic J. BROWN / AFP)

site_title: Red Dot Design Museum Singapore reopens
summary: The Red Dot Design Museum Singapore has reopened after a 6-month closure due to poor footfall, primarily from tourism, caused by the pandemic. The museum reopened on April 7 and features a permanent exhibition, as well as two new showcases, including the 2021/2022 winners of the Red Dot Award: Design Concept. The annual award recognizes innovative ideas.

site_title: KTL Global to acquire 51% stake in e-commerce platform EBuy for S$1.5m
summary: KTL Global is acquiring a 51% stake in e-commerce platform EBuy for S$1.5 million, with the option to pay additional consideration if Ebuy achieves positive net profit after tax in 2023 and 2024. This acquisition is seen as the next logical step for the group to expand its supply and distribution business, leveraging Ebuy's capabilities and network. KTL Global had previously acquired a vegetable and fruits supplier and distributor, Tianci Agritech, for S$200,000 in June last year.

site_title: Demand for Akzo Nobel products outpaces supply despite price hike
summary: Akzo Nobel, a Dutch paint maker, reported a 17% price hike in the first quarter to offset supply chain issues, despite demand outpacing supply. The company's adjusted operating income was 230 million euros, beating analyst forecasts. Demand remained "pretty strong" across all segments, with an order backlog of 120 million euros. Cost inflation is expected to ease in the second half of the year. The company's revenue increased 12% to 2.52 billion euros, and shares rose 6.9% after the results beat expectations.

site_title: Japan upgrades view of economy following lifting of Covid curbs
summary: Japan has upgraded its monthly economic assessment in April for the first time in 4 months, citing a decline in Covid-19 cases and lifted pandemic restrictions. The Cabinet Office reported signs of economic recovery, particularly in consumption and public spending. Despite this, the economy is still expected to have contracted in the first 3 months of the year, and other factors such as Russia's war on Ukraine, surging energy prices, and a weakening yen are clouding the outlook. The government is set to unveil measures to cushion the blow from higher fuel bills.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 4.57 points to 1,598.32. The market saw 518 gainers compared to 445 losers, with a total volume of 2.846 billion lots worth RM2.033 billion.

site_title: Six ways to win digital growth in South-east Asia
summary: Southeast Asia is experiencing rapid digital growth, with 350 million digital consumers, outpacing China at a 1.6x growth rate. To succeed, brands must adopt six crucial strategies: rewriting their digital-first agenda, rewiring supply chain business models, reimagining consumer engagement, refreshing product offerings, re-envisioning sustainability, and realigning to consumers' new hybrid lifestyle. These strategies aim to maximize brand success by leveraging digital channels, managing supply chain challenges, and catering to changing consumer demands.

site_title: DBS partners GovTech, Nets, HPB to launch digital payment method for healthier F&B options
summary: DBS has partnered with GovTech, Nets, and HPB to launch a digital payment method for healthier F&B options through the Healthy 365 app. Over 500 merchants islandwide will support this initiative. Customers can scan the Nets or SG QR code at participating stores to use their HPB Credit$ to purchase select healthier options. This feature will be available starting April 25, allowing app users to convert Healthpoints into credits and redeem them at participating outlets.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise for third straight day; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% to 3,348.46, marking its third consecutive day of gains. Top gainers included Singtel, SATS, and Jardine Cycle & Carriage, while Dairy Farm International was the top decliner, falling 1.8%. The broader market saw 246 decliners compared to 245 gainers, with 1.5 billion securities worth S$1.3 billion changing hands. The rally follows positive performances in most Asian markets, despite concerns over China's markets and US delisting fears in Hong Kong.

site_title: Myanmar exempts foreign entities from exchange rules after business outcry
summary: Myanmar's central bank has exempted foreign entities from a controversial exchange rule requiring foreign exchange to be converted into local currency. The exemption, announced on April 20, includes companies with approved foreign investments, international organizations, and diplomats. The rule change was made after industry groups and embassies warned it would severely impact business activity in the country. The exemption is expected to provide relief for fuel importers, who have been impacted by the exchange requirement, and is seen as a move to exert more control over foreign currency flows in the military-run nation.

site_title: Manchester United name Ten Hag as new permanent manager
summary: Manchester United has named Erik ten Hag as their new permanent manager, replacing interim boss Ralf Rangnick at the end of the season. Ten Hag, 52, previously led Ajax to Dutch league titles and Champions League semi-finals. He will manage United until June 2025, with the option to extend for a further year. Ten Hag expressed his excitement and determination to deliver success for the club, despite leaving Ajax after an incredible run.

site_title: Carlsberg expects US$1.4b Russia writedown and lowers profit guidance
summary: Carlsberg expects a writedown of approximately $1.4 billion due to the sale of its Russian business, which will result in a loss of 9.5 billion Danish crowns. The company has 8 breweries and 8,400 employees in Russia and plans to sell its business over the next 12 months. This decision follows other Western companies exiting Russia, including Heineken, which expects to book charges of $437 million. Carlsberg lowered its operating profit growth forecast for this year to between -5% and 2%.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A bartender holds a glass of Carlsberg beer in a bar in St. Petersburg June 17, 2014. REUTERS/Alexander Demianchuk/File Photo

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore startups and tech SMEs can now access opportunities in the Nordic region through a Global Innovation Alliance (GIA) pilot programme in Stockholm, Sweden. The Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS) launched an industry standard questionnaire to engage clients on environmental risk issues. Chinese President Xi Jinping reiterated opposition to unilateral sanctions and "long-arm jurisdiction". Chinese e-commerce giants JD and Alibaba are shifting shares to the Hong Kong market due to concerns over US listing eligibility. Singapore stocks rose for the third consecutive day, with the STI up 0.4%.

site_title: Amazon targets rival Shopify with new 'Buy With Prime' service
summary: Amazon has launched a new "Buy With Prime" service, allowing merchants to sell products directly from their own websites, combining Amazon's payments and fulfillment services. This move aims to counter Shopify's growth and provide fast-shipping benefits to Prime members. The service will be invite-only, with merchants paying Amazon fees. Amazon seeks to distinguish itself from Shopify, which is expanding its fulfillment services through a potential acquisition of Deliverr.

site_title: Singapore-based halal cosmetics company raises US$55m in Series C funding led by Venturi
summary: Singapore-based halal cosmetics company Believe has raised US$55 million in Series C funding led by Venturi Partners. This marks Venturi's second investment, following its participation in India's interior design and home renovation platform Livspace. IIFL Asset Management Company (AMC) is also set to join as an incoming investor, subject to SEBI approval. The funding round aims to support Believe's expansion and growth in the Muslim audience-focused brands market.

images.alt_text: KKR leads US$180m round for Ikea-backed unicorn Livspace
East Ventures, Central Retail Corp invest in startup behind theAsianparent

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close deep in the red
summary: Hong Kong and mainland Chinese shares plummeted on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 1.25% and the Shanghai Composite Index losing 2.26%. Trader confidence was eroded by supply chain woes, a tech sector crackdown, and a lack of policy support from Beijing. The Shenzhen Composite Index also dropped 3.11%.

site_title: As Malaysia reopens to the world, airlines see healthy pick-up in flight bookings
summary: Malaysia's aviation industry has seen a surge in flight ticket bookings since the country reopened its borders on April 1, with airlines such as AirAsia Malaysia and Malaysian Airlines reporting a significant increase in bookings. AirAsia Malaysia has seen a 20% increase in bookings, while Malaysian Airlines has seen a 100% surge in ticket sales. The industry is expected to recover to 70% of its pre-pandemic capacity by the end of 2022, with a projected 525% increase in air passenger traffic to 49 million passengers in 2022.

site_title: ECB rate at zero or more by year end a 'no brainer', Wunsch says
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) Governor Pierre Wunsch suggests that the ECB may raise interest rates to zero or more by the end of the year to combat high inflation, unless a severe economic shock occurs. Traders now see an 80% chance of a quarter-point rate hike in July, with the deposit rate expected to turn positive by December. Wunsch notes that data will be crucial in determining the timing of rate hikes, but emphasizes that the ECB is committed to exiting ultra-loose policy settings.

site_title: Djokovic criticises Wimbledon ban on Russian, Belarusian players
summary: Novak Djokovic criticized Wimbledon's decision to ban Russian and Belarusian players due to the Ukraine invasion, calling it "crazy." The Grand Slam tournament, starting June 27, will not allow competitors from the two countries, affecting men's world No. 2 Daniil Medvedev and women's No. 4 Aryna Sabalenka. This decision marks the first tennis tournament to ban players from Russia and Belarus following the Kremlin-led invasion.

site_title: Why we admire Zelensky
summary: The article highlights the admiration for Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky due to his courageous leadership in the face of adversity, particularly against Russian aggression. He embodies virtues such as honesty, love of country, and the power of personal example, inspiring others to stand up against tyranny. Zelensky's leadership has also restored the idea of the free world and serves as a model for leaders who can inspire and ennoble their people, particularly in the context of the ongoing Ukraine-Russia conflict.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rise at open
summary: Europe's stock markets rose in opening deals on April 21, 2022, with Frankfurt's DAX index gaining 0.2% and Paris's CAC 40 rising 0.4%. However, London's FTSE 100 fell 0.4%. The gains followed a mixed Asian performance and were driven by gains in mining and healthcare shares.

site_title: Ukraine war spurs demand for fundraising: JPMorgan
summary: JPMorgan Chase sees increased demand for fundraising from companies due to volatility caused by Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The bank is navigating "complex" sanctions and has stopped new business, but is talking with clients about incremental fund-raising. CEO Jamie Dimon warned the bank could lose around $1 billion over time due to limited exposure to Russia. The bank's first-quarter results showed a $524 million loss tied to market fallout. JPMorgan also maintains a positive view of China's economy, despite the ongoing Covid outbreak and lockdowns.

site_title: Japan agrees extra budget to tackle rising living costs
summary: Japan's ruling coalition agreed on a supplementary budget to support lower-income households and small firms, aiming to combat inflationary pressures for the first time in decades. The budget, estimated at around 2.5 trillion yen (US$19.5 billion), includes one-off cash payouts to low-income households and expanded subsidies for fuel wholesalers. The package aims to ensure stable supplies of oil and basic foods, and is expected to be approved during the current parliamentary session scheduled to end in June.

site_title: Russia tests nuclear-capable missile that Putin calls best in world
summary: Russia test-launched a nuclear-capable intercontinental ballistic missile, the Sarmat, from Plesetsk in northwest Russia, hitting targets 6,000 km away. President Vladimir Putin called it the "best" missile in the world, stating it would make Moscow's enemies "stop and think." The test came as Russia continues its assault on Ukraine, with Putin ordering Russia's nuclear forces to be put on high alert last month. The Sarmat's delivery is set to begin in the autumn, and experts say more tests are needed before deployment.

site_title: China's Xiaohongshu kicks off staff layoffs: source
summary: Chinese social e-commerce app Xiaohongshu has kicked off staff layoffs, reportedly affecting less than 10% of its workforce. The layoffs are part of the company's performance review process and follow similar moves by other Chinese tech giants, including Alibaba and Tencent, amid regulatory crackdowns. Xiaohongshu has been targeted by Chinese regulators, including a fine for excessive personal information collection and a call to stop sharing lewd content featuring minors. The layoffs are the latest move by the company, valued at up to $20 billion after a $500 million fundraising round in November.

site_title: Digital Core Reit posts US$12.1m in Q1 distributable income, beats IPO forecast
summary: Digital Core Reit posted US$12.1 million in Q1 distributable income, beating its IPO forecast of US$11.9 million by 1.9%. The Reit's portfolio of 10 data centres had a value of US$1.46 billion as of March 31. Gross revenue was 0.1% lower than its IPO forecast at US$26.5 million, while net property income (NPI) beat its forecast by 6.9% at US$17.9 million.

site_title: Yellen, ministers leave G-20 meeting as Russia envoys speak
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and other finance ministers and central bank governors walked out of a G-20 meeting when Russian officials began addressing the gathering, according to people familiar with the events. The meeting was the first G-20 gathering since the war in Ukraine began, and nations in the Group of Seven have taken the lead in pursuing sanctions against Russia. The G-20 did not issue a communique, but Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati of Indonesia acknowledged that the meeting was held under challenging circumstances, and expressed confidence that differences won't hinder cooperation on global issues.

site_title: Keppel Corp posts higher Q1 profit; 3 out of 4 key segments fare better
summary: Keppel Corp reported higher year-on-year net profit in Q1, driven by increased contributions from its energy & environment, asset management, and connectivity segments. The company's property development arm, Keppel Land, saw a net profit dip due to lower contributions from China property trading projects. Despite the challenges in China, Keppel remains optimistic about opportunities in the mid to long term, citing economic growth and urbanization trends. The company has also made progress in asset monetization and is actively looking to invest in China, with a focus on Tier 1 cities.

images.alt_text: Keppel Marina East Desalination Plant's staff inspecting the filtration membranes used in the water treatment process. Keppel Corp provides solutions for sustainable urbanisation.

site_title: Australia: Shares gain as upbeat output reports offset tech, BHP slump
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to 7,586.30 points, driven by upbeat earnings and production reports, including Brambles' 7.2% gain and Viva Energy's record high. Energy and financials also rose, while tech stocks fell 2.63%. BHP Group slumped 2.7% after lower-than-expected iron ore production and a cut to its copper production view. The positive sentiment offset concerns over economic growth stagnation and supply restrictions.

site_title: Investors sceptical of Netflix's plans to crack down on account sharing
summary: Netflix's plan to crack down on account sharing failed to reassure investors, with its stock down 36% after announcing it would charge subscribers for sharing accounts outside their households. The company blames password sharing for missing subscriber growth targets, with an estimated 100 million shared accounts worldwide. Analysts express skepticism, citing concerns the strategy won't generate enough revenue to offset declining growth. Netflix plans to introduce the charge globally within a year, but some analysts question its effectiveness in sparking new growth.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Smartphone with Netflix logo is seen in front of a descending stock graph in this illustration taken April 19, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on April 21, 2022, with the Nikkei 225 index up 1.2% and the Topix index up 0.7%. The gains came despite a mixed finish on Wall Street, as investors reacted positively to a lull in US treasury yield increases. The Nikkei 225 index ended at 27,553.06, while the Topix index ended at 1,928.00.

site_title: Crypto exchange Binance limits services in Russia after EU sanctions
summary: Binance, the largest crypto exchange, has limited services for Russian nationals with crypto assets exceeding 10,000 euros due to EU sanctions. Affected accounts will be put into a withdrawal-only mode, with no deposits or trading permitted. Russian nationals have 90 days to close their positions. This move comes after the company restricted access for sanctioned Russian individuals and cardholders of sanctioned Russian banks. Binance's decision aims to comply with EU restrictions targeting crypto wallets and other assets.

site_title: Musk appeals for more lithium production to meet battery demand
summary: Elon Musk made a public appeal for increased investment in lithium mining to meet growing demand for batteries in electric vehicles. He cited a "yawning gap" between supply and demand, stating that battery production, particularly lithium, is the "fundamental limiting factor" for EV adoption worldwide. Musk encouraged entrepreneurs to get into the lithium business, noting that lithium margins are currently "practically software margins." This move aims to address the supply chain challenge facing the electric vehicle industry.

site_title: China’s Xi pushes back on sanctions, de-coupling
summary: China's President Xi Jinping reiterated opposition to unilateral sanctions and "long-arm jurisdiction" in a speech, without directly mentioning Western sanctions on Russia. He emphasized the need for global security cooperation and a balanced security architecture, warning that economic de-coupling and supply chain pressure tactics would not be effective. Xi also highlighted China's resilient economy, despite facing headwinds from the COVID-19 crisis, and expressed support for a global security initiative based on the principle of indivisibility of security.

site_title: Cathay offers pilots up to HK$432,000 allowances to stem exodus
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways is offering pilots up to HK$432,000 annually, including a monthly allowance of HK$36,000 for senior captains, to stem a wave of resignations due to the impact of Hong Kong's Covid-19 policies. The airline is also providing annual school fees of HK$100,000 per child for up to three children. These changes aim to address the crisis caused by the pandemic, which has led to record losses, thousands of job cuts, and lower wages for the airline's staff.

site_title: A Napa favourite goes back to the future
summary: Stony Hill Vineyard, a 70-year-old Napa Valley pioneer of California chardonnay, is undergoing significant changes under new ownership. The vineyard, which was previously dominated by white wines, will shift to a red-dominant producer with 14 acres of cabernet sauvignon and 8.5 acres of chardonnay. Winemaker Jaimee Motley, known for her fresh and savory wines, has been brought in to lead the transformation. The cellar is being rebuilt, and the vineyard is being replanted with biodynamic and regenerative viticulture practices. Despite changes, the iconic Stony Hill chardonnay will continue to be produced, with Motley opting to maintain its traditional style.

site_title: Horror master Cronenberg makes art from 'beautiful' kidney stones
summary: Canadian filmmaker David Cronenberg is auctioning an image of his recently removed kidney stones as a digital token (NFT), titled "Inner Beauty", with a starting bid of approximately $30,000. The image is part of his latest project, "Crimes of the Future", which is competing for the Palme d'Or at Cannes. Cronenberg, known for his graphic "body horror" movies, believes the kidney stones are too beautiful to be destroyed and feels a "closeness" to them, inspiring his artistic creation.

site_title: Indo coal billionaire Thohir to use profit boom to begin green shift
summary: Indonesian coal billionaire Garibaldi Thohir plans to shift Adaro Energy's focus to renewable energy, building solar-powered plants and hydro power plants on retired mine sites. The company aims to cease its dependence on coal and become a leading player in Indonesia's green energy sector. With a net income that soared over 500% in 2021, Adaro plans to use excess profits to fund its 10-year pivot to clean energy, aligning with Indonesia's goal to double national renewable energy capacity by 2025 and reduce carbon emissions.

site_title: Djokovic slams 'crazy' Wimbledon ban on Russian, Belarusian players
summary: Novak Djokovic criticized Wimbledon's decision to ban Russian and Belarusian players from the tournament due to the ongoing conflict in Ukraine. The tennis world number one stated that the athletes have nothing to do with the conflict and that politics should not interfere with sport. Djokovic expressed his opposition to the decision, calling it "crazy," and compared it to the exclusion of German and Japanese players after World War II. The ATP and WTA tours have also criticized the move, with Wimbledon saying it would "consider and respond accordingly" if circumstances change.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Thursday, following two days of losses, with the Hang Seng Index falling 0.78% or 163.81 points to 20,780,86.84. This decline comes amid mixed results on Wall Street, where Netflix shares plummeted due to dwindling subscriptions. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also experienced losses, with the Shanghai Composite Index down 0.40% and the Shenzhen Composite Index down 0.53%.

site_title: Eight-hour blackouts hit India after hottest March since 1901
summary: India is experiencing widespread eight-hour blackouts due to a coal shortage, exacerbating a power crisis that could impact the country's $2.7 trillion economy. The scarcity of coal, which accounts for 70% of India's electricity generation, has prompted states to cut off power supply, forcing customers to endure the heat or seek costly backup options. The blackouts are threatening to hobble industrial output, fuel inflation, and pose a "stagflationary shock" to the economy, with some economists warning of a coal crisis worse than last year's.

site_title: Asian central banks in the fight against inflation
summary: Asian central banks are lagging behind OECD countries in raising interest rates to combat inflation, with factors including lower inflationary pressures, modest exchange rates, and concerns about the Russia-Ukraine war affecting consumer confidence. In contrast, countries like South Korea have raised rates unexpectedly, with the Bank of Korea increasing its policy rate to 1.5%. Most Asian economies are focusing on managing inflation and economic growth rather than aggressively fighting inflation.

site_title: Hong Kong reopens venues, extends dining hours as Covid-19 cases fall
summary: Hong Kong has reopened gyms, beauty parlors, theme parks, and cinemas for the first time in over four months as COVID-19 cases fall below 1,000 for six consecutive days. Restaurant dining hours have been extended to 10 pm and group gatherings have been expanded to four people. Many schools have resumed in-person learning after months of online classes. The easing comes as the city grapples with a "dynamic zero" COVID-19 policy similar to mainland China, but the labor market remains under pressure due to the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end at 2-week high with earnings in focus
summary: South Korea's benchmark Kospi index closed at a 2-week high, rising 9.52 points to 2,728.21, driven by strong buying from institutional investors ahead of quarterly earnings reports from major companies, including Samsung Electronics and Hyundai Motor. Despite uncertainty from the Russia-Ukraine war and a slump in Chinese stocks, the local stock market continued its robust trend, with exports rising 16.9% year on year and imports jumping 25.5%. The won weakened, while the benchmark bond yield rose, with the central bank governor warning that economic growth is expected to weaken further.

site_title: Twitter, analysts wary of Musk takeover bid
summary: Elon Musk has made an unsolicited bid of US$43 million for Twitter, citing better freedom of speech as a motivation. However, Twitter's board is wary of Musk's takeover, considering his history of controversy and authoritarian tendencies. The company has implemented a "poison pill" plan to prevent Musk from acquiring more than 15% of the shares, and analysts warn of potential issues with content moderation and worker treatment if Musk were to take over. Despite Musk's free speech rhetoric, his actions have been criticized for lacking true commitment to the principles.

site_title: AIA's group chief distribution officer Bill Lisle dies at 57
summary: AIA Group announced the death of Bill Lisle, its group chief distribution officer and regional chief executive for Thailand, Vietnam, India, and Sri Lanka, at 57. Lisle, who was also instrumental in integrating ING Groep's life insurance business in Malaysia in 2012, passed away without a stated cause. The Hong Kong-based insurer described Lisle's death as "profoundly saddened" and expressed its condolences to his family.

site_title: Britain's Queen Elizabeth gets own Barbie doll for Platinum Jubilee
summary: Queen Elizabeth is being honored with a Barbie doll for her Platinum Jubilee, marking 70 years on the throne. The doll, created by Mattel, features the monarch in an ivory gown and tiara, similar to her wedding attire. The doll will be sold in London stores ahead of official Platinum Jubilee celebrations in early June, as Queen Elizabeth turns 96.
