site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Thursday, rising 5.14 points or 0.32% to 1,598.89. The index saw a significant volume of 279.55 million lots worth RM93.35 million. Gainers outpaced losers 210 to 152, indicating a positive market sentiment.

site_title: Goldman Sachs flagged Morgan Stanley block trades to Hong Kong regulator: sources
summary: Goldman Sachs reported rival Morgan Stanley to Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission three years ago over a series of block trades in Hong Kong-listed companies, citing price drops. The alert was part of an "informal" discussion. It's unclear if Hong Kong authorities investigated the claim.

site_title: Can Biden turn his ship before midterms storm?
summary: US President Joe Biden is facing a challenging political environment ahead of the midterms, with a Gallup poll showing a significant decline in support among young voters, Black and Latino voters, and his overall approval rating at 42%. Despite efforts to regain momentum, Biden's approval ratings have dropped from 54-35 in his first days as president, and polls show a "trend of buyer's remorse" among his base. The president is under pressure to deliver on his agenda before the November elections, with some experts warning that the Biden administration is "politically unsalvageable" if he fails to make progress.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets open higher on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, despite a mixed finish on Wall Street, where Netflix's earnings miss led to a sell-off in tech shares. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.31% to 27,301.84 and the Topix index edged up 0.19% to 1,918.85.

site_title: Amazon's cloud chief eyes acquisitions, expanding market lead
summary: Amazon's cloud chief Adam Selipsky stated the company has no current plans to spin off its profitable Amazon Web Services division, citing customer benefits and maintaining market lead. AWS generated $62 billion in revenue in 2021 and 74% of Amazon's operating profit. Selipsky believes the cloud market is in its early stages, with only 5-15% of corporate spending dedicated to cloud services, and that AWS can maintain its lead if the company continues to move fast.

site_title: Gold prices dip as uptick in Treasury yields, dollar weighs
summary: Gold prices dropped 0.2% to $1,953.21 per ounce, following a rebound in US Treasury yields and a stronger dollar. The US Federal Reserve's expected interest rate hikes due to accelerating inflation are weighing on demand for safe-haven bullion. Treasury yields firmed after a sale of 20-year bonds, while the dollar strengthened, making gold less attractive for other currency holders. Silver, platinum, and palladium also fell, with spot silver down 0.4% to $25.08 per ounce.

site_title: Sabana Reit posts slightly lower portfolio occupancy of 85.2% in Q1
summary: Sabana Industrial Reit reported a portfolio occupancy of 85.2% for Q1 2022, slightly lower than the previous quarter. The company signed 11,786 sq ft of new leases and renewed 208,633 sq ft, with 4% of renewed leases having higher rental rates. 44.1% of leases expiring this year have been renewed, and the Reit is engaging with tenants to sign longer-term leases. The company secured a S$150 million sustainability-linked loan and reduced its total borrowings to S$305.5 million, bringing its overall leverage to 34.8%.

site_title: US: Wall Street ends mixed after big Netflix disappointment
summary: US stocks ended trading mixed on Wednesday, with the Dow gaining 0.7% and the S&P 500 down 0.1%. The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite Index fell 1.2% after Netflix reported a 35.1% drop in subscribers for the first time in a decade. US companies continue to struggle with high inflation, and existing home sales dropped for the second straight month in March. Global economic developments, including IMF and World Bank meetings, are also being digested by traders.

site_title: Elon Musk's Boring Co. raises funding at nearly US$6b valuation
summary: Elon Musk's Boring Co. has raised US$675 million in a funding round led by Vy Capital and Sequoia Capital, valuing the company at US$5.675 billion. The funding will be used to "significantly increase hiring" and expand the company's transportation networks in tunnels. Boring Co. has already completed a tunnel system at the Las Vegas Convention Center and plans to expand in other cities. The company's technology is now considered state-of-the-art and improving at an exponential rate, according to Sequoia Capital.

site_title: Singapore shares open Thursday higher; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.1% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,340.4 points. Gainers outnumbered losers 73 to 40, driven by the heavy trading of Jiutian Chemical and Sembcorp Marine. Local banks DBS and UOB also traded higher, while OCBC dipped. The gains follow mixed US indices, with the Dow up 0.7% and the S&P 500 down 0.1%, due to a streaming giant's earnings miss.

site_title: Brokers' take: Maybank upgrades Keppel Reit to 'buy' on office demand tailwinds
summary: Keppel Reit's first-quarter distributable income increased by 4.3% to S$53.8 million, driven by the acquisition of Keppel Bay Tower. Maybank Securities upgraded the real estate investment trust to "buy" from "hold" due to rising office demand and improved occupancy, raising its target price to S$1.30. RHB Securities also increased its target to S$1.31, citing attractive valuations and a favorable risk-reward.

images.alt_text: The Reit’s manager attributed the increase in distributable income mainly to the acquisition of Keppel Bay Tower in May last year.

site_title: ABS launches initiative for banks to engage clients on environmental issues
summary: ABS launches the Environmental Risk Questionnaire (ERQ) for Singapore banks to engage clients on environmental issues. Developed by a workgroup of six banks, the questionnaire gathers data points to finance Singapore's transition to a low-carbon economy. The ERQ is applicable to high-risk sectors and provides a standardized template for banks to assess environmental risks. ABS encourages members to adopt the ERQ and plans to develop subsequent versions with more detailed questions. The initiative aims to establish a best practice for banks to engage clients in environmental risk assessment and mitigation.

site_title: BHP reports weaker-than-expected iron ore production on Covid-19 curbs
summary: BHP Group reported weaker-than-expected iron ore production for the March quarter due to pandemic-related labour crunch, falling short of estimates. Despite this, the miner expects to meet fiscal 2022 costs and volume forecast. Copper production declined 9% at Escondida mine in Chile, and iron ore production from Western Australia remained flat at 66.7 million tonnes. BHP's CEO warned of ongoing skills shortages and labour market tightness in Australia and Chile, impacting the company's production in the coming period.

site_title: Russian inflation is back to pre-war level as worst appears over
summary: Russian weekly inflation has slowed to 0.2% as of April 15, a level last seen before the invasion of Ukraine in February, thanks to a stronger ruble and end of panic buying. The central bank has unwound part of its emergency interest rate hike and promised further monetary easing. However, the economy faces a deep recession, with a forecasted 8.5% contraction in gross domestic product for 2022, and annual inflation approaching 20%. Bank of Russia Governor Elvira Nabiullina has warned of a reckoning for the economy due to international sanctions.

site_title: Hong Kong landlords brace for even deeper cuts to retail rents
summary: Hong Kong's retail landlords are bracing for a further cut in rents, with some already having reduced rates by 30-50% due to government pressure and tenant bargaining power. A proposed law allowing a 3-month moratorium on payments will give tenants leverage to negotiate discounts. Shop rents have fallen to their lowest since 2008, with a 4.5% decline in Causeway Bay, and the vacancy rate has risen to 11%. Landlords are concerned that the relief will add pressure on property firms, while tenants say landlords aren't doing enough to help.

site_title: Is Coinbase's new NFT marketplace the answer to its growth problems?
summary: Coinbase's new NFT marketplace has launched, aiming to diversify its revenue and bring predictability to the business. The platform, designed to sell ownership of digital art and possibly other items, enters a crowded field six months after its announcement. With the NFT hype cooling down and competition from other crypto exchanges and platforms, Coinbase needs the platform to be a hit to reduce its reliance on trading fees. The company has 2.5 million email addresses on its waiting list, but analysts question whether it will be able to generate meaningful revenue outside of trading.

site_title: Amazon, SpaceX snag Nasa space communications contracts
summary: NASA has awarded a combined $278.5 million in contracts to SpaceX, Amazon's Project Kuiper, and other satellite firms to demonstrate space communications. Amazon's Project Kuiper won $67 million, while SpaceX's Starlink venture received $70 million. The contracts aim to replace NASA's current satellite network and stimulate commercial activity in space communications. Companies must complete development and demonstrations by 2025, with the goal of reducing costs for customers beyond NASA. This move marks NASA's increasing reliance on private space companies for operations and aims to generate billions in revenue for broadband internet from space.

site_title: Ackman gives up on Netflix, taking US$400m loss as shares tumble
summary: Billionaire investor William Ackman's hedge fund Pershing Square Holdings sold all its Netflix shares after the streaming service's stock price plummeted 35% following a subscriber loss announcement. Ackman absorbed a $400 million loss on the bet, citing a loss of confidence in predicting Netflix's future prospects. Ackman, who had invested $100 million in Netflix in January, had become the company's most prominent backer.

site_title: Tesla reports Q1 profits of US$3.3b, topping expectations
summary: Tesla reported Q1 profits of $3.3 billion, exceeding expectations, with 658% growth in profits and 81% increase in revenues to $18.8 billion. The company cited a boost from higher retail prices due to rising production costs and semiconductor shortages. Despite a temporary China factory shutdown, Tesla maintained its 50% average annual growth target in deliveries, citing supply chain constraints. Shares rose 4.1% to $1,017.02.

site_title: Shopify is in talks to buy tech startup Deliverr: sources
summary: Shopify is in talks to acquire tech startup Deliverr, a move that would help expand the Canadian e-commerce company's fulfillment services. A deal could value Deliverr at over $2 billion. Deliverr provides fast shipping to merchants on Amazon and other online marketplaces, and a successful acquisition would be Shopify's largest-ever deal. The deal would complement Shopify's subscription-based software and help the company compete with Amazon's growing logistics network.

site_title: JD, Alibaba stock exodus from New York intensifies
summary: JD.com and Alibaba Group Holding are shifting a significant portion of their shares from the New York Stock Exchange to the Hong Kong market, amid concerns over US delisting. As of April 19, 77% of JD.com's shares are circulating in Hong Kong, up from 44% at the beginning of the year, while Alibaba's Hong Kong-listed share portion rose to 56% from 53%. Investors are converting US shares to Hong Kong-listed shares to avoid direct regulatory shocks and lower exposure to American depositary shares.

images.alt_text: Brexit and growing trade barriers are manifestations of the peak globalisation, and the more constrained movement of people and products is likely to crimp profit margins as we move forward

site_title: Internationalisation efforts pay off as silver linings emerge from pandemic
summary: Singaporean companies like Cocoba and Eigen Energy are seeing success in overseas expansion, despite the initial challenges posed by the Covid-19 pandemic. Cocoba's internationalisation efforts have paid off, with exports now accounting for 60% of its revenue, and the company is eyeing European markets. Eigen Energy, an engineering firm, has also expanded into new markets, including Bangladesh and Cambodia, with support from Enterprise Singapore's business matching programmes and Market Readiness Assistance Grant. Companies are adapting to the new normal, with remote management becoming the norm, and diversification becoming crucial for resilience. Experts stress the importance of innovation, internationalisation, and digitalisation to sustain business growth, as the pandemic has accelerated the adoption of these strategies.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sabana Reit, Mapletree Commercial Trust, Keppel Reit, Singtel, SMI Vantage
summary: Singapore stocks saw mixed results, with Sabana Reit's distribution per unit declining 3.4% to S$0.0514, and Mapletree Commercial Trust's units rising 0.5% to S$1.87. Keppel Reit's distributable income increased 4.3% to S$53.8 million, and Singtel successfully priced a US$100 million 5-year digital sustainability-linked bond. SMI Vantage's shares jumped 3.57% to S$0.058 after resuming its travel retail business. The STI closed 0.4% higher, despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Obamas to leave Spotify, seek multimillion-dollar deal elsewhere: sources
summary: The Obamas' production company, Higher Ground, is set to leave Spotify after failing to secure a new deal with the audio platform. Instead, Higher Ground is exploring options with other distributors, including Amazon's Audible and iHeartMedia, in a deal worth tens of millions of dollars. The company is seeking a deal that allows it to produce multiple shows and release them on multiple platforms simultaneously. The Obamas are willing to commit to an 8-episode program, but the deal is reportedly not comparable to those for popular shows like "SmartLess" and "Call Her Daddy."

site_title: Judge rejects ‘gag order’ for Elon Musk
summary: A US District Judge rejected a proposed "gag order" for Elon Musk, allowing him to discuss a lawsuit claiming he defrauded Tesla shareholders. The judge found the order to be "overbroad" as it prevented Musk from speaking to anyone about the case. Musk's tweets in 2018 about taking Tesla private were deemed false and made with sufficient knowledge they were false. The judge will instruct jurors at the scheduled January 2023 trial that Musk's tweets were false and made fraudulently.

site_title: Europe: Shares rebound on earnings boost
summary: European shares rebounded 0.8% on Wednesday, driven by positive earnings from chipmaker ASML and consumer stock Danone. Technology stocks led gains, with ASML rising 5.3% and Danone jumping 5.8%. However, miners fell 2.6% as Rio Tinto reported lower iron ore shipments. Despite the rebound, investors remain cautious due to lingering risks of war escalation, sanctions, and central bank tightening, which could limit short-term gains.

site_title: US, allies say new intel suggests coming Russian cyberattack
summary: US and its allies, including Britain, Canada, Australia, and New Zealand, warned that Russia is poised to launch powerful cyberattacks against rivals supporting Ukraine, citing "evolving intelligence." The cyber threat alert warned that Russian state-sponsored cyber actors can compromise IT networks, steal data, deploy malware, and launch destructive attacks, targeting critical infrastructure in countries that support Ukraine. The countries urged critical infrastructure network defenders to prepare for and mitigate potential cyber threats by hardening their defenses and identifying indicators of malicious activity.

site_title: False alarm sees US Capitol evacuated
summary: The US Capitol building was briefly evacuated on Wednesday after a false alarm triggered a police response to an aircraft deemed a "probable threat." However, police later stated that the order was given out of caution and there was no actual threat. The incident occurred as the House of Representatives and Senate were not in session. Unverified reports suggested the aircraft may have been a demonstration plane from the Army Golden Knights at a nearby stadium, which may not have informed Capitol Police of its presence in the airspace.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on April 5, 2022 the US Capitol is seen in Washington, DC2. - Police at the United States Capitol ordered the complex be evacuated on April 20, 2022, saying it was "tracking an aircraft that poses a probable threat" -- but swiftly issued an update to say the craft did not pose any danger. (Photo by Stefani Reynolds / AFP)

site_title: BOJ offers unlimited buying of 10-year bonds
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) offered to buy an unlimited amount of 10-year Japanese government bonds at 0.25% to defend its yield target, following a sharp rise in yields due to the yen's 2-decade lows against the US dollar. The move aims to maintain market confidence and prevent a clear message to the market that the BOJ is losing control. The BOJ has previously offered unlimited purchases of 10-year bonds in February and March, and the decision comes as the US Federal Reserve prepares to raise interest rates.

site_title: UK PM Johnson heads to India for hard sell on anti-Russia action
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson visited India, touting job-creating investment and seeking to secure Western action against Russia. Despite long odds, Johnson is expected to meet with Prime Minister Narendra Modi, with Downing Street promising £1 billion in two-way investment deals and new partnerships on defense, AI, and green energy. However, India has refused to condemn Russia, and the UK acknowledges it is far from clinching a post-Brexit trade deal. Johnson will also discuss renewable energy and Ukraine with Modi, but aims to "broaden the Western coalition" rather than "lecture" him.

site_title: United Airlines sees Q2 profit, record revenue on booming travel demand
summary: United Airlines forecasts a profit for the second quarter, driven by booming travel demand and record revenue. The airline expects a 17% increase in total revenue per available seat mile compared to 2019, with an adjusted operating margin of 10%. Travel demand has surged back to 89% of pre-pandemic levels, and the company's fuel bill is expected to increase 19% quarter-over-quarter. United's shares jumped 7.6% in extended trading, with the company also adjusting its plans to boost capacity and pricing power.

site_title: JPMorgan loses lead role in Kingsoft Cloud IPO
summary: JPMorgan Chase has lost its lead role in Kingsoft Cloud Holdings' Hong Kong stock offering after an analyst cut the company's share-price target by half, citing the China Internet sector as "uninvestable" in the near term. The demotion may cut fees for JPMorgan, which remains a sponsor of the offering but is now ranked behind UBS Group and China International Capital Corp. This move highlights the challenges faced by global banks seeking to expand in China amid market concerns over slowing growth and strict policies.

site_title: Singapore joins hands with NZ to tackle 'a wicked problem' in aviation
summary: Singapore and New Zealand have formed a memorandum of arrangement to collaborate on promoting sustainable aviation, focusing on policy and regulation, industry development, infrastructure planning, and workforce transformation. The two countries will study the feasibility of developing "green lanes" for SAF-fuelled flights, aiming to reduce aviation's environmental impact. The collaboration is seen as a step towards decarbonizing aviation, a "wicked problem" that requires global cooperation.

site_title: New Zealand 30-year high inflation flags need for more tightening
summary: New Zealand's consumer price index rose 1.8% in the first quarter, exceeding expectations and marking the fastest pace in 30 years. Annual inflation rose 6.9%, driven by broad-based price increases in food, petrol, construction, and housing. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand has signaled further interest rate hikes to contain inflation, with economists warning of a persistent inflationary environment.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Singtel successfully priced its first digital sustainability-linked bond, a $100 million, 5-year bond with a 3.56% fixed coupon rate. The bond will be issued on April 27, 2022, and used to fund the company's ordinary course of business. The bond is guaranteed by Singtel and will be tokenized on ADDX's digital securities exchange. The net proceeds will also support Singtel's sustainability goals.

site_title: Inflation, interest rates and the housing paradox
summary: The Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates repeatedly to combat high inflation, which has reached a 40-year high. However, this policy may have unintended consequences, including a cooling of the economy and a decrease in housing construction. The Fed's efforts to curb inflation will mainly affect the housing market, driving down sales and construction, which is already at a low level. The US has not been building enough houses over the long term, leading to rising shelter costs. For now, the Fed seems set to prioritize controlling inflation over addressing the housing shortage.

site_title: E-commerce brand Hook Coffee gets physical with first cafe, expands workshops
summary: Hook Coffee, an e-commerce brand, has opened its first permanent coffee bar in Singapore at Lau Pa Sat, marking its offline expansion. The brand had initially targeted the online market, but the pandemic drove it to seek an offline space, citing consumers' desire for in-person experiences. Hook Coffee also offers workshops, which have been digitalized to reach a wider audience, and plans to continue both physical and online workshops. The brand aims to expand its retail and cafe concepts in Singapore, using the new coffee bar as a test bed.

site_title: Heineken sells more beer than expected as Europe reopens
summary: Heineken reported a 5.2% rise in beer sales on a like-for-like basis in the first quarter of 2022, beating forecasts. The increase was driven by the reopening of European bars, with sales in the region almost tripling. Despite uncertainty from the Ukraine conflict, Heineken maintained its 2022 forecast and expects a "stable to modest" improvement to its operating profit margin. The company attributed rising costs and supply chain challenges to its decision to leave Russia, but expects to benefit from hedging positions taken in 2021.

site_title: Global smartphone market had worst drop since virus outbreak
summary: Global smartphone shipments fell 11% in the first quarter, the worst drop since the coronavirus outbreak, due to China's Covid Zero policy impacting demand and supply. Inflation fears, the Russia-Ukraine war, and the Omicron variant also contributed to the slowdown. Despite this, Samsung Electronics reclaimed the lead from Apple with a 24% share, while Chinese vendors Xiaomi, Oppo, and Vivo maintained their top 5 positions. Component shortages are expected to improve soon, providing cost relief to manufacturers, and global smartphone demand is forecast to remain around $527 billion in 2022.

site_title: Japan's trade deficit extends its longest run since 2015 fuelled by weaker yen
summary: Japan's trade deficit extended for an eighth-straight month, driven by higher energy prices and a weaker yen, with imports surging 31.2% and exports growing 14.7% year-over-year. The trade deficit narrowed to 412.4 billion yen, but policymakers warn of negative impacts from costlier imports and higher energy bills. The yen's sharp drop to a 20-year low may compound the impact of energy prices, and economists predict exports will be unable to support a fragile economy.

site_title: For China investors, Covid lockdowns are the biggest threats
summary: China's prolonged Covid lockdowns, particularly in Shanghai, pose a significant threat to its economy and markets, with investors cutting holdings or becoming defensive on stocks. The lockdowns have disrupted production at major companies and have a worrying impact on consumer and business confidence. The government's zero-Covid policy has become a major concern, outweighing external factors, and analysts predict a further economic slowdown if the situation is not brought under control or adjusted. China's stock markets have been the second worst performers globally this year, with a main benchmark index down 17% so far in 2022.

site_title: Apple store workers in US seek vote to form union
summary: Workers at an Apple store in Atlanta, US, have called for a vote to form the tech giant's first union in the US. The "Apple Retail Union" was formed with the support of the CWA union and has secured signatures from over 70% of employees. To proceed, at least 30% of the workers must support the effort. This would be the first union formed at an Apple store in the US, following similar drives at Starbucks and Amazon.

site_title: Singapore-based Stripe users can now accept payments via PayNow
summary: Singapore-based Stripe users can now accept payments via PayNow, a local electronic fund transfer service. This integration allows businesses to generate dynamic QR codes, automatically reconcile transactions, and process refunds with one click. The move is expected to bring PayNow closer to international acceptance, following a 70% adoption rate of Stripe among Singaporean adults since 2017. Online retailers HipVan and JobStreet are among the first to offer PayNow through Stripe, reducing manual transaction management.

site_title: Oil settles mixed on Russia supply, demand concern
summary: Oil prices settled nearly unchanged on Wednesday due to mixed factors, including concerns about economic growth and oil demand stagnation, versus tightening supplies. Brent crude futures rose 45 cents to $106.80 a barrel, while WTI crude futures remained unchanged at $102.75. Supply tightening due to sanctions on Russia and a decline in Russian output has supported prices, but economic concerns and lockdowns in China have weighed on demand.

The Biden administration announced on Friday, April 15, 2022, that it would resume selling leases for new oil and gas drilling on public lands, but would also raise the federal royalties that companies must pay to drill, the first increase in those fees in more than a century. site_title: Climate risk pricings are 'approximations' at best, but they cannot be ignored: Temasek risk head
summary: Temasek's head of risk management, Robert Mainprize, notes that climate risk pricings are "approximations" but cannot be ignored. The company uses a generalised technique to quantify climate risk based on an internal carbon price assumption of US$42 per tonne, despite acknowledging its limitations. Mainprize also highlighted the importance of monitoring information flows outside of standard disclosures to assess companies' progress on their net-zero targets, warning against greenwashing. A report by Tsinghua University's Center for Green Finance Research found that existing climate risk analysis practices have limitations, including limited consideration for adaptation and insufficient scenario types.

site_title: Yen to snap record-losing streak on intervention worries
summary: The Japanese yen briefly hit a 2-decade low on April 20 after the Bank of Japan intervened to defend its ultra-low interest-rate policy, but rebounded in London trading amid concerns about verbal intervention and a potential US-Japan bilateral meeting. Despite the yen's bounce, positioning in derivatives and currency futures suggests further weakness is possible. US Treasury yields surged to 3-year highs, while the US dollar reached a 20-year high against the yen, reaching 129.43 yen in Asian trading.

site_title: Chinese banks hold lending rates as yuan weakness looms
summary: Chinese banks maintained their lending rates for a third month, with the one-year loan prime rate (LPR) at 3.7% and the 5-year rate at 4.6%. The decision was influenced by the Federal Reserve's rate hikes, which fueled concerns of capital leaving China and a weakening yuan. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) may prefer to use quantitative tools to provide liquidity and support growth, with no expected change in benchmark interest rates in the second quarter.

site_title: Credit Suisse signals Q1 loss on Russia, legal provisions
summary: Credit Suisse expects to post a Q1 loss due to a 200 million Swiss francs hit from Russia's invasion of Ukraine and a 600 million franc increase in legal provisions. The bank's results, due April 27, will be negatively affected by counterparty and credit-risks related to the war. This is the latest setback for the bank, which emerged from its worst year since the financial crisis. Credit Suisse has also warned of 350 million franc losses related to a decrease in value of an Allfunds Group stake, which will be offset by provisions related to Archegos and real estate gains.

site_title: Indonesia probes Wilmar staff, trade ministry in CPO case
summary: Indonesia has detained suspects, including a Wilmar International official and a senior trade ministry official, in a corruption case involving palm oil exports. The case involves approval of export permits that didn't meet requirements and a lack of local palm oil distribution, leading to high cooking oil prices. Attorney General ST Burhanuddin said there is strong indication of criminal corrupt action, which has affected the public, especially the poor. The government has taken measures to safeguard local supply, including deploying police surveillance and raising export levies for palm oil.

site_title: Singapore stocks close higher in line with other regional markets
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.9% to 3,335.32, with 264 gainers outnumbering 192 decliners. Key gains were led by Genting Singapore, while Keppel DC Reit declined 5.9% after a Q1 business update. Regional markets mostly ended higher, except for Chinese equities, which fell 1.3% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index dropped 0.4%.

site_title: Five more buildings opt in on Marina Bay district cooling network
summary: SP GROUP's Marina Bay district cooling network has secured 5 new buildings, including 8 Shenton Way, 80 Anson Road, IOI Central Boulevard Towers, Marina Bay Sands Integrated Resort Expansion, and NS Square, bringing the total to 28 buildings. The network, which reduces carbon emissions by 19,439 tonnes annually, will be expanded by 30% to 70,000 refrigerant tonnes by 2024. The new developments will save up to 15% on air-conditioning costs and free up prime space for other uses.

site_title: ATP and WTA join hands to launch joint mobile app
summary: The ATP and WTA tours have launched a joint mobile app, "ATP WTA Live," allowing fans to follow both men's and women's tennis on a single platform. The app, replacing existing apps, will feature official scores and results, as well as behind-the-scenes content. Despite the collaboration, the app will not include scores from Grand Slam tournaments. The move aims to reduce fragmentation and promote a unified tennis experience, with a broader strategic vision for the sport.

site_title: Keppel Reit Q1 distributable income up 4.3% to S$53.8m
summary: Keppel Reit reported a 4.3% increase in Q1 distributable income to S$53.8 million, driven by the acquisition of Keppel Bay Tower in May last year. Property income rose 6.7% and net property income increased 9.9%. The Reit's portfolio occupancy stood at 95.1%, slightly lower than the same period last year. Despite expected interest rate rises, the Reit's manager noted reduced all-in interest rates and expects Grade A properties to benefit from improved office market fundamentals.

site_title: Australian scientists to power Tesla on 15,000km trip with printed solar panels
summary: Australian scientists are testing printed solar panels to power a Tesla on a 15,100km journey, starting in September. The panels, made from a lightweight, laminated plastic, are 18 meters long and can be made at a cost of under $10 per square meter. The "Charge Around Australia" project aims to demonstrate the potential of printed solar panels for other applications, including remote locations and space. The team plans to visit 70 schools during the 84-day journey, sparking discussions about electric vehicles and climate change.

site_title: Saudi wealth fund weighs stake in Thyssenkrupp’s hydrogen unit
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund is considering buying a stake in Thyssenkrupp's hydrogen unit, Nucera, as the oil-rich kingdom shifts towards greener energy production. The sovereign wealth fund is studying a potential investment, which could value Nucera at up to $5.4 billion. This move aligns with Saudi Arabia's ambition to become the world's largest exporter of hydrogen, a key element in reducing emissions from industrial processes. A deal would support the kingdom's efforts to diversify its energy portfolio and prepare for a post-oil future.

site_title: Investments in China's 3 core growth engines hint at rising recessionary pressures
summary: China's Q1 GDP growth exceeded expectations at 4.8%, but investments in infrastructure, manufacturing, and real estate development hint at rising recessionary pressures. Analysts warn of a sharp decline in activity due to ongoing Omicron waves and lockdowns, with Goldman Sachs economist Andrew Tilton predicting a soft start to Q2 and Nomura economist Lu Ting forecasting a decline in activity. The IMF has also cut China's 2022 GDP growth estimate to 4.4% due to concerns over Beijing's zero-Covid policy.

site_title: Canadian inflation blows past expectations, spiking to 6.7%
summary: Canada's inflation rate surged to a 3-decade high of 6.7% in March, exceeding expectations and prompting the Bank of Canada to consider further interest rate hikes. This marks the highest inflation rate since January 1991. The increase in prices, driven by soaring food and energy costs, may be the peak of the inflation run-up, but policymakers are concerned about prolonged price gains and potential hardening of inflation expectations.

site_title: YouTube shuts channel of Hong Kong's leadership candidate
summary: YouTube and Facebook have taken action against Hong Kong's sole chief executive candidate, John Lee, by shutting down his campaign channel and preventing him from using their payments services due to US sanctions. The move is seen as an unusual action by the social media platforms to comply with US law, but Lee claims it's an act of bullying. Despite this, Lee has already surpassed the threshold of support needed to win the election, set to take place on July 1. The action is part of a broader trend of foreign powers interfering in Hong Kong's elections, with Beijing backing Lee's candidacy.

site_title: Canadian inflation blows past expectations, spiking to 6.7%
summary: Canada's inflation rate surged to a 3-decade high of 6.7% in March, exceeding expectations and prompting the Bank of Canada to consider aggressive interest rate hikes. This is the highest inflation rate since January 1991 and surpasses the median economist estimate of 6.1%. The increase is attributed to soaring food and energy costs, particularly petrol prices, which rose 12% in March and 40% over the year. The Bank of Canada's inflation forecast has been revised upward, with policymakers expected to raise interest rates further in coming weeks.

site_title: Mapletree Commercial Trust H2 DPU down 3% to S$0.0514
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) reported a 3.4% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0514 for the half-year ended Mar 31, down from S$0.0532 a year earlier. Gross revenue fell 1.8% to S$255.8 million, and net property income declined 3.3% to S$198.8 million. Despite this, tenant sales rebounded by 10.3% in the fourth quarter and 15.6% for the full-year, driven by the easing of Covid-19 measures. Unitholders will receive the distribution on Jun 3.

site_title: Singapore remains key to Gojek's plans, says its GM
summary: Singapore remains a crucial hub for Gojek's operations, with the company's general manager, Lien Choong Luen, stating that the city-state is key to Gojek's journey. Despite its smaller size compared to other South-east Asian markets, Singapore boasts mature and sophisticated riders and drivers, making it an ideal location for Gojek's data science models. The company has also established itself as a major player in the Singapore ride-hailing market, with a "comfortable No 2" market share. With its public listing behind it, Gojek is now focused on investing in its back-end infrastructure and talent, with Lien describing its future in Singapore as "promising".

site_title: Sheng Siong aims to open at least 3 new stores every year over next 3-5 years
summary: Sheng Siong aims to open 3-5 new stores annually over 3-5 years, expanding its presence in Singapore and Kunming, China. The supermarket chain plans to look for retail spaces in new and existing public housing estates, particularly areas without existing presence. This expansion strategy is part of the company's efforts to continue growing its footprint in the region.

site_title: Venice Biennale: Singapore spotlight
summary: The Venice Biennale, a premier arts event, features Singapore's representative Shubigi Rao with an ambitious exhibit examining book destruction's impact on knowledge. The Singapore pavilion is designed as a paper maze, featuring a world of pages and text. Additionally, the Red Dot Design Museum reopens with an exhibition of 2021/2022 Red Dot Award winners, while Gucci's Love Parade collection offers fashion inspiration.

site_title: Singapore consumer businesses in anxious limbo under Shanghai lockdown
summary: Shanghai, China's financial hub, is slowly reopening after a prolonged lockdown, with supermarkets and factories already open. However, shopping malls and retail brands face uncertainty, with some predicting a reopening as late as May 1. Consumer businesses in Singapore, which has experience with lockdowns, expect at least a month for normalcy to return. Despite this, some companies remain optimistic about the longer-term recovery, citing China's large market and potential government stimulus packages.

site_title: Sanofi's vaccine production facility to strengthen Singapore's future pandemic readiness
summary: Sanofi has broken ground for a vaccine production facility in Singapore, expected to create up to 200 local jobs and increase production capacity. The modular facility can produce 3-4 different vaccines simultaneously, including mRNA, enzymes, and monoclonal antibodies. The $638 million investment, set for completion in 2025, aims to enhance Singapore's capacity for manufacturing vaccines and prepare for future pandemics. The facility is seen as a strategic move to strengthen the biopharmaceutical industry and manufacturing sector in Singapore.

site_title: New Zealand is 'fully open for business', says trade minister
summary: New Zealand has announced it is fully open for business, easing pandemic restrictions and removing vaccine pass mandates, allowing fully vaccinated travelers from visa-waiver countries, including Singapore, to enter without quarantine. Trade Minister Damien O'Connor urged companies to invest in New Zealand, citing a shortage of skills and labor in certain areas. The country is seeking to strengthen bilateral trade and investment with Singapore, with a focus on climate change and sustainability, and has added a new fifth pillar to its Enhanced Partnership.

site_title: Patriots vs globalists replaces the left-right divide
summary: French presidential election marks a shift away from the traditional left-right divide, with nationalists and internationalists emerging as the dominant camps. The collapse of centre-right and centre-left parties in the first round, where far-left candidate Jean-Luc Mélenchon and right-wing candidate Marine Le Pen advanced, sets the stage for a final round between Emmanuel Macron and Le Pen. Macron and Le Pen reject the traditional left-right labels, instead framing the election as a choice between patriots and globalists, with Le Pen advocating for a more nationalist and isolationist approach.

site_title: How will shorter leases on commercial sites shape the future of work?
summary: Singapore is considering shorter leases for commercial sites to drive workplace transformations in the post-Covid era. The proposed strategy, unveiled by Second Minister for National Development Indranee Rajah, aims to provide businesses with more flexibility and allow the city to adapt to fast-changing economic trends. Shorter leases may lead to more innovative and sustainable commercial buildings, and could benefit from channeling cost savings into better quality design and technology. However, shorter leases may limit a building's economic lifespan and reduce upfront investment outlays on land, potentially impacting institutional investors and Reits.

site_title: How much digitalisation must the F&B industry go through to be 'future-ready'?
summary: Singapore's food and beverage industry, severely impacted by the Covid-19 pandemic, is undergoing a digital transformation to become 'future-ready'. Digitalisation has provided a lifeline for businesses, with the introduction of e-commerce, digital tools, and Industry 4.0 technologies. The industry is now shifting towards automation, smart restaurants, and the Internet of Things (IoT) to streamline workflows, optimise manpower, and reduce costs. With governmental support and increasing accessibility of technology, digitalisation is becoming a necessity for F&B enterprises to remain competitive, offering greater room for innovation and improving the consumer experience.

site_title: Hundreds of Rohingya escape Malaysian detention centre
summary: Hundreds of Rohingya refugees broke out of a Malaysian detention centre in Penang state early Wednesday, with over 100 still at large. The escape occurred after a riot at the Sungai Bakap Temporary Immigration Depot. Six people died in the chaos, and 362 were re-arrested. The incident highlights the lack of provisions for refugees in Malaysia, with the majority being Rohingya fleeing from Myanmar.

site_title: REC clarifies reports regarding charges filed over India dispute
summary: MAINBOARD-LISTED Raffles Education Corporation (REC) has clarified reports regarding a charge sheet filed against its directors and top management over a dispute in India. REC stated that there is no basis for the allegations, which included attempts to grab land and buildings, and a "criminal conspiracy" to defame Educomp Group. The company has not received any summons or notice and is taking legal advice to respond to the article and allegations. REC believes the charges are a response to pending disputes and shares closed up 1.5% on Wednesday.

site_title: Thailand's hospital profits may treble in Q1 on Covid, but cases could peak soon: CGS-CIMB
summary: Thailand's hospitals are expected to report a year-on-year spike in Q1 financials due to the recent surge in Covid-19 infections, with 6 hospitals' aggregate recurring net profit potentially tripling. However, cases may peak soon, with analysts predicting a surge in cases over the Thai New Year holidays and a subsequent decline in late April. The Thai healthcare sector index has risen 19% since the Russia-Ukraine crisis, leading to a downgrade of CGS-CIMB's call on the Thai hospital sector to "neutral" from "overweight".

site_title: Break down digital-divide barriers to drive growth in S-E Asia
summary: South-east Asia's digital economy is emerging stronger than expected, with the Internet economy set to surpass US$1 trillion by 2030. However, many countries in the region are still struggling to bridge the digital divide, with an estimated 30% of the adult population (150 million adults) being digitally excluded. To address this, key recommendations include increasing awareness about the benefits of digital inclusion, promoting public-private collaboration, and implementing policies to support digital literacy and upskilling. Governments must seize the moment to accelerate digital inclusion and build an ecosystem that will power the region's economic recovery.

site_title: Retail sector on firmer path to recovery
summary: The retail sector in Singapore is on a firmer path to recovery, driven by the easing of travel curbs and the relaxation of safe distancing measures. Footfall is expected to pick up, benefiting shopping malls in popular areas like Orchard Road, and tenants may expand their footprint. Rental reversions are also expected to improve, with prime retail rents rising 2-4% in 2022. However, suburban malls may still face challenges due to residents' potential exodus during school holidays. Analysts predict a gradual recovery, with vacancy rates dipping as the year progresses.

site_title: Ensuring that sustainability efforts actually bear fruit
summary: A recent UN report highlights the worsening climate crisis, despite global commitments, as extreme weather events accelerate and vulnerable populations are disproportionately affected. Sustainability efforts are hindered by outdated solutions, including inaccurate carbon reporting, which relies on traditional analogue methods. Blockchain technology can provide transparency, accuracy, and integrity in managing carbon assets and liabilities, enabling more precise tracking of carbon emissions and facilitating efforts towards net-zero. The industry must adopt digital technologies to catch up with its sustainability goals, prioritizing equitability and accountability in carbon emissions tracking.

site_title: No surrender in Mariupol as Russian deadline expires; refugees top 5 million
summary: Russia's deadline for Ukrainian troops in Mariupol to surrender expired without a mass capitulation, with the commander of a unit believed to be holding out saying his forces could survive just days or hours. The number of refugees fleeing Ukraine since Russia's invasion on February 24 has exceeded 5 million, with over half being children. The UN and Ukrainian officials have criticized Russia's actions, with the UN saying the siege of Mariupol is a "humanitarian catastrophe" and the world watching the "murder of children online and remains silent."

images.alt_text: A Ukrainian soldier sits atop a tank passing the Lysychansk Oil Refinery (not pictured) after if was hit by a missile at Lysychansk, Luhansk region, Ukraine, April 16, 2022. REUTERS/Marko Djurica

site_title: Higher input costs, interest rates raise challenges for green energy transition
summary: A surge in inflation, driven by factors such as global economic activity, supply chain snarls, and war, has raised costs for green energy technologies, sparking concerns about the affordability of a renewable energy transition. The International Energy Agency notes that rising commodity prices have increased production costs by 10-25%, while interest rates on the rise pose another challenge for clean energy manufacturers and developers. Governments may need to step up with fiscal incentives and subsidies to support the transition to net-zero emissions, as the cost of green energy becomes more expensive in the short run.

site_title: Earth Day: how corporate leaders can break through the inertia
summary: Corporate leaders can break through the inertia to address environmental challenges on Earth Day. Despite some businesses adopting sustainable practices, a recent UN report found climate change impacts worse than expected, with extreme weather events and food shortages. To drive change, leaders must set bold ESG goals, engage stakeholders, and value introspection. They must also embody the values of their organisations, empower employees, and lead cultural change. Those who do will be rewarded with the capacity to balance multiple strategic objectives and be successful in the future, as regulations will eventually catch up with those that fail to act.

site_title: Wimbledon to ban Russian and Belarus players: report
summary: Wimbledon organisers plan to ban Russian and Belarus players from this year's tournament due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine, despite previous neutrality agreements. The decision follows talks with the British government and comes after other Grand Slam events, including the Davis Cup, have already imposed similar restrictions. Russian and Belarus players, including men's world number two Daniil Medvedev, are likely to be barred from all British grass-court tournaments this summer. The Lawn Tennis Association has confirmed it will follow Wimbledon's lead.

site_title: Netflix shares plunge more than 30% after massive subscriber loss
summary: Netflix's shares plummeted 39% on Wednesday, extending a year-to-date decline of 64%, after reporting a sharp decline in subscribers and projecting another 2 million subscriber losses in the second quarter. The company's massive subscriber loss of 200,000 in the first quarter marked the first time it had shed subscribers since 2011. Analysts have downgraded the stock, citing rising bond yields and increased competition, with the company now having the lowest number of buy ratings since 2015.

site_title: LHN eyes growth and valuations with spin-off and listing of logistics arm
summary: LHN Limited, a Catalist-listed company, is spinning off its logistics arm, LHN Logistics, to gain clarity on its valuation and growth potential. The move, described as a restructuring, aims to allow the logistics unit to grow independently and raise funds on its own. LHN Logistics plans to raise S$5 million from a placement of shares and will list on Apr 29. The company expects to use the funds to finance an ISO tank depot, expand its transportation fleet, and acquire moving equipment. The spin-off is expected to provide a clearer identity for the company, potentially leading to better valuation.

site_title: BMW's new flagship EV has a private screening room in the back seat
summary: BMW unveiled its new flagship electric vehicle, the i7, featuring a private screening room in the back seat, starting at 135,900 euros. The car boasts a luxurious interior, more legroom, and a range of 625 kilometers. However, BMW is behind rivals like Mercedes and Tesla in terms of range and availability. To catch up, the company is using a different technology strategy, leveraging the same architecture as its fossil fuel-powered sibling, providing greater flexibility to adapt to regional EV demands.

site_title: Ukraine's war efforts gain an unlikely source of funding: memes
summary: Ukraine's war efforts have gained an unexpected source of funding: internet memes and merchandise. A Canadian journalist created a website in February, featuring internet memes, which raised over $1.5 million in just days. The memes, such as the Virgin Mary holding an antitank missile, have become a symbol of support for Ukraine, helping to fight Russian disinformation and raising funds for charities and the military. The merchandise sales have been surprising, with many people buying items without knowing much about Ukraine before the conflict. The internet-generated support has helped shift the public image of Ukraine from a relatively unknown country to a plucky underdog fighting against powerful forces.

site_title: Russian players to be barred from competing at Wimbledon: report
summary: Russia's players will not compete at Wimbledon due to Moscow's invasion of Ukraine, according to a report. The All England Lawn Tennis Club is banning Russian players, including world No. 2 Daniil Medvedev and Andrey Rublev, from the tournament. The decision affects men's and women's draws, with Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova also impacted. The ban comes amid international pressure and follows a ban on Russia and Belarus from international team competitions. Wimbledon has not banned athletes from countries since after World War Two.

site_title: World Bank sees economies reducing dependence on Russia for energy, on China for supply chains
summary: World Bank President David Malpass expects major economies to reduce dependence on Russia for energy and China for supply chains, but notes cross-border trade and investment will continue. This shift is seen as necessary to address overdependence and fragmentation of the global economy. Malpass argues that regional trade growth will increase, and markets will remain open, despite adjustments. He also expresses confidence that global productivity will not be negatively affected by this shift.

site_title: Philippines' poll body throws out last petition against Marcos
summary: The Philippines' Commission on Elections (Comelec) dismissed the final petition calling for Ferdinand Marcos Jr.'s disqualification from the May 9 election, clearing a major legal hurdle in his path to the presidency. The ruling found no tax evasion despite Marcos' repeated failure to file income tax returns. Five other cases were earlier dismissed, and the petitioners did not respond to a request for comment. Marcos has consistently topped opinion polls, but his lead over rival Leni Robredo narrowed in a recent survey, and analysts say his popularity may be impacted by his refusal to pay a tax bill on his father's estate.

site_title: Sales of US previously owned homes fall to lowest since 2020
summary: US previously owned home sales fell 2.7% in March to 5.77 million, the lowest since June 2020, due to historically low inventory and rising mortgage rates. Mortgage rates are over 5%, the highest since 2018, curbing purchases. The median selling price rose 15% to a record $375,300, with cash sales and investors making up a significant portion of the market. The housing market is feeling the impact of rising rates and inflation, leading to concerns about affordability and further price increases.

site_title: US: Nasdaq leads Wall Street higher as yields retreat
summary: US stocks rose for a second straight session on April 20, 2022, led by the tech-heavy Nasdaq, which climbed 45.7 points to 13,665.37. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also gained, with the Dow rising 51.5 points and the S&P 500 increasing 10.1 points. Easing Treasury yields and optimistic earnings helped counter a decline in Netflix shares, contributing to the overall market lift.

site_title: New Zealand is 'fully open for business', says Trade Minister
summary: New Zealand Trade Minister Damien O'Connor has announced the country is "fully open for business" after easing pandemic restrictions. From May 1, fully vaccinated travelers from visa-waiver countries, including Singapore, can enter New Zealand without quarantine. Minister O'Connor urged companies from Singapore and beyond to invest in New Zealand, citing a shortage of skills and labor. The country is also strengthening its partnership with Singapore, including a new climate change and green economy pillar.

site_title: Yangzijiang spin-off gets shareholder nod, to list on Apr 28 as STI constituent
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's proposed spin-off of its investment segment, Yangzijiang Financial Holding (YZJFH), has received overwhelming approval from shareholders, with 100% approval rate. YZJFH will list on the Singapore Exchange on April 28, adding to the Straits Times Index (STI) and other indices. The move aims to unlock value and reduce conglomerate discount. YZJFH will be helmed by Ren Yuanlin, son of Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's executive chairman, Ren Letian.

site_title: China’s local land sales revenue tumbles 27% in Q1
summary: China's local land sales revenue plummeted 27.4% in Q1 to 1.2 trillion yuan, down from the same period last year. This slump in revenue signals a worsening housing market, impacting government finances. China's real estate sector contracted for the third consecutive quarter due to the ongoing Covid-19 outbreak and property slump. Fiscal spending rose 8.3% to 6.36 trillion yuan, while fiscal revenue increased 8.6% to 6.2 trillion yuan.

site_title: Sales of US previously owned homes fall to lowest since 2020
summary: US sales of previously owned homes fell 2.7% in March to 5.77 million, the lowest since June 2020, due to historically low inventory and rising mortgage rates. The median selling price reached a record $375,300, with cash sales making up 28% of transactions. First-time buyers accounted for 30% of sales, while investors made up 18%. Rising mortgage rates, coupled with inflation, are expected to continue curbing purchases, according to NAR's chief economist.

site_title: For China investors, Covid lockdowns are the biggest threats
summary: China's prolonged lockdowns in major cities, driven by its zero-Covid policy, pose a significant threat to its economy and markets. Global fund managers are cutting holdings or turning defensive on stocks due to the worrying toll on people and businesses. China's stock markets have performed poorly this year, with the main benchmark index down 17% since January, and the economy slowed sharply in March. The lockdowns are seen as a persistent risk, unlike the Russia-Ukraine crisis, and may impact China's GDP growth and policymakers' pressure.

site_title: Border reopening is godsend to Singapore retail space landlords
summary: Singapore's retail sector is experiencing a resurgence, driven by the easing of travel curbs and the relaxation of safe management measures. Footfall is expected to increase as vaccinated individuals can dine together, boosting tenant sales and rental reversions. Prime retail rents are forecast to rise 2-4% for 2022, with Knight Frank predicting a stabilization in rental reversions. However, elevated oil prices and higher interest debt costs may pose risks to landlords. Analysts also expect vacancy rates to dip as the year progresses, with suburban malls benefiting from the shift to endemic living.

site_title: Singapore remains key to Gojek’s plans, says its GM
summary: GoTo Group's General Manager for Singapore, Lien Choong Luen, emphasizes the importance of Singapore to the company's plans, despite being a smaller market compared to Indonesia. Singapore's mature riders and drivers provide a high demand for data science models, making it a key location for GoTo's regional functions. Gojek has carved out a significant share of the Singapore ride-hailing market, and Lien foresees a "promising" future for the company in the city-state.

site_title: Climate risk pricings ‘approximations’ at best, but not to be ignored: Temasek risk head
summary: Temasek's head of risk management, Robert Mainprize, stated that climate risk pricings are "approximations" but crucial to address, despite being a "small step" towards a better approach. A report by Tsinghua University's Center for Green Finance Research found limitations in existing climate risk analysis practices, including limited consideration for adaptation and insufficient scenario types. Mainprize emphasized the importance of monitoring information flows and using various techniques to verify companies' progress on net-zero targets, as greenwashing is a significant issue.

site_title: Oil rebounds as supply concerns dominate
summary: Oil prices rebounded on Wednesday, April 20, as US oil inventories dropped and concerns over tighter supplies from Russia and Libya drove a recovery from the previous session's sharp losses. Brent crude futures rose 1.4% to $108.71 a barrel, while WTI crude futures rose 1.5% to $104.06. The tighter supply outlook is driven by sanctions on Russia and outages in Libya, while a softer global economic outlook and ongoing Covid lockdowns in China weigh on prices.

site_title: UK sets target of 40% women on company boards
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority has set a target of 40% women on company boards, with at least one senior position (chair, CEO, or CFO) held by a woman. The rule applies to listed companies, with companies required to report annually on their diversity progress. The goal aims to enhance transparency and drive progress in diversity at the top of companies. The rule, effective from April 1, 2022, aims to increase representation and hold companies accountable for diversity.

site_title: Shell urges shareholders to reject activist’s climate resolution
summary: Shell urges shareholders to reject an activist group's climate resolution, citing that adopting it could harm the company's energy transition strategy and governance. The resolution, proposed by Follow This, wants Shell's policies to align with the Paris climate accord. Despite receiving 30% of votes in favor, the resolution is still not enough to pass. Shell will instead publish a non-binding energy transition progress report to convince investors that it's already taking steps to reduce emissions. The company aims to reach net-zero carbon by 2050.

site_title: Abbott profit jumps on Covid testing demand, strong medical device sales
summary: Abbott Laboratories reported a rise in quarterly profit driven by strong demand for Covid-19 tests and medical device sales. The company's Covid-19 test kits generated $3.3 billion in revenue, with total diagnostics business sales growing 31.7%. Abbott forecasts $4.5 billion in Covid-19 testing sales for the year, largely in the first half. The company reiterated its full-year adjusted profit per share forecast of at least $4.70.

site_title: McDonald's sales of its plant-based burger get a boost from Peta stunt
summary: McDonald's plant-based burger, the McPlant, has seen a short-term sales boost after a marketing stunt by Peta, an animal rights group. Peta worked with McDonald's operators in Texas and California to buy the burgers in bulk for a giveaway, helping to increase sales. The stunt aims to promote the McPlant as a way to reduce animal suffering. While the sales boost is encouraging, analysts say the product's long-term success depends on sustained demand, and the McPlant is still in the testing phase.

site_title: East Timor's Ramos-Horta takes commanding lead in presidential vote
summary: East Timor's presidential candidate Jose Ramos-Horta secured a commanding lead in the second round of the election, winning 62.09% of the votes, according to the country's elections agency. He will become the country's next president, with incumbent President Francisco "Lu Olo" Guterres trailing at 37.91%. Ramos-Horta, a Nobel laureate and former foreign minister, will be sworn in on May 20, the 20th anniversary of East Timor's independence.

site_title: Netflix tumbles as 200,000 users exit for first drop in decade
summary: Netflix experienced its first quarterly subscriber loss in a decade, with 200,000 users exiting the platform. The streaming giant reported a 26% drop in premarket trading, wiping out nearly $40 billion in market value. In response, Netflix plans to introduce an advertising-supported option and crack down on password sharing. The company will also curb spending on films and TV shows. Analysts and competitors are taking notice, with shares of Disney and Warner Bros. Discovery declining. Despite this setback, Netflix remains the largest streaming service worldwide and expects to add customers this year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 12.61 points to 1,593.75, closing higher on Wednesday. The index saw 3.111 billion lots traded worth RM2.602 billion, with gainers outnumbering losers 573 to 386.

site_title: Sri Lanka seeks bridge loans as IMF aid will take 6 months
summary: Sri Lanka is seeking up to $4 billion in emergency aid to address power cuts, fuel shortages, and import costs, as a comprehensive IMF package may take six months to materialize. The country is reaching out to nations like India, Japan, and the Gulf Cooperation Council for bilateral credit, with Foreign Minister GL Peiris stating that talks with the IMF are going well. Meanwhile, islandwide protests turned deadly, with police killing at least one person and wounded several others, as President Gotabaya Rajapaksa's ouster is sought.

images.alt_text: Business leaders in Britain and beyond warned on Wednesday of catastrophic job losses and chaos at ports if the country does not agree a European Union withdrawal, turning up the heat on politicians to deliver clarity.

site_title: World Bank sees economies reducing dependence on Russia for energy, on China for supply chains
summary: World Bank President David Malpass expects major economies to reduce their dependence on Russia for energy and China for supply chains, citing the need for regional trade growth. Despite this shift, Malpass believes trade and investment across borders will continue, arguing it will not subtract from global productivity. He also notes that fragmentation into separate blocs would allow China to move into other sectors, potentially benefiting the country. Malpass emphasizes the importance of keeping markets open to address the current food security crisis, stating that the world will continue trading.

site_title: Why a Chinese security deal in the Pacific could ripple through the world
summary: China has signed a sweeping security agreement with the Solomon Islands, a move that could have significant implications for global stability. The deal, which has been shrouded in secrecy, grants China broad powers to intervene in the country in the event of threats to its investments or interests. The agreement is seen as a precedent for other nations, raising concerns about the global contest between democracy and autocracy. China's growing presence in the Pacific, with a potential military base in the Solomon Islands, has sparked warnings from Australia and the US about the potential for China to rebalance the global order in its favor.

site_title: China plane crash report does not identify cause
summary: China's preliminary investigation into the country's deadliest plane crash in about 30 years, which killed 132 people, has found no cause for the crash. The Civil Aviation Administration of China reported that flight and cabin crews' qualifications, maintenance staff, and aircraft airworthiness certificate were all valid. Two damaged flight recorders are being analyzed in the US for data restoration and analysis, but no abnormalities in navigation and monitoring equipment were found. The investigation deadline was met, but the cause of the crash remains unknown.

site_title: Indonesia allows airlines to raise fares as fuel prices soar
summary: Indonesia has allowed airlines to raise economy class fares due to surging fuel prices, aiming to ensure airline operations' continuity. Fuel surcharges can exceed the government-regulated price ceiling by up to 10% for jet planes and 20% for propeller planes. The measures will be evaluated every 3 months, and airlines can maintain unchanged tariffs if they choose. The move comes ahead of the Eid al-Fitr festival, where millions of Indonesians travel, and aims to prevent further pressure on inflation, which was already at a two-year high of 2.64%.

site_title: Anxiety continues for Singapore consumer businesses under Shanghai lockdown
summary: Singapore consumer businesses in Shanghai expect a 2-week delay in reopening and longer for normalcy, following the city's prolonged lockdown. Supermarkets and factories have reopened, but shopping malls and retail brands remain uncertain. Experts predict at least a month for normalcy and stabilisation, with China's policy of zero-Covid hindering business optimism. Despite this, some companies remain optimistic, with BreadTalk and Putien's founder expressing hope for an imminent reopening and Charles & Keith preparing for reopening with new product launches.
