site_title: Keppel Reit Q1 distributable income up 4.3% to S$53.8m
summary: Keppel Reit reported a 4.3% increase in first-quarter distributable income to S$53.8 million, driven by the acquisition of Keppel Bay Tower in May last year. Property income rose 6.7% and net property income climbed 9.9%. The Reit's portfolio occupancy stood at 95.1%, slightly lower than the same period last year. Despite expected interest rate rises, the manager expects Grade A properties to benefit from improved office market fundamentals.

site_title: How will shorter leases on commercial sites shape the future of work?
summary: Singapore plans to roll out commercial sites with shorter leases, ranging from 10 to 30 years, to drive workplace transformations post-pandemic. This strategy aims to provide businesses with flexibility, allowing them to adapt to changing economic trends. Shorter leases may impact commercial real estate, but developers may invest in better-quality buildings, and rents will remain dependent on factors like location and quality. Existing commercial buildings with shorter balance leases will face pressure to redevelop or refurbish to stay competitive. The government's plan is expected to reshape the city's physical landscape and capital investments, cementing Singapore's position as a financial hub.

site_title: Singapore spotlight at Venice Biennale
summary: Singaporean artist-writer-filmmaker Shubigi Rao's exhibit at the Venice Biennale explores the history of book destruction and its impact on knowledge. The exhibit transforms the Singapore pavilion into a paper maze, inviting visitors to navigate through pages and text. Meanwhile, the Red Dot Design Museum reopens with an exhibition of 2021/2022 Red Dot Awards winners, and fashion inspiration can be found in Gucci's Love Parade collection.

site_title: Cathay to launch major corporate sustainable aviation fuel programme
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways is launching a major corporate sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) programme in Asia, partnering with 8 clients to promote the use of SAF on flights from Hong Kong International Airport. The programme, which uses fuel made from used cooking oil and animal fat waste, aims to reduce the airline's carbon footprint. The move follows growing demand for SAF and airlines' efforts to meet net-zero carbon emission targets. Cathay's CEO, Augustus Tang, described the programme as a "first step in sending an important demand signal to the SAF supply chain."

site_title: Goldman leads US$51m funding in Japan's Rapyuta Robotics
summary: Goldman Sachs led a US$51 million funding round in Rapyuta Robotics, a Tokyo-based company developing autonomous machines for logistics. The investment, part of a US$81 million raised in three funding rounds, will support the development of warehouse robots, cloud robotics, and research. Rapyuta's robots have seen a doubling of productivity in logistics operations within 5 months, with the company targeting further growth in the rapidly expanding industry. Goldman Sachs has committed at least US$30 billion to Asian alternative assets over the next 5 years.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore-based businesses using Stripe can now accept payments via PayNow, a local electronic fund transfer service. Sanofi broke ground for a vaccine production facility in Singapore, expected to create 200 local jobs. Environmentally friendly properties showed resilience during the pandemic, with smaller drops in valuations. LHN Limited plans to spin off and list its logistics arm, aiming to grow and increase investor clarity. Sheng Siong aims to open 3-5 new stores annually over the next 3-5 years. Singapore shares closed higher on Wednesday, with the STI up 0.9%.

site_title: Mapletree Commercial Trust H2 DPU down 3% to S$0.0514
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) reported a 3.4% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0514 for the half-year ended Mar 31, down from S$0.0532 a year earlier. Despite this, VivoCity tenant sales in the fourth quarter ended Mar 31 recovered to pre-Covid levels, with a 10.3% year-on-year increase. The Reit's net property income (NPI) fell 3.3% to S$198.8 million, while distributable income fell 5.2% to S$154.8 million.

site_title: China exports to North Korea surge with edible oil, wheat flour in demand as trade resumes
summary: China's exports to North Korea surged in January-March, with sales of edible oil, wheat flour, and pharmaceutical compounds increasing after a COVID-induced pause in trade. The total value of exports reached $173.4 million, nearly recovering to the $215.3 million figure for the first quarter of 2020. Imports also more than quintupled to $23.5 million. The top export items were edible oil and wheat flour, with North Korea buying $16.4 million of soybean oil and $4.3 million of wheat flour. This rebound in trade comes as the US urges further sanctions on North Korea over its ballistic missile launches.

site_title: Singapore stocks close higher on Wednesday; STI up 0.9%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.9% to 3,335.32 on Wednesday, driven by gains from companies like Genting Singapore. The broader market saw 264 gainers out of 192 decliners, with 2.1 billion securities changing hands. This follows overnight gains on Wall Street. In contrast, Chinese equities declined, with the Shanghai Composite Index falling 1.3%.

site_title: Japan opens biggest esports park to level up competitive gaming
summary: Japan's largest esports park, Red Tokyo Tower, has opened in Tokyo, aiming to transform the country into a competitive gaming champion. The park offers space for esports competitions, motor racing, virtual reality, and games simulators. Japan's esports market has been slow to grow, favoring home-grown RPG games and mobile titles, with a loyal fanbase for Nintendo's Switch device. The country's esports reticence contrasts with neighboring South Korea and China, which have strong competitive teams in multiplayer PC titles. The growth of streaming on platforms like Twitch has driven global esports revenue to near $1.38 billion this year.

site_title: China buys cheap Russian coal as world shuns Moscow
summary: China significantly increased imports of steel-making coal from Russia in March, procuring the fuel at discounted rates as other nations shun Moscow due to the war in Ukraine. Imports jumped to 1.4 million tons, more than doubling from the same period last year. China is taking advantage of lower prices from Russia, despite international roadblocks, to meet its steel-making needs. The country's domestic coal production is low quality and unsuitable for steel mills, making overseas imports necessary.

site_title: BT's Top Stories from Last Week
summary: Singapore's MAS has tightened criteria for family offices to qualify for tax incentives, requiring a minimum fund size of S$10 million. Thailand will scrap Covid-19 RT-PCR tests for visitors, and vaccinated travelers won't need hotel reservations. Meanwhile, demand for older flats in Singapore is rising due to frustration with Build-To-Order (BTO) flats, which are heavily subsidized. Standard Chartered has reduced its Singapore office space by half, and 9,000 HDB flats and private homes are set to rise from a Keppel Club site.

site_title: Shanghai hopes Covid tide turning, with fewer cases outside quarantine areas
summary: Shanghai reported no new Covid-19 infections outside quarantine areas, sparking hopes that the city's pandemic battle is turning a corner. The city's 25 million people have been struggling with lockdown measures, income loss, and poor conditions, but 7.85 million can now return to factories or walk outside, a rise of 2 million from last week. Authorities are ramping up testing and transfers of positive cases to quarantine centers, with the goal of stopping the spread of Covid-19 outside quarantined areas.

site_title: Higher input costs and interest rates raise challenges for green energy transition
summary: Higher input costs, particularly for metals and minerals, and rising interest rates are challenging the green energy transition. The cost of renewable energy production, such as solar and wind, has increased by 10-25% due to rising commodity prices and freight charges. This could lead to higher energy bills and a more expensive transition to net-zero emissions. Economists warn that the shift to a greener economy may be more expensive in the short run, and governments may need to provide fiscal incentives and subsidies to support the transition.

site_title: Singtel prices first digital sustainability-linked bond with UOB, ADDX
summary: Singtel successfully priced its first digital sustainability-linked bond with UOB and private markets platform ADDX, raising US$100 million for 5 years. The bond carries a 3.56% fixed coupon rate and matures on April 27, 2027. If Singtel fails to meet its 2025 greenhouse gas emissions target, it will invest at least 0.25% of the bond's principal in green efforts. The net proceeds will be used to fund its ordinary course of business, with Singtel shares closing 0.8% higher at S$2.60.

images.alt_text: 291 Serangoon Road is on the market through an EOI, which closes on Feb 21.

site_title: Six freehold Balestier Road shophouses for sale
summary: Six freehold shophouses on Balestier Road in Singapore have been listed for sale via expression of interest, with a guide price of S$40 million. The 2-storey shophouses, spanning 11,976 sq ft, are zoned for commercial and residential use and can be built up to 6 storeys with approval. The units are fully tenanted and being sold as-is, with potential for building residential or co-living units or serviced apartments behind the shophouses. The EOI exercise closes on June 1.

site_title: DBS extends barbell portfolio to retail investors in Singapore
summary: DBS Bank is now offering retail investors in Singapore the chance to buy into a ready-made, professionally-managed portfolio modelled after its private banking unit's "barbell" product. The Amundi Asia Funds - CIO Barbell Income Fund aims to balance risk and reward by investing in assets at both ends of the risk spectrum. Retail investors can invest a minimum of S$1,000, and the fund is managed by Amundi, exclusively distributed by DBS. This move aims to democratize access to wealth management products and services, and is available to DBS Treasures and retail customers through Internet banking and the digibank app.

images.alt_text: People at the DBS ATM machines in Takashimaya Shopping Centre on 29 September 2021.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed lower on April 20, 2022, following the International Monetary Fund's downgrade of its 2022 growth forecast and unchanged lending rates from Chinese banks. The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.40%, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices fell 1.35% and 1.71%, respectively.

site_title: Break down digital divide barriers to drive economic growth in SE Asia
summary: Southeast Asia's digital economy is emerging stronger than before, with its internet economy set to surpass US$1 trillion in gross merchandise value by 2030. However, many countries in the region are still lagging in bridging the digital divide, with an estimated 30% of the adult population digitally excluded. To address this, experts recommend increasing awareness about digital inclusion, promoting public-private collaboration, and implementing policies that promote digital literacy and accessibility. Governments must seize the moment and accelerate digital inclusion to build an ecosystem that will power the overall recovery of the region's economies.

site_title: COE premiums dip across the board in latest round of bidding
summary: COE premiums across all categories in Singapore have dipped in the latest round of bidding, with cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp seeing a 5.9% decrease to S$68,699. Commercial vehicle COE premiums fell 5.3%, while motorcycle COE prices dropped 6.7%. The Open category COE price also decreased 4.2% to S$95,801. The latest bidding exercise is the last under the current quota period, with more COEs available for bidding from May to July.

site_title: Inflation, interest and the housing paradox
summary: The Federal Reserve is expected to raise short-term interest rates several times over the next year to curb inflation, but this may have unintended consequences. Higher rates will mainly affect the housing market, potentially cooling off the economy and reducing housing construction, which is already below pre-2008 levels. This could exacerbate the housing shortage, contributing to rising shelter costs and rental rates. Despite the potential risks, the Fed believes inflation has not become entrenched and that higher rates are necessary to bring it down.

site_title: Australian scientists to power Tesla on 15,000km trip with printed solar panels
summary: Australian scientists are testing printed solar panels on a 15,100km journey in a Tesla, aiming to raise awareness about climate change. The panels, made from a lightweight and affordable plastic material, are being used to power the car, which will visit 70 schools along the route. The project, called Charge Around Australia, hopes to demonstrate the potential of printed solar technology for other applications, such as powering technology in remote locations like space. The team, led by inventor Paul Dastoor, aims to show how their innovative technology is combining with Tesla's developments to develop new solutions for the planet.

site_title: Yangzijiang spin-off gets shareholder nod, to list on Apr 28 as an STI constituent
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's proposed spin-off of its investment segment, Yangzijiang Financial Holding (YZJFH), has been approved by shareholders with a 100% approval rate. YZJFH will list on the Singapore Exchange on Apr 28 and join the Straits Times Index, FTSE ST Mid Cap Index, and FTSE ST All-Share Index. The company will remain on the STI at an unchanged investable weight, and its distribution date is set for Apr 27. The spin-off aims to reduce the conglomerate discount and unlock the value of the separate businesses and assets.

site_title: Patriots vs globalists replaces the left-right divide
summary: A shift in global politics is underway, with the left-right divide being replaced by a distinction between "patriots" and "globalists." In France, the traditional centre-right and centre-left parties have collapsed, and the presidential election will be contested between Emmanuel Macron and Marine Le Pen, who both reject the traditional left-right label. Macron advocates for deeper European integration, while Le Pen seeks to unravel the EU and promote a more nationalist approach. This shift has similar implications in the US and Britain, where nationalist politics has diverted parties towards protectionism and isolationism. The rise of nationalist politics increases the chances of international conflict, as it often leads to suspicion of foreigners and a focus on national greatness over international cooperation.

site_title: Ensuring that sustainability efforts actually bear fruit
summary: The world is falling short of its sustainability goals despite increasing investments in the ESG sector. Outdated solutions and lack of digitalization hinder accurate carbon reporting, leading to inaccurate data and underreporting of carbon emissions. Blockchain technology offers a solution by providing transparency, accuracy, and integrity in managing carbon assets and liabilities, enabling real-time data updates and eliminating double counting. Its application can facilitate efforts towards net-zero and promote equitability in carbon emissions tracking, particularly in international trade-related emissions.

site_title: Taiwan TV station apologises after mistakenly reporting Chinese attack
summary: A Taiwan government-backed TV station apologized and calmed the public after mistakenly reporting a Chinese attack in Taipei, citing a technical error that displayed fake news alerts. The alerts, which included messages about war and destruction, were meant for a drill but were mistakenly shown on live broadcast. No panic was reported in Taipei, amid rising military tensions with China, which has never renounced the use of force to bring Taiwan under its control. The incident comes amid heightened global tensions and concerns about China's intentions.

site_title: Earth Day: How corporate leaders can break through the inertia
summary: On Earth Day, corporate leaders are urged to break through inertia and prioritize environmental concerns. A recent UN report highlights the worsening impact of climate change, with extreme weather events and food shortages affecting humans and other species. To address this, business leaders must set bold environmental, social, and corporate governance goals, engage stakeholders, and value introspection. These leaders will drive cultural change, empower employees, and win hearts and minds. As regulations catch up, organizations that act early will be rewarded with the capacity to balance multiple strategic objectives, ensuring success in the future.

site_title: Goldman Sachs boosts hiring of dealmakers in Singapore: sources
summary: Goldman Sachs is hiring senior investment bankers in Singapore to bolster its dealmaking capabilities in South-east Asia. The firm has hired Chua Hui Yin from JPMorgan Chase and Andrew Teo from Oversea-Chinese Banking. This move comes as dealmaking surges across the region, with South-east Asian companies raising US$2.7 billion in initial public offerings this year. Goldman ranks third for mergers and acquisitions in Asia and fifth for equity offerings in Asia ex-Japan so far in 2022.

site_title: Indonesia probes Wilmar staff, trade ministry in CPO case
summary: Indonesia has detained suspects, including the commissioner of Wilmar International's unit and a senior trade ministry official, in a corruption case involving palm oil exports. The case centers on the approval of export permits that didn't meet requirements and a lack of local palm oil distribution. Attorney General ST Burhanuddin stated there is strong indication of criminal corrupt action, leading to difficulties for the public, particularly the poor. The government has taken measures to safeguard local supply, including deploying police surveillance and raising export levies.

site_title: Danone says has no plans to sell any of its 3 main divisions
summary: Danone, a French food group, has denied plans to sell its three main divisions: dairy and plant-based products, infant formula, and bottled water. The company's new CEO, Antoine de Saint-Affrique, stated that Danone's businesses are "nothing wrong" and that the key to growth lies in improving execution, investing in worthy brands and innovation, and parting with underperforming assets. Danone shares rose over 7% following a media report on potential merger interest from Lactalis, a non-listed French dairy firm.

site_title: YouTube removes channel promoting future HK leader
summary: YouTube suspended a channel promoting Hong Kong official John Lee's uncontested bid to be the city's next leader, citing compliance with sanctions against the ex-security chief. Lee is expected to be appointed Chief Executive by a Beijing-backed committee next month, with no rivals. The move comes as Lee has promoted his campaign through various social media platforms.

site_title: Heineken sells more beer than expected as Europe reopens
summary: Heineken exceeded expectations with a 5.2% rise in like-for-like beer sales in the first quarter, driven by the reopening of European bars and restaurants. The Dutch brewer attributed the increase to a loosening of coronavirus restrictions, with beer sales in bars and restaurants almost tripling. However, Heineken warned of mounting inflationary pressures and supply chain challenges, which may impact its operating profit margin in 2022. Despite this, the company maintained its guidance of a "stable to modest" improvement to its operating profit margin.

images.alt_text: Heineken 0.0, the latest innovation from the Dutch beer brand. Its first non-alcoholic lager is brewed using only natural ingredients with a unique recipe for a distinct balanced taste.

site_title: Bank of Japan defends yield target, offers to buy unlimited 10-year bonds
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has defended its yield target by offering to buy unlimited 10-year Japanese government bonds (JGBs) at 0.25% to prevent a rise in yields. The move comes as the yen weakens sharply to 2-decade lows against the US dollar, prompting markets to test the central bank's commitment to its yield-curve-control policy. The benchmark 10-year Treasury yield rose to its highest since 2018, while the equivalent JGB yield remained at 0.25%. The BOJ's guidance is to keep the 10-year yield flexible around its 0% target as long as it stays below 0.25%.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end higher on US gains, cheap yen
summary: Tokyo stocks ended higher on Wednesday, April 20, 2022, driven by a cheaper yen and gains on US Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.86% to 27,217.85, while the Topix index gained 1.03% to 1,915.15. The US housing starts data and solid corporate earnings boosted investor confidence, despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: First protest death fuels calls to oust Sri Lanka President
summary: Sri Lanka's President Gotabaya Rajapaksa faces intensified calls to resign following the death of a protester in a police shooting during a clash in Rambukkana. One person was killed and several injured, including police officers, after protesters blocked a train track and tried to set fire to a diesel truck. An indefinite curfew has been imposed in the area. A key opposition leader has stated that Rajapaksa is "responsible for every death," further fueling the demand for his resignation.

site_title: LHN eyes growth and valuations with spin-off and listing of logistics arm
summary: LHN Limited, a Catalist-listed company, is spinning off its logistics arm LHN Logistics in a move aimed at clarifying its identity and allowing for independent growth. The logistics unit plans to raise S$5 million through a share placement, with LHN Limited holding an 84.1% stake. The restructuring aims to improve the company's valuation and provide clearer guidance on its property and logistics segments. The logistics arm will use the funds to finance an ISO tank depot, expand its transportation fleet, and acquire moving equipment, with revenue expected to grow in Singapore and other markets.

site_title: Green commercial, logistics properties hold their value better in pandemic: study
summary: A study by the Institute of Real Estate and Urban Studies (IREUS) found that environmentally friendly properties, particularly green commercial and logistics buildings, held their value better during the global pandemic. In contrast, non-green certified buildings experienced larger drops in valuations. Specifically, green logistics and warehouse assets saw a 12.7% increase in valuations, while green data centres posted a 2.8% increase. The study suggests that green buildings are more resilient due to their energy savings, which will be beneficial in the face of rising energy costs and geopolitical tensions.

site_title: Credit Suisse signals Q1 loss on Russia, legal provisions
summary: Credit Suisse expects to post a Q1 loss due to a 200 million Swiss francs hit to revenues from Russia's invasion of Ukraine and increased legal provisions, totaling 700 million francs. The bank's exposure to the war in Ukraine has led to a revenue loss and higher legal costs. This is another setback for the bank, which has emerged from its worst year since the financial crisis.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets ahead at open
summary: Europe's stock markets opened higher on Wednesday, April 20, 2022, after a mixed performance in Asia. London's FTSE 100 index rose 0.1%, Frankfurt's DAX index gained 0.3%, and the Paris CAC 40 increased 0.5%. The gains followed a decline on Tuesday due to fears of Ukraine war fallout and the International Monetary Fund's reduced global economic growth forecasts.

site_title: Elon Musk races to secure financing for Twitter bid: sources
summary: Elon Musk is racing to secure financing for his $43 billion bid to buy Twitter. He is primarily focused on raising debt, including preferred debt and a loan against his Tesla shares, before seeking equity financing. Investment bank Morgan Stanley is working with Musk to shore up financing, and private equity firm Apollo Global Management is considering offering debt financing. Musk's efforts to secure funding come as he prepares to make a formal bid for the social media platform.

site_title: How much digitalisation must the F&B industry go through to be ‘future-ready’?
summary: Singapore's food and beverage (F&B) industry has faced significant disruption due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with 3,440 establishments closing and employment falling by 8% between 2019 and 2021. However, digitalization has provided a lifeline for many businesses, with the emergence of cloud kitchens, hybrid restaurants, and Industry 4.0 technologies. Automation, IoT systems, and data analytics are key to streamlining workflows, optimizing manpower, and driving innovation, making the industry more resilient and future-ready. With government support and decreasing capital costs, digitalization is becoming a necessity for F&B operators to thrive.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks flat with investor focus on corporate earnings
summary: South Korea's benchmark Kospi closed flat at 2,718.69 on Wednesday, as investors focused on corporate earnings results amid uncertainty over US monetary policy and the Ukraine crisis. The International Monetary Fund slashed its global economic growth forecast, citing inflation concerns, while the Chicago Federal Reserve Bank President suggested a potential rate hike in the US. Foreigners were net buyers of 94.2 billion won worth of shares, while the Korean won strengthened slightly.

site_title: OCBC phishing scam: 20-year-old is first person to plead guilty
summary: A 20-year-old, Leong Jun Xian, has pleaded guilty to 6 charges related to the OCBC phishing scams, which resulted in 790 customers losing approximately S$13 million. He admitted to money laundering and a charge under the Organised Crime Act. The other alleged offenders' cases are still pending. OCBC had made full goodwill payouts to victims and is developing a framework to share losses from scams. Leong is expected to be sentenced in June and may receive probation or reformative training.

site_title: Singapore joins hands with New Zealand to tackle 'a wicked problem' in aviation
summary: Singapore and New Zealand have joined forces to tackle the "wicked problem" of decarbonizing aviation. The two countries signed a memorandum of arrangement on sustainable aviation, focusing on policy and regulation, industry development, infrastructure planning, and workforce transformation. The collaboration aims to promote sustainable aviation practices and develop "green lanes" for fuel-efficient flights. Aviation industry experts acknowledge that decarbonizing aviation requires a comprehensive approach involving governments, private sectors, and stakeholders worldwide, with Singapore and New Zealand aiming to lead by example and inspire other countries to follow suit.

site_title: E-commerce brand Hook Coffee gets physical with first cafe, expands workshops
summary: Hook Coffee, an e-commerce brand, has opened its first permanent coffee bar in Singapore, marking a shift from online-only to offline sales. The move was prompted by the pandemic, which drove consumers to seek in-person experiences. The coffee bar, located in Food Folks @ Lau Pa Sat, offers specialty roasts and brewing techniques. Hook Coffee also expanded its workshops, which now reach up to 500 participants, both online and offline. The company aims to leverage its existing logistics strength to pursue wider e-commerce sales and set up more retail concepts in Singapore.

site_title: Brokers' take: Phillip Securities initiates coverage on TDCX with 'buy'
summary: Phillip Securities initiates coverage on TDCX with a "buy" rating and a target price of US$22, implying a 50.8% potential upside. The valuation is based on a discounted cash flow model, expecting revenue growth mainly from new economy clients, driven by a 13% compound annual growth rate in the South-east Asian digital customer experience industry. Phillip Securities estimates a 25% year-on-year rise in revenue for FY2022, in line with TDCX's guidance.

site_title: Global smartphone market had worst drop since virus outbreak
summary: The global smartphone market experienced its worst drop since the coronavirus outbreak, with shipments falling 11% in the first quarter due to inflation fears, the Russia-Ukraine war, and the Omicron variant. Samsung reclaimed the lead from Apple, while Chinese vendors maintained a significant share. The slowdown was attributed to China's pursuit of a Covid Zero policy, which impacted demand and supply, particularly for entry-level devices. Component shortages may improve soon, but global smartphone demand is expected to be curbed by an inflationary environment, with 2022 sales projected at $527 billion.

site_title: 5 more buildings opt in on Marina Bay district cooling network
summary: SP GROUP's massive underground district cooling system at Marina Bay has secured 5 new customers, bringing the total to 28 buildings and increasing network capacity by 30% to 70,000 refrigerant tonnes. The expansion is expected to reduce carbon emissions by 19,439 tonnes annually, equivalent to taking 17,672 cars off the roads. The new developments will also enable the incorporation of more renewable energy sources, further enhancing the network's reliability.

site_title: Singapore-based Stripe users can now accept payments via PayNow
summary: Stripe has integrated its platform with PayNow, a Singapore-based electronic fund transfer service, allowing Singapore-based businesses to accept payments via PayNow. This move brings PayNow closer to international acceptance. The integration reduces manual-input errors and automatically reconciles transactions, making it easier for merchants to process refunds and subscriptions. The integration is expected to benefit thousands of Singapore-based merchants using Stripe, with online furniture retailer HipVan and job portal JobStreet among the first to offer PayNow through Stripe.

site_title: Singapore buyout firm KV Asia weighs Malaysian education unit sale: sources
summary: KV Asia Capital, a Singapore-based private equity firm, is considering selling its Malaysian post-secondary education group, Asia Pacific Education Holdings, for approximately US$350 million. The group, which owns two universities in Kuala Lumpur, has over 10,000 students. KV Asia acquired the education group in 2018 from Ekuiti Nasional, a Malaysian state-backed buyout firm. Deliberations on the potential sale are ongoing, with the firm working with a financial adviser. A deal could be finalized in the near future, but KV Asia could also decide not to proceed.

site_title: Thailand's hospital profits may treble in Q1 on Covid, but cases could peak soon: CGS-CIMB
summary: Thailand's hospitals are expected to report a 3x increase in Q1 profits due to the surge in Covid-19 cases, but cases may peak soon. According to CGS-CIMB, 6 hospitals will see their recurring net profit triple year-over-year, while aggregate recurring net profit drops 19% on a quarterly basis due to lower margins. The number of new Covid-19 cases has increased significantly, with 15,610 cases in Q1 2022 compared to 244 in Q1 2021.

site_title: Raffles Education clarifies media reports regarding charges filed over dispute in India
summary: Raffles Education Corporation (REC) has clarified media reports about a charge sheet filed against its directors and top management over a dispute in India. The company denies the allegations, stating there is no basis for the claims and it has not received any summons or notice. REC attributes the allegations to pending disputes with Educomp Solutions and its units, including an arbitration award against Educomp that REC has yet to receive compensation for. The company is taking legal advice to respond to the allegations.

images.alt_text: A shocking announcement by Raffles Education (REC) that its auditors had highlighted material uncertainty on its ability to continue as a going concern has added another chapter to the ongoing saga of the troubled company.

site_title: Just Eat Takeaway weighs GrubHub sale, scales back 2022 growth view
summary: Just Eat Takeaway.com, Europe's largest meal delivery company, has scaled back its 2022 growth expectations due to a decline in first-quarter orders. The company reported a 1% decrease in orders and is exploring a possible sale of GrubHub, a US company it bought for $7.3 billion last year. Just Eat Takeaway now expects "mid-single digit growth" in Gross Transaction Value, down from previous predictions of "mid-teens." The company aims to strengthen its business and improve profitability throughout 2022.

site_title: Encouraging Q1 real estate performance builds for optimistic year ahead: Edmund Tie
summary: Singapore's Q1 real estate performance is expected to remain resilient despite headwinds, driven by stronger business and consumer confidence. Total investment sales rose 35% to S$9.8 billion, with the retail sector leading the way. Commercial-zoned sites are expected to attract developers, while suburban retail assets remain in high demand. The office segment also saw growth, driven by limited supply and the finance sector's strong demand. However, the residential market is expected to slow due to fewer new launches and cooling measures, with primary home sales projected to reach 11,000-12,000 units in 2022.

site_title: Sheng Siong aims to open at least 3 new stores every year over next 3-5 years
summary: Sheng Siong Supermarket plans to open 3-5 new stores annually over the next 3-5 years in Singapore and Kunming, China, as part of its expansion strategy. The company aims to secure new retail spaces in public housing estates and build on its e-commerce capabilities. Despite a 4.2% net profit decline to S$132.8 million in FY2021, Sheng Siong expects elevated demand to taper down as consumers increase spending on other activities. The company has no plans to pay higher dividends, instead conserving cash for operational reasons or major capital expenditures.

These measures include a cap on group sizes to two people; dining in and other mask-off activities banned once more and mandatory SafeEntry check-in for all markets and hawker centres.

site_title: Indonesia posts budget surplus of 10.3t rupiah in Q1
summary: Indonesia posted a budget surplus of 10.3 trillion rupiah (S$981.2 million) in the first quarter of 2022, equivalent to 0.06% of GDP. The surplus was driven by high commodity prices and an improving domestic economy, with total revenue surging 32.1% and spending falling 6.2%. The government has reduced bond issuance but will continue to monitor the market amid global monetary tightening. Tax revenue is expected to increase further in April, and the government is weighing options to adjust energy prices to contain spending on subsidies.

site_title: Sanofi's vaccine production facility to strengthen Singapore's future pandemic readiness
summary: Sanofi broke ground for a vaccine production facility in Singapore, expected to create 200 local jobs and increase vaccine production capacity by 3-4 vaccines simultaneously. The modular facility, set to be completed in 2025, will enable flexible manufacturing of multiple vaccines and biological platforms. The move aims to strengthen Singapore's future pandemic readiness and push the country's biopharmaceutical industry forward. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of pandemic preparedness and supply chain resilience, highlighting the need for innovation in vaccine manufacturing.

site_title: Shell withdraws staff from Russia projects as exit plan begins: sources
summary: Shell is withdrawing staff from its joint ventures with Gazprom and Gazprom Neft in Russia, part of its exit plan from investments due to the war in Ukraine. The company has started demobilizing employees, including those on temporary assignment at the Sakhalin-2 liquefied natural gas export project. This move is expected to result in $4 billion to $5 billion in impairments. Shell aims to distance itself from Moscow and has already halted new purchases of Russian oil and gas, as well as idled LNG vessels chartered from Russian companies.

site_title: China’s 3 core growth engines hint of rising recessionary pressures
summary: China's Q1 GDP growth exceeded expectations at 4.8% but core activities, such as retail sales, manufacturing, and real estate development, show signs of recessionary pressures. The Omicron outbreaks and lockdowns in Shanghai have taken a toll, with retail sales down 3.5% and jobless rate rising to 5.8%. Infrastructure investment growth accelerated 12.5% but is largely due to government spending. Analysts predict a soft start to Q2 and warn of rising recessionary pressures, with Goldman Sachs and Nomura cutting their GDP growth forecasts.

site_title: China unexpectedly keeps lending benchmark unchanged
summary: China unexpectedly kept its benchmark lending rates steady on Wednesday, with the one-year loan prime rate (LPR) at 3.70% and the five-year LPR unchanged at 4.60%. This move was seen as Beijing's cautious approach to easing measures amid a slowing economy due to Covid-19 lockdowns. Despite this, policy divergence with major central banks could prompt capital outflows, adding pressure on the yuan, and some analysts still predict a possible rate cut in the second quarter.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, following US gains, as investors were encouraged by better-than-expected US housing starts data and solid corporate earnings. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.76% and the Topix index gained 0.83%.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on tech and healthcare boost; Ramsay soars on A$20b bid
summary: Australian shares rose 0.8% to a four-session gain, driven by gains in healthcare and technology stocks, as the US dollar strengthened. Ramsay Healthcare surged 29.8% on a $20.05 billion takeover bid from KKR & Co. Tech stocks, including Iress and Block Inc, also rose, while miners fell due to weaker iron ore prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 7,624.80.

site_title: China's lockdowns could drive more US policy action, says Fed's Kashkari
summary: US Federal Reserve Bank President Neel Kashkari warned that China's ongoing lockdowns could drive more aggressive policy action to combat inflation, which rose 8.5% in March, the fastest pace since 1981. Kashkari said the pandemic's impact on global supply chains and the Russia-Ukraine conflict would determine the US economy's performance in 2022, with inflation expected to remain a challenge if lockdowns persist. The Fed is expected to continue raising interest rates to bring inflation under control, with potential rate hikes starting next month.

site_title: FTX CEO Bankman-Fried wants to fix social media with blockchain
summary: Cryptocurrency billionaire Sam Bankman-Fried, CEO of FTX, plans to use blockchain technology to fix social media's "broken model" by creating a system where platforms can draw from the same underlying data, allowing for independent censorship decisions and increased competition. He believes this would solve issues with user experience, freedom of speech, and interoperability between platforms. Bankman-Fried, who wants to give away his entire fortune, has not directly discussed his plan with Elon Musk, who has made a bid to take Twitter private.

site_title: Freehold Oxley Garden apartments up for en bloc sale, asking at least S$200m
summary: The 58,000 sq ft freehold Oxley Garden apartment complex in District 9 is up for en bloc sale with a minimum asking price of S$200 million. The site can be rebuilt into a 5-storey condominium with a gross floor area of 85,246 sq ft. The sale comes after the successful sale of nearby 5 Oxley Rise, which is expected to fetch over S$300 million. A tender is expected to be launched soon, with marketing agent JLL Singapore citing potential benefits of a comprehensive redevelopment for both sites.

site_title: Japan stimulus to include cash for low-income households
summary: Japan's government plans to provide 100,000 yen (S$1,058) cash handouts to newly cash-strapped households as part of an emergency relief package. The handouts will be offered to households exempt from paying residential taxes due to falling incomes. The spending will come from last fiscal year's extra budget and reserves, and the government also plans to provide aid for low-income families. Discussions on financing the relief package are ongoing, with the government resisting calls for an extra budget before an upper house election this summer.

site_title: Gold prices extend losses as firmer Treasury yields dent appeal
summary: Gold prices fell 0.2% to $1,946.04 per ounce, as US Treasury yields surged to multi-year highs, making the dollar-priced metal less attractive. The stronger US dollar and rising yields overshadowed safe-haven inflows into bullion. Spot silver and platinum also declined, while palladium edged down. The decline in gold prices follows a sharp drop in the previous session, as investors prepare for the Federal Reserve to aggressively raise rates to stem soaring inflation.

site_title: SoftBank robotics invests in Hong Kong startup Avalon SteriTech
summary: SoftBank Robotics has agreed to buy a 5% minority stake in Hong Kong-based cleaning technology startup Avalon SteriTech, marking its first investment in the city. As part of the deal, SoftBank Robotics' chief business officer Kent Yoshida will join Avalon SteriTech's board of directors. The investment follows an existing joint venture and follows Avalon SteriTech's revenue growth, reaching $8-10 million this year. The company plans to expand into new markets and could break even in 2023.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks began trading lower on April 20, 2022, after the IMF downgraded its global growth forecast for 2022. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.26% to 20,972.84, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. The decline was attributed to the IMF's reduced growth forecast, which may have dampened investor sentiment.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Wednesday, rising 10.21 points or 0.65% to 1,591.35. Trading volume was 293.85 million lots worth RM161.14 million. Gainers outpaced losers 309 to 148.

site_title: L'Oreal sales jump as shoppers buy perfume, pricey creams
summary: L'Oreal's sales rose 14% in the first quarter, driven by higher demand for luxury products, despite virus restrictions in China. The luxury unit grew 18% and surpassed the mass-market consumer products business. Analysts expect the beauty market to grow 4-5% this year, with L'Oreal outperforming. The company's gross margin will be affected by input-cost increases, but it expects to offset this with price increases and reduced advertisement spending. L'Oreal's Chinese sales also grew double-digit, outperforming the market, and the company remains confident in the country's cosmetics market.

site_title: Uber, Lyft and Disney end mask mandates as Covid cases fall
summary: Ride-hailing companies Uber and Lyft, and theme park Disney, have ended mask mandates for riders and drivers in the US due to declining Covid cases. Other companies, including Allegiant Travel Co, Hawaiian Holdings Inc, Spirit Airlines, and Frontier Group Holdings Inc, also lifted their mask mandates. The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends wearing masks if certain conditions are met, and the Biden administration no longer enforces a federal mask mandate on public transportation.

site_title: LHN Logistics prices its IPO for placement at S$0.20 each to raise S$5m
summary: LHN Logistics has priced its initial public offering (IPO) at S$0.20 per share, aiming to raise S$5 million. The net proceeds will fund the construction of a new ISO tank depot and the expansion of its transportation fleet. The company will have a market capitalization of S$33.5 million and a share price of 10.1 times its earnings in FY2021. LHN Logistics will retain approximately 84.1% of the post-placement share capital, with the remaining 15.9% available for public listing.

site_title: New surrender deadline in Mariupol as West promises Ukraine more arms
summary: Russia urged Ukrainian fighters in Mariupol to surrender by midnight on April 20, but Ukrainian commanders vowed not to yield. Despite the ultimatum, thousands of Russian troops advanced in the Battle of the Donbas, capturing the city of Kreminna. Western governments, including the US, Canada, and Britain, pledged more military aid to Ukraine, with the US expected to announce a new aid package. A humanitarian pause in the fighting is also being proposed by UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres, amid the ongoing conflict that has displaced nearly 5 million people and reduced cities to rubble.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Wednesday's open, tracking Wall Street gains; STI up 0.7%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.7% to 3,330.01 on Wednesday, tracking Wall Street gains. Gainers outnumbered losers 120 to 33, with Sembcorp Marine, Jiutian Chemical, and Golden Agri-Resources among the top gainers. Banking stocks also rose, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC up 0.8%, 1%, and 0.6%, respectively. The rally follows positive earnings and dovish comments from US Federal Reserve officials on interest rate rises, which also boosted Tokyo stocks.

site_title: Exxon sees carbon capture market at US$4t by 2050
summary: ExxonMobil predicts a $4 trillion carbon capture market by 2050, accounting for 60% of the estimated $6.5 trillion oil and gas market. Carbon capture technology involves capturing CO2 from fuel combustion, transporting it, and storing it underground. The technology is seen as key to mitigating global warming, with large oil companies investing in its development. Exxon's energy transition strategy does not include renewable sources, and the company has recently hired a leader to focus on low-carbon business, following public pressure to reduce emissions.

site_title: IMF economist concerned about inflation expectations climbing upward
summary: IMF economist Pierre-Olivier Gourinchas expresses concern over rising inflation expectations, warning that a "wage-price spiral" could ensue if inflation remains elevated. A tight labor market in the US is fueling demands for wage increases, which could entrench inflationary expectations. This could prompt aggressive monetary policy tightening in advanced economies, posing a downside risk to the US and other economies. The IMF has revised its global economic growth outlook downward due to the war in Ukraine, and Gourinchas warns that elevated inflation could lead to a more aggressive tightening of monetary policy.

site_title: Japan posts bigger-than-expected trade gap as energy imports jump
summary: Japan recorded a trade deficit for the eighth straight month in March, with a 412.4 billion yen (S$4.36 billion) shortfall, exceeding expectations. Energy imports jumped 31.2% due to soaring prices, while exports rose less than expected, driven by slowing growth in shipments to China. Despite a narrow deficit, Japan's economy faces risks from global supply constraints and the pandemic. The yen's weakening value has also inflated import costs for fuel and food.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A businessman walks near the Bank of Japan headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, Feb. 15, 2016. REUTERS/Thomas Peter/File Photo

site_title: New Zealand home construction costs advance at a record pace
summary: New Zealand's home construction costs surged 7.3% in the first quarter, the fastest gain since 2013, driven by higher timber, structural products, and metal prices, as well as climbing wages. This increase is expected to contribute to higher inflation, with Reserve Bank Governor Adrian Orr predicting interest rates will keep rising. Despite this, construction industry experts believe the industry will remain busy due to a pipeline of approved dwelling consents, with potential for double-digit cost inflation into next year.

site_title: Hatten Land forms JV and collaboration with e-sports organisations as part of business pivot
summary: Hatten Land, the owner of Elements Mall in Melaka, Malaysia, has formed a joint venture with e-sports organization Kitamen Holdings to rebrand the mall as an e-sports hub. The partnership aims to organize e-sports events and tournaments, as well as provide e-sports coaching to develop the community's skillsets. This move marks a pivot in Hatten Land's business strategy, following years of organizing events at the mall. The joint venture will focus on developing the e-sports community in Malaysia, with over 2 million gamers expected to participate in Kitamen's events.

site_title: Oil prices fall 5% after IMF cuts growth outlook
summary: Oil prices fell 5% in volatile trading on Tuesday after the International Monetary Fund (IMF) cut its economic growth forecasts and warned of higher inflation. The IMF's lower growth forecast, combined with a stronger US dollar and concerns over demand growth, led to a decline in oil prices. Brent crude fell to $107.25 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate fell to $102.56 a barrel. The IMF's warning also sparked calls for increased sanctions on Russia, which has been producing less oil following sanctions imposed over its invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: Sunseap, Riau Islands to build large-scale solar energy plants
summary: Sunseap, a clean energy solutions provider, has partnered with the Riau Islands government in Indonesia to develop large-scale solar energy plants and storage systems. The plants will supply electricity to both Singapore and the Riau Islands, creating thousands of jobs in the process. The partnership covers 3,000 hectares of land and includes plans for 1,380-1,682 MWp solar power plants and 3,000-3,500 MWh energy storage systems. The move aims to transform the Riau Islands into a renewable energy hub in Indonesia and lower energy costs for its people and industries.

site_title: US: Wall Street advances on earnings optimism, dovish rate rise remarks
summary: US stocks advanced on Tuesday, with the Nasdaq closing 2.2% higher and the S&P 500 gaining 1.61%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.45%. Johnson & Johnson and IBM reported strong quarterly earnings, while Netflix forecast further losses. The Federal Reserve's dovish comments on interest rate hikes also boosted markets. Despite higher bond yields, defensive sectors rallied, with gaming companies leading the way.

site_title: Europe: Rising bond yields, Ukraine crisis weigh on shares
summary: European shares fell 0.8% on Tuesday, their worst day in two weeks, amid rising bond yields and concerns over the Ukraine crisis. Energy shares rose 0.5% despite plunging oil prices, driven by expectations of value in the sector during rising yields. The International Monetary Fund and World Bank slashed their global economic growth forecast, citing prolonged Ukraine tensions. Earnings season for European companies continues, with Accor and L'Oreal reporting this week.

site_title: Netflix plans lower-priced service with ads, marking big shift
summary: Netflix plans to launch a lower-priced version of its service with ads, marking a significant shift for the company. This move comes after the streaming giant posted a loss of 200,000 customers in the first quarter and forecast a further drop of 2 million this quarter. Netflix aims to attract new subscribers with a lower price point, which will be accompanied by ads, a change from the company's long-standing ad-free model.

site_title: Netflix shares plunge as subscribers drop
summary: Netflix shares plummeted 25% after revealing a 1.4 million subscriber decline in the first quarter, marking the first time the company lost subscribers in a decade. The streaming service ended the quarter with 221.6 million subscribers, down from the final quarter of last year. Netflix attributes the decline to the suspension of its service in Russia due to the Ukraine invasion. Despite reporting a net income of $1.6 billion, the company's growth is slowing, and it expects to reaccelerate growth by improving programming and recommendations.

site_title: Johnny Depp calls Amber Heard accusations 'heinous', says he never struck ex-wife
summary: Actor Johnny Depp testified in a Virginia courtroom, stating that he never struck his ex-wife Amber Heard and was challenging her accusations in a $50 million defamation case. Depp described Heard's allegations as "heinous and disturbing" and claimed he has never physically harmed a woman in his life. He aims to correct the public's perception and stand up for his children, who he believes are being negatively impacted by the allegations.

site_title: Taiwan’s Unimicron says Kunshan plant gradually resuming production
summary: Taiwan's Unimicron Technology Corp announced that its plant in Kunshan, China is gradually resuming operations after suspending production from April 2 to 19 to comply with Covid-19 rules. The factory, which supplies major companies like Apple and Intel, had stopped production to follow Chinese regulations. Production is expected to resume at a normal level, with Unimicron stating that the factory is "gradually resuming operations".

site_title: Crypto firm Blockchain.com is planning IPO as soon as this year: sources
summary: Crypto firm Blockchain.com is planning an initial public offering (IPO) as soon as this year, according to sources. The company, valued at around $14 billion, is interviewing banks for the IPO, which could take place sooner than expected. This comes as the Bloomberg Galaxy Crypto Index has fallen 19% this year, and other crypto firms are exploring public markets. Blockchain.com, a rival to Coinbase Global, has recently launched an asset-management service, BCAM, to cater to institutional investors. The company's IPO plans could provide a boost to the struggling crypto market.

site_title: Ukraine's war efforts gain an unlikely source of funding: memes
summary: Ukrainian charity Help Us Help has received nearly $1.5 million in funding from a Toronto-based online business, Saint Javelin, which sells merchandise featuring internet memes and images of Ukrainian resistance to the Russian invasion. The site, created by Canadian entrepreneur Christian Borys, has raised funds through T-shirts, stickers, and other items, with sales reaching $170,000 per day. The online support has helped shift public perception of Ukraine, portraying the country as a plucky underdog fighting against a powerful invader. The funds will be used to assist Ukrainian charities and provide protective equipment for journalists covering the war.

images.alt_text: The Canadian entrepreneur Christian Borys with some of the T-shirts and stickers sold by his Toronto-based online business, which has raised $1.5 million for the Ukrainian charity Help Us Help, at his hotel room in Lviv, Ukraine, April 15, 2022. An unprecedented campaign using internet memes and merchandise has rallied international public support for Ukraine in its war with Russia. (Finbarr O'Reilly/The New York Times)

site_title: UK PM Johnson apologises for party fine but is called ‘man without shame’
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson apologized to MPs for breaking lockdown rules at a birthday party in 2020, but faced criticism for lacking shame. Johnson denied misleading parliament, but opposition leader Keir Starmer called him a "man without shame." The fine is the first for a British leader, and Johnson's integrity is under scrutiny. The scandal has distracted from his response to Russia's invasion of Ukraine, and the public's perception of him has soured, with a recent survey showing two-thirds view him negatively.

site_title: Australia’s Ramsay Health Care receives A$20b offer from KKR-led consortium
summary: Ramsay Health Care, Australia's largest private hospital operator, received a A$20.05 billion (S$20.2 billion) takeover offer from a KKR-led consortium, valuing the company at A$88 per share, a 37% premium to its closing price. The proposal, at a preliminary stage, involves a non-exclusive due diligence process and is supported by financial adviser UBS.

site_title: Sega reboots Crazy Taxi, Jet Set Radio to chase Fortnite riches
summary: Sega is rebooting its classic Dreamcast games Crazy Taxi and Jet Set Radio in a bid to replicate Fortnite's success. The new titles, part of the Super Game initiative, aim to create recurring revenue and online communities. The development of Crazy Taxi is already underway, with a release expected within 2-3 years, while Jet Set Radio's development is in its early stages. Sega aims to capitalize on the success of Epic Games' Fortnite, which has become a model for free-to-play, multiplayer games with recurring revenue streams.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise amid mixed regional trading
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.1% on Tuesday, rebounding from a 2-day losing streak, amid mixed regional markets. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,307.13, with Sembcorp Industries leading gains as its shares rose 3.8%. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding was the worst performer, falling 1.8%. Institutional investors continued to sell Singapore stocks, with a third consecutive week of net outflows, which may pose a headwind for the STI's sustained upside.

site_title: Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust's H2 DPU up 2.8%
summary: Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT) reported a 2.8% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.03393 for the second half-year ended March 31, 2022, driven by lower rental reliefs granted to retail tenants at Festival Walk mall and contributions from its Hewlett-Packard Japan Headquarters Building acquisition. Gross revenue and net property income (NPI) also rose 4.9% and 5.1%, respectively. Despite a partial offset by lower average rental rates, MNACT's CEO remains cautiously optimistic about the recovery of consumer sentiment and tenant businesses.

site_title: Shanghai urges public cooperation with Covid-19 tests amid rising scepticism
summary: Shanghai authorities are urging public cooperation with Covid-19 tests as the city aims to stop community transmission by Wednesday, following a decline in new local cases. The city has been under pressure from Beijing to speed up transfers of positive cases and their close contacts to quarantine centers. Residents have expressed concerns about the costs and effectiveness of China's "zero tolerance" policy, with some experts questioning its feasibility. Seven more deaths were reported, all elderly and with underlying health conditions, bringing the total to 10.

site_title: SIA and the 3 stocks that offer potential exposure to the aviation sector recovery
summary: Singapore Airlines' passenger traffic reached 31% of pre-Covid levels in April, with 38% of flights operating at pre-Covid capacity. Other aviation stocks to watch include Korean Air Lines, which plans to add hundreds of international flights and has become profitable despite pandemic restrictions, and China Eastern Airlines, which saw a 14.3% revenue improvement in the last 12 months. Lessors like BOC Aviation are also performing well, with a 10% rise in net profit in 2021.

site_title: Apac prime office rents seeing sustained recovery: Knight Frank
summary: Apac prime office rents saw a year-on-year increase of 0.2% in Q1 2022, with Shanghai recording the highest rise at 4.2%. Shenzhen continued to decline, falling 4.5% year-over-year. Singapore and Hong Kong saw rents increase 1.9% and 1.1% year-over-year, respectively. Occupancy costs were led by Hong Kong at $186 per square foot. Despite elevated vacancies at 13.1%, Knight Frank expects stable leasing demand in the coming quarters as tenants seek premium spaces at low rents.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Raffles Education, Hatten Land, Keppel DC Reit, KORE, Singtel, MNACT, LHN, Nanofilm
summary: Singtel has filed an appeal to the Full Federal Court of Australia. The company is contesting a court ruling that ordered it to pay $11 million in damages to a customer who claimed he was misled about his mobile phone plan. Meanwhile, Raffles Education Corporation shares fell 2.33% after the company sought to clarify media reports about a charge sheet filed by the Delhi Police's Economic Offences Wing against its directors and top management.

images.alt_text: US chipmaker Qualcomm said Thursday it had fulfilled the requirements set out by a court in a patent dispute case against Apple to ban the sale of older iPhone models in Germany.

site_title: Business must step up in new era of environmental activism
summary: EARTH Day highlights the urgent need for businesses to take bold action on environmental issues. The event's theme, "Investing in Our Planet," coincides with a UN report warning of an "unliveable world" due to climate change. Amid global challenges, businesses must step up to drive a greener and more prosperous future through innovation and partnerships. The report emphasizes the need for greater business participation to achieve a sustainable pathway, as the green agenda risks being sidelined by other pressing issues.

site_title: Is it the Cold War all over again?
summary: The US is facing a new Cold War, with President Biden needing to mobilize public support and unite allies to counter perceived existential threats from Russia and China. This echoes the era of the Cold War, which began with President Harry Truman's leadership in the aftermath of World War II. The US needs to adjust its strategy, as cooperation with Russia is no longer an option. Biden has rallied bipartisan support for a tough posture, including legislation to end trade relations with Russia and codify the US ban on Russian oil imports. However, the costs of a long Cold War remain unclear.

site_title: McDonald's biggest franchisee plans to debut ESG-linked bonds
summary: Arcos Dorados Holdings, the world's largest McDonald's franchisee, plans to sell sustainability-linked bonds to fund its sustainability goals, including reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 36% and 31% in its supply chain by 2030. The bonds, rated Ba2 by Moody's, will be used to pay off existing debt and fund general corporate purposes. This move marks the first time a McDonald's franchisee has issued ESG-linked bonds, which are gaining popularity among borrowers seeking to tap into the growing ethical fund industry and secure cheaper borrowing costs.

images.alt_text: The logo for McDonald's restaurant is seen as McDonald's Corp. reports fourth quarter earnings, in Arlington, Virginia, U.S., January 27, 2022.      REUTERS/Joshua Roberts

site_title: Rare freehold landed site in Orchard area expected to draw offers of over S$300m
summary: A freehold landed site in Singapore's Orchard area, 5 Oxley Rise, is expected to draw offers of over S$300 million. The site, comprising 151,205 square feet, is one of the last remaining freehold residential landed sites in the prime Orchard Road district. The property, which has been owned by 7 members of the same family, features an iconic mansion with a 360-degree view of the city. Potential developers and owner-occupiers can consider redeveloping the site into a single large mansion, strata, or mixed landed developments, or multiple Good Class Bungalows, subject to approval from authorities.

site_title: IBM forecasts upbeat 2022 revenue on cloud strength; flags Russia hit
summary: IBM forecasts upbeat 2022 revenue, exceeding expectations, driven by strong cloud growth and consulting business. The company expects to hit the top end of its revenue growth forecast, with cloud revenue jumping 14% to $5 billion in the first quarter. However, IBM flags a $300 million revenue hit from suspending its business in Russia and a $200 million profit hit. The company's adjusted profit per share topped estimates, with shares up 3% in extended trading. Analysts expect annual revenue growth of 5.8% for the year.

site_title: China's property sector contracts for third straight quarter
summary: China's property sector contracted for a third consecutive quarter, with output in the real estate industry declining 2% in the first quarter compared to the same period last year. New-home sales plummeted 29% in March, adding to the woes of cash-strapped developers. Despite a stronger-than-expected 4.8% economic growth in Q1, the lockdowns are weighing on consumer spending, with retail sales contracting for the first time since 2020 and catering revenue plummeting 16.4%. The surveyed jobless rate reached 5.8%, the highest since May 2020.

site_title: Benefiting from a commodities supercycle
summary: Russia's invasion of Ukraine poses significant risks to the global economy, exacerbating inflation and supply chain disruptions. The country is a major commodity producer, with sanctions driving up energy prices and threatening fertiliser supplies, which are crucial for food production. In a high inflationary environment, commodities typically outperform other asset classes, making commodity-related equities a decent hedge. A growing demand-supply imbalance in oil, gas, and metals markets, driven by increasing energy demand and weak supply, also supports commodity investments.

site_title: New Covid-19 cases in S'pore nearly double to 4,718, one death reported
summary: Singapore reported 4,718 new Covid-19 cases on April 19, nearly doubling from the previous day's 2,480 cases. One death was also reported, bringing the total to 1,317 deaths. Hospitalizations increased to 278, and 9 patients were in the ICU. The week-on-week infection ratio remains below one, indicating a controlled spread.

site_title: Flight bookings show pent-up demand, bodes well for Singapore's air traffic target
summary: Singapore's air traffic is expected to reach at least 50% of pre-Covid levels this year, driven by strong travel demand. Flight bookings have surged to 178% of pre-Covid levels for upcoming public holidays and 81% for June school holidays. Airlines are increasing capacity, with over 21,400 scheduled flights in and out of Singapore in the April-June quarter, up from 6,800 in the same period in 2021. Flag carrier Singapore Airlines expects passenger capacity to reach 61% of pre-pandemic levels by May.

site_title: These 3 stocks offer potential exposure to the current aviation sector recovery
summary: Singapore Airlines passenger traffic reached 31% of pre-Covid levels, with 38% of pre-Covid flights, following the city-state's reopening to fully vaccinated travelers. Other companies with potential exposure to the aviation sector recovery include Korean Air Lines, which is adding hundreds of international flights, and China Eastern Airlines, despite being loss-making in 2021. Lessors such as BOC Aviation are also showing resilience. The recovery in the aviation sector is expected to drive growth in these companies, but investors should be aware of elevated fuel prices.

site_title: 'Painted over': Russian village artist finds peace art unwelcome
summary: Retired Russian artist Vladimir Ovchinnikov, 84, has been painting murals in his small town near Moscow, but some of his art is not welcome due to Russia's conflict with Ukraine. He had painted a blue-and-yellow Ukrainian flag on an abandoned building, but it was covered over in white paint. Despite facing fines and threats, Ovchinnikov insists on continuing his work, believing in the power of art to promote peace and show how he understands the conflict.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit posts 0.2% increase in Q1 DPU
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported a 0.2% increase in Q1 DPU to S$0.02466, up from S$0.02462 last year. The real-estate investment trust (Reit) posted a 1.4% decline in net property income to S$60.1 million and a 0.9% fall in gross revenue to S$66.1 million.

site_title: KORE reports 11% increase in Q1 distributable income
summary: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit (KORE) reported a 10.9% increase in Q1 distributable income to US$16.6 million, driven by 6.9% growth in gross revenue and 6.7% rise in net property income. The Reit's manager attributed the growth to recent acquisitions and a strong portfolio occupancy of 91.7%. The Reit's balance sheet remains strong, with no long-term refinancing requirements until November 2023. KORE's exposure to rising interest rates is expected to decrease distributions by 0.062 US cents per annum for every 50 basis points increase in interest rates.

site_title: What the US yield curve is telling us
summary: The US yield curve, which measures the difference between yields on long-dated and short-dated US Treasuries, has historically predicted every recession since 1950 with only one false signal. Currently, the gap between 2- and 10-year Treasuries is at its lowest level since the pandemic-induced recession of 2020, sparking concerns about the outlook for US and global growth. The Federal Reserve may need to pivot in policy to support the economy, as past episodes of flat yield curves followed by inversion and recession have seen the Fed cut rates to stabilize corporate and consumer sentiment.

site_title: Investing in credits: Look under the hood
summary: Investors are seeking income in portfolios despite rising interest rates and inflation. Credit, particularly, is worth examining, according to panelists. Rising interest rates and higher inflation are raising questions about the fixed income asset class, but experts believe there are opportunities within credit. The panellists discussed the importance of dollar asset diversification, driven by Asia's growth, and the potential for credit to provide income in challenging market conditions.

site_title: Open source is critical to addressing Singapore's tech talent shortage
summary: Singapore faces a growing tech talent shortage, with a need for skilled developers, data scientists, and engineers. The country is not alone in this challenge, as a global shortage of skilled developers is caused by soaring expectations for seamless digital experiences. Open source can drive innovation and address the shortage by enabling collaboration, sharing code, and attracting global talent. The Singapore government has already taken steps to promote open source adoption, and companies must now embed it into their working cultures to solve the skills crisis and pave the way for innovation.

site_title: Japan's finance minister warns against yen slump, economic fallout
summary: Japan's finance minister Shunichi Suzuki warned against the yen's slump, stating that the damage to the economy outweighs the benefits, amid worsened imported inflationary pressures due to rising commodity and oil costs. The yen has fallen to fresh 20-year lows against the dollar, with Suzuki urging stability in the currency market and cautioning against sharp moves. Suzuki's comments, made before a trip to the US, marked the clearest signal from Japanese authorities of discomfort with the yen's decline, but verbal warnings are seen as insufficient to impact the currency's fundamental trend.

site_title: Oil above US$100/b, a new reality for 2022
summary: Oil prices are expected to remain above $100 per barrel for the rest of 2022 due to deepening geopolitical tensions, constrained production, and chronic underinvestment in the oil industry. Western sanctions on Russia and the ongoing Russia-Ukraine war are contributing factors. Experts predict Brent to average around $105 per barrel, with some speculating prices could reach $120-130 per barrel if sanctions are imposed. However, lockdowns in China and recession concerns in Europe and the US may limit demand, and underinvestment in the oil industry is seen as a major factor driving prices.

site_title: How to recession-proof your investments
summary: A recession is a normal occurrence in the economic cycle, often triggered by long periods of growth. Investors can "recession-proof" their portfolios by focusing on defensive shares, which are companies with stable profits regardless of economic conditions. Examples of defensive shares include utility companies, supermarkets, and healthcare providers. These companies tend to be cash-generative and resilient during economic downturns, providing a steady stream of income for investors. By investing in these companies, investors can potentially protect their portfolios from the impact of a recession and generate stable returns.

site_title: Growth, inclusion and sustainability in a post-pandemic world
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the need for growth, inclusion, and sustainability in a post-pandemic world, citing global economic headwinds and the war in Ukraine. As a small city-state, Singapore takes a proactive interest in global economic trends and structural challenges. Economies worldwide have not fully recovered from COVID-19, and the ongoing conflict exacerbates these issues. Wong's views highlight the importance of addressing these challenges to ensure sustainable growth and a more inclusive global system.

site_title: 75-basis-point hike could be option if needed, Fed's Bullard says
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis President James Bullard suggests the central bank could raise interest rates by 75 basis points if needed, targeting a 3.5% rate by the end of the year with multiple half-point hikes. Bullard mentioned this approach, citing the 1994 50 basis point hike under Alan Greenspan, which led to a decade-long expansion, as a potential scenario.

site_title: Greenback hits fresh 20-year high against yen
summary: The US dollar reached a fresh 20-year high against the Japanese yen, rising to 128.46 yen, and tested a 2-year peak against the euro, reaching $1.07935. The dollar index climbed past 101 for the first time in over 2 years, driven by high US Treasury yields and expectations of US Federal Reserve interest rate hikes. The yen's decline has been fueled by investors betting on further falls and the Bank of Japan's efforts to keep yields low.

site_title: Aztech Global down 4.5% after Q1 results miss expectations
summary: Aztech Global's Q1 results fell short of market expectations, with a 4.5% decline in shares after posting a 10.4% increase in revenue and a 5.3% rise in net profit. Analysts attributed the miss to inflationary cost pressures and margin compression. Despite this, some analysts raised their forecasts for FY2022 revenue and maintained their "buy" calls on the stock, citing a strong order book and optimism on business prospects.

site_title: No fuel, inflation surcharge for third-party sellers, say local e-commerce sites
summary: Local e-commerce platforms and logistics firms in Singapore are unlikely to implement fuel and inflation surcharges on third-party sellers, unlike Amazon in the US, which will levy a 5% surcharge on Fulfillment by Amazon services starting April 28. In contrast, ride-hailing companies in Singapore have introduced temporary flat fees to help drivers cover rising operating costs. The move aims to avoid copying Amazon's strategy, instead focusing on supporting local businesses and drivers.

site_title: US single-family homebuilding; permits plunge in March
summary: US single-family homebuilding declined in March due to soaring mortgage rates, which increased costs. The 30-year fixed mortgage rate rose to 5% for the first time in over a decade. This is the latest challenge to the housing market, which is sensitive to interest rates. Permits for single-family houses also plummeted last month, following a survey showing sentiment among homebuilders hit a seven-month low. Despite the decline, residential construction remains underpinned by a severe shortage of houses.

site_title: US stocks see biggest outflows of year as recession fears bite
summary: US stocks experienced the largest weekly outflows of the year, with $15.5 billion leaving US equity funds through April 13, amid growing recession fears. This follows a ninth consecutive week of outflows for European funds. Strategists attribute the exodus to rising food and energy prices, surging bond yields, and concerns about global growth. However, some analysts, like BlackRock, remain optimistic, citing low real yields and central banks' reluctance to slow the economy.

site_title: What to expect from due diligence on and by an investment adviser
summary: The CFA Institute emphasizes the importance of diligence and a reasonable basis for investment recommendations. Investors expect professionals to exercise diligence and have a basis for recommending specific actions. The Diligence and Reasonable-Basis Standard requires investment advisers to review managers and funds thoroughly, considering factors like code of ethics, compliance procedures, and investment process. A case study illustrates the consequences of failing to meet this standard, highlighting the need for thorough analysis and consideration of client needs and circumstances when selecting investment products.

site_title: Russia's war in Ukraine to blame for worsening global food insecurity, says Yellen
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen says Russia's war in Ukraine is to blame for worsening global food insecurity, citing 800 million people already suffering from chronic food insecurity. Higher food prices could push 10 million more into poverty. Yellen urges countries to avoid export restrictions and support vulnerable populations, while the US works with partners to mitigate the effects of Russia's war and ensure food availability.

site_title: Singapore and New Zealand to collaborate on climate change, green economy: PM Lee, Ardern
summary: Singapore and New Zealand have strengthened their collaboration on climate change and the green economy, with a focus on initiatives such as energy transition technology, carbon markets, and sustainable transport. The two countries aim to work together to reduce their carbon footprint and seize growth opportunities in the green economy. This new area of collaboration is part of the Singapore-New Zealand Enhanced Partnership, which also includes trade and economics, security and defence, science, technology and innovation, and people-to-people links.

site_title: Oxley Garden seeking at least S$200m, on heels of adjacent 5 Oxley Rise tender
summary: Oxley Garden, a 58,207 square feet freehold plot in prime district 9, is set to be put up for collective sale with a minimum price of S$200 million. The sale follows the sale of 5 Oxley Rise, a nearby iconic mansion on a 151,205 square feet plot valued at over S$300 million. The sale of both sites is expected to enhance their value proposition and allow for a comprehensive redevelopment. The site is located near Somerset MRT Station and is within a Special Control Area, with potential for increased GFA and bonuses.

site_title: Perfect Ten's pricing shows early buyers don't always get the best deals
