summary: Singapore property developer CK Asset's Perfect Ten project is offering discounts to early buyers, sparking questions about the practice of "one-time" discounts and potential refunds. Analysts and consultants say that early-bird buyers don't always get better deals, and refunds are unlikely in a downtrend. Developers are not obligated to refund buyers after price reductions, and such cases are rare. The practice raises questions about transparency in pricing and the potential for future price increases, with some experts suggesting that developers may be more cautious in their pricing strategies amid economic uncertainty.

site_title: No final declaration at G-20 finance ministers summit
summary: The G-20 finance ministers and central bank heads meeting will not produce a final declaration with common goals due to Russia's planned virtual participation. The meeting will focus on global economic issues, the consequences of the Ukraine war, and pandemic preparedness. Germany and its allies will condemn Russia's invasion as the reason for the global economic slowdown, soaring energy prices, and possible famines.

site_title: When 'one-time' condo discounts are anything but, do buyers have any recourse?
summary: Developers in Singapore's private residential sector offer discounts on units, raising questions about buyers' recourse when prices drop further. Analysts and lawyers express mixed views on the issue, with some arguing that developers should provide clarity and transparency on pricing and discounts. In the case of CK Asset's Perfect Ten condominium, units were initially launched at high prices, but subsequent discounts have been offered. Buyers who purchased units at the discounted price may not be entitled to partial refunds if prices continue to fall, as developers are not obligated to refund early buyers in a price downtrend.

site_title: Flight bookings show pent-up travel demand, bodes well for Singapore’s air traffic target
summary: Singapore's air traffic is expected to recover, with flight bookings surging 178% of pre-Covid levels for upcoming public holidays in May. The strong demand is attributed to pent-up travel, with regional countries like Maldives, Cambodia, and Thailand seeing a significant increase in bookings. This trend suggests Singapore may reach its target of at least 50% of pre-Covid airport traffic this year, according to global air travel analytics firm ForwardKeys.

site_title: Price cuts at Perfect Ten condo in Bukit Timah raise eyebrows
summary: Price cuts at the luxury condominium Perfect Ten in Singapore's Bukit Timah have raised eyebrows among industry watchers, with some units sold at discounted prices exceeding the initial 5% offer. The developer, CK Asset, offered a "one-time" 5% discount on listed prices when the project launched in December 2022, but subsequent price revisions have been implemented, with some units sold at prices lower than the original list. The developer has not confirmed whether discounts larger than 5% have been offered, but industry observers have expressed surprise at the timing and quantum of certain discounts.

site_title: LHN’s logistics arm to be spun off, will raise S$5 million through IPO
summary: LHN Logistics, a subsidiary of LHN Group, plans to spin off and list on the stock market through an initial public offering (IPO), raising approximately S$5 million. The IPO will see the listing of 25.2 million shares at S$0.20 each, with net proceeds going towards the construction of an ISO tank depot and expansion of its transportation fleet. The IPO is expected to raise S$3.6 million after deducting listing expenses.

site_title: US lifts mask mandate on aeroplanes, trains after court ruling
summary: The US lifted its mask mandate on public transportation after a federal judge in Florida ruled the 14-month-old directive was unlawful. US District Judge Kathryn Kimball Mizelle overturned the White House effort to reduce Covid-19 spread, citing the CDC exceeding its authority and not seeking public comment. The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) will no longer enforce the mask mandate, but the CDC recommends continuing to wear masks in indoor public transportation settings. The ruling comes as Covid-19 cases rise in the US, with 36,251 new infections reported daily.

site_title: City Energy unveils cross-border EV charging service in Singapore, Malaysia
summary: City Energy has launched a cross-border EV charging service, Go, connecting Singapore and Malaysia through the Go mobile application. The service, valued at S$100 million, aims to eradicate range anxiety for EV drivers traveling between the two countries. A strategic partnership with Malaysian company EV Connection allows seamless access to charging services on both sides of the causeway and along the North-South Highway in Malaysia. This service is set to expand to 13 charging points by 2030, catering to the growing demand for electric vehicle charging infrastructure in the region.

site_title: As China's travel chill deepens, tourist-starved regions struggle to get by
summary: China's domestic tourism continues to decline due to ongoing Covid-related curbs and lockdowns. Provinces heavily reliant on tourism, such as Hainan and Yunnan, are slashing ticket prices and offering tax breaks to attract visitors. The slump has worsened since the Omicron variant took hold, with the industry facing its worst state since before the pandemic. The downturn may remove 0.5 percentage points from China's 2022 GDP growth, threatening the government's 5.5% growth target.

site_title: Nanofilm records 27% growth in Q1 revenue amid growth in all business units
summary: Nanofilm Technologies reported a 27% increase in Q1 revenue, driven by growth in all business units. The advanced materials business unit accounted for 81% of revenue, with the 3C segment contributing 77.8%. The company expects a strong business pipeline in the 3C segment, despite potential logistics and production challenges.

site_title: Price cuts at Perfect Ten condo nettle at least one early buyer
summary: A luxury condominium in Singapore's prime District 10, Perfect Ten, is offering discounts exceeding 5% after initial price cuts in December, raising eyebrows among industry watchers. The developer, CK Asset, initially offered a 5% discount, but subsequent price revisions have resulted in discounts of up to 6.19% for certain units. An individual buyer is seeking compensation for the difference, citing a legal letter to the developer. Industry observers question the timing and quantum of the discounts, with some units selling at lower prices than expected.

site_title: Shipping and ESG: sailing through a minefield
summary: The shipping industry is under increasing pressure to reduce its environmental impact, with many companies setting ambitious targets to achieve net zero greenhouse gas emissions. Despite this, some critics argue that the industry is not doing enough, citing examples such as the approval of new coal and oil carriers. The introduction of ESG criteria has become a key consideration for investors, with companies like AP Moller-Maersk and OCBC Bank providing loans with sustainability-linked conditions. However, the industry's social and governance issues, such as labor practices and transparency, remain a challenge, and the environmental lobby may continue to push for further action.

site_title: Billionaire Lego fund surges on toymaker, portfolio gains
summary: Kirkbi Invest, the investment fund behind the Lego family, reported record returns of 23.3% in 2022, driven by higher profit at Lego and a stock-market boom. The fund's net income quadrupled to 27 billion kroner (S$5.4 billion), with equity portfolio gains outpacing the company's target of 5-7%. Notable gains were seen in ISS and Nilfisk Holding, with the latter experiencing its first annual gain after being split from NKT in 2017. The fund's performance surpassed losses in bonds and green energy investments.

site_title: Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust's H2 DPU up 2.8%
summary: Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT) reported a 2.8% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) for the second half-year ended Mar 31, 2022, to S$0.03393, driven by lower rental reliefs and contributions from the Hewlett-Packard Japan Headquarters Building. Gross revenue and net property income also rose 4.9% and 5.1%, respectively. The trust attributed the increase to easing COVID-19 measures and improved consumer sentiment. For the full-year, MNACT posted a 10.4% rise in DPU.

site_title: Online merchants spared fuel, inflation surcharges for now
summary: E-commerce platforms and logistics firms in Singapore have decided not to implement additional fuel and inflation surcharges on online merchants using their services, despite rising costs. Companies like Qxpress, J&T Express, and Pickupp have opted for alternative measures, such as optimizing productivity and efficiency, and leveraging their networks to reduce costs. These firms aim to mitigate the impact of inflationary pressures on their business without passing on costs to customers.

site_title: New Covid-19 cases in Singapore nearly double to 4,718, one death reported
summary: Singapore reported 4,718 new Covid-19 cases on Tuesday, nearly doubling from the previous day, with 1 death. The number of hospitalised cases increased to 278. The country's Covid-19 week-on-week infection ratio remains below one, indicating a stable trend. Of the local cases, 4,085 were detected through antigen rapid tests, while 459 were detected through PCR tests. Singapore has recorded 1,167,498 Covid-19 cases and 1,317 deaths, with 96% of the eligible population fully vaccinated.

site_title: Delegate protests over Russia to upstage G20 meeting
summary: Western nations are preparing to stage diplomatic protests at the G20 finance ministers meeting in Washington on April 20, amid Russia's ongoing invasion of Ukraine. The protests will include walk-outs and snubs, with US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and French finance ministry officials expected to skip sessions joined by Russian officials. The IMF has slashed its global economic growth forecast due to the war, warning of a "clear and present danger" for many countries. The meeting, originally focused on global economic recovery, will likely be marred by divisions among G20 nations over trade and finance rules.

site_title: Singtel to appeal court case relating to acquisition financing of Optus
summary: Singtel is appealing a court case related to the acquisition financing of its Australian subsidiary, Optus, from 2001. The company's Australian subsidiary, STAI, has filed an appeal to the Full Federal Court of Australia after receiving an unfavorable judgment. Singtel had previously deferred payment of primary tax, interest, and penalties until the legal process is completed. The company is seeking to resolve the matter, but no further details have been provided.

site_title: Japan to fund 114.5 billion yen to help develop low-emission fuels
summary: Japan's state-backed New Energy and Industrial Technology Development Organization (Nedo) will allocate 114.5 billion yen (S$1225 million) to develop low-emission fuels, including synthetic liquefied fuels and sustainable aviation fuels. The funding is part of Japan's 2 trillion yen green innovation fund to achieve carbon neutrality by 2050. The projects will focus on reducing CO2 emissions, with goals including the development of synthetic liquefied fuels, made by combining hydrogen with CO2 extracted from the atmosphere.

site_title: Guitar that broke Oasis up for auction in Paris
summary: A guitar smashed by Oasis frontman Noel Gallagher backstage at a 2009 concert in Paris is set to be auctioned in Paris on May 17. The red Gibson guitar, which Noel later had repaired, is expected to fetch 500,000 euros. The incident contributed to the band's breakup, which was also fueled by a long-standing feud between Noel and brother Liam. The auction also features other rare music items, including a Depeche Mode bondage gear set and a signed vinyl by Jimi Hendrix and Johnny Hallyday.

site_title: Hasbro misses profit estimates, warns of US$100m Russia hit
summary: Hasbro reported a quarterly profit of 57 cents per share, missing estimates of 61 cents per share, due to a surge in freight and raw material costs. The toy maker warned of a potential revenue hit of about $100 million this year due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Despite a 4% increase in net revenue to $1.16 billion, Hasbro's adjusted operating margin fell to 12.2% from 15.6%. The company expects fiscal 2022 operating profit to rise in the mid-single digits, compared to its previous forecast of a low-single-digit increase.

site_title: BT Explains: Singapore's non-monetary gold trade
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) remained positive in March due to a 86.5% year-on-year growth in non-monetary gold shipments. The US was a significant end-market for non-monetary gold, while China's NODX was kept positive by miscellaneous transactions, which jumped nearly 10 times from last year.

site_title: US: S&P 500 opens flat as bond yields hit new highs
summary: US stocks opened flat on Tuesday, with the S&P 500 index unchanged and the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.05%. Bond yields hit new highs amid expectations of aggressive interest rate hikes due to inflation and the Ukraine war. Investors awaited more earnings reports to assess the impact on companies.

site_title: IMF cuts global growth forecast due to 'seismic waves' from Russia's war in Ukraine
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has cut its global growth forecast due to the "seismic waves" caused by Russia's war in Ukraine, slashing its 2022 and 2023 forecasts by 0.8 and 0.2 percentage points, respectively. The war is expected to slow growth and increase inflation, with medium-term global growth projected at 3.3% and inflation forecast to remain higher for longer. The IMF warns of a rising risk of social unrest and a more permanent fragmentation of the world economy.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit posts 0.2% increase in Q1 DPU
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported a 0.2% increase in Q1 distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.02466, despite a 1.4% decline in net property income and 0.9% drop in gross revenue. The Reit's distributable income rose 5.9% due to recent acquisitions and investment gains. The company attributed lower contributions from Singapore assets to a client payment dispute and higher electricity costs. Despite this, the Reit's portfolio occupancy remained high at 98.7% and its aggregate leverage stood at 36.1%.

site_title: Lockheed quarterly profit falls 5.7% on supply chain snags
summary: Lockheed Martin's quarterly revenue fell 8% to $14.96 billion, while profits dropped 5.7% to $1.73 billion, due to supply chain disruptions caused by the Covid-19 pandemic and inflation. The company reaffirmed its full-year revenue outlook of $66 billion. Despite this, its Aeronautics unit saw a 2% increase in revenue and 2% decline in profits, with 26 F-35 fighter jet deliveries in the quarter. Lockheed shares fell 2.4% to $456 in premarket trading.

site_title: Russia launches 'Battle of Donbas' all-out assault on east Ukraine
summary: Russia has launched a full-scale assault on eastern Ukraine, dubbed the "Battle of Donbas," with thousands of troops attempting to seize two provinces. Ukrainian officials claim their forces will withstand the attack, but Russia has already made gains in the frontline town of Kreminna in Luhansk province. The assault comes after Russia regrouped following its failed assault on Kyiv in March and is also targeting the southeastern port city of Mariupol, where hundreds of civilians are believed to have died. Western countries accuse Russia of unprovoked aggression, and Ukraine's president, Volodymyr Zelenskiy, vows to defend his country against the new attack.

site_title: What to expect from due diligence on and by an investment adviser
summary: Investors are advised to conduct their own due diligence when seeking investment advice, whether from a professional or a friend. A professional investment adviser is expected to exercise diligence and have a reasonable basis for recommending a course of action. The Diligence and Reasonable-Basis Standard, provided by the CFA Institute, emphasizes the importance of thorough analysis and transparency. Investment advisers must review external managers as diligently as they review individual funds and securities. A case study highlights the importance of diligence, as an investment adviser failed to conduct a thorough analysis before recommending a fund managed by a friend.

site_title: Russia to spend over 2.5 trillion roubles to support economy under sanctions
summary: Russia plans to spend over 2.5 trillion roubles (S$42.4 billion) to support its economy under western sanctions, Finance Minister Anton Siluanov announced. The move comes as the country faces soaring inflation, capital flight, and a possible debt default due to the sanctions imposed over President Vladimir Putin's actions in Ukraine.

site_title: Opec+ supply gap widens in March as sanctions hit Russian output
summary: Opec+ saw a widening supply gap in March, with production 1.45 million barrels per day (bpd) below targets. Russia's output declined by 300,000 bpd due to Western sanctions. Compliance with production cuts rose to 157% in March, the highest since May 2020. Opec+ agreed to a 432,000 bpd oil output boost for May, despite pressure from major consumers. The group is unwinding production cuts, but some West African countries are struggling to meet their targets.

site_title: KORE reports 11% increase in Q1 distributable income
summary: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit (KORE) reported a 10.9% increase in Q1 distributable income to US$16.6 million, driven by gross revenue and net property income growth. The Reit's acquisitions in August 2021 contributed to the increase. KORE's balance sheet remains strong with 91.7% portfolio occupancy and no long-term refinancing requirements until November 2023. The Reit's exposure to rising interest rates is manageable, with a 0.062 US cents decrease in distributions per unit per annum for every 50 basis points increase in interest rates.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise on Tuesday amid mixed regional trading; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.1% on Tuesday, rebounding from a 2-day losing streak, amid mixed regional trading. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,307.13, with Sembcorp Industries leading gains and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding falling. Institutional investors continued to pare down on exposure in the financial sector, posing a headwind for the STI. Despite this, regional markets ended higher, with Tokyo, Australia, and South Korea rising between 0.6 and 1%.

site_title: Mercedes-Benz launches second all-electric SUV
summary: Mercedes-Benz has unveiled its EQS, the company's second all-electric SUV, with a 660 km range and production starting in Tuscaloosa, Alabama this year. The vehicle will be sold in the US and Canada, with Europe to follow by the end of the year. The US market, where three-quarters of new car sales are trucks and SUVs, poses a challenge for reducing carbon footprint. Mercedes-Benz sold 21,900 fully-electric vehicles in the first quarter of 2022, up 3 times from the same period last year.

site_title: Thai central bank chief says growth a bigger worry than inflation for now
summary: Thailand's central bank chief, Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput, has stated that the country's focus is on shoring up sluggish growth rather than addressing inflation, which has reached a 13-year high of 5.73% in March. The economy is expected to grow 1.8% year-on-year in the first quarter, and the central bank will prioritize maintaining the recovery. Despite inflation concerns, the bank expects it to return to target levels next year and does not anticipate stagflation.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close with heavy losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted on Tuesday, April 19, 2022, with the Hang Seng Index falling 2.28% to close at 21,027.76, due to concerns over China's growth and regulatory restrictions on tech companies. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also fell, with losses of 0.05% and 0.11% respectively. The decline was attributed to Beijing's ongoing regulatory restrictions and China growth concerns.

site_title: Ukraine war, high energy costs and ESG rules hit copper supply, keeping prices high
summary: Copper supply is expected to remain short due to ongoing war between Russia and Ukraine, high energy costs, and stricter emissions standards in China, keeping prices high. DBS analyst Lee Eun Young forecasts a 336,000-tonne deficit in copper supply for 2022, with prices averaging $9,500 per tonne. Despite a 4.4% growth in mined copper supply, refined copper production is expected to grow 3.2% in 2022, largely driven by growth in China and Chile. Demand is expected to remain intact, but with a strong recovery in China expected in 2023, the market is expected to switch to a slight surplus.

site_title: Sri Lanka to seek US$3b to stave off crisis, says finance minister
summary: Sri Lanka's finance minister, Ali Sabry, announced the country needs approximately $3 billion in external assistance in the next six months to address fuel and medicine shortages, amid a prolonged economic crisis. The government plans to restructure international sovereign bonds, seek a moratorium on payments, and negotiate with bondholders. Sabry emphasized that the goal is not to default on debt, but to address the crisis and restore essential supplies. The country has reached out to rating agencies, rating agencies, and international financial institutions for support.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets drop at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets declined at the start of trading on Tuesday, Apr 19, following a long Easter weekend. London's FTSE 100 index dropped 0.1%, while Frankfurt's DAX index fell 0.7% and the Paris CAC 40 lost 0.8%. The declines were attributed to no major news or economic data releases, leaving investors with limited reasons to buy.

site_title: City Energy unveils cross-border EV charging service in Singapore and Malaysia
summary: City Energy has launched a cross-border electric vehicle (EV) charging service, Go, between Singapore and Malaysia, with a S$100 million investment. The service allows EV owners to charge their vehicles on both sides of the causeway and along the North-South Highway in Malaysia. By 2030, City Energy plans to install charging points in private residential and commercial sites, with at least 100 chargers in Singapore within the next decade. The service aims to alleviate range anxiety for EV owners and supports Singapore's transition to low-emission vehicles.

site_title: How to recession-proof  your investments
summary: A recession is inevitable, but investors can mitigate its impact by focusing on defensive shares. These companies, such as utility providers, supermarkets, and healthcare REITs, tend to perform well during economic downturns due to their stable demand. Examples of defensive shares include Sembcorp Industries, Singtel, and Parkway Life REIT. These companies are cash-generative and can help protect portfolios from recession by generating cash that can be reinvested to improve total returns.

site_title: Business must step up in new era of environmental activism
summary: Business must step up its environmental activism in the wake of a landmark report from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), warning that global emissions must start declining in under three years to limit average temperature rise to 1.5 degrees Celsius. Despite governments' efforts, the private sector is crucial in driving a greener and more prosperous future, with the need for greater participation and investment in sustainable technologies. The report's stark message is that it is "now or never" to act, with the world at a crossroads on whether to avoid climate catastrophe.

site_title: Japan's 7-Eleven operator picks former Uber executive as it looks overseas
summary: Japanese retailer Seven & I Holdings has nominated Elizabeth Miin Meyerdirk, a former Uber executive, to join its board of directors. The move aims to address pressure from activist investors to reform the company's structure and focus on growth overseas, particularly in North America. As part of this strategy, Seven & I will expand online shopping and delivery services in Japan. The nomination, pending shareholder approval, is seen as a step towards addressing activist investors' demands, which include selling underperforming assets and doubling the company's share price.

site_title: As China's travel chill deepens, tourist-starved regions struggle to get by
summary: China's domestic tourism continues to struggle due to Covid-related curbs, with provinces like Hainan and Yunnan bearing the brunt. Ticket prices have been slashed, tax breaks offered, and locals are being encouraged to visit popular spots. The slump has worsened with the Omicron variant, leaving the industry in its worst state since the pandemic. The tourism sector, which employs tens of millions of people and contributed 11.05% to China's GDP in 2019, may see a 0.5 percentage point reduction in GDP growth this year.

site_title: Benefiting from a commodities supercycle
summary: Russia's invasion of Ukraine poses significant risks to the global economy, with soaring inflation and supply chain disruptions. The war has driven up energy prices due to sanctions on Russia, which is the world's second-largest crude oil exporter and supplies over 40% of Europe's natural gas. Additionally, Russia's dominance in metal and fertilizer production has led to price increases and supply shortages, particularly for fertilizers. This commodity supercycle presents opportunities for investors seeking to profit from the market's uncertainties.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: A rare freehold landed site in Orchard, Singapore, is up for sale with expected offers of over S$300 million. Oil prices have reached a new milestone, rising to around US$100 per barrel, due to geopolitical tensions. United Hampshire US Reit has revised the sale consideration of its self-storage assets to US$45.5 million. A cross-border EV charging service, Go by City Energy, has been unveiled between Singapore and Malaysia. Singapore stocks rebounded on Tuesday, rising 0.1% amid mixed regional trading.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks hit 2-week high as chipmakers boost
summary: South Korea's Kospi index rose 0.95% to a 2-week high on Tuesday, driven by gains from chipmakers Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix. The benchmark index closed at 2,718.89, led by a rebound in the US Philadelphia semiconductor index. The Korean won weakened, and the benchmark bond yield fell. Foreigners were net sellers of 1.3 billion won worth of shares, while the central bank nominee suggested a more sedate pace of monetary policy hikes.

site_title: BT podcast: The importance of ESG in the Asian bond market
summary: The Business Times podcast discusses the importance of Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) factors in the Asian bond market. Hosted by Howie Lim and Lee Kim Siang, the episode explores how investors are increasingly incorporating ESG considerations into their investment decisions. Key findings include a growing demand for ESG-compliant bonds and a shift towards sustainable investing in Asia. The discussion highlights the significance of ESG in the Asian bond market and its potential impact on the region's economic growth and development.

site_title: Russia unleashes offensive into east Ukraine: Zelensky
summary: Russia has launched a major offensive into eastern Ukraine, targeting the Donbas region, according to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. The US is set to hold a video meeting with allies to discuss the conflict. This new phase of the invasion follows failed attempts to capture the capital, Kyiv. Russia has been preparing for the battle for Donbas for a long time, Zelensky said.

site_title: China developers speed up diversification after debt-led growth fuels crisis
summary: Chinese developers are accelerating diversification efforts to cut their reliance on high-debt, high-turnover property development models. Following Beijing's call, companies such as KWG Group Holdings, CIFI Holdings, and China Resources Land have listed plans to expand into asset-light businesses like property services and commercial real estate. However, analysts warn that diversification will pile cost pressure on smaller firms and may not yield immediate benefits. Premier Li Keqiang has urged companies to adopt a new development model, but some developers say the process will be "long and painful."

site_title: Tokyo: Shares rebound on bargain-hunting
summary: Tokyo stocks rebounded on Tuesday, April 19, 2022, as investors engaged in bargain-hunting after modest falls on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.69% to 26,985.09, while the Topix index gained 0.83% to 1,895.70. This rebound follows similar trends in other Asian markets.

site_title: Sri Lanka says IMF to consider request for rapid aid
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is considering providing quick financial assistance to debt-burdened Sri Lanka, following representations by India and the Sri Lankan finance ministry. Sri Lanka has requested a loan under the IMF's rapid financial instrument (RFI) window to top up its reserves and pay for essential imports. The IMF has agreed to consider the special request, despite it being outside of standard circumstances for RFI issuance. Sri Lanka is seeking $3 billion in funding from multiple sources to stave off its financial crisis, which has been exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic and rising fuel prices.

site_title: Asia-Pacific lags in hiring for green jobs: LinkedIn
summary: The Asia-Pacific region lags behind Europe and the US in hiring for green jobs, according to LinkedIn's report. Despite rising demand for green skills globally, the 5 Asia-Pacific countries studied (Australia, China, India, New Zealand, and Singapore) saw a lower growth rate in green job postings and hiring compared to Europe and the US. India's green hiring declined, while China's growth was marginal. Singapore's green transformation is making mixed progress, and Australia's green job growth is mostly due to government-backed initiatives. The report highlights the urgent need for Asia-Pacific countries to accelerate their green transformations to meet climate change goals.

site_title: Australia rate hike brought nearer by inflation, wages: RBA
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia is closer to raising interest rates for the first time in over a decade due to accelerating inflation and a tightening labor market. Core inflation rose above the bank's 2-3% target range in the March quarter, while wage growth is expected to pick up as the unemployment rate falls to 4% or lower. The RBA's Board believes the timing of the first interest rate increase has been brought forward, with more evidence on inflation and labor costs to be released in the coming months.

site_title: Boris Johnson to face MPs' fury over 'partygate'
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson will face angry lawmakers for the first time since being fined for breaking Covid lockdown laws. Despite facing calls to resign, Johnson is expected to try to sidestep the controversy with a "business as usual" approach. The Metropolitan Police Service is investigating dozens of alleged lockdown breaches, with over 50 fines issued so far. Johnson's survival chances have been boosted by his response to the war in Ukraine, but commentators doubt he can maintain his party's support if repeatedly fined and further scandals emerge.

site_title: Oil above US$100 a new reality for rest of 2022
summary: Oil prices are expected to remain above $100 per barrel for the rest of 2022 due to geopolitical tensions, constrained production, and rising demand. Experts predict Brent to average around $105/b, with some speculating prices could reach $120-130/b if Western sanctions on Russia increase. However, others rule out prices exceeding $200/b, citing caution and self-sanctioning among oil traders. The upcoming peak US driving season and China's potential exit from lockdowns could further impact oil prices, with some predicting a possible surge to $125/b.

site_title: What the US yield curve is telling us: How likely is a US recession?
summary: The US yield curve, which measures the difference between yields on long-dated and short-dated US Treasuries, is being closely watched by investors for guidance on the US economy. Historically, the curve has "predicted essentially every recession since 1950 with only one false signal," according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. A recent yield curve inversion, where yields in 2-year US Treasuries exceeded those in 10-year Treasuries, has raised concerns about a potential US recession.

site_title: Zilingo board said to discuss replacing CEO after suspension
summary: Zilingo's board is discussing replacing CEO Ankiti Bose amid an investigation into the Singapore startup's accounting practices. Bose was suspended in April after concerns emerged about the company's financial practices, including how it accounts for revenue on a platform used by thousands of small merchants. The board has not yet decided on a replacement, with options including interim leadership and senior executives. Sequoia Capital India, a major investor, has expressed concern over the situation and urged the company to fix the situation. Bose has denied any wrongdoing and is cooperating with the board's investigation.

site_title: Stellantis says it is suspending production in Russia
summary: Stellantis suspends production at its Russian plant in Kaluga due to logistical difficulties and sanctions imposed on Moscow. The move comes after the automaker stated it would close the plant in late March due to a shortage of parts. Stellantis is the world's fourth largest automaker and produced and sold several brands in Russia, including Peugeot, Citroën, Opel, Jeep, and Fiat. The company's decision is likely to impact the Russian automotive market.

site_title: Payments startup Thunes acquires majority stake in tech firm Tookitaki; invests over US$20m
summary: Thunes, a Singapore-based global payments startup, acquired a majority stake in anti-money laundering and compliance technology firm Tookitaki for over US$20 million. Both companies will continue to operate independently, expanding their global business presence. Tookitaki's capabilities will be integrated into Thunes, enhancing payment flow transparency and safeguarding its businesses. The deal will also allow Tookitaki to deepen its presence in key markets, including Asia-Pacific, the Middle East, Europe, and the Americas.

site_title: Is it the Cold War all over again?
summary: The US is facing "momentous" global challenges under President Joe Biden, who must mobilize public support and unite Western allies to counter perceived existential threats. The invasion of Ukraine by Russia has reignited concerns about a new Cold War, but it's unclear if the US is ready to lead the Western bloc in a renewed battle with Russia. Historically, the US and Russia have not posed an existential threat to each other, unlike the US and China, and the notion of a new Cold War seems "ludicrous." However, the US is reinvigorating NATO and adopting a tougher stance against Russia, with bipartisan support for President Biden's approach, but it remains uncertain whether Americans are willing to pay the costs of a long Cold War.

site_title: UN to debate move to limit veto power of Security Council permanent members
summary: The United Nations is set to debate a draft resolution that would require the 5 permanent members of the Security Council to justify their use of the veto power. The proposal, backed by the US, aims to limit Russia's use of the veto since its invasion of Ukraine. If approved, it would require a debate by the General Assembly within 10 working days of a veto. The proposal has been co-sponsored by over 50 countries, but the 4 permanent members, Russia, China, France, and Britain, have not yet committed to voting.

site_title: Singapore and New Zealand to collaborate on climate change, green economy: PM Lee, Ardern
summary: Singapore and New Zealand announced a collaboration on the green economy and climate change. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Jacinda Ardern made the announcement at a joint press conference. The two countries share similar perspectives on climate change, which they consider an existential challenge. They plan to strengthen cooperation to protect vulnerable peoples and places on the planet. This partnership aims to address the growing threat of climate change and promote sustainable development.

site_title: Rare freehold landed site at Oxley Rise expected to draw offers of over S$300m
summary: A freehold landed site at 5 Oxley Rise in District 9, Singapore, has been put up for sale by public tender. The 151,205 sq ft site, valued at over S$300 million, is one of the last remaining freehold sites in the Orchard Road district. It can be redeveloped into a single large mansion, strata, or mixed landed developments. The site features a 2-storey bungalow and 4 outhouses, surrounded by greenery. The sale is expected to draw significant interest from developers.

site_title: Indonesia central bank trims GDP outlook, keeps rates on hold
summary: Indonesia's central bank reduced its 2022 economic growth outlook due to inflation and geopolitical risks, while maintaining record-low interest rates to boost recovery. The benchmark 7-day reverse repurchase rate remained at 3.50% and other policy rates were left unchanged. This move signals concerns about the economy's growth, despite efforts to maintain low interest rates to support the recovery.

site_title: Sunseap, Riau Islands to build large-scale solar energy plants
summary: Sunseap, a clean energy solutions provider, has partnered with the Riau Islands provincial government in Indonesia to develop large-scale solar energy plants and storage systems. The plants will supply electricity to the Riau Islands and Singapore, creating thousands of jobs. The partnership covers 3,000 hectares of land for a 1,380-megawatt peak solar power plant and a 3,000-megawatt hour energy storage system on Combol Island, and a 1,682 MWp solar plant and 3,500 MWh energy storage system on Citlim Island. The move aims to transform the Riau Islands into a renewable energy hub.

site_title: Japan researchers develop electric chopsticks to enhance salty taste
summary: Japanese researchers have developed computerized chopsticks that enhance salty tastes by transmitting sodium ions from food to the mouth using electrical stimulation. The device, co-created by Meiji University professor Homei Miyashita and Kirin Holdings Co., aims to help those reduce sodium in their diets. The chopsticks can amplify the salty taste by 1.5 times, potentially benefiting those in Japan, where the traditional diet favors salty tastes and excessive sodium intake is linked to various health issues. The prototype is set to be commercialized as early as next year.

site_title: Japan's finance minister makes most explicit warning against yen slump, economic fallout
summary: Japan's finance minister Shunichi Suzuki warned that the damage from the yen's weakening is greater than its benefits, making it the most explicit warning against the currency's recent slump. The yen's fall has worsened imported inflationary pressures, exacerbating supply snags amid a global commodity and oil spike. Suzuki declined to comment on government response, but vowed to communicate with US and other countries' currency authorities. The yen hit a 20-year low against the dollar, despite Suzuki's verbal warnings, with investors citing fundamental factors driving the decline.

site_title: Bank of Korea governor nominee says monetary policy tightening will continue
summary: South Korea's Bank of Korea governor nominee, Rhee Chang-yong, stated that monetary policy tightening will continue to combat inflation and growth risks. The central bank will closely examine inflation and growth risks, citing uncertainties from the Ukraine crisis and US monetary policy. Rhee emphasized the need for continued policy tightening to ease household debt growth and maintain financial stability. The Bank of Korea recently raised its benchmark rate to 1.50% and Rhee is expected to start his four-year term once formally appointed.

site_title: Why open source is critical to addressing Singapore's tech talent shortage
summary: Singapore is facing a significant tech talent shortage, with a growing need for skilled data scientists, engineers, and developers. The country's investments in tech and global giants like Grab and Sea have exacerbated the issue. A global challenge, the shortage is driven by soaring expectations for seamless digital experiences. Companies are recognizing the transformative value of developers and are focusing on attracting and retaining the right talent to gain an edge over competitors. Open source is being highlighted as a critical factor in addressing this shortage, enabling developers to collaborate and innovate.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down in early trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks declined 1.78% in early trade on April 19, 2022, tracking global growth concerns and modest Wall Street falls. The Hang Seng Index dropped 382.28 points to 21,135.80, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.15%. The Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up 0.51%.

site_title: Pantera leads CoinDCX funding round at US$2.2b valuation
summary: CoinDCX, a Coinbase-backed cryptocurrency exchange, has raised US$135 million in a funding round led by Pantera Capital and Steadview Capital Management, valuing the company at US$2.15 billion. Despite Indian payment service providers stopping crypto transactions, CoinDCX plans to double its workforce and invest in the market, with co-founder Sumit Gupta stating the funding is "promising" and the company will continue to invest in India. The funding round also resulted in a 6% dilution of stake for Gupta and fellow co-founder Neeraj Khandelwal.

site_title: Hong Konger who bit off activist's ear sentenced to 15 years in jail
summary: A Hong Kong man, Joe Chen, was sentenced to nearly 15 years in jail for biting off the ear of democracy activist Andrew Chiu and attacking three others during protests in 2019. Chen shouted Chinese nationalist slogans before the attack, with a judge describing it as "very barbaric" and "defying belief". This is the longest prison term among those charged in relation to Hong Kong's social turmoil in 2019.

site_title: Hot stock: Aztech Global down 4.5% after Q1 results missed expectations
summary: Aztech Global's Q1 results missed market expectations, with revenue and net profit falling short of forecasts. The company reported a 10.4% on-year increase in revenue to S$128 million and a 5.3% on-year rise in net profit to S$13.9 million, but analysts noted that inflationary cost pressures and a temporary factory closure in March impacted the results. Despite this, analysts maintained "buy" calls on the stock, with some raising their target prices, citing a strong order book and optimism for business growth.

site_title: US homebuyers are getting discouraged by rising rates and prices
summary: US homebuyers are becoming discouraged due to rising mortgage rates and home prices. According to a New York Federal Reserve survey, consumers expect mortgage rates to increase to 6.7% and 8.2% in the next year and three years, respectively. The average probability of buying a home in the next three years dropped to 60.7% from 68.5% in 2021. Home prices are also expected to rise by 7% over the next year, with rents increasing by 11.5% in the same period. This trend may lead to a decline in housing market activity.

site_title: United Hampshire US Reit lowers sale consideration for self-storage assets
summary: United Hampshire US Reit has revised the sale consideration of its two self-storage properties, Elizabeth and Perth Amboy, to $45.5 million from $49 million. The revised consideration is 2.5% above the properties' latest valuation and 17.7% above their book value of $38.7 million. The Reit manager estimates net proceeds of $44.1 million after deducting transaction-related expenses, resulting in a cumulative divestment gain of $5.4 million. The divestment is expected to complete in Q2 2022 and is expected to enhance value for unitholders and strengthen the Reit's balance sheet.

site_title: Gold prices steady as lower Treasury yields offset dollar strength
summary: Gold prices steadied at $1,977.61 per ounce on Tuesday, offsetting pressure from 2-year highs in the dollar. Lower US Treasury yields, which eased off their highest level since 2018, limited losses in zero-yield gold. The dollar remained near a two-year high as investors braced for multiple interest rate hikes from the US Federal Reserve. Despite inflation concerns and a Ukraine crisis, gold prices remained stable, with spot silver and platinum also holding steady.

site_title: Reserve Bank of New Zealand Governor says policy weighted toward containing inflation expectations
summary: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand Governor, Adrian Orr, stated that policy is weighted towards containing inflation expectations, with the Monetary Policy Committee expecting more interest rate increases in coming quarters. Orr emphasized that if the bank doesn't act quickly, inflation expectations could escalate, posing a risk to the target inflation range. This indicates the bank's focus on controlling inflation, highlighting the potential for future rate hikes.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Tuesday's open; STI up 1.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 1.1% to 3,337.74 at Tuesday's open, led by gains from banks and other index counters. Gainers outnumbered losers 100 to 36, with 65.5 million securities worth S$74.9 million traded.

site_title: Taiwan faces tough choices as Covid cases hit record levels
summary: Taiwan is facing a challenging decision as COVID-19 cases surge to record levels, with the health minister predicting 1,000 daily cases by the end of the month. The island must choose between adopting a "zero-COVID" strategy like Hong Kong or embracing a "living with the virus" approach like New Zealand. Despite a high vaccination rate, concerns about the unvaccinated population and waning vaccine effectiveness are hindering efforts to reopen borders. The government is pushing for increased vaccination efforts, but residents remain divided on the issue, with some fearing the risks of reopening while others prioritize economic growth.

site_title: Asia-Pacific lags in hiring for green jobs: LinkedIn
summary: The hiring of green jobs in the Asia-Pacific region lags behind Europe and the US, according to a LinkedIn report. In 5 countries - Australia, China, India, New Zealand, and Singapore - green hiring accounts for less than 2% of total job postings. India and China have seen a decline in green hiring growth, while Singapore's green transformation is making mixed progress. The report highlights the urgent need for green skills in the workforce to address climate change, with the US, Australia, and New Zealand outpacing the region in green job hiring.

site_title: Australia: Miners, energy stocks lift shares to over 3-month high
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.7% to a 3-month high on Tuesday, driven by gains in mining and energy stocks due to strong commodity prices. Iron ore prices surged, supporting miners like Rio Tinto, BHP, and Fortescue. Energy stocks also rose, tracking an increase in oil prices amid Libyan outages. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 7,575.40, its highest since January 5. Investors await the Reserve Bank of Australia's minutes of its policy meeting for further guidance on monetary policy.

site_title: Yellen to push institutions to scale up response to war-fueled food security crisis
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen will convene a high-level panel to discuss the global response to a worsening food security crisis exacerbated by Russia's war against Ukraine. The panel will include heads of the IMF, World Bank, and other international institutions, aiming to push them to scale up their response to the crisis, which is particularly affecting emerging markets and developing countries. Yellen will warn against export bans and emphasize the need for continued research and innovation to adapt agricultural production to climate change.

site_title: On life transitions, legacy, and money
summary: A Singaporean writer reflects on his mother's legacy, who passed away after a battle with lung cancer. Unlike wealth management experts who focus on legal structures and financial products, Christopher Tan believes that legacy is about the values and memories left behind. His mother, a homemaker, prioritized giving to her family and creating a harmonious home, not accumulating wealth. The writer concludes that the intention behind a legacy, not the instruments used to achieve it, is what truly matters. He shares his own experiences of distributing his mother's remaining cash to his siblings and keeping her legacy alive through memories and values.

site_title: Japan to model digital yen tests on Sweden's approach, not China's
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) will model its digital yen tests on Sweden's approach, rather than China's, according to Kazushige Kamiyama, the head of the BOJ's payment system department. The BOJ will conduct experiments in measured steps, focusing on the framework and design of a central bank digital currency (CBDC) as part of an overall settlement system. The decision on issuing a CBDC is expected to be made by 2026, with ongoing studies in close cooperation with other major central banks.

site_title: Apollo Global interested in helping finance a bid for Twitter: sources
summary: Apollo Global Management is considering backing a potential bid for Twitter following Elon Musk's $43 billion unsolicited offer to take the company private. The firm may provide equity or debt to support the deal, potentially in the form of credit or preferred equity. This move comes after The Wall Street Journal reported Apollo's interest in financing a Twitter bid.

site_title: Cristiano Ronaldo says one of his newborn twins has died
summary: Cristiano Ronaldo announced on social media that one of his newborn twins has died, sharing a heartfelt post with his partner Georgina Rodriguez. The couple had announced the pregnancy last year and welcomed a baby girl, who gave them the strength to cope with the loss. Ronaldo, who already has four children, expressed his devastation and asked for privacy during this difficult time, describing the deceased baby boy as their "angel" and promising to always love him.

site_title: US will no longer enforce mask mandate on airplanes, trains after court ruling
summary: The Biden administration will no longer enforce the US mask mandate on public transportation after a federal judge in Florida ruled the 14-month-old directive was unlawful. The CDC recommends wearing masks in indoor public transportation settings, while the TSA will not enforce its security directives requiring mask use. Airlines such as United and Alaska have relaxed mask restrictions on domestic flights. The ruling comes as Covid-19 infections rise in the US, with 36,251 new infections reported daily. The White House called the ruling "disappointing."

site_title: Stocks to watch: United Hampshire US Reit, SIA, Keppel Infrastructure Trust, Aztech Global
summary: United Hampshire US Reit revised the sale consideration of its self-storage properties to US$45.5 million, above valuation and purchase price, benefiting unitholders. Singapore Airlines reported a 64% increase in passengers carried in March 2022 and improved passenger load factor. Keppel Infrastructure Trust saw a 21.1% decline in distributable income for the first quarter, while Aztech Global posted a 5.3% rise in net profit for the first quarter.

site_title: Oil rises over 1% as Libya outages add to Russia supply fears
summary: Oil prices rose over 1% on Monday, with Brent crude reaching $113.16 a barrel, amid concerns over tight global supply due to Libya's National Oil Corp outages and Russia's production decline. The Ukraine crisis and China's slowing economy also contributed to supply pressures. Analysts warn that even minor disruptions could have a significant impact on prices.

site_title: Aztech Global Q1 net profit up 5% on IoT, data comm products demand
summary: Aztech Global, a design and manufacturing services provider, reported a 5.3% year-over-year increase in net profit to S$13.9 million for Q1 FY2022. Revenue rose 10.4% to S$128 million, driven by strong demand for IoT devices and data communication products. However, inflationary cost pressures led to margin compression. The company remains in a strong net-cash position and has a robust order book of S$677.4 million.

site_title: Abercrombie & Fitch film on Netflix is latest tale of corporate misdeeds
summary: The Netflix documentary "White Hot: The Rise & Fall of Abercrombie & Fitch" premieres on April 19, 2022, focusing on Mike Jeffries' 2-decade tenure as CEO of Abercrombie & Fitch. Jeffries' marketing strategy, which promoted an "all-American" look of white, fratty, and fit individuals, drove record profits for the brand. The documentary explores how Abercrombie leveraged exclusionary practices to achieve success, featuring celebrities like Taylor Swift and Channing Tatum in its ads. The film serves as a cautionary tale of corporate misdeeds in the retail industry.

site_title: Singapore coal tycoon is making billions in a world aiming to go green
summary: Low Tuck Kwong, a Singapore coal tycoon, has seen his stake in Indonesian mining company PT Bayan Resources more than double in value, making him one of the wealthiest people in the industry, with a stake worth $6.1 billion. Despite global efforts to shift away from coal, demand remains high, driven by post-pandemic economic activity and the war in Ukraine. Coal producers, including Bayan Resources, are benefiting from the increased demand, with revenue more than doubling to $2.9 billion last year and plans to increase production capacity to 60 million tons by 2026.

site_title: Cruise ships return to Australia after 2-year Covid ban
summary: A cruise ship, Pacific Explorer, docked in Sydney Harbour for the first time in over 2 years, marking the end of a 2-year COVID-19 ban. The ship began its 18,000-km journey back to Australia in March, and its arrival was met with crowds gathered at the base of the Sydney Harbour Bridge. This lifting of the ban is seen as a significant step forward for the Australian tourism industry, which has been severely impacted by the pandemic.

site_title: Trendlines seeks new board member after independent director retires
summary: The Trendlines Group is seeking a new board member following the retirement of independent director Stephen Haslett, effective April 13, citing personal and family commitments. Haslett's departure poses a compliance risk under Singapore's Code of Corporate Governance, requiring a majority of independent directors and a minimum of three directors on the remuneration committee. Once a suitable candidate is identified, Trendlines plans to review and adjust its board composition to comply with the code and applicable Catalist rules.

site_title: US: Stocks edge lower as treasury yields rise further
summary: US stocks fell on Monday as treasury yields rose further, driven by worries over the economic impact of higher interest rates. The yield on the 10-year US Treasury note surpassed 2.8%, amid the Federal Reserve's aggressive plan to combat inflation. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index all declined, with Twitter and Bank of America rising. The housing market faces an inflection point due to rising interest rates and home prices, according to the National Association of Home Builders.

site_title: US warns on China pact as diplomats head to Solomon Islands
summary: The US has voiced alarm over a potential security deal between China and the Solomon Islands, citing concerns that Beijing will gain a military foothold in the South Pacific. US diplomats led by Kurt Campbell and Daniel Kritenbrink will visit the Solomon Islands, Fiji, and Papua New Guinea to curb China's inroads. A leaked draft of a security agreement between the Solomon Islands and China has sparked fear, despite the Solomon Islands' Prime Minister stating that no military base will be built. The US believes signing such an agreement could destabilize the Solomon Islands and set a concerning precedent.

site_title: Russia hits targets across Ukraine, fighters cling on in Mariupol
summary: Russia launched missile attacks across Ukraine, destroying hundreds of military targets, including command posts and facilities in the Kharkiv, Zaporizhzhia, and Donetsk regions. The attacks killed 7 people in the western city of Lviv and wounded 11. Ukrainian forces continue to fight in the besieged port city of Mariupol, with Russian troops attempting to take full control of the city, which would unite Russian forces on two main axes of the invasion.

site_title: Kuroda steps up yen warning to stave off stimulus doubts
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda has stepped up warnings about sharp yen movements to maintain unity with the government on continuing monetary stimulus. Kuroda's comments, made in a parliamentary session, emphasize the need to consider negative factors from rapid yen changes, which could harm businesses. The yen has weakened to a 20-year low, prompting concerns about its impact on the economy. Kuroda's aim is to slow down the yen's decline without altering his commitment to stimulus, as investors bet on a potential policy adjustment by the BOJ.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 1.04% and the Topix index gaining 0.94%. Investors sought bargains after modest falls on Wall Street, pushing the benchmark indices higher. This move follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a fresh record for the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq despite US-EU trade uncertainty.

site_title: Covid hammers China's developers by starving them of cash flow
summary: China's Covid-19 outbreak is prolonging the country's property slump, starving developers of cash flow and weighing on the economy. The industry is experiencing a 29% drop in new home sales in March, the largest since July last year, due to lockdowns in key cities like Shanghai. Debt-laden developers are struggling with liquidity crisis as financing dries up and more bonds come due. Policymakers face pressure to shore up an economy with weakening consumer spending and the highest unemployment rate since the pandemic.

site_title: Edtech startups bank on continuing demand for online learning
summary: Edtech startups are banking on continued demand for online learning despite economies emerging from the pandemic and potentially tighter funding. Recent funding rounds for companies like Unacademy, Emeritus, LingoAce, and Cialfo indicate investor interest in the sector. The surge in demand for upskilling and reskilling, as well as universities shifting online, is driving growth. Experts predict edtech will remain integral to schools even as Covid-19 restrictions loosen, and companies like Cialfo are seeing structural changes in people's lives. However, the sector faces a rocky road ahead with inflation, monetary tightening, and geopolitical risk.

site_title: Biden has 'no plans' to visit Ukraine: White House
summary: US President Joe Biden has no plans to visit Ukraine, despite Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky's request for US support. Press Secretary Jen Psaki stated that a high-ranking official, such as Secretary of State Antony Blinken or Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin, will instead represent the US. Biden's visit would pose security challenges, but the administration hopes to reopen the US embassy in Kyiv in the future, with no timeline given. Zelensky expressed confidence that Biden will visit, but it is ultimately the president's decision, citing safety concerns.

site_title: Steps taken to mitigate situation in Russia and Ukraine: Food Empire
summary: Food Empire, a Singapore-based food and beverage manufacturer, has made changes to its inventory management and pricing policies in response to the conflict in Ukraine. The company expects profits from operations in Russia and Ukraine to decrease in FY22, but remains cautiously optimistic due to its past experience and diversified markets. Food Empire has also temporarily halted share buyback and is exploring alternatives to ensure business continuity under challenging market conditions.

site_title: New tranche of US arms for Ukraine starts to arrive
summary: The US has started delivering a new $800-million military aid package to Ukraine, including 18 155mm howitzers, 40,000 artillery rounds, and 200 armoured personnel carriers. The first shipments arrived at Ukraine's borders just 48 hours after President Joe Biden authorized the aid delivery. The training of Ukrainian soldiers to handle the howitzers is set to begin in the next several days, with the training taking place outside of Ukraine. The US aid is seen as a significant boost to Ukraine's fight against the Russian invasion, with the US official stating it has had an effect on Russia's ability to restock and resupply.

site_title: China slowdown threatens Singapore trade as exports ease again in March
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic export (NODX) growth slowed for the fourth month in March, despite beating private-sector economists' forecasts. Analysts attribute this to mainland China's zero-Covid stance, which poses a significant downside risk to Singapore's exports. Despite this, the global demand for electronics and pharmaceuticals remains robust, offering a positive outlook for exports.

site_title: PUB seeks proposals on using emerging tech for coastal protection
summary: Public Utilities Board (PUB) in Singapore is seeking proposals for using emerging technologies like machine learning and radar satellite imagery to protect the country's coastlines from rising sea levels. PUB, which was appointed the nation's coastal protection agency in 2020, has allocated S$51 million for the initiative. The agency is also conducting site-specific studies to protect the north-west coast, particularly the 24 km coastline from Tuas Checkpoint to Lim Chu Kang jetty, from seawater inundation and sea level rises.

site_title: With Sers and Vers, HDB homes can trump private leasehold homes
summary: Singapore's Housing and Development Board (HDB) has introduced two schemes, Sers and Vers, to mitigate land lease decay for HDB flat owners. These schemes allow HDB homes to outlast private leasehold homes, which sit on 99-year land leases. Successful en bloc sales of leasehold residential developments have led to the construction of new condominiums. The schemes aim to provide a more stable and secure living environment for HDB owners, reducing the risk of land expropriation upon lease expiry.

site_title: As major economies meet, US looks to increase pressure on Russia
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen will urge major economies to increase pressure on Russia over its Ukraine invasion during the IMF and World Bank spring meetings. The discussions will focus on the war's economic impact and the global economy. Finance officials from the G-7 and G-20 nations will also meet this week to address the issue.

site_title: Storm clouds over the global economy
summary: The global economy is experiencing a fraught period of geopolitical realignments, supply disruptions, and financial-market volatility, leading to a loss of growth momentum. Key factors contributing to this include the war in Ukraine, Covid-19's resurgence in China, and limited policymaking space. The US economy remains strong, but the Federal Reserve's risk of losing control of inflation could lead to a growth slowdown in 2023. Emerging-market economies face challenges from surging global inflation and unfavourable financial conditions, while the Russian economy has been severely impacted by sanctions. Policymakers must address underlying problems to boost long-term productivity and fix the global economy.

site_title: Annual meetings are the new frontline in the battle over corporate purpose
summary: US companies face a surge in shareholder resolutions on social and environmental issues, with a record 576 proposals filed in proxy season, up from 499 in 2021. Shareholders, including large asset managers like BlackRock and Vanguard, are increasingly backing proposals on climate change, racial equity, and corporate governance. The Securities and Exchange Commission's new rules have made it easier for activists to operate, and some companies are pre-empting shareholder action by publishing environmental reports or agreeing to proposals before voting. Critics argue that environmental and social proposals are more about values than actual value, but the trend is expected to continue, with smaller investors seeking to win support for broader issues.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall on Monday amid regional decline; STI down 1%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 1% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,303.07, amid regional decline and concerns over China's zero-Covid policies. Analyst Jeffrey Halley attributed the decline to weak US price action and mixed data from China, which may weigh on other Asian markets. Local stocks such as Jardine Matheson and DBS fell 1.9% and 1.4% respectively, while Keppel DC Reit rose 0.9%.

site_title: Lakepoint up for en bloc again at same S$640m reserve price
summary: Lakepoint Condominium in Jurong, Singapore, is set to relaunch for en bloc collective sale on April 19 with a reserve price of S$640 million. The site, comprising 309 residential units, has recently obtained URA approval for a higher height redevelopment, enhancing its attractiveness. The land rate is S$959 to S$982 per square foot per plot ratio. The owners believe the site's potential upside in capital appreciation and rental yields will be driven by the transformation of the Jurong Lake District.

site_title: Price gap between RCR and CCR homes narrows in March
summary: The price gap between new homes in Singapore's central region (CCR) and outside of it narrowed to 20.3% in March, according to PropNex Realty. Median transaction prices for non-landed new private homes in CCR fell 4.9% to S$2.24 million, while those in the outside central region (OCR) rose 5.7% to S$1.75 million. This narrowing gap presents buying opportunities in CCR projects, with some analysts expecting pent-up demand to drive sales in the second half of the year.

site_title: Thailand's small power players 'to remain under pressure'
summary: Thailand's small power producers may face pressure from high-energy fuel sources despite the Energy Regulatory Commission's plan to implement a new Energy Pool Price formula to mitigate rising power tariffs. The formula aims to encourage power operators to produce diesel- and fuel-generated electricity at a cheaper rate. However, this will have a negative impact on the Petroleum Authority of Thailand due to a higher natural gas for vehicles subsidy. Independent power producers and Thai refineries are expected to benefit from the change, with Thai Oil and Indorama Ventures being top picks.

site_title: Ant to acquire majority stake in Singapore fintech 2C2P
summary: Ant Group is acquiring a majority stake in Singapore-based payments platform 2C2P, expanding its regional business-to-business activity. The deal connects 2C2P's merchants with Alipay+, Ant's enterprise cross-border payments solution, enhancing its international expansion strategy. 2C2P, which offers payment acceptance solutions in over 20 countries, will benefit from Ant's larger merchant base and digital marketing solutions. site_title: Time to double down on S-Reit investments amid MAS 'double barrel' policy tightening

site_title: Why the dollar dominates
summary: The US dollar's dominance in the world financial system is unlikely to erode, despite changes in the global economy, such as the creation of the euro and the rise of China. The dollar's unique role as a medium of exchange, store of value, and unit of account, reinforced by self-reinforcing feedback loops, makes it difficult for other currencies to supplant it. Factors such as the size and liquidity of the US bond market, and the unpredictability of Chinese economic policies, also contribute to the dollar's stability. Even if the dollar were to lose its dominance, its advantages would be relatively minor, and the global economy would likely adapt to the change with minimal disruption.

site_title: China's electric vehicle sector charged for growth
summary: China's electric vehicle sector is expected to continue growing despite rising materials costs, supply bottlenecks, and global macroeconomic uncertainty. Electric car sales surged 142% year-on-year as of February, and manufacturers have been able to pass on price increases to consumers, maintaining demand. Projections suggest NEV penetration will more than double over the next three years to 39% of the overall car market, with some predicting NEVs will account for 80% of auto sales by 2030. China's unique advantages, including concentrated battery supply chains and policy support, are driving growth in the sector.

site_title: UOB Malaysia appoints first female CEO
summary: UOB Malaysia has appointed Ng Wei Wei as its first female CEO, effective May 1, 2022. Ng, who previously held leadership roles at other financial institutions, succeeds Wong Kim Choong, who will become senior adviser. The bank's deputy chairman and CEO Wee Ee Cheong stated that Ng's appointment reflects the importance of diversity in a complex and changing environment. Ng's tenure is expected to focus on growing the Wholesale Banking franchise, advancing ESG and innovation agendas, and supporting regional expansion.

site_title: Metaverse: Untold opportunities and risks
summary: The metaverse, built on Web 3.0, is emerging as a new frontier with potential trillions of dollars in economic opportunities. As 60% of the world's population spends 5-6 hours daily digitally, the metaverse will become increasingly real and engaging. Initial applications will focus on commerce, entertainment, and advertising, with gaming platforms driving innovation. The metaverse will require significant investment in hardware, infrastructure, and data processing. However, it also poses risks, including regulations, computing power, and data privacy issues, with active management key to identifying winners and losers.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust posts 21% decline in Q1 distributable income
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust reported a 21.1% decline in distributable income for Q1 2022, reaching S$44.7 million, due to a 20.7% decline in Ixom's distributable income. Ixom expanded its product offerings after acquiring Bituminous Products and divested its Fiji business. The decline was attributed to the company's focus on core capabilities.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end lower despite China's upbeat quarterly data
summary: South Korean stocks ended 2.85 points lower at 2,693.21 on Monday, despite China's stronger-than-expected first-quarter growth data. The won weakened, with a 0.39% decline to 1,234.4 per dollar. Foreign investors were net sellers of 97.1 billion won, extending a sell-off to a ninth straight session. The benchmark bond yield hit a new 8-year high at 2.985%, while Samsung Electronics rose 0.15% and SK Hynix gained 0.93%.

site_title: Broker's take: UOB KayHian raises Sembcorp Industries target price to S$3.59
summary: UOB KayHian has raised its target price for Sembcorp Industries to S$3.59, representing a 25.5% potential upside, due to higher expected earnings and aggressive renewable energy plans. Analyst Adrian Loh expects the company to achieve its 10-gigawatt renewable capacity target by 2025 and sees a key indicator of its success in the return on equity for its renewable business, which he expects to increase to 10-20% as assets mature. The company's sustainability-linked notes have shown market confidence in its strategy.

site_title: Ant to acquire majority stake in Singapore fintech 2C2P
summary: Ant Group is acquiring a majority stake in Singapore-based payments platform 2C2P, expanding its regional B2B business. The deal connects 2C2P's merchants to Alipay+, Ant's enterprise cross-border payments solution. This partnership aims to advance 2C2P's international expansion strategy and create a connected digital ecosystem across Southeast Asia. Ant has also been investing in other South-east Asian fintech companies, including e-wallet players in Thailand, Vietnam, and Malaysia. The investment is Ant's latest bet in the region's tech landscape.

site_title: On life transitions, legacy and money
summary: A Singaporean writer reflects on his mother's legacy after her passing due to lung cancer. Despite being a homemaker, his mother managed to maximize every dollar, buying essential items and cooking delicious meals. After her death, the family found little of value, with most possessions given away during her lifetime. The writer emphasizes the importance of legacy planning, not just financial, but also emotional and values-based. He shares how his mother's love and values were expressed through her actions, and how the family remains harmonious despite not having equal financial gifts.

site_title: Why the dollar dominates
summary: The US dollar's dominance in the global financial system is unlikely to be challenged, despite changes in the world since 1980, including the rise of the euro and China. The dollar's unique role as a medium of exchange, store of value, and unit of account in international business, combined with self-reinforcing feedback loops, keeps it at the top. Alternative currencies, such as the euro and yuan, are hindered by factors like Europe's sovereign debt crisis and China's autocratic policies, making the dollar's position secure. Even if the dollar were to lose its dominance, its impact would be minimal, as the US benefits from trivial advantages, such as borrowing at lower interest rates and receiving a zero-interest loan from dollar holders.

site_title: Rex International's unit to acquire 2 North Sea oil and gas licences
summary: Rex International's subsidiary Lime Petroleum will acquire a 40% interest in 2 North Sea oil and gas licences from MOL Norge, adjacent to the Balder oil field. The licences, discovered in 2019, are estimated to contain 1.82 million standard cubic metres of oil. Lime Petroleum's analysis suggests an upside potential in the recoverable volumes, and the company aims to become an operator to boost competitiveness. Regulatory approval is required for the takeover, which is expected to be completed once received.

site_title: Malaysia's March exports rise 25.4%, above forecast
summary: Malaysia's exports in March rose 25.4% from the previous year, exceeding forecasts, with a trade surplus of RM26.7 billion. This is higher than the expected 12.5% growth and forecast surplus of RM22.8 billion. Meanwhile, imports grew 29.9% from the previous year, also above expectations.

site_title: Crypto fund founder warns industry on North Korean cyber attacks
summary: Crypto fund founder Arthur Cheong warns prominent cryptocurrency organizations to strengthen their cybersecurity due to North Korean hackers' increasing attacks. North Korea's cybercrime organization, Lazarus, was linked to a $600 million cryptocurrency theft. Cybercrimes have been a lifeline for the struggling North Korean economy, which has been affected by sanctions. Cheong advises firms to hire remote teams securely, use dedicated computers, and revoke unnecessary token approvals to prevent further attacks.

site_title: Deadline for Singapore O&G takeover offer extended to May 4
summary: The Singapore O&G takeover offer has been extended to May 4, from April 18, with the closing date now set at 5:30pm. NewMedCo Group, a consortium led by Hanaan Health Group, has received 84.6% valid acceptances, representing about 88.96% of issued shares. The offer price represents a 15.7% premium over the previous day's price, with the share price increasing to S$0.30 after the announcement.

site_title: PUB seeks proposals on using emerging tech for coastal protection
summary: The Public Utilities Board (PUB) in Singapore is seeking proposals on using emerging technologies for coastal protection. The agency, which was appointed the nation's coastal protection agency in 2020, is conducting studies on the Republic's coastlines to protect against rising sea levels. Emerging technologies include machine learning, radar satellite and imagery, and crowdsourced data. Funding for the proposal, which closes on July 15, comes from a $51 million allocation by the National Research Foundation. PUB is also conducting site-specific studies on the north-west coast to protect against sea level rises.

site_title: China port delays spur ships to bypass Singapore for fuel stop
summary: China's port delays have prompted ships to bypass Singapore for fuel stops, with 441 fewer vessels refueling in Singapore last month compared to the previous year. The delays, caused by Shanghai's lockdown and congestion at other ports, have led to a 3.77 million-ton decrease in bunker fuel sales, the lowest seasonally since 2016. Hundreds of bulk ships are waiting off East China to unload and are likely to refuel in Guangzhou or Zhoushan instead of Singapore to save time, straining global supply chains.

site_title: China slowdown threatens trade growth as Singapore exports ease for 4th straight month in March
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) growth slowed for the fourth month in March, with a 7.7% year-on-year increase, due to a decline in shipments to mainland China and a unfavorable base effect. The slowdown is attributed to China's stringent zero-tolerance stance on Covid-19, which is affecting the global supply chain. Despite this, export demand from the US was strong, with a 68.1% increase in March. Analysts expect Singapore's trade sector to stay above-water in the medium term but with a slower pace of growth.

site_title: Boris looks to India to avoid homegrown scandal
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson is visiting India to seek a change of fortunes abroad with a potential bilateral free trade deal. Johnson's trip aims to drive a new 'Global Britain' campaign, focusing on economic growth, energy security, and defense. The UK seeks to strengthen ties with India, with a trade deal forecast to boost UK exports by £28 billion annually. Johnson wants to emphasize cooperation in defense manufacturing, technology, and health, while addressing immigration reform. Despite remaining bilateral differences, economics has come to dominate bilateral relations, with traditional irritants such as human rights in India being cast aside.
