summary: Sunac China, China's third-largest property developer, has missed a US$29.5 million coupon payment for a dollar bond maturing in October 2023. The company has a 30-day grace period before defaulting and is reportedly seeking a funding solution. This marks the first missed offshore payment for Sunac and follows a series of defaults in China's property sector.

images.alt_text: Sunac China has not paid a coupon worth US$29.5 million due Monday for a dollar bond, a person with knowledge of the matter said on Tuesday, marking the first missed offshore payment for the country's third largest property developer by sales.

site_title: WTO slashes 2022 global trade growth forecast amid Covid, Ukraine 'double whammy'
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) has revised down its forecast for global trade growth in 2022 to 3% due to the impact of the Russia-Ukraine war and the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The conflict has damaged the world economy, disrupting supply chains and increasing inflationary pressures. The WTO warns of a potential food crisis caused by surging prices, particularly affecting poor countries. Global trade growth is expected to inch up to 3.4% in 2023, but the estimates are less certain due to the ongoing uncertainty.

images.alt_text: The WTO also warned of a potential food crisis because of disruptions to exports from Ukraine and Russia, both major suppliers of grains and other commodities, that could hit poor countries, including some 35 African importers, the hardest.

site_title: Government didn't get every call right on Covid-19, but was prepared to revise, reverse its decisions: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong acknowledged that the government did not get every call right during the Covid-19 pandemic, but was prepared to update and revise decisions as more information became available. Key lessons learned include making tough calls in uncertainty, planning ahead, and implementing policies effectively. The government successfully secured vaccines, implemented strict measures, and secured essential supplies, with a focus on protecting lives and preventing avoidable deaths. Lee praised the public service's efforts, saying they demonstrated the difference a good government can make.

site_title: Manager discloses indicative timeline of ESR-Reit-Ara Logos Logistics Trust merger
summary: ESR-Reit and Ara Logos Logistics Trust are set to merge on April 22, with the court hearing scheduled for April 18. Transfer books and registers will close on April 21 to determine unitholder entitlements. Ara Logos units will stop trading on April 19, while ESR-Reit units will trade ex-distribution on April 20. Unitholders will receive 9.7 cents in cash and 1.7729 ESR-Reit units for every Ara Logos unit owned by April 28, when the merged Reit starts trading.

site_title: Salvage sector sees environment protection role after Ukraine conflict abates
summary: The International Salvage Union (ISU) has highlighted the environmental protection role salvors will play in the Black Sea and Sea of Azov once the Ukraine conflict abates. The ISU has suspended membership of its Russian member, MRS/MORSPAS, due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Salvage operations in 2021 showed that ISU members provided services to vessels carrying 2.6 million tonnes of potentially polluting cargo and fuel, emphasizing their critical role in protecting the marine environment. The organization's president noted that salvors play a crucial part in meeting environmental obligations and demonstrating commitment to ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) credentials.

site_title: Fifa launch new digital streaming service for documentaries, live games
summary: FIFA has launched a new digital streaming service, Fifa+, offering free live games from competitions worldwide, as well as 'Netflix-style' documentaries. The platform, funded by advertisers, will stream 40,000 live games annually from 100 member associations. It includes an archive of every World Cup and Women's World Cup match, live games geo-blocked to avoid competing with existing broadcasters, and highlights packages. Fifa+ will feature documentaries, including one on Ronaldinho, and an 'all-access' series with Brazilian defender Dani Alves. The service is free, with potential for subscription-based models in the future.

site_title: US consumer prices accelerate in March
summary: US consumer prices increased by 1.2% in March, the largest monthly gain in 16-1/2 years, driven by a surge in gasoline prices to a record high of $4.33 per gallon. The Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates by 50 basis points next month due to the inflationary pressure. Petrol, food, and rental housing also contributed to the inflation, with the consumer price index surpassing the previous record in September 2005.

site_title: Mercedes-Benz bets on India's nouveau riche to drive luxury car sales
summary: Mercedes-Benz is optimistic about luxury car sales in India, driven by a growing number of young, high-earning individuals who value luxury and technology. The company expects higher growth rates in the luxury segment than mass market cars, with buyers' average age falling below 40. India's growing "dollar millionaires" are fueling demand, with luxury car sales rising 40% in 2021 to 11,242 cars. Mercedes plans to launch 10 new models in 2022, capitalizing on the momentum in the luxury market.

images.alt_text: Germany's Mercedes-Benz is betting that a growing crop of young new millionaires will drive demand for luxury cars in India, growing sales at a pace faster than that of mass market cars, a top company official said.

site_title: US trade policy agenda being scuttled by politics
summary: US Trade Representative Katherine Tai's recent appearances before Congress revealed that President Biden's administration is shelving ambitious trade policy initiatives due to opposition from the Democratic Party's progressive wing. The administration is instead focusing on reforming the global trade system and addressing anti-competitive behavior by China, with Ambassador Tai suggesting that tariffs are a "20th century tool" and proposing a new economic framework for the Indo-Pacific region. The administration's lack of a strong trade agenda is a result of the growing influence of economic nationalist positions among Republican lawmakers, who have expressed opposition to new trade deals, and the Democratic Party's resistance to liberalizing international trade.

site_title: 9,000 HDB flats and private homes to rise from Keppel Club site
summary: A 9,000-unit housing development, comprising 6,000 public housing flats and 3,000 private residential units, is set to rise on the 48-hectare Keppel Club site on Singapore's southern waterfront. The first BTO flats are expected to launch within 3 years, with the remaining units launching in 3-5 years. The development plans align with the government's plan to transform the Greater Southern Waterfront into a live-work-play locale. The site's proximity to nature areas and coastal habitats will be preserved with the creation of parks and open spaces, including a 10-hectare area set aside for green spaces.

site_title: Asos warns full-year target is at risk from inflation, war
summary: Asos warns its full-year target is at risk due to accelerating inflation and Russia's war in Ukraine, despite maintaining its forecast for the fiscal year ending in August. The company's shares have lost a third of their value this year, and it's still seeking a new CEO. Asos expects pretax earnings of £110-140 million, with second-half sales set to accelerate after a 4% increase in the first half. The retailer's Russia and Ukraine business accounts for about 4% of revenue and £20 million of profit.

site_title: Singapore stocks track lower for second consecutive day, STI down 1%
summary: Singapore stocks declined for the second consecutive day, with the Straits Times Index falling 1% to 3,330.25. The decline was attributed to concerns over global interest rates, inflation, and the ongoing war between Russia and Ukraine. Despite this, some tech stocks like AEM Holdings and First Resources rose, while DBS and UOB were among the top losers. The market displayed resilience, with Principal Global Investors advising investors to stay invested despite the Fed tightening and balance sheet reductions.

site_title: Why I am averse to investing in Chinese tech leaders
summary: A key tech leader to invest in is uncertain due to the US-China tech rivalry. Big-tech groups like Alphabet, Apple, and Microsoft are investing heavily in research and acquisitions. Chinese groups, such as Alibaba and Tencent, are also expanding their presence. As a lay investor, it's challenging to pick a winner, and the outcome may depend on various factors, including the development of driverless cars and the metaverse.

site_title: Some 469 cases valued at US$6.54b filed with Singapore International Arbitration Centre in 2021
summary: 469 cases valued at US$6.54 billion were filed with the Singapore International Arbitration Centre (SIAC) in 2021. 86% of these cases were international, with the highest disputed sum being US$1.95 billion. The SIAC reported these figures in its annual report, providing insight into the arbitration services provided to the global business community.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 7.48 points lower on Tuesday, at 1,597.13. Volume reached 3.907 billion lots worth RM2.438 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 578 to 340.

site_title: Three trends that will shape the future of payments in Singapore in 2022
summary: Visa predicts three trends shaping the future of payments in Singapore in 2022: the world as a marketplace, digital goods, and the metaverse. Consumers are increasingly comfortable shopping online, with live-stream shopping and digital-only goods emerging as popular trends. Digital goods such as NFTs and downloadable virtual clothing are gaining traction, and the metaverse is expected to become a key platform for digital commerce, with seamless payment experiences becoming essential.

site_title: Singaporeans' trust in the government key to handling of Covid-19 crisis: PM Lee
summary: Singaporean trust in the government played a crucial role in handling the Covid-19 crisis, according to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. The trust has been demonstrated through citizens' willingness to follow government advice, comply with safety measures, and get vaccinated. Lee emphasized the importance of a top-notch public service, capable and committed officers, and the need for effective collaboration between the government and public service leaders. He also stressed the need for ministers to understand key issues, set direction, and chart the country's strategy, while providing necessary support to public servants to focus on their duties.

site_title: Q2 game plan for investors
summary: The Russia-Ukraine war and US-European sanctions continue to impact market sentiment, with devastating effects on energy and commodity prices, inflationary expectations, and global growth. Despite this, Asia is expected to drive and benefit from dollar asset diversification. Meanwhile, retail investors in Asia and Europe are expected to drive "massive" ETF growth. The S&P 500 has reached a record high, suggesting the worst of the trade war may be behind us. Productivity gains are key to unlocking wealth creation, while de-dollarisation and shifting safe havens are also on the horizon.

site_title: SP Group donates S$1.35m to support 450 disadvantaged ITE students
summary: SP Group is donating S$1.35 million over 3 years to support 450 disadvantaged engineering students at the Institute of Technical Education (ITE) through the SP Group Engineering Study Awards. The monthly funds will help students from low-income families focus on their education, complementing existing book prizes. The awards aim to encourage youth to pursue their career aspirations, regardless of their socio-economic background.

site_title: 'Uninvestable' China argument rings hollow as long-term positives remain intact
summary: China shares have recovered from a March collapse, sparking questions about the country's investability. The sell-off was driven by Omicron, regulatory actions, and sanction fears. However, experts view this as a short-term reaction rather than a fundamental change in China's investment prospects. Key long-term positives remain intact, including the country's growing economy and potential for dollar asset diversification. Investors should consider China's overall market trends rather than isolated events, as the country is expected to continue driving global economic growth.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close with modest gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed with modest gains on Tuesday, April 12, 2022, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.52% to 21,319.13. This followed gains in the Shanghai Composite Index (1.46%) and Shenzhen Composite Index (1.81%). The gains came ahead of US inflation data later in the trading day, with investors watching for market reactions.

site_title: Hong Kong's OneDegree says it's been approached on SPAC listing
summary: OneDegree, a Hong Kong-based insurer of digital assets, has been approached by investment banks to go public through a SPAC listing. The company expects to carry out a funding round in coming months to finance expansion, following a US$28 million raise in August. OneDegree has seen sales jump 30% and its customer base double to 200,000 since last summer. The firm is expanding into traditional insurance areas, such as pets, health, and real estate, amid a booming market for insuring digital assets, with crypto thefts reaching US$3.2 billion last year.

site_title: IPhone maker halts plants as China Covid battle hits tech supply
summary: Pegatron, a Taiwanese iPhone assembler, suspended production at its Chinese plants in Shanghai and Kunshan due to China's Covid-zero strategy. The plants will resume output upon government notification. The lockdowns have disrupted global supply chains, affecting other electronics manufacturers, including Foxconn Technology Group. China's lockdowns are exacting an unknown toll on the world's No 2 economy, with widespread factory shutdowns and worsening logistics jams. Pegatron's suspension is the latest blow to global electronics supply chains, which are already strained by the pandemic.

site_title: Sunwoda seeks EV battery unit funding at US$3b value
summary: Sunwoda Electronic is considering raising new funds for its electric-vehicle battery unit, seeking a valuation of over $3.1 billion. The company has reached out to potential investors for a $3 billion to $4 billion raise. This move comes as EV battery manufacturers in China are attracting billions of dollars from carmakers seeking to diversify their supply. Sunwoda has already raised $400 million from investors in February and has 8 production bases in China and India.

site_title: Global growth optimism at all-time low, fund manager survey finds
summary: Fund managers are at their most pessimistic about global growth, with 71% expecting poor prospects, the lowest level since the survey began in the early 1990s. Cash holdings eased to 5.5%, while allocations to commodities surged to a record 38% amid inflationary pressures. Investors expect the US Federal Reserve to raise interest rates seven times, with a majority anticipating inflation to soften over the next year. Global profit expectations have deteriorated to their weakest levels since March 2020, with regional stock market allocations favoring US equities over European and UK equities.

site_title: Can Silicon Valley still dominate global innovation?
summary: Bengaluru, India, has emerged as a significant hub for global innovation, rivaling Silicon Valley in attracting US$13 billion in venture capital and hosting 26 unicorns. The city's success is attributed to its unique combination of a deep talent pool, openness to people and ideas, and the presence of local risk capital. Unlike Silicon Valley, which has a strong connection to elite universities and brain trusts, Bengaluru boasts nearly 70 engineering colleges and a population of over 55% Indians with technical skills. The city's openness to foreigners and its ability to attract "sea turtles" – returnees who have studied or worked abroad – have also contributed to its startup success. Additionally, Bengaluru's local risk capital, fueled by former employees of successful startups, has encouraged risk-taking and entrepreneurship.

site_title: Singapore's Zilingo is said to suspend CEO amid investigation
summary: Singaporean startup Zilingo has suspended CEO Ankiti Bose amid an investigation into its accounting practices, following questions from investors about the company's finances during a funding round. The investigation, led by investors including Temasek Holdings and Sequoia Capital India, was sparked by concerns raised by Zilingo's auditor about the company's accounting practices. Bose has disputed the allegations, claiming her suspension was due to complaints about harassment, and has hired an attorney to represent her.

site_title: Hmlet merges with European co-living player Habyt
summary: Hmlet, a Singapore-based co-living startup, has merged with European co-living player Habyt through an equity share swap. The combined entity will be led by Luca Bovone, Habyt's CEO, and Joshua Li, Hmlet's chief real estate officer. The merger aims to expand Habyt's presence in Asia and create a global player in the sector. Hmlet will continue to operate under its brand, and the combined entity will manage over 8,000 rooms across two continents. The move is seen as a strategic step to scale faster and compete with other players in the rapidly growing co-living sector.

images.alt_text: Hmlet is merging with European co-living player Habyt in an all share swap

site_title: Australia to fund A$1.5b Darwin port to stem China threat
summary: Australia will invest A$1.5 billion in a new port in Darwin to boost gas and mineral exports, competing with the city's main port leased to a Chinese-owned company in 2015. The move comes amid growing tensions with China and instability in the Asia-Pacific region. Deputy Prime Minister Barnaby Joyce cited these factors, stating the new facility is crucial for Australia's national security and economic growth. The announcement precedes the May 21 national election, where the centre-right government seeks a fourth term. The existing port has been seen as a liability due to deteriorating relations with China.

site_title: Down and back again: How Booking.com could thrive post-pandemic
summary: Booking.com is experiencing a surge in demand post-pandemic, driven by pent-up travel after 2 tumultuous years. The company's revenue is expected to exceed pre-pandemic levels, thanks to the sector's rebound. As a shareholder since 2010, the author has witnessed the industry's evolution during tough times, highlighting the company's resilience. With borders reopening, Booking.com is poised to thrive, capitalizing on the surge in travel.

site_title: Bitcoin rallies back above US$40,000 to show some recovery signs
summary: Bitcoin has rallied above US$40,000, recovering from a seven-day losing streak. The cryptocurrency rose 0.8% to US$40,146, with ether also gaining around US$3,000. Altcoins like Solana and Cardano fell. Analysts attribute the recovery to a "triangle pattern" and key resistance levels at US$40,000 and US$2,900. The move comes amid concerns over the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes to combat high inflation and geopolitical turmoil.

site_title: China nudges listed firms, investors to buy stocks to stabilise market
summary: China's securities watchdog is encouraging long-term investors to buy more equities and major shareholders to increase their holdings to stabilize the stock market amid a worsening Covid-19 outbreak. The government will also facilitate corporate financing in Covid-hit areas and urge state shareholders to buy undervalued stocks. Despite this, investors remain skeptical due to structural bubbles, risks, and external uncertainty, with some predicting a recession. The benchmark CSI300 index has fallen 17% this year, and capital outflows continue, with US$6.3 billion leaving China equities in March.

site_title: Amid mounting turbulence, can the Fed engineer a soft landing?
summary: The US Federal Reserve has signaled 6 interest rate hikes this year, with a probability of reaching 2.54% by its December meeting. However, experts believe that to combat 40-year-high inflation, rates may need to rise above 8-9%. Fed chief Jerome Powell has hinted at more aggressive rate hikes, sparking a rise in market odds. This could lead to a "soft landing" for the economy, but the outcome remains uncertain.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets drop at open
summary: Europe's major stock markets dropped on Tuesday, April 12, 2022, with London's FTSE 100 index down 0.8% and the Paris CAC 40 and Frankfurt's DAX down 1.7% and 1.8% respectively. The decline followed weak overnight US stock market performance and preceded key inflation data in the US.

site_title: Citigroup appoints new Asia Pacific wealth boss
summary: Citigroup appointed Angel Ng as the new head of its Asia Pacific global wealth management business, replacing Fabio Fontainha and Steven Lo. Ng, currently Hong Kong chief executive, will oversee the wealth management business in Singapore and Hong Kong, aiming to grow client assets to $150 billion by 2025 and adding 2,300 staff in the region.

site_title: Opec tells EU that Russia oil crisis is beyond its control
summary: Opec's secretary-general Mohammad Barkindo told EU officials that the current oil crisis caused by Russia's invasion of Ukraine is beyond the group's control. Russian oil supply losses could exceed 7 million barrels a day, far beyond Opec's capacity to replace. Barkindo stated that the crisis is driven by non-fundamental factors, such as politics, and markets are volatile due to these factors. Opec nations, including Saudi Arabia, have rebuffed calls to fill the gap left by Russia, potentially due to preserving political ties with Moscow and their own market views.

site_title: Australia's Victoria state to host 2026 Commonwealth Games
summary: Victoria state in Australia has been announced as the host of the 2026 Commonwealth Games, with all events taking place in regional hubs in Geelong, Ballarat, Bendigo, and Gippsland, outside of Melbourne. The decision was praised by the state's premier, Daniel Andrews, who noted that hosting the games in regional areas is a "bit riskier" but could lead to significant economic benefits. The 2026 Games will feature four regional hubs with their own athletes' villages.

site_title: Japan's Osaka Gas backs US$11b green hydrogen project in Australia
summary: Osaka Gas has agreed to provide technical support for the US$10.75 billion Desert Bloom Hydrogen project in Australia, which aims to produce green hydrogen using a unique technology that extracts water from the air and solar power. The project, backed by Sanguine Impact Investment Group, plans to start up in 2023 and could be the first producer of green hydrogen in Australia. Osaka Gas may consider investing in the project in the future, but no concrete plan is currently in place.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit 2-week low, energy top laggard
summary: Australian shares closed 0.4% lower, hitting a 2-week low, as investors awaited US inflation data that may reinforce the Federal Reserve's aggressive policy normalisation. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell to 7,454, with energy stocks down 0.6% despite rising oil prices, and miners easing 0.2% due to falling iron ore prices. Technology stocks also declined, with Xero and WiseTech Global shedding 0.6% and 2.2% respectively.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall 1% ahead of US inflation data
summary: South Korean stocks fell 1% on Tuesday, their lowest close in nearly a month, amid concerns over a global economic slowdown and US inflation data. The benchmark Kospi ended down 26.34 points, while the Korean won weakened and bond yields rose. Foreigners sold 465.1 billion won worth of shares, extending a five-day sell-off. The finance minister said the government is ready to deploy market-stabilizing measures if needed, and will lobby for South Korea's inclusion in the MSCI developed market index.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end at near 4-week low on Wall Street weakness
summary: Japanese shares closed at a 4-week low on Tuesday, ending 1.81% lower at 26,334.98, due to a sharp drop on Wall Street. Investor sentiment was weighed down by concerns over Covid-19 lockdowns in China and rising commodity prices. The Nikkei's top performers were airlines, which rose 0.45%, while the worst performers were shipping companies, which fell 5.68%. The decline was attributed to rising bond yields and a risk-off mood ahead of key inflation data.

images.alt_text: The Nikkei share average ended 1.81 per cent lower at 26,334.98, the lowest since Mar 16.

site_title: UK workers see biggest fall in living standards in 8 years
summary: UK workers experienced the largest decline in living standards in over 8 years, with average earnings excluding bonuses rising 4.1% but adjusting for prices dropping 1.3% in February. The cost of living is depriving Britons of benefits from a strong labor market, despite low unemployment at 3.8%. Employer additions of 35,000 payrolls in March fell short of estimates, suggesting growth may be slowing.

site_title: Shorter leases for commercial land unlikely to depress CBD Grade A office rents
summary: The Singapore government's plan to release more commercial sites with lease durations below 99 years may lead to downward pressure on rents for some office spaces, particularly in suburban locations. However, Grade A buildings in the Central Business District (CBD) are unlikely to face significant competition from these shorter-tenured spaces, according to real estate analysts. The Urban Redevelopment Authority's (URA) Long-Term Plan Review (LTPR) aims to provide more flexible spaces and refresh land uses in shorter cycles, but its impact on CBD rents is expected to be minimal.

site_title: Sri Lanka defaults on entire US$51b external debt
summary: Sri Lanka defaulted on its $51 billion external debt, citing a "last resort" measure to prevent financial deterioration. The country's economic crisis has worsened, with regular blackouts, food and fuel shortages, and a 20% inflation rate. The government is set to expedite talks with the International Monetary Fund, but the announcement may increase pressure on President Gotabaya Rajapaksa and his brother, Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa, to step down.

images.alt_text: A man gives free food to demonstrators as they take part in a protest against the economic crisis at the entrance of the president's office in Colombo.

site_title: India hopes 'Pharma City' will break China's grip on industry
summary: India's "Pharma City" project aims to break China's grip on the global pharmaceutical industry by producing vital raw ingredients for medicines. The $8.4 billion initiative, set to employ 560,000 people, will focus on bulk drugs and promises to streamline India's environmental clearance and land acquisition processes. The project is part of India's efforts to reduce its dependence on China, which supplies 70% of the world's active pharmaceutical ingredients. India's pharmaceutical industry, valued at $42 billion, has faced shortages and price surges due to China's lockdowns during the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Taiwan issues first war survival handbook amid China threat
summary: Taiwan has released its first war survival handbook, providing citizens with guidance on how to respond to a military crisis and possible disasters in the event of a war with China. The handbook, which draws from similar guides issued by Sweden and Japan, includes tips on finding bomb shelters, preparing emergency first aid kits, and distinguishing air raid sirens. The move comes amid China's increased military activities near Taiwan, and Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen has vowed to defend the island. The handbook will be updated with localized information and is part of Taiwan's efforts to boost preparedness and safety.

site_title: Strong appetite for Malaysian hotel investment: Knight Frank
summary: Malaysia sees a surge in hotel investment interest, with 64% of respondents considering increasing their exposure, a significant jump from 36% in 2020. The survey, conducted by Knight Frank Malaysia, also found a drop in respondents not interested in investing in hotels from 64% to 36%. The survey highlights a return in sentiment towards the sector, likely driven by the easing of Covid-19 restrictions and improving economic conditions.

site_title: Japan finance minister closely communicating on yen moves with US
summary: Japan's Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki stated the government will closely communicate with the US and other countries to respond to currency moves, following the yen's 6-year low against the dollar. The yen broke beyond 125 yen due to differing interest rates between Japan and the US, with the Bank of Japan maintaining ultra-easy monetary settings. Despite verbal warnings, investors believe little immediate action will be taken, as policymakers emphasize the benefits of a weak yen for exporters.

site_title: When all else fails, crypto watchers blame slide on the taxman
summary: Cryptocurrency prices have slumped, with Bitcoin falling over 12% since April 4, due to investors selling digital assets ahead of the US tax deadline in mid-April. This trend is reminiscent of 2021, when investors sold cryptocurrencies to make tax-related payments. The Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes also contribute to the decline, as investors turn to riskier assets. Despite a recent conference, investors have withdrawn $134 million from digital assets, with Bitcoin being the primary target, and the cryptocurrency's correlation with US stocks has reached record levels.

site_title: Thai government approves 1.41 trillion baht in new borrowing for 2022 fiscal year
summary: Thailand's Cabinet approved 1.41 trillion baht (S$57.2 billion) in new borrowing for the 2022 fiscal year, exceeding a previous plan of 1.36 trillion baht. The revised debt management plan aims to keep public debt at 62.76% of GDP, below the government-approved limit of 70%. The new debt includes 10 billion baht for the state oil fund, 29.3 billion baht for debt restructuring, and 39.4 billion baht for investment projects, as well as 15.2 billion baht for power system projects.

images.alt_text: Thailand's Cabinet on Tuesday (Apr 12) approved new borrowing of 1.41 trillion baht (S$57.2 billion) in the current fiscal year to September, up from a previous plan of 1.36 trillion baht, a government spokesperson said.

site_title: Tencent stock soars after China ends 8-month gaming freeze
summary: Tencent Holdings surged over 5% after China's National Press and Publication Administration approved 45 domestic gaming titles, ending an 8-month freeze. The move calmed investors' fears about Beijing's gaming sector intentions, which had faced criticism for encouraging addiction. Analysts expect Tencent and NetEase to eventually get games approved, citing a positive development for the industry and a potential resumption of regular approval processes. The approval includes mostly casual games with lower player spending.

site_title: EY acquires Australia business consultancy company Blackdot
summary: EY acquires Australian business consultancy company Blackdot, strengthening its customer transformation and growth capabilities. Founded in 2001, Blackdot provides customer strategy and implementation services to clients in Australia, the UK, Singapore, and Canada. The acquisition will allow EY to develop and implement customer-centric growth strategies, with 64 Blackdot staff joining EY globally. Post-acquisition, Blackdot's founder and CEO Marty Nicholas will join the EY partnership in Australia, and 64 employees will join EY's consulting services globally. The acquisition is expected to unlock more value for clients looking to transform their market presence.

site_title: Condo resale volumes rebound, up 35.6% in March: SRX, 99.co
summary: Condo resale volumes in Singapore rebounded 35.6% in March, with 1,302 units changing hands, up from 960 in February. Resale prices rose 0.8% from February and 9.7% year-over-year, with the OCR seeing the highest price gain at 11.8%. Despite cooling measures, demand remains high, with less than 7,000 new condos expected for sale this year. Experts predict the easing of travel restrictions may attract more foreign buyers, while rising interest rates could weigh on the market.

site_title: Ethereum undergoes another stress test ahead of software change
summary: Ethereum's network has completed a key testing step ahead of its software upgrade, known as the Merge. The mainnet shadow fork stress test uncovered at least one bug but was largely successful. The test marks a crucial step towards the Merge, which will change transaction ordering and significantly reduce Ethereum's energy use. The upgrade is projected to cut energy consumption by 99% and is closely watched due to its impact on the cryptocurrency market and decentralized-finance apps valued at over $108 billion. The test is part of ongoing efforts to detect bugs before the system goes live later this year.

site_title: Mountbatten Road conservation bungalow up for sale with S$27m guide price
summary: A freehold conservation bungalow at 759 Mountbatten Road in Singapore's District 15 has been launched for sale with a guide price of S$27 million (S$1,295 per square foot). Originally built in the 1920s, the 41-room Sing Hoe Hotel sits on a 20,847.54 square foot site within the Mountbatten Road Bungalow Conservation Area. The property offers various possibilities, including a family home, hotel, or strata-titled residential units, with the option to convert it into a co-living concept or strata-titled flats subject to government approvals. The tender closes on May 24.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Tuesday's open; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.4% at Tuesday's open, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dropping 14.24 points to 3,349.32. The decline followed a sharp drop on Wall Street, where investors entered a risk-off mood ahead of inflation data. Local banks, including DBS, OCBC, and UOB, were among the biggest losers, while international cement shares rose 3.5%. The market's losses came as European and Asian stocks also fell, with the Dow Jones and Nasdaq Composite closing lower on Monday.

site_title: Gold slips as Treasury yields, dollar climb ahead of inflation data
summary: Gold prices fell 0.2% to $1,950.52 per ounce as Treasury yields and the dollar rose ahead of US inflation data. The benchmark 10-year US Treasury yield reached its highest in over 3 years, making gold less attractive for investors. Higher interest rates and yields increase the opportunity cost of holding bullion, despite gold being considered a hedge against inflation. Safe-haven demand for gold sustained due to concerns of an upcoming Russian offensive in Ukraine.

site_title: US State Department orders non-emergency staff to leave Shanghai over Covid
summary: The US State Department has ordered non-emergency staff at its Shanghai consulate to leave due to the ongoing Covid-19 outbreak and harsh lockdown in the Chinese city. The decision was made to ensure the safety and welfare of US citizens. The move comes amid concerns raised by US diplomats to Chinese officials.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open with modest gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.61% at the open on April 12, 2022, despite a weak lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index gained 128.34 points to 21,336.64. This comes ahead of key US inflation data later in the day.

site_title: Twitter staff 'super stressed' over Musk board chaos on day off
summary: Twitter employees were left "super stressed" after CEO Parag Agrawal backed away from a plan for Elon Musk to join the board, despite a previous Q&A session with employees. Musk's reversal means he can now buy more shares and tweet freely without restrictions, sparking concerns about his intentions. Employees described the situation as a "sh-t show" and expressed worry about Musk's impact on the company, with one employee saying he was "just getting started, which is unfortunate".

site_title: Taiwan premier calls for speedy passage of chip protection laws
summary: Taiwan's Premier Su Tseng-chang has called for the swift passage of revised chip protection laws, aiming to deter China from stealing the island's chip technology. The laws, proposed by the Cabinet in February, include tougher punishments for economic espionage, with up to 12 years in prison. Taiwan is home to industry giant TSMC and possesses 92% of the world's most advanced semiconductor manufacturing capacity, making it a target for China's economic espionage efforts. Su's call comes amid rising concern about China's military and diplomatic pressure on Taiwan.

site_title: UK retailers see sales slow as cost pressures rise: BRC
summary: British retailers reported 3.1% annual sales growth in March, down from 6.7% in February, due to rising cost pressures and seasonal factors. Prices rose by 2.1%, the largest increase in 11 years, contributing to slower sales. Consumer spending is being closely watched by the Bank of England and economists as households face a predicted cost-of-living squeeze. Some poorer shoppers are skipping meals to save money, while richer households may shift spending towards foreign holidays.

site_title: Honda to spend 5t yen on EV push, plans 30 models
summary: Honda Motor plans to spend 5 trillion yen (S$54.5 billion) on electric vehicles over the next decade, launching 30 EV models by 2030 with a production volume of over 2 million vehicles per year. The company aims to build a demonstration line for all-solid-state batteries by 2024 and phase out petrol-powered cars by 2040. Honda is also exploring a joint venture for battery production and has partnered with Sony and General Motors to develop affordable EVs.

site_title: Airports clogged with queues as travel rebound strains resources
summary: Airports worldwide are struggling with long queues and flight disruptions due to a surge in travel as entry restrictions drop. Understaffed airports and airlines, including Qantas Airways and EasyJet, are experiencing staff absences of up to 50% and 30% respectively. The industry, which laid off hundreds of thousands of workers during the pandemic, is now facing a "perfect storm" of staff shortages and increased travel demand. Airlines are taking measures to mitigate disruptions, such as offering bonuses to flight attendants and reducing summer schedules.

site_title: Asia: Stocks wobble, dollar firm as markets wary before key US inflation data
summary: Asian stocks fell on Tuesday as Treasury yields spiked to a 3-year high ahead of US inflation data, which could foreshadow aggressive interest rate hikes from the Federal Reserve. The US dollar strengthened, with the yen falling to its highest level since June 2015, while the euro was buffeted by politics. Markets are wary of the impact of the data on corporate profits and global growth, with economists forecasting a 8.4% year-over-year increase in US consumer prices.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 3.09 points or 0.2% to 1,601.52. The market saw a lower volume of 204.5 million lots worth RM71.5 million, with 246 losers outnumbering 100 gainers.

site_title: Philippines fintech firm Voyager nears funding at US$1.5b valuation: sources
summary: Philippines fintech firm Voyager Innovations is nearing a $200 million funding round that could value the company at $1 billion to $1.5 billion. The digital arm of PLDT, a major telecommunications company, is expected to expand its services with the funding. Susquehanna International Group and existing investors like KKR & Co and Tencent Holdings may participate in the deal, which could be announced as early as Tuesday. Voyager has already raised $167 million in June to expand its online payment unit PayMaya and won a digital bank permit in September.

site_title: World markets are falling again with echoes of the 2018 rout
summary: Global markets are experiencing a significant decline, with stocks, bonds, and oil falling in a concerted cross-asset selloff. The Federal Reserve's intent to restrict policy to combat inflation is driving the downturn, despite the labour market's robust performance and corporate plans for capital spending. Investors are shifting to defensive stocks, cash, and dividend-paying stocks, and demand for hedging is rising. The S&P 500 index is down 2.6% this month, with emerging markets also nursing losses.

images.alt_text: The feel-good days of March are firmly over in global markets.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand Investment, ESR-Reit, Dasin Retail Trust, Lian Beng
summary: Several Singaporean companies experienced trading developments on Tuesday, Apr 12, 2022. CapitaLand Investment's lodging business, The Ascott, set a target to sign 150 properties with over 30,000 units under its lyf co-living brand by 2030. ESR-Reit announced a redevelopment of its 21B Senoko Loop property, while its auditors flagged a material uncertainty regarding its ability to continue as a going concern. Lian Beng and Dasin Retail Trust also saw their share prices affected by the developments.

site_title: China's echoes of Russia's alternate reality intensify globally
summary: China has intensified its support for Russia's disinformation campaign about the war in Ukraine, echoing Russia's alternate reality and creating an alternate reality for a global audience. China's state media has parroted Russia's claims, including President Vladimir Putin's justification that he is fighting a neo-Nazi government in Kyiv, and has used the word "Nazi" more times than in the 6 months before the war began. China's diplomats and official journalists have become combatants in the informational war, further undercutting China's effort to present itself as a neutral actor in the war.

site_title: Shopify plans stock split that's bound to tap retail frenzy
summary: Shopify plans a 10-for-1 stock split, aiming to make its shares more attractive to retail investors. The proposal, pending shareholder approval on June 7, is expected to boost the company's liquidity and appeal to individual investors. The move follows similar announcements from tech giants like Alphabet, Amazon, and Tesla. Despite the potential rally, Shopify's shares have lost 55% of their value this year, and the company's CEO, Tobi Lutke, will retain a significant voting power under the new plan.

site_title: Australian prime minister vows to create million new jobs in election pitch
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison has vowed to create 1.3 million new jobs over the next 5 years, focusing on wage growth and cost-of-living pressures in the upcoming election. This promise comes after his main rival, Opposition Leader Anthony Albanese, failed to answer questions about the unemployment rate. Morrison's government has driven the unemployment rate down to 4% from 5.7% when Labor left office in 2013, and is expected to fall into the 3% range for the first time since the early 1970s.

site_title: Ukraine's Zelensky warns Russia could use chemical weapons, calls for more sanctions
summary: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky warned that Russia could use chemical weapons in Ukraine, calling for strong sanctions to deter such actions. There were unconfirmed reports of a chemical attack in Mariupol, but Petro Andryushchenko, an aide to the mayor, said the reports were not confirmed. The US is monitoring the situation closely, and the European Union is considering new sanctions on Russia, including an oil embargo, to prevent the use of chemical weapons.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower after Wall Street plunge
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on April 12, 2022, following a Wall Street plunge. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.80% to 26,607.29, while the Topix index slid 0.45% to 1,880.22. Investors are watching US inflation data, set to be released later in the day, for potential market impact.

site_title: Benettons, Blackstone to launch bid for Atlantia this week: sources
summary: The Benettons and US investment fund Blackstone plan to launch a takeover bid for Italy's Atlantia this week, without involving other partners initially. The bid is a response to an unsolicited approach by Global Infrastructure Partners and Brookfield. Atlantia, which operates airports and motorways, is cash-rich after selling its Italian motorway unit, and the bid could be announced before Saturday. The new company, led by Edizione and Blackstone, will launch the offer for the infrastructure group, with potential involvement from other investors later.

site_title: China slashes LNG purchases on high prices and pandemic slowdown
summary: China has reduced its liquefied natural gas (LNG) imports by 14% in the first quarter due to high prices and a slowdown in domestic demand. The country's strict COVID-19 measures are also affecting neighboring countries. As a result, more LNG is available to be rerouted to Europe, reducing dependence on Russian pipeline deliveries. High prices have made it uneconomic to sell LNG into the domestic market, leading to a surge in spot prices and cancellations of private imports. This slowdown in LNG demand could impact power plants and energy-intensive industries.

site_title: Britney Spears, newly free, says she is pregnant
summary: Britney Spears, 40, announced on Instagram that she is pregnant with her third child, 6 months after her conservatorship ended. The singer had long expressed her desire to have more children, citing a contraceptive IUD that prevented her from getting pregnant. Spears' father, Jamie Spears, was removed as her guardian in November 2021. The pop star is already a mother to two teenage sons and has spoken publicly about her struggles with perinatal depression. Spears' representatives did not comment on the pregnancy, and she has not disclosed a due date.

site_title: ESR-Reit undertakes S$38.5m redevelopment of Senoko Loop property
summary: ESR-Reit is redeveloping its 21B Senoko Loop property into a high-spec facility for existing tenant NTS Components Singapore at a cost of S$38.5 million. The project, expected to be completed by Q1 2024, will increase the portfolio's high-spec assets to 9, representing 18.4% of its valuation. The redevelopment will allow NTS to expand operations with minimal delay, and the property will be leased on a triple net basis for 15 years.

site_title: Biden to Modi: Buying more Russian oil is not in India's interest
summary: US President Joe Biden told Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi that buying more Russian oil is not in India's interest, potentially hampering the US response to the war in Ukraine. Biden expressed growing alarm at the destruction in Ukraine, particularly in Bucha, without making a concrete ask of Modi. The two leaders discussed the issue during a "warm and candid" video call, amid concerns about deepening ties between Russia and China.

images.alt_text: Starting an hour-long video call US officials described as "warm" and "candid", Biden and Modi both publicly expressed growing alarm at the destruction inside Ukraine, especially in Bucha, where many civilians have been killed.

site_title: As Malaysia tests AI court sentencing, some lawyers fear for justice
summary: Malaysia is testing AI-powered court sentencing in the states of Sabah and Sarawak, with some lawyers expressing concerns about the technology's use before full understanding and consultation. The AI tool, developed by Sarawak Information Systems, provides sentencing recommendations, but critics warn it may entrench bias against minorities and lacks human discretion. Lawyers, including a defense attorney, argue that the technology is unconstitutional and may lead to overly harsh sentences. The Malaysian government aims to conclude its nationwide trial of the AI sentencing tools, which they claim can improve the quality of judgment, but concerns about bias and legitimacy persist.

site_title: Oil dives 4%, below US$100 on China lockdowns, reserves release plan
summary: Oil prices plummeted 4% on Monday, dipping below $100 a barrel, due to China's Covid-19 lockdowns and a plan to release record volumes of oil from strategic stocks. The International Energy Agency (IEA) will release 240 million barrels over the next six months to offset a Russian crude shortage. Fuel consumption in China has stalled, and analysts predict the country's zero-Covid policies will continue to impact demand. A stronger US dollar also contributed to the price drop, which has pushed the market into oversupply.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip on tech selloff, French election jitters
summary: European stocks fell 0.6% on Monday, led by a 2.2% drop in technology shares, amid rising bond yields and volatility in France ahead of the presidential election. France's CAC 40 index rose 0.1% despite initial fears of a Le Pen victory, while euro zone banks and insurers gained as government bond yields jumped. The Stoxx 600 index also fell, with technology stocks suffering the largest decline.

site_title: Software maker Datto to be taken private in US$6.2b deal supported by Temasek
summary: Datto, a cybersecurity software provider, will be taken private by Kaseya for US$6.2 billion in an all-cash deal. The offer is a 52% premium to Datto's closing price before the announcement. The deal is supported by a consortium led by private equity firm Insight Partners, with investments from TPG Capital, Sixth Street Partners, and Singapore state investor Temasek.

site_title: AMRO forecasts growth of 4.7% for Asean+3 as growth normalises
summary: The Asean+3 region is forecasted to grow at a moderate pace of 4.7% this year, mainly due to China's strong rebound after containing the Covid-19 pandemic in 2020. China's GDP growth is expected to be 5.2% in 2022, down from 8.1% in 2021. The Asean+3 Macroeconomic Research Office (AMRO) also predicts the region's GDP to grow at 4.6% in 2023, indicating a more moderate pace of growth.

site_title: Intel's US$3b factory expansion opens in key comeback step
summary: Intel has opened a $3 billion expansion of its D1X plant in Oregon, aiming to regain leadership in the chip industry by 2025 with better production technology. The 20% increase in the facility, dubbed Gordon Moore Park, will enable Intel to develop multiple manufacturing methods in parallel and transfer them to mass production. The move is part of CEO Pat Gelsinger's plan to reverse Intel's recent decline, with the company aiming to progress through 5 nodes in 4 years to catch up with Asian competitors.

site_title: Wall Street banks face biggest Texas loss yet in mega bond deal
summary: Wall Street banks are facing their biggest loss of business yet in a Texas bond deal worth $3.4 billion, as the state seeks underwriters for a storm-bond sale. The deal, aimed at bailing out natural gas utilities hit by losses from the 2021 winter storm, is the largest municipal-bond sale in Texas in at least 2 decades. Banks that have curtailed ties to the gun industry, such as Bank of America and JPMorgan, are excluded from bidding due to a GOP-backed law enacted in September.

site_title: UOB expects 5% revenue at risk after new digital banks enter the fray
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) expects 5% of its revenue to be at risk due to competition from new digital banks entering the Singapore market. Despite this, the bank believes the market is highly penetrated and consumers trust incumbent banks. UOB is confident in the long-term prospects of Asia, particularly Asean, and has a 5% average growth forecast for 2022. The bank also expects opportunities in green technologies and sustainable business models, valuing the sector at $1 trillion annually.

site_title: US: Wall Street stumbles as surging Treasury yields slam growth stocks
summary: US stocks plummeted Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite all ending in negative territory. The decline was driven by surging Treasury yields, which weighed on growth stocks ahead of crucial inflation data, and ongoing geopolitical tensions. The benchmark 10-year US Treasury yield hovered near a 3-year high, with analysts expecting a series of 50-basis-point interest rate hikes from the Federal Reserve in the coming months.

site_title: GoTo rises 13% on IDX debut, draws record number of investors
summary: GoTo Group, an Indonesian tech giant, made its debut on the Indonesia Stock Exchange (IDX) on April 11, 2022, valuing the company at over $30 billion. The company's shares rose 13% on the first day of trading, with 300,000 investors participating in the initial public offering (IPO). GoTo, formed by the merger of Gojek and Tokopedia, plans to expand into international markets, with CEO Andre Soelistyo stating that the company's business potential in Singapore is "still very big."

site_title: Growth a bigger worry than inflation: Thai central bank
summary: Thailand's central bank prioritizes economic growth over inflation, focusing on shoring up the country's sluggish economy. Despite surging global price pressures, the Bank of Thailand's governor expects a 1.8% year-on-year growth rate in the first quarter, with the impact of the Russia-Ukraine war not expected to derail the recovery. The central bank will continue to hold interest rates at an all-time low, with inflation expected to return to target levels next year, and will monitor for signs of deviation from the expected recovery.

site_title: The great supply chain 'reset' in Asia
summary: The supply chain in South-east Asia has experienced a significant reset due to the COVID-19 pandemic and Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Procuring raw materials and finished goods now takes 2-3 times longer, and supply chain planning effort has increased 10 times. The region's manufacturing hubs are struggling with manpower shortages, higher oil and commodity prices, and cascading supply chain disruptions. To adapt, supply chains must become more resilient, agile, and connected to the wider enterprise. Key trends driving the future of supply chain include the growing role of AI, effects of disruption cascade from linked supply chains, shrinking planning and execution time, and increasing focus on sustainability.

site_title: Meta to start testing money-making tools for its metaverse
summary: Meta Platforms is testing commerce tools for selling digital assets within its virtual reality social platform Horizon Worlds, a key part of its metaverse plan. The tools allow users to sell virtual fashion accessories or offer paid access to digital world sections. Meta is also testing a "creator bonus" program, where users in the US receive payments for adopting new tools or features. The tests are initially available to select users in the US via VR headsets, marking the social media giant's push into monetizing its metaverse platform.

site_title: MAS may opt for aggressive tightening to tame inflation in April meeting
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) may implement an aggressive monetary policy tightening to combat rising inflation, with some economists suggesting a steepening of the Singapore dollar's nominal effective exchange rate (S$NEER) policy band by 100 basis points to 2% per annum. This could allow the currency to appreciate faster and contain imported inflation. While some economists expect MAS to take a more hawkish stance, others believe a more moderate approach may be sufficient to address inflation concerns. MAS is set to review its monetary policy on April 14.

site_title: Corporate giving increases amid pandemic
summary: A survey by the National Volunteer and Philanthropy Centre (NVPC) found that 75% of businesses gave back to the community during the Covid-19 pandemic, up from 52% in 2017. This increase was driven by businesses aligning their giving objectives with their core values and advocating for causes such as social services and community causes. However, only 14% of respondents believed their businesses had contributed to the well-being of society, highlighting the need for further mindset shifts.

site_title: War gives oil producers greater clout at global climate talks
summary: Oil producers, boosted by Russia's war in Ukraine, are gaining greater influence at global climate talks. The industry is shifting its focus from being a target to a key player, with oil-producing countries working to increase supplies of energy, including fossil fuels. The United Arab Emirates and Egypt, hosting COP27 and COP28 respectively, are prioritizing oil and gas production, and Saudi Arabia is offering significant financial support to Egypt. Experts argue that efforts should focus on cutting emissions first, and that the industry's influence could co-opt climate agreements, highlighting the need for a balanced approach to address climate change.

site_title: Why Le Pen could win French presidential poll
summary: French far-right candidate Marine Le Pen emerged in second place in the presidential election, securing around 23.5% of the vote, while incumbent Emmanuel Macron trailed behind with 28%. Le Pen's strong performance is seen as a potential threat to Macron's re-election, with many of Le Pen's supporters likely to opt for her in the second round. Macron faces a tough challenge, with Le Pen's euroscepticism and anti-immigration platform potentially resonating with French voters. The election is set to be a close contest, with financial markets on edge due to the ongoing Ukraine conflict and economic uncertainty.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: US stocks opened lower due to a fresh tariff salvo by former US President Donald Trump on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potentially lower-than-expected H2 revenue, with similar operating losses as in H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. In Singapore, MAS and PBOC agreed to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Meanwhile, Indonesia detained an employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with CGSI downgrading Grab to 'hold' due to slowing earnings growth.

site_title: SGX securities turnover value down 8% at S$35.7b in March
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 8% decrease in securities turnover value to S$35.7 billion in March 2022, with volumes 44% higher month-over-month at 38.1 million shares. This marks a 29% year-over-year decline.

site_title: Indonesia police fire tear gas to disperse protest at parliament
summary: Indonesian police used tear gas and water cannons to disperse hundreds of university students protesting against high cooking oil prices and a potential extension of President Joko Widodo's term in office. The protesters, wearing neon jackets, marched towards parliament in Jakarta, calling for democratic reforms and an end to speculation about the president's stay in power. Despite no immediate reports of violence or injuries, the rally was one of several across Indonesia, with students citing concerns about the threat to democratic reforms and the prospect of a president outstaying his two-term limit.

site_title: Buffett needed 2 weeks for US$11.6b Alleghany purchase, baulked at Goldman fee
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway acquired Alleghany for $11.6 billion in its largest deal in 6 years. Buffett initially offered $850 per share, but after meeting with Alleghany's chairman, he increased the offer to meet the $27 million fee for bankers at Goldman Sachs. The deal was finalized in just two weeks. Buffett's decision to pay the fee was seen as a significant concession, but ultimately led to the successful acquisition of the insurer.

site_title: The changing world order and next decade's bubble
summary: A global turning point is underway, marked by the end of established trends and the rise of new factors that will significantly impact world economies and investors' portfolios. The last 30 years were driven by globalization, but this is coming to an end as global capital flows decrease, China's labor force peaks, and tariffs and geopolitical tensions increase. The writer predicts a prolonged bear market for top-performing sectors like technology, and warns investors to rebalance and diversify their portfolios, anticipating the next bubble. The end of the Bretton Woods II monetary system will have massive ramifications for the global economy and investment markets.

site_title: China banks allow delays of mortgage payments in Covid-hit Shanghai
summary: China's largest banks are offering Shanghai residents a payment holiday on their mortgage loans for up to 3 months due to the city's severe Covid-19 outbreak. This move aims to support the city's financial hub as it struggles with lockdowns and a growing debt crisis. The payment holiday is part of China's broader efforts to combat the pandemic, which has led to a surge in new infections, with over 26,000 cases reported on Sunday.

site_title: Cascade of allegations threatens future of Australian casinos
summary: Australia's casino industry is facing an existential crisis due to allegations of misconduct, including money laundering and exploitation of problem gamblers. Four public inquiries into Crown Resorts and Star Entertainment Group have uncovered widespread wrongdoing, with Star allegedly disguising A$1 billion in hotel expenses as gambled funds. The industry's reliance on China has led to a regulatory crackdown, with one lawmaker questioning whether the industry should be shut down. The industry's future is uncertain, with Blackstone's A$8.9 billion purchase of Crown facing scrutiny.

site_title: Landed homes: a dying breed with well supported values
summary: In Singapore, a joint venture between Hoi Hup Realty and Sunway Developments purchased a 2.45-hectare site in the Katong area for S$815 million, with plans to build high-rise condominiums. The sale represents the monetizing of long-held assets and the replacing of landed homes with condominium units. Landed homes, once the preferred choice, now account for less than 3.3 times the number of resident households, with private landed homes growing only 5% between 2010 and 2021. As demand for private homes increases, condominiums are expected to meet this demand, and high-rise developments can offer more green spaces and efficient land use.

site_title: Cut coal loose, climate advocates tell banks
summary: Climate advocates urge banks in South-east Asia to cut financing to high-carbon sectors, citing the need for stronger resolve in supporting emerging markets through the climate crisis. While some argue that fossil fuels are still needed for transition, advocates say not cutting ties can send the wrong message.

images.alt_text: BANKS in South-east Asia must demonstrate stronger resolve to cut financing to high-carbon sectors as they play a critical role in supporting the region's emerging markets through the climate crisis.

site_title: Sentosa-Brani plan to be refreshed as project's first milestone hits delay
summary: Singapore's Sentosa-Brani Master Plan, a mega-project to transform the resort island, has hit a snag with the first milestone delay due to construction challenges from the Covid-19 pandemic. A $90 million linkway connecting southern beaches and Resorts World Sentosa is now expected to open in 2023, a year later than planned. Longer-term plans, including the 30,000 square-metre Sentosa Sensoryscape, are still underway and will be redeveloped in stages over 3 decades. The project's timeline is being reviewed to ensure relevance to evolving guest preferences and industry developments.

site_title: Singapore private home sales to rise in the coming months: analysts
summary: Singapore's private home sales are expected to rise in the coming months as buyers adjust to cooling measures and take advantage of low mortgage rates. In March, developers sold 651 new private homes, a 23.5% increase from February, with 699 units sold including executive condominiums. Analysts predict further sales growth with the launch of major projects such as Piccadilly Grand and LIV @ MB. The top-performing project was Normanton Park, which sold 84 units at a median price of S$1,885 per square foot.

site_title: Sonic 2 booms to US$71m, Michael Bay's Ambulance stalls
summary: Sonic the Hedgehog 2 debuted with a US$71 million opening in the US, outperforming Michael Bay's Ambulance, which opened to a disappointing US$8 million. The film set a new high watermark for video-game adaptations, surpassing the opening weekend record of its predecessor. Director Jeff Fowler's return and the voice cast's success contributed to the strong opening, with an "A" CinemaScore from audiences. This success contrasts with Ambulance's underwhelming start, highlighting changing consumer tastes in the current movie theatre environment.

site_title: China food security at risk from growing list of farming issues
summary: Chinese farmers face significant challenges in securing enough grains for this year due to the spring planting season. Strict Covid curbs and anti-pollution rules are hindering growth in the north-east region, which produces over a fifth of China's national grain output. Soaring fertiliser and fuel costs add to the difficulties, putting food security at risk. The situation raises concerns about China's ability to meet its grain production targets.

site_title: China's Covid curbs hit EV output, including Tesla's
summary: China's COVID-19 curbs have impacted electric vehicle (EV) production, including Tesla's Shanghai factory, which produced 55,462 units in March, a 154-unit increase from February. This is despite a 16% increase in production compared to the previous month. The lockdowns have disrupted logistics and affected retail sales, with overall passenger car sales in China totaling 1.61 million, down 10.9% from last year. Tesla's exports of cars made in China dropped to 60 units, while domestic deliveries more than doubled from February.

site_title: Twitter says Musk not joining its board, warns of 'distractions ahead'
summary: Twitter CEO Parag Agrawal stated that Elon Musk rejected the company's offer to join its board, following Musk's acquisition of Twitter as its biggest shareholder. The decision came after multiple discussions between the two. Agrawal warned of "distractions ahead" for Twitter, but did not specify the reason for Musk's rejection.

site_title: SocGen to quit Russia with sale of Rosbank stake
summary: French bank Societe Generale has agreed to sell its stake in Rosbank and its insurance subsidiaries to Interros Capital, linked to billionaire Vladimir Potanin, amid Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The deal, worth about 2 billion euros, will allow SocGen to exit Russia and ensure continuity for Rosbank's employees and clients. The sale will also result in a 20 basis point dent in SocGen's CET 1 capital ratio, but the bank's guidance suggests it remains "comfortably above".

site_title: Dividing the world into ideological 'blocs' isn't smart diplomacy
summary: US President Joe Biden's definition of the conflict between the Western alliance and Russia as a "battle between democracy and autocracy" may be a self-fulfilling prophecy, as it provides incentives for Russia and China to bond against the US. However, a more nuanced approach is needed, considering the interests of the US and its partners rather than ideological blocs. The varied responses to the Ukraine war by governments worldwide suggest they are driven by economic and diplomatic interests, not ideology. A more pragmatic approach is necessary to consolidate US alliances without fueling an ideological conflict.

site_title: Sentosa-Brani Master Plan to be refreshed amid pandemic as project's first milestone hits delay
summary: Singapore's Sentosa-Brani Master Plan, a mega-project to transform the resort island, is facing delays due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The first project milestone, a $90 million linkway, is now expected to open in 2023, a year later than planned. The plan's long-term tourism infrastructure is still under way, with studies underway to understand evolving trends and new sustainable tourism opportunities. The project's delay is part of a series of tourism infrastructure delays in Singapore, including the Jurong Lake District development and the expansion of Marina Bay Sands.

site_title: Heathrow to speed up hiring as traffic at highest since start of Covid
summary: Heathrow airport is ramping up hiring as it sees a surge in passenger numbers, with 4.2 million travellers passing through in March, the highest since the Covid-19 pandemic began. The airport aims to hire 12,000 new workers to meet demand, driven by UK holidaymakers going overseas. However, the medium-term outlook remains uncertain due to the war in Ukraine, high fuel prices, and potential new Covid variants. Despite this, Heathrow expects a summer travel season that could approach 2019 levels at its peak, with some airlines experiencing delays and disruptions.

site_title: DBS Private Bank records robust growth on multiple fronts despite pandemic
summary: DBS Private Bank recorded a 12.7% increase in assets under management (AUM) in 2021, outperforming the 7% growth in 2020. The bank's fresh inflows came from multiple geographies, including Asean, Greater China, and Europe. Despite the pandemic, clients engaged in virtual meetings and wealth planning, thanks to an advanced digital platform. The bank's family office advisory and in-house managed products also saw significant growth, with assets more than doubling and surging 115% respectively. Sustainable investments accounted for 53% of portfolios, exceeding the bank's original target.

site_title: A cure for Europe's addiction to Russian energy
summary: The European Union is seeking to reduce its reliance on Russian fossil fuels after Russia's invasion of Ukraine, aiming to cut dependence by two-thirds this year and end it entirely by 2030. To achieve this, the EU must prioritize energy efficiency, which can significantly reduce gas imports and greenhouse gas emissions. The EU's "Fit for 55" package proposes increasing energy efficiency targets to 36% by 2030, but the European Parliament and governments must agree on more ambitious targets, including binding national targets and retrofitting social housing. Greater energy efficiency can also shield households from energy price increases and create skilled jobs, making it a crucial step towards advancing Europe's geopolitical and climate goals.

site_title: Shanghai eases lockdown in some areas despite record Covid-19 infections
summary: Shanghai, China's financial hub, began easing lockdowns in some areas despite a record 25,173 new Covid-19 infections, as authorities sought to revive the city after over two weeks of curbs. The easing allows residents in neighborhoods with no positive cases for two weeks to engage in "appropriate activity." The move comes as China's zero-tolerance approach to Covid-19 is increasingly strained by the highly infectious Omicron variant.

site_title: Euro gains respite from Macron's election lead
summary: The euro has gained 0.75% against the US dollar following French President Emmanuel Macron's victory in the first round of presidential voting, ending a 7-day losing streak. Macron will face far-right challenger Marine Le Pen in the runoff on April 24, but analysts say the contest remains on a knife-edge, potentially weighing on the euro. Meanwhile, the dollar has risen due to rising US yields and expectations of a quick Federal Reserve response to inflation, pushing the yen to a fresh 7-year low against the dollar.

site_title: Singapore stocks start trading week in the red alongside regional peers
summary: Singapore stocks began the week in the red, following a rise in China's inflation data. The Straits Times Index fell 0.6% to 3,363.56, as fears of extended lockdowns in China weighed on markets. Regional peers also declined, with the KLCI, Kospi, and Hang Seng Index losing 0.2%, 0.3%, and 3% respectively. Ascent Bridge was the top gainer, while Jardine Matheson Holdings was the biggest loser. Market analysts attributed the decline to China's Covid-zero policy and potential spread of lockdowns to other major industrial cities.

site_title: Is Putin's war driving up commodity prices?
summary: Commodity prices have surged to 7% inflation in the US and Europe, despite Russia's war in Ukraine not significantly impacting supply. Most price increases occurred before the war, and Ukraine's wheat exports are only 3% of global production. The "hog cycle" and ESG investing may be major factors, as reduced investment in exploration leads to lower production capacity and higher prices. The war's impact is likely minor, and a responsible policy response should focus on adjusting to new levels of scarcity, rather than compensating consumers for lost purchasing power.

site_title: Strategy to tame the inflation tiger
summary: Investors are facing increased concerns about inflation, with the global economy experiencing a surge in energy prices due to the ongoing war in Europe. However, long-term investors should not panic and sell out of equities or private assets, as these tend to protect against inflation. A plan is essential, with a focus on global equities and private assets, which have historically delivered strong returns and retained purchasing power. Historically, inflation has eroded the value of currencies over 30 years, but assets like equities and private equity have outperformed inflation, with returns of 8.5% and 13.6% respectively in the 10 years to September 2020.

site_title: NutryFarm requests trading suspension pending review of ongoing concerns
summary: NutryFarm International, a Singapore-based durian and health foods distributor, has requested a trading suspension on the Singapore Exchange pending a review of ongoing concerns. The company faces a letter of demand from creditor Corpbond IV for unpaid debt of S$3.9 million and US$271,849, and has also been questioned over the suitability of its executive chairman Wu Yongqiang due to his involvement in 18 civil lawsuits in China. NutryFarm had previously sought two trading halts in the past week.

site_title: Hong Kong shares close with heavy losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted over 3% on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index down 3.03% and the Shanghai Composite Index down 2.61%. The decline was attributed to unease over tightening US monetary policy and the impact of a Covid-19 outbreak on the Chinese economy.

site_title: Guangzhou, Shanghai add new potholes to China's road to recovery
summary: China's road to economic recovery is experiencing setbacks as the manufacturing hub of Guangzhou closed to most arrivals due to Covid-19 cases, while Shanghai, a key financial center, is lifting lockdown restrictions. This has led economists to cut their full-year growth projections below the official 5.5% target, with some estimating a 0.3-0.9 percentage point decline in GDP. The Chinese government is expected to unveil more policy easing measures in the second half of the year to cushion growth, despite its commitment to maintaining a "zero-Covid" policy.

site_title: OCBC Securities, Lion Global to list low carbon ETF on SGX
summary: OCBC Securities and Lion Global Investors will list a low-carbon exchange-traded fund (ETF) on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on April 28. The ETF tracks the iEdge-OCBC Singapore Low Carbon Select 50 Capped Index, which includes top 50 Singapore companies with low carbon intensity. The index is verified by Sustainalytics and has outperformed market benchmarks. The ETF will be available in S$ and US$ denominations, allowing for smaller lot sizes and potentially attracting younger investors. The listing is part of OCBC's efforts to promote sustainable investing and lead the way for corporations to reduce their carbon footprint.

site_title: Viet carmaker VinFast's planned US IPO more than just a lofty aspiration
summary: Vietnamese carmaker VinFast has submitted a draft registration statement to the US Securities and Exchange Commission, signaling its plan for a potential initial public offering (IPO). The move follows the company's announcement of a US$2 billion factory in North Carolina, which will create 7,000 jobs, and a US$200 million investment in its California headquarters. VinFast aims to compete in the US electric car market, where Tesla dominates, and faces a challenging task given the saturated market and competition from established brands.

images.alt_text: VINFAST Trading & Investment - the Singapore-based subsidiary of Vietnamese carmarker Vinfast - recently submitted a confidential draft registration statement to the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC).

site_title: China's Covid lockdowns, surging oil add to inflation risks
summary: China's producer price index (PPI) rose 8.3% in March, above expectations, driven by surging oil prices and Covid lockdowns. Consumer price growth accelerated to 1.5%, with food prices jumping 17.2% and fuel prices rising 24.1%. The lockdowns are expected to disrupt food supplies, adding to global risks. Despite inflation concerns, China's central bank is likely to ease monetary policy to cushion the economy, with a policy rate cut or other easing measure possible soon.

site_title: Queues of bulk ships waiting off China's ports amid lockdowns
summary: Bulk cargo ships are forming queues off Chinese ports due to lockdowns, with congestion expanding beyond Shanghai to other ports. The city-wide lockdown in Shanghai at the end of March has disrupted the delivery of raw materials, including metal ore and grain. The delays are affecting the country's resource supply and economic growth.

site_title: SoftBank leads US$185m round in Pax8 at US$1.7b value
summary: SoftBank Vision Fund led a $185 million investment in Pax8 Inc, valuing the company at $1.7 billion. The Denver-based startup helps small businesses manage cloud technology services, with customers ranging from dentists to plumbers. Existing investors also participated in the round. SoftBank managing partner Nagraj Kashyap cited Pax8's edge in navigating small business technology needs, citing the company's 10-year scaling success.

site_title: Ascott targets 150 lyf co-living properties by 2030
summary: Ascott targets 150 lyf co-living properties by 2030, with 17 existing properties in 14 cities and 9 countries. The company aims to grow its lyf portfolio through management contracts, private investments, and its Ascott Residence Trust. A collaborative innovation laboratory will explore immersive virtual reality and augmented reality technologies to enhance the co-living experience.

site_title: China needs own seeds to guarantee country's 'food bowl', says Xi
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping emphasized the need for China to be independent in seeds to guarantee its 'food bowl' and achieve food security.
