He made the remarks during a visit to the Yazhou Bay Seed Laboratory in Hainan, a major breeding base for the seed sector. Xi stated that only by holding Chinese seeds tightly with their own hands can they stabilize the Chinese food bowl and achieve food security. This comes amid growing concerns about China's reliance on imports of food.

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust's going concern flagged as auditor notes net current liabilities
summary: Dasin Retail Trust's auditor has flagged a material uncertainty that may cast significant doubt on the Reit's ability to continue as a going concern due to its negative working capital position and significant net current liabilities of S$719.9 million. The Reit has loan repayments due on June 19, July 15, and September 18, totaling S$499.5 million, and a revolving credit loan facility of US$13.1 million. Despite this, the trust's financial statements have been prepared on a going concern basis due to active negotiations with lenders and assessments of stable growth potential and sufficient cash reserves.

site_title: US: Stocks retreat ahead of key inflation report
summary: US stocks retreated ahead of the key inflation report, with tech shares taking a hit as investors await potential aggressive Federal Reserve action. Despite this, Twitter's stock price rose after Elon Musk announced he wouldn't join its board upon becoming the largest shareholder. The consumer price index reading for March is set to be released on Tuesday, following a 7.9% year-over-year inflation rate in February, a 40-year high.

site_title: Acra investigates Singapore Kitchen Equipment over possible falsification of report
summary: Singapore Kitchen Equipment has been informed by the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) of an investigation into possible falsification of a report. The regulator requested a copy of the finalized report on potential irregularities related to accounting records of the company's wholly owned subsidiary, Q'son Kitchen Equipment. Alternatively, the draft report by law firm Rajah & Tann Singapore, dated August 6, 2021, should be handed over if the finalized version is not ready.

site_title: Singapore and Chongqing deepen collaboration in financial services, healthcare and other sectors
summary: Singapore and Chongqing signed 30 agreements on April 11, 2022, to deepen collaboration in financial services, healthcare, and other sectors. The agreements include renewing a memorandum of understanding in information, communications, and media, and supporting 18 projects through the Joint Innovation Development Fund. The collaboration aims to strengthen air connectivity, promote financial services, and explore opportunities in emerging areas such as the digital economy and green economy. The agreements were signed virtually by Minister for Communications and Information Josephine Teo and Chongqing mayor Hu Henghua.

site_title: Epic Games valued at about US$32b in funding from Sony, Lego firm
summary: Epic Games, the creator of "Fortnite," has raised US$2 billion in funding from Sony Group Corp and the Kirkbi investment company, valuing the company at US$31.5 billion. The investment will help advance the company's metaverse partnership with the Lego Group. This deal comes as tech giants invest heavily in the metaverse, a shared virtual platform, and follows Microsoft's US$68.7 billion acquisition of Activision Blizzard. The funding will allow Sony to deepen its investment in Epic's metaverse business, which is considered part of the metaverse.

site_title: Higher oil prices a positive in merger of Keppel O&M and Sembmarine
summary: Keppel O&M and Sembmarine, two Singaporean companies, have set April 30 as the deadline for a definitive agreement on a potential merger. The move comes after nine months of talks, with shares of both companies rising despite the Straits Times Index falling. Elevated oil prices, driven by a rebounding economy and energy crunch, offer renewed hope for the offshore sector. The merged entity would have a renewable energy slant, with Sembmarine focusing on renewables and clean energy. Analysts expect the merger to create an offshore juggernaut, with a combined orderbook of S$6.4 billion.

site_title: MoneyOwl rolls out digital CPF investment service and 2 lower-cost funds
summary: MoneyOwl, a robo advisory platform, has launched a digital investment service for the CPF (Central Provident Fund) in Singapore, partnering with Lion Global Investors and UOB Asset Management to offer two lower-cost funds. The funds are retrocession-free, meaning investors won't pay trail fees to distributors, and are available to CPF investors. The move aims to simplify the investment experience and provide better returns for Singaporeans. MoneyOwl will waive advisory fees for the new products until the end of 2022.

site_title: UOB expects 5% revenue at risk after new digital banks enter the fray
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) expects 5% of its revenue to be at risk due to new digital banks entering the Singapore market, despite believing the market is highly penetrated and incumbent banks are well-trusted by consumers. The bank anticipates limited impact from competition in the near term and is confident in its long-term prospects, particularly in the Asia-Pacific region, with a 5% average growth forecast for Asean in 2022.

site_title: Philippine tycoon Lucio Tan's bank brings forward property listing
summary: Philippine National Bank (PNB) is moving forward with its plan to list its property unit, aiming to float the asset by the end of 2022. The listing is expected to generate approximately 10 billion pesos (S$263 million) of additional capital, with PNB Holdings now targeting a 2022 listing instead of the original 2023 schedule.

site_title: Pakistan parliament elects Sharif PM; Khan MPs quit en masse
summary: Pakistan's Parliament elected Shehbaz Sharif as prime minister, completing the ousting of Imran Khan in a no-confidence vote. Khan's Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf party MPs resigned en masse from the lower house in protest. Sharif, the younger brother of three-time prime minister Nawaz Sharif, vows to tackle Pakistan's economic malaise and improve relations with the US, India, and China. The election marks the end of a week-long constitutional confrontation, with Khan remaining defiant despite his defeat.

site_title: Twitter shares fall and then recover after Elon Musk declines potential board role
summary: Elon Musk, Twitter's largest shareholder, declined a potential board role, sparking a share price swing. Twitter shares initially fell 7% before recovering 3% after the decision, fueling speculation about a potential takeover. Musk can now increase his stake and push for changes in the company, raising concerns about a potential hostile takeover. The US Securities and Exchange Commission is proposing new rules to prevent secret stake-building, but Musk's vast wealth and influence make a takeover more plausible.

site_title: Benettons, Blackstone nearing takeover bid for infrastructure player Atlantia
summary: The billionaire Benetton family and US buyout firm Blackstone are nearing a takeover bid for Italian infrastructure giant Atlantia, reportedly worth nearly $97 billion. The deal, expected to be announced as early as Wednesday, would make it the year's largest deal. Atlantia's minority shareholders, including Singapore's GIC and CRT, are expected to invest in a new company for the takeover. The Benettons already own about 33% of Atlantia, which is set to receive $8 billion from the sale of its Autostrade highway unit following the 2018 Genoa bridge collapse.

site_title: Tesla China exports only 60 cars in March as Covid hits auto sector
summary: Tesla China exported only 60 cars in March due to pandemic-related disruptions, despite delivering 65,814 cars at its factory. The company's Shanghai factory, which is its main export hub, has suspended production since March 28 amid virus lockdowns. In contrast, the new-energy sector has seen a surge in deliveries, jumping 137.6% compared to March 2021. China's auto market has also seen a decline, with car sales falling 10.5% from last year.

site_title: Delays in British port of Dover damaging fresh produce exports, producers warn
summary: British food producers are warning that delays at the port of Dover due to congestion and technical issues are damaging fresh produce exports. The port's main route for road freight to mainland Europe has been disrupted by P&O Ferries' suspension of operations and heavy Easter traffic. The British Meat Processors Association says fresh meat has been stranded for 1-2 days, reducing its shelf life and value. Environment Minister George Eustice has criticized authorities for not prioritizing perishable food, but said establishing a priority lane for these goods is complicated.

site_title: New home sales up in March, expected to stay buoyant in coming months
summary: New home sales in Singapore increased by 23.5% in March to 651 units, driven by developers selling 48 executive condominiums (ECs) and a Lunar New Year seasonal lull passing. Analysts attribute the growth to cooling measures, rising interest rates, and foreign investment. The top-performing project was Normanton Park, followed by The Florence Residences and Ki Residences at Brookvale. EC sales are expected to rise further with the launch of the 616-unit North Gaia project, and major projects like Piccadilly Grand and LIV @ MB are expected to drive sales in April and May.

site_title: Corporate giving in Singapore increases during pandemic: NVPC survey
summary: In a survey by the National Volunteer and Philanthropy Centre (NVPC), 75% of businesses in Singapore engaged in corporate giving during the Covid-19 pandemic, up from 52% in 2017. The median philanthropy value decreased to S$1,000, but the median percentage of employees volunteering increased to 50%. Financial and insurance, and information and communications industries showed the highest community contributions. Businesses are increasingly aligning their giving objectives with core values, but more work is needed to shift mindset towards investing in ESG.

site_title: Why far right, pro-Russia Le Pen could win French presidential poll
summary: Marine Le Pen, a far-right and pro-Russian candidate, secured 23.5% of the vote in the first round of the French presidential election, emerging in second place behind incumbent Emmanuel Macron, who received 28%. The two will face off in the second round on April 24, with Macron's lead narrowing to 2-3 percentage points, according to polls. Le Pen's strong performance has raised concerns about her potential to win the election, particularly given the economic and social tensions in France, and her euroscepticism and anti-immigration stance.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What happened today
summary: CBD office rents in Singapore rose 1.5% quarter-over-quarter in Q1 2022 to S$10.26 per square foot, the fastest pace of growth since Q3 2021. Indonesian tech giant GoTo Group's shares surged 14.8% on its debut on the Indonesia Stock Exchange, valuing the company at US$31.6 billion. Meanwhile, Singapore Exchange's securities turnover value fell 8% to S$35.7 billion in March, while a freehold commercial building in Joo Chiat Road was put up for sale at S$50 million. An ETF focusing on low-carbon Singapore companies is set to list on the SGX in April.

site_title: Is Putin's war in Ukraine driving up commodity prices?
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin's war in Ukraine is not the primary cause of spiking energy and commodity prices. Despite being the world's largest exporter of oil and petroleum products, Russia has not led to large-scale interruptions in the supply of oil, gas, or other commodities. The expectation of a shortage in markets is driving up prices, but this expectation seems to have little basis. The global economy is instead facing inflation and the risk of stagflation due to other factors, including the pandemic's economic recovery stalling. Commodity prices remain high, affecting consumers in the US and Europe.

site_title: Sterling falls as data shows Britain's economic growth stutters
summary: The British pound fell against the euro and dollar after the UK economy showed slower-than-expected growth in February, with a 0.1% increase in gross domestic product. This missed forecasts of a 0.3% increase. Sterling briefly fell below $1.30 before recovering to $1.3025. The Bank of England is expected to hike interest rates, but money markets currently price around 142.6 basis points by year-end. Rising US yields have also contributed to the dollar's strength near its highest level since May 2020.

site_title: Apple faces extra EU antitrust charge in music streaming probe, says source
summary: Apple faces an additional EU antitrust charge in a music streaming investigation triggered by a complaint from Spotify, according to a person familiar with the matter. The European Commission had previously accused Apple of distorting competition in the music streaming market via restrictive App Store rules. The extra charges, set to be issued in the coming weeks, reflect new evidence gathered by the EU competition enforcer. Apple's practices in e-books and Apple Pay are also under scrutiny. Companies found breaching EU antitrust rules face fines of up to 10% of global turnover.

site_title: Strategy to tame the inflation tiger
summary: Investors face the challenge of navigating inflation amid global crisis. Despite recent energy price increases, long-term investors should consider the long-term benefits of equities and private assets. A plan is crucial, especially for retirement goals, which require a long-term perspective. Complexity and uncertainty can lead to delayed planning or giving up. Experts emphasize the importance of productivity gains in unlocking wealth creation, while de-dollarisation and shifting safe havens are also on the horizon.

site_title: Dividing the world into ideological blocs isn't smart diplomacy
summary: US President Joe Biden has framed the conflict between the Western alliance and Russia as a global "battle between democracy and autocracy", but this binary approach may be self-fulfilling, as it provides incentives to Russia and China to bond against the US. In reality, responses to the Ukraine war are driven by economic and diplomatic interests, not ideological orientation. Key allies like India, Brazil, and South Africa have refused to join the anti-Russia campaign, while US allies in the Middle East have resisted sanctions. Washington should consolidate alliances based on mutual interests, not an ideological conflict.

site_title: The Great Supply Chain 'reset': The 5 trends affecting supply chains in Asia
summary: The supply chain in Asia is experiencing a "reset" due to the COVID-19 pandemic, Russia's invasion of Ukraine, and other disruptions. Key trends include supply chain becoming a board-level topic, the growing role of AI, effects of disruption cascading from linked supply chains, the need for shorter planning cycles, and the increasing importance of sustainability. As a result, companies must adapt to new demands and challenges, leveraging digital transformation, AI, and circular economy approaches to remain competitive and mitigate risks. Supply chain planning must connect to the wider enterprise and prioritize resilience and agility.

site_title: Indonesia students rally against mooted move to extend president's term
summary: Indonesian students protested against a mooted extension of President Joko Widodo's term, despite his efforts to dismiss speculation. Demonstrations took place in several cities, citing rising goods costs and concerns about democratic reforms. The idea of a term extension has gained momentum, with some influential figures backing it. However, a recent survey showed over 70% of Indonesians reject the plan, and President Widodo has been criticized for his ambiguous stance on the issue.

images.alt_text: Indonesian student protesters in front of the Parliament compound in Jakarta on Monday (Apr 11). Thousands of students across the archipelago demonstrated against extending the presidential term to 3 terms and postponing the 2024 elections; they were also asking for a reduction in the prices of basic necessities and fuel.

A police officer wounded in the clashes with student protesters outside the Parliament building in Jakarta on Monday (Apr 11). Although President Joko Widodo has high approval ratings among the people, the idea of allowing more than the maximum 2 5-year terms as president has fuelled concern about a threat to hard-won democratic reforms.

site_title: India's 'unicorn couple' aim for first startup IPO within a year
summary: India's 'unicorn couple' Ruchi Kalra and Ashish Mohapatra, who founded separate billion-dollar startups, aim to debut one of their firms, OfBusiness, on public markets within a year. OfBusiness could go for an IPO in six months, while Oxyzo, their digital lending startup, may float shares in two years. Both companies are profitable and have received funding from prominent investors, including SoftBank Group Corp and Norwest Venture Partners. The couple plans to debut their firms at the opportune time, with both companies ready for public markets.

site_title: Seoul: 10-year treasury yield hits 8-year high; stocks fall
summary: South Korea's 10-year treasury yield hit an 8-year high at 3.297% due to bets on faster monetary tightening at home and abroad, while a supplementary budget plan also weighed on the market. The Bank of Korea raised its benchmark interest rate by 75 basis points to 1.25%, with analysts predicting further rises to 2% by the end of the year. The Kospi closed down 0.27% at 2,693.10, with technology giant Samsung Electronics gaining and peer SK Hynix falling.

site_title: Australia hopes to keep early F1 slot after strong reboot
summary: Australia's Formula One Grand Prix has seen record crowds of 419,000 people, surpassing the previous record of 401,000 in 1996. The event, which took place from Thursday to Sunday, has boosted the country's hopes of retaining its early F1 slot in the calendar. Traditionally, the Australian Grand Prix has opened the championship, but this year it was scheduled as the third stop after a Middle East doubleheader. The success of the event may help Australia secure its position in the F1 calendar.

site_title: Shanghai to ease lockdown in some areas despite record Covid infections
summary: Shanghai is easing lockdowns in some areas despite a record 25,000 new Covid-19 infections. The city is grouping residential units into three "risk categories" to allow "appropriate activity" in neighborhoods with no positive cases for 2 weeks. This move comes as residents grow frustrated with the prolonged lockdowns, which have led to food and medicine shortages. The easing of restrictions is aimed at getting the city moving again after over two weeks of curbs.

site_title: SMEs must commit to digital innovation, upskilling and R&D collaboration to maintain growth
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) must prioritize digital innovation, upskilling, and research and development (R&D) collaboration to maintain growth in the face of ongoing challenges. Despite a 7.6% GDP expansion in 2021, new headwinds such as supply chain disruptions and inflation may impact SMEs. The Singapore government has introduced a new Jobs and Business Support Package, offering grants and schemes to support affected businesses. SMEs must invest in digital solutions, such as productivity grants and advanced digital solutions, to drive long-term growth. Upskilling and R&D collaboration can also help SMEs build agility and resilience.

site_title: SocGen to quit Russia with sale of Rosbank stake to oligarch Potanin
summary: French bank Societe Generale has agreed to sell its stake in Russian lender Rosbank and its insurance subsidiaries to Interros Capital, a firm linked to billionaire Vladimir Potanin, in a deal worth around 2 billion euros. The sale comes amid mounting pressure for Western companies to cut ties with Russia due to its invasion of Ukraine. The deal will allow SocGen to exit Russia in an orderly manner, ensuring continuity for Rosbank's employees and clients, and will result in a write-off for the bank.

site_title: EU can no longer afford to neglect energy efficiency
summary: The European Union is under pressure to increase energy efficiency as it seeks to reduce its reliance on Russian fossil fuels following the invasion of Ukraine. The EU aims to cut its dependence on Russian hydrocarbons by two-thirds this year and end it entirely "well before" 2030. Increasing energy efficiency can significantly reduce gas imports and greenhouse gas emissions, and the EU's "Fit for 55" package proposes a binding energy-efficiency target of 36% by 2030. However, the European Parliament is pushing for an even more ambitious target of 43% and binding national targets to ensure the EU's climate goals are met.

site_title: CBD office rents continue northwards, underpinned by healthy demand: Colliers
summary: Singapore's CBD Premium and Grade A office rents rose 1.5% quarter-over-quarter to S$10.26 per square foot, marking the fastest pace of growth since Q3 2021. Leasing demand remained positive, with 134,000 square feet of net absorption and a vacancy rate of 3.3%. Colliers expects rents to grow 4-5% by end-2022 and vacancy to tighten further, driven by economic recovery and return-to-office momentum. Occupiers are becoming more selective, favoring high-quality office spaces, while landlords are expected to outperform amid tight yields and interest rate uncertainties.

site_title: Heathrow hiring as traffic hits highest since start of Covid
summary: Heathrow airport is hiring 12,000 new workers as passenger numbers surged to 4.2 million in March, the highest since the Covid-19 pandemic began. The UK's lifted travel curbs led to a 7-fold increase in travellers, with the airport expecting a summer travel season approaching 2019 levels. However, the rapid upswing in travel volumes has put pressure on Heathrow and other airports, with fuel shortages and staff shortages contributing to congestion. The airport's chief executive warned that the surge in demand may not be sustainable due to ongoing Covid concerns and other factors.

site_title: SGX securities turnover value down 8% to S$35.7b in March
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a total market turnover value of S$35.7 billion in March 2022, down 8% from the year-ago period but up 21% from February. Securities daily average value (SDAV) decreased 5.4% month-over-month and 8% year-over-year, while derivatives daily average volume (DAV) reached a 2-year high at 1.2 million contracts. Securitised products, ETFs, and structured warrants saw strong growth due to market volatility, with ETF market turnover increasing 63% month-over-month.

site_title: Positioning your portfolio for the Changing World Order and Next Decade's Bubble
summary: A global turning point is underway, with many established trends set to have significant ramifications for world economies and investors' portfolios. The last decade's top-performing companies, such as Apple, Google, and Amazon, are unlikely to continue their dominance in the next decade. A new bubble is emerging, with sectors like Facebook, Amazon, Netflix, and Microsoft (FANMAG) experiencing strong growth. However, investors should be cautious, as this trend is likely to be followed by a prolonged bear market. The end of globalization, a decrease in global capital flows, and a shift towards protectionism and self-sufficiency will impact the investing landscape, making it essential to reassess investment strategies and anticipate the next bubble.

site_title: Singapore stocks start trading week in the red alongside regional peers
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index fell 0.6% to close at 3,363.56 on Monday, mirroring a decline in regional peers due to China's 8.3% year-on-year rise in inflation data. Analysts attribute the market's downturn to concerns over China's Covid-zero policy and potential lockdowns, which may impact growth. Notably, Ascent Bridge and Keppel Corporation were the top gainers, while Jardine Matheson Holdings and the trio of lenders (DBS, UOB, and OCBC) were the biggest losers.

site_title: Scottie Scheffler runs away with Masters for first major title
summary: Scottie Scheffler secured his first major title at the Masters, winning by three shots with a 10-under 278. Scheffler shot a 1-under-par 71 in the final round, despite a four-putt double bogey on his last hole. The 25-year-old's dominance was evident, and he expressed gratitude for the opportunity to return to Augusta National for a lifetime. Rory McIlroy finished as the runner-up, posting a bogey-free 64, while Tiger Woods returned to competitive golf after a year-long injury, finishing 47th.

site_title: Money FM: Podcasts of the week (Apr 4)
summary: Singapore is setting aside $500 million to kick-start the country's tourism recovery, with the goal of boosting the sector's job market. The initiative comes as the tourism industry continues to face challenges. Meanwhile, TeamViewer, a Singapore-headquartered company, is expanding its focus in the Asia-Pacific region, creating new job opportunities for locals. Additionally, sustainable farming techniques are being discussed, with experts highlighting the importance of environmentally-friendly practices in agriculture. These developments are part of a broader effort to revitalize Singapore's economy and promote sustainable growth.

site_title: Indonesia coal miners likely to gain from rising prices, supply disruptions
summary: Indonesia's coal mining companies are expected to post strong earnings growth in 2022 due to rising coal prices and a supply disruption from the Ukraine conflict. Analyst William Simadiputra raised his estimates for the Newcastle coal price index to $150/tonne in 2022 and $125/tonne in 2023. Indonesia's coal production is likely to grow in the second quarter, but existing companies with strong capital positions will be able to ramp up production, while others may struggle due to equipment waiting times. The analyst expects coal prices to stay elevated, with prices potentially dropping to $70/tonne in the long term due to global energy transitions.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close lower ahead of US data
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Monday as investors awaited key US economic data, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index losing 0.61% and the Topix index sliding 0.38%. The dollar jumped to 125 yen, and chip-related shares were lower following a sell-off of US tech shares due to concerns over the Federal Reserve's monetary policy. Key US data, including consumer price indexes for March, is expected to influence the Fed's monetary policy and global markets.

site_title: Australia: Shares end slightly higher on banking, gold stocks boost
summary: Australian shares closed 0.1% higher on Monday, driven by gains in banks amid expected rate hikes, outweighing weakness in mining stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended at 7,485.2. Financial stocks rose 0.8-1.4%, while energy stocks slipped 0.2%. Gold stocks reached a 1-month high, and nickel miner Western Areas jumped 5.8% after agreeing to a takeover offer. Investors remain cautious due to global inflationary pressures and the Russia-Ukraine conflict.

site_title: Australian election campaign kicks off with opposition ahead in polls
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison's government may lose the federal election on May 21, according to polls, with opposition leader Anthony Albanese leading by 5 percentage points. A Newspoll survey showed Morrison gaining a point to 44% and Albanese falling 3 points to 39%. The ruling coalition could lose 10 seats to Labor, potentially leading to a Labor win for the first time since 2013. Morrison launched his campaign from a marginal seat in New South Wales, focusing on cost-of-living pressures and climate change.

images.alt_text: A Newspoll survey conducted for The Australian newspaper showed Morrison (above) gaining a point to 44 per cent, while opposition leader Anthony Albanese falling 3 points to 39 per cent.

site_title: Savills appoints managing director of industrial and commercial leasing services
summary: Savills appoints Sally Tan as managing director of its industrial and commercial leasing services, aiming to grow sales and leasing capabilities in the industrial market. Tan, with over 25 years of experience, will lead the industrial platform and provide strategic oversight to the commercial leasing team. Her expertise spans business strategy, building operations, and marketing across various sectors, and she will report to Marcus Loo, Savills Singapore's chief executive.

site_title: OCBC Securities, Lion Global to list low carbon ETF on SGX in April
summary: OCBC Securities and Lion Global Investors will list a new low-carbon exchange-traded fund (ETF) on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on April 28, tracking Singapore companies with low carbon intensity. The ETF, which will track the iEdge-OCBC Singapore Low Carbon Select 50 Capped Index, has outperformed market benchmarks and will offer investors convenience and low cost. This is the third ETF listed by Lion Global and OCBC Securities on the SGX, with the first two focusing on the Hang Seng Tech Index and China.

site_title: China's Zhihu starts Hong Kong dual primary listing
summary: Chinese question-and-answer website Zhihu has begun its dual primary listing in Hong Kong to raise $133 million, amid a regulatory standoff between the US and China over access to Chinese company audits. The deal comes as Zhihu's New York-listed shares have fallen 53.8% in 2022. This move may be part of a larger trend of Chinese firms considering secondary or dual primary listings in Hong Kong to avoid potential US delistings. The deal is expected to be finalized on April 14.

site_title: China inflation beats expectations on oil, Covid disruptions
summary: China's factory gate prices rose 8.3% in March, beating expectations, driven by rising oil prices and repeated Covid outbreaks. Consumer prices accelerated to 1.5% year-over-year, exceeding projections. The war in Ukraine and lockdowns have added to economic pressures, while China's central bank is in easing mode, preparing for potential policy rate cuts to boost liquidity. Despite inflation, policymakers are unlikely to constrain support for economic growth.

site_title: Fitch revises outlook on Golden Energy to 'positive' from 'stable'
summary: Fitch Ratings revised its outlook on Golden Energy and Resources (Gear) to 'positive' from 'stable', affirming its long-term foreign-currency issuer default rating at B+. The revision is due to expected improvements in Gear's key subsidiary, Golden Energy Mines (GEMS), with a projected 50-55 million tonnes of annual production and a low-cost structure. GEMS' reserves are the fourth-largest in Indonesia, with a 20-year reserve life. The rating reflects GEMS' competitive cost position and strong financial profile, leading to a sustainable increase in operating cash flow.

site_title: Singapore's Coda is said to near funding at US$2.5b value: sources
summary: Singaporean online payment processing company Coda Payments is nearing a deal to raise private funds at a US$2.5 billion valuation. The company, founded in 2011, is poised to announce a fresh fundraising deal to fuel growth plans, with investors including Advent International and Primavera Capital potentially participating. Coda has been exploring options such as a sale, initial public offering, or private round, following a strategic review with Goldman Sachs. The deal's details, including valuation and prospective investors, are still being finalized.

site_title: Tesla China exports slump to just 60 cars on strong local demand
summary: Tesla exported just 60 cars from its Shanghai factory in March, a record low due to strong domestic demand. The US-based electric vehicle maker shipped 65,814 cars from China, with 65,754 going to the domestic market. This marks the highest local production and delivery since December. Despite a 6-day plant shutdown, Tesla's March output is the highest since then. Strong local demand in China, where passenger vehicle sales slid 10.9% year-on-year, has led to a surge in new-energy vehicle deliveries, with BYD also experiencing significant growth.

site_title: China 10-year bond yield drops below US yields, first time since 2010
summary: China's 10-year bond yield dropped below US yields for the first time in 12 years, reaching a 3-year peak of 2.784% on Monday, amid expectations of more monetary easing to counter the impact of prolonged Covid-19 lockdowns. This move follows similar short-term yield inversions and is driven by concerns of a global economic slowdown, particularly in China. Analysts anticipate potential interest rate cuts or cash injections to support the Chinese economy, which has been hit by the lockdowns.

site_title: China traders gear up to add stocks, betting worst is over
summary: Chinese investors are planning to boost stock positions, forecasting gains of 4-5% by the end of June, according to a Bloomberg survey of 21 fund managers and analysts. 43% believe A-shares have already reached a trough, while 33% expect markets to bottom out this quarter. Investors expect modest gains, with median estimates for China's CSI 300 Index and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index at 4% and 5%, respectively. The survey points to around 11% gains for China's stocks and 14% for Hong Kong's by the end of the year.

site_title: China developer Zhenro defaults on interest payments for 2 offshore bonds
summary: China developer Zhenro Properties defaulted on interest payments for two offshore bonds worth US$540 million, citing lockdowns in Shanghai as a cause. The company expects to miss four more interest payments due to the lockdown and plans to make the payments by the end of May. Shares and bond prices plummeted, with Zhenro's shares sliding 10% in morning trade. The company may also default on four other bonds worth over US$860 million, and plans to extend debt maturity and dispose of assets worth up to S$857.3 million.

site_title: China food security at risk from growing list of farming issues
summary: Chinese farmers in the northeast region, responsible for producing over a fifth of the country's grain output, face numerous challenges as the spring planting season begins. Strict Covid curbs and anti-pollution rules have hindered farmers from clearing fields and burning stubble, while alternative methods are deemed ineffective. The situation raises concerns about China's ability to secure enough grains domestically, potentially leading to a shortage and increased reliance on imports. The Chinese government has urged farmers to adopt alternative methods, but many have pushed back, citing concerns about land quality and pest risks.

site_title: Philippine tycoon Tan's bank brings forward property listing
summary: Billionaire Lucio Tan's Philippine National Bank (PNB) is moving forward with its plan to list its property unit by the end of this year, aiming to generate 10 billion pesos (S$263 million) of additional capital. The move is expected to boost the bank's capital and help resolve its nonperforming loans issue. PNB's CEO Wick Veloso also plans to reduce the bank's provisions and increase its retail lending, aiming for a higher return on equity (ROE) of at least 7% in the next three years.

site_title: Shaping Southeast Asia's supply chains in 2022
summary: Southeast Asia's supply chains in 2022 have been shaped by the COVID-19 pandemic's disruptions, with regional supply chain challenges increasing globally. Long vessel waiting times, port-side labor shortages, and rising ocean freight rates have complicated cargo transportation, particularly in Asia. Businesses are pivoting to multimodal transport to balance cost efficiencies and transit time requirements. Local players are dominating regional supply chains, offering faster deliveries and better value propositions to businesses. To adapt, supply chain players must maintain open dialogue with partners and enhance resilience while enabling supply chains to respond to the e-commerce boom.

site_title: Asia: Shares slip ahead of ECB meeting, US inflation test
summary: Asian shares declined on Monday ahead of a week of central bank meetings, including the European Central Bank's inflation test and the US Federal Reserve's rate hike decision. The euro gained against the dollar due to relief over the French presidential election results, while inflation figures in China and the US will also be closely watched. Markets are anticipating higher interest rates and a potential recession.

site_title: Freehold Joo Chiat commercial building for sale at indicative price of S$50 million
summary: A 4-storey freehold commercial building in Singapore's Joo Chiat Road is up for sale at an indicative price of S$50 million. The 5,708 sq ft site, zoned commercial under the Master Plan 2019, offers a 16.5m frontage and regular floor plates. The building features a ground floor approved for a permanent restaurant and upper floors for function rooms, offices, and staff resting areas. An expression of interest exercise will be conducted for the sale.

site_title: China banks allow mortgage payment holiday in Covid-hit Shanghai
summary: China's largest banks are offering mortgage payment holidays in Shanghai due to the city's Covid-19 outbreak, allowing residents to delay payments for up to 3 months. Lenders such as Industrial & Commercial Bank of China and Bank of Communications are providing the relief as Shanghai struggles with a record-breaking 26,000 new Covid infections. This move is part of China's broader efforts to support the financial hub and comes amid growing public discontent and economic disruption.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on April 11, 2022, due to unease over tightening US monetary policy and awaiting retailers' earnings reports. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.49% to 26,852.40, while the Topix index fell 0.21% to 1,892.84.

site_title: Billionaire Musk rejects Twitter's offer to join its board
summary: Elon Musk has declined Twitter's offer to join its board, according to CEO Parag Agrawal. Musk had previously disclosed a 9.2% stake in the company and expressed his desire for changes, including an edit button and automatic verification marks. His suggestions sparked a poll among Twitter users, with 91% voting in favor of the homeless shelter idea proposed by Jeff Bezos. Musk accepted the suggestion, which was seen as a surprising development in the saga. Musk ultimately decided that joining the board was not the best option for him.

images.alt_text: Musk (above) had held discussions with Twitter's directors but the entrepreneur ultimately declined their offer of a board seat, chief executive officer Parag Agrawal tweeted.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with losses on Monday, April 11, 2022, due to concerns over the US Federal Reserve's plan to tighten monetary policy to combat inflation. The Hang Seng Index fell 1.19% to 21,611.17, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.89% to 3,222.77.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng Index slipped 1.19 per cent or 260.84 points to 21,611.17.

site_title: Gold eases as dollar, yields firm; Ukraine woes cap losses
summary: Gold prices eased 0.2% to $1,942.93/oz due to a firmer US dollar and rising Treasury yields, as traders anticipate aggressive interest rate hikes by the US Federal Reserve. However, concerns over Russia's attacks in eastern Ukraine provided some support to the safe-haven metal. The US dollar index remained steady, and the 10-year US yield hit 2.73%, its highest since 2019, increasing the opportunity cost of holding bullion.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 3.08 points or 0.2% to 1,610.37. The market saw 323.3 million lots traded worth RM94.1 million. Despite the gain, losers outnumbered gainers 199 to 191.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Hotel Properties, Keppel Reit
summary: Hotel Properties Ltd sold its entire interest in two properties for £40.8 million (S$72 million), reaping a gain of S$29 million. Keppel Reit's Tan Swee Yiow will assume chairmanship of its manager from June 1, replacing Penny Goh. Hatten Land requested a trading halt pending an announcement.

site_title: DBS Private Bank sees robust growth on multiple fronts
summary: DBS Private Bank achieved robust growth in 2021, with assets under management (AUM) rising 12.7% and net new monies increasing by nearly 40%. Key business areas, including in-house managed products and family office advisory, drove the growth. DBS Private Bank successfully expanded its presence in Asean, Greater China, and Europe, and clients engaged in virtual meetings facilitated by an advanced digital platform. The bank's sustainable investments accounted for 53% of portfolios, surpassing its original target of 50% by 2023.

site_title: Chechen chief Kadyrov says Russian forces will take Kyiv
summary: Ramzan Kadyrov, Chechen chief, stated that Russian forces will launch an offensive on Kyiv, alongside other Ukrainian cities, and will "fully liberate" Luhansk and Donetsk. Kadyrov described himself as Putin's "foot soldier" and assured that no steps will be taken back. This statement comes amid ongoing attacks in eastern Ukraine, with the Kremlin describing its actions as a "special operation" to demilitarize and "denazify" Ukraine.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Monday's open; STI down 0.5%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.5% at Monday's open, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dropping 16.69 points to 3,366.59. The decline came after Wall Street indices ended mixed on Friday. Losers outnumbered gainers 58 to 52, with 28.6 million securities worth S$39.7 million changing hands. The move follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, which is set to be released on Friday.

site_title: Musk polls followers on converting Twitter HQ to homeless shelter; Bezos likes idea
summary: Elon Musk and Jeff Bezos, two of the world's richest people, have proposed converting Twitter's headquarters into a homeless shelter. Musk, who recently became Twitter's largest shareholder, started a poll on the idea, which gained over a million votes with 90% of users supporting it. Bezos, the founder of Amazon, also expressed support for the idea, citing his own company's successful homeless shelter initiative in Seattle. Musk clarified that he was serious about the proposal, and a separate poll was conducted to consider changing Twitter's name to "Twitter Blue".

site_title: Binance gets Abu Dhabi crypto nod as billionaire CEO touts UAE
summary: Binance, the world's largest cryptocurrency exchange, has received in-principle approval from Abu Dhabi Global Market (ADGM) to operate as a broker-dealer in virtual assets. The company still needs to complete the application process. If successful, Binance will offer virtual asset services to the Middle East and North Africa region through a subsidiary, Binance (AD). This marks Binance's expansion in the UAE, following approvals in Bahrain and Dubai. CEO Changpeng 'CZ' Zhao plans to base himself in Dubai, relocating some employees to the city.

site_title: NutryFarm requests trading suspension pending review of ongoing concerns
summary: NutryFarm International has requested a trading suspension on the Singapore Exchange pending a review of ongoing concerns. The company is facing issues related to outstanding debts of S$3.9 million and US$271,849 due to a loan taken from Corpbond IV and Furong Investments in 2017. NutryFarm had previously announced that it will seek legal advice and take appropriate action. The request comes after the company was questioned over the appointment of its executive chairman Wu Yongqiang, who is involved in 18 civil lawsuits in China.

site_title: New Zealand prime minister to visit Singapore, Japan
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern will lead a trade mission to Singapore and Japan, starting later this month. Accompanied by Minister for Trade and Export Growth Damien O'Connor and 13 business leaders, the visit aims to reconnect with key Indo-Pacific economic and security partners. Ardern expressed her commitment to supporting businesses and meeting with counterparts in person. This visit comes amid a period of strengthening economic ties between New Zealand and its Indo-Pacific partners.

site_title: General who ran Syria operation to lead Russia troops in Ukraine
summary: Russia has appointed General Alexander Dvornikov, commander of the Southern Military District, to lead its troops in Ukraine, marking a refocus on the eastern Donbas regions and the Black Sea area. Dvornikov previously led Russian forces in Syria in 2015-2016. The move comes as Russia has largely withdrawn from the north after failing to secure territory around Kyiv. The US and other nations have accused Russian troops of committing war crimes, with US National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan warning that the appointment of Dvornikov does not erase the strategic failure in Ukraine.

site_title: Singapore reopening to put wind in sails of real estate investment
summary: Singapore's reopening is expected to boost property investment, with analysts predicting a 10% increase in property investment volumes and transactions this year. The office market is expected to outperform, driven by rental growth and spillover demand from the residential market. Despite cooling measures and rising interest rates, analysts believe the growth in rents could outstrip higher funding costs. Investment sales are projected to reach S$28-30 billion, with a focus on commercial assets and the CBD Incentive Scheme. The residential market is also expected to see increased activity, with a focus on GLS sites and underperforming properties.

site_title: UK travel disruption drags on, set to impact Easter holiday
summary: UK travel disruptions continued on Sunday, with British Airways cancelling 7% of flights and delaying 9%, while EasyJet cancelled 40 flights due to staff shortages. FlightAware data shows over 20% of EasyJet flights are delayed. Immigration Services Union staff are being deployed to Heathrow airport to help mitigate queues, with officials warning of significant numbers of travellers expected over Easter. Airlines are scrambling to add staff and meet passenger demands, with the UK Civil Aviation Authority urging airlines to manage staff shortages and minimize disruption.

site_title: Maker of US$777,000 flying motorbike prepares for IPO in Japan
summary: ALI Technologies, a Tokyo-based startup, is preparing for an initial public offering (IPO) in Japan, valuing its flying motorbike, the Xturismo Limited, at over $1 billion. Founded by Shuhei Komatsu, the bike can reach speeds of 80kmh and travel up to 40 minutes on a charge. With investments from Japanese firms and a strong interest from Middle Eastern nations, ALI aims to revolutionize air mobility, enabling people to travel in difficult terrain and across bodies of water. The company's IPO will be the first of its kind in Japan, with discussions ongoing with the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

site_title: Startups transforming pleasure boating draw investor interest
summary: Arc Boat, a startup, has gained investor interest with its electrified pleasure boats. The company's first design, the Arc One, features a 200 kWh battery, increasing its capacity by 10% compared to a Tesla Model Y. The vessel's price is $300,000, roughly 50% more than comparable gas-powered vessels. Arc plans to start shipping the limited edition e-boat this summer, with a production capacity of 1 unit per day. The company faces a challenge in scaling production to meet demand, but its innovative approach has drawn attention from investors.

site_title: Bosses burn out too; leaders need to be well to lead well
summary: Leaders are not immune to burnout, a growing concern in the wake of the pandemic. According to a report, 92% of workers in Singapore experience burnout, with 36% reporting high or extreme levels. CEOs and leaders are expected to be resilient, but chronic workplace stress and a lack of self-care can lead to burnout. Experts emphasize the need for leaders to prioritize their own mental wellbeing to lead effectively. Organizations like WorkWell Leaders are working to create a culture of mental wellbeing, encouraging leaders to share their struggles and prioritize self-care.

site_title: Temasek-backed trucking startup G7 weighs US$500m Hong Kong IPO: sources
summary: G7, a Temasek-backed logistics company, is considering a Hong Kong IPO worth around US$500 million. The startup, founded in 2010, uses AI and IoT technology to manage road freight and logistics services. It has raised US$200 million in funding from investors including Trustbridge Partners and CS Capital. G7 has also formed partnerships with companies such as GLP and Nio to focus on developing smart heavy-duty trucks. The company's IPO plans are ongoing and details may change, but a potential listing is expected as soon as this year.

site_title: GoTo rises 14.8% on IDX debut, draws record number of investors
summary: GoTo Group, an Indonesian tech giant, made its debut on the Indonesia Stock Exchange (IDX) with a 14.8% rise to 388 rupiah, valuing the company at $31.6 billion. The IPO drew a record 300,000 investors, marking another major tech IPO in South-east Asia. Trading ended the day at 382 rupiah, up 13%. This listing benefits from Indonesia's new regulations allowing dual class shares.

site_title: Ukraine says 1,200 bodies found near Kyiv as east braces for onslaught
summary: Ukraine has found over 1,200 bodies in the Kyiv region, amid allegations of atrocities committed during Russian occupation. Heavy bombardments continue to claim lives, with 2 deaths reported in northeast Kharkiv and 10 civilians killed in southeast of the city. The death toll has risen in the east, where a missile strike on a railway station killed 57 people. Residents are fleeing in their thousands as Ukraine prepares for battles against Moscow's forces. The UN has recorded 4,232 civilian casualties, with 1,793 killed and 2,439 injured.

site_title: Amazon's drone delivery programme is hit by crashes and safety concerns
summary: Amazon's drone delivery program has faced significant setbacks, including crashes and safety concerns, despite spending over $2 billion and assembling a team of over 1,000 people. A serious crash in June prompted federal regulators to question the drone's airworthiness, and the company has been criticized for prioritizing speed over safety. Amazon plans to ramp up testing in the coming months, but experts say it will be years before the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) approves commercial drone deliveries. The company's founder, Jeff Bezos, had initially pledged to launch drone deliveries within 5 years, but the timeline has been repeatedly delayed.

site_title: War to slash Ukraine's GDP output by over 45%, World Bank forecasts
summary: The World Bank forecasts Ukraine's GDP output will contract by 45.1% in 2022 due to Russia's invasion, which has shuttered businesses, slashed exports, and disrupted economic activity. Russia's GDP is also expected to fall 11.2% due to financial sanctions. The Eastern Europe region, including Ukraine, Belarus, and Moldova, is forecast to show a 30.7% GDP contraction. The World Bank has already provided over $923 million in loans and grants to Ukraine, with a further support package of over $2 billion in preparation.

site_title: Wild ride by US-listed China stocks: Reasons go beyond delisting concerns
summary: China has proposed revisions to its offshore listing rules, aiming to address US concerns over auditing and delisting Chinese companies. The move may help alleviate volatility in US-listed Chinese stocks, but it's unclear if it will address underlying issues such as weak operational performance and rising interest rates. The Holding Foreign Companies Accountable Act, which requires foreign issuers to submit documentation, is also a factor in the market's uncertainty. Investors should exercise caution, as the market's recent turmoil may not be solely due to delisting concerns.

site_title: France's Macron and Le Pen head for cliffhanger Apr 24 election runoff
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron and far-right challenger Marine Le Pen qualified for the presidential election runoff on April 24, with Macron leading in the first round by a narrow margin. Macron garnered 27.41% of the votes, while Le Pen secured 24.9%. The election is expected to be a tight contest, with some polls predicting a 1% margin between the two candidates. Macron has urged voters to rally behind him to stop the far-right from ruling the European Union, while Le Pen has campaigned on cost-of-living issues and promises to protect the weak and unite the nation.

site_title: Low-fee funds offer head start in a low-returns world
summary: Investors face significant challenges in 2022, with inflation and rising interest rates posing risks to fixed income and equity portfolios. As of April 6, both fixed income and equity funds are negative, with global equity funds down 7% and fixed income down 6%. Low-fee funds are offering a head start in a low-returns world, providing a potential solution for older investors who rely on fixed income for income. With interest rates expected to continue rising, investors are advised to diversify their portfolios and consider low-cost options to mitigate losses.

site_title: The surprising joy and liberation of knowing your career limits
summary: A career's natural progression is not a linear climb, but rather a hill with a plateau, where success and productivity peak then decline. Research suggests that the average person's career success increases for the first 20 years, then wanes. Singapore's manpower ministry statistics show that prime earning years are between 40-44, and median income decreases thereafter. Acknowledging career limits can lead to better decisions, such as pursuing growth over promotions or exploring new opportunities. It's essential to distinguish between employer-defined success and personal goals, and to recognize that worth extends beyond career achievements.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit targets Asia-Pac data centre hubs
summary: Keppel DC Reit, a data centre investor, is targeting Asia-Pacific markets, including Singapore, South Korea, Japan, mainland China, and Australia. The company plans to acquire more assets after a successful acquisition spree last year, with deal sizes above $100 million considered "nice" and "needle-moving". CEO Anthea Lee stated that larger deals would be more impactful.

site_title: Oil prices edge lower in early trading
summary: Oil prices dropped in early Asian trading, falling 38 US cents to $102.40 a barrel for Brent crude and $0.16 to $98.18 a barrel for US crude. This marks the second straight weekly decline, following announcements from world consumers to release crude from strategic stocks and continued Chinese lockdowns, which affect the world's biggest oil importer.

site_title: BT Group's new London HQ shows hybrid work is here to stay
summary: BT Group's new London HQ showcases hybrid work's future, as the company prepares to shut hundreds of offices and move staff to 30 high-tech buildings by 2025. A recent poll found 94% of businesses plan to make physical changes to support post-pandemic needs. The 3,500-capacity tower will open in April, offering a glimpse into the evolving office landscape. Hybrid working seems to be here to stay, with BT's new HQ reflecting this shift towards flexible work arrangements.

site_title: World needs new rules for global trade: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for new rules in global trade, citing the changing balance of the world economy since the IMF and World Bank's establishment in 1944. The current system, with the US and Europe holding more influence, may not be suitable for a more multipolar world. Lee noted that China's growing economic power and its increasing influence in international institutions could lead to a decoupling of the US and China, potentially destabilizing the global economy. He advocated for a more inclusive and connected world, with new rules to govern international trade and cooperation.

site_title: Data centre S-Reits committed to sustainable growth
summary: Singapore's data centre industry has experienced significant growth, driven by the need for cloud capacity to support work-from-home arrangements. Reits such as Keppel DC Reit and Digital Core Reit have committed to sustainable growth, aiming to halve Scope 1 and Scope 2 emissions by 2030 and introduce renewable energy to at least 50% of their assets. These Reits have also reported high portfolio occupancy rates and distribution per unit growth, highlighting their potential for long-term sustainability and profitability.

site_title: The way of the DAO could be the future of work
summary: A decentralized autonomous organization (DAO) may be the future of work, offering a decentralized structure to attract followers, organize resources, and incentivize talent. Since the infamous "The DAO" in 2016, the ecosystem has grown, with over 4,800 DAOs managing $12.6 billion in treasuries and 1.8 million governance token holders. Despite initial doubts, DAOs have shown positive trends in online community culture, efficient decision-making, and talent coordination. Tools like governance platforms and reputation-building systems facilitate community involvement and incentivization. As the younger generation favors community over institution, DAOs may become a formidable force to compete with conventional enterprises for talent.

site_title: HPL to book S$29m gain from sale of London hotel interests
summary: HPL sells its entire interest in HOL and Maple Olympia Propco 4 for £40.8 million (S$72 million), reaping a gain of S$29 million. The transaction doesn't affect the group's net tangible assets for the year ended December 2021. HPL shares rose 0.3% to S$3.57, driven by a cum dividend basis. The sale is made via HOPL, which owns HPL (Olympia) and Maple, with Ong Beng Seng holding a 20% deemed interest in HOPL.

site_title: What it takes to succeed as a solopreneur
summary: A record number of professionals in Singapore are becoming solopreneurs, with 228,200 individuals operating their own businesses or trades without employing paid employees as of June 2020, representing 6.6% of employed residents. According to Brenda, one of the top executive coaches in the world, six key factors are necessary for success as a solopreneur: saving financially, shining with expertise, selling oneself, establishing systems, seeking support, and prioritizing self-care. By focusing on these six "S's," solopreneurs can overcome the challenges of solo entrepreneurship and achieve success.

site_title: Football: Man City, Liverpool share spoils in pulsating title clash
summary: Manchester City and Liverpool ended in a 2-2 draw, with Kevin De Bruyne opening the scoring for City in the 5th minute, but Diogo Jota equalized 8 minutes later. Gabriel Jesus restored City's lead in the 36th minute, only for Liverpool to level again through Sadio Mane 46 seconds after the restart. City regained control of the midfield in the second half but were unable to capitalize on chances, with a point maintaining their 1-point lead over Liverpool in the Premier League standings.

images.alt_text: Manchester City remained 1 point clear of Liverpool at the top of the Premier League standings after the highly-anticipated clash of the giants ended in a pulsating 2-2 draw at the Etihad Stadium on Sunday.

site_title: Energy 2050: a quick recap
summary: The Energy 2050 Committee, commissioned by Singapore's Energy Market Authority, recommends that the nation aim for net-zero emissions by 2050 while maintaining energy security and affordability. The report emphasizes the need for decarbonization efforts across the power sector value chain, and Singapore is expected to rely on imported electricity and low-carbon hydrogen. The committee sees opportunities for economic growth in the transition to a net-zero carbon world, but warns that the journey will be fast and turbulent due to the urgent need to address irreversible climate effects.

site_title: US dollar posts largest weekly gain in a month on hawkish Fed messages
summary: The US dollar index surged to a 100 for the first time in nearly 2 years, posting its largest weekly gain in a month, driven by hawkish Federal Reserve messages and concerns over inflation. The dollar rose against a basket of 6 currencies, particularly the euro, which hit a 1-month low. The euro has fallen in 7 straight sessions amid investor concerns about war in Ukraine and a French presidential election. The dollar also rose against the Japanese yen, its highest in over a week, as the Bank of Japan intervenes in the bond market.

site_title: Who will be the winners and losers in Singapore's energy transition?
summary: Singapore's power sector is set to undergo significant changes as the country navigates a global energy transition. The sector accounts for nearly 40% of the country's total carbon emissions and will be impacted by the shift to low-carbon energy sources. Opportunities and risks abound, with sectors like energy efficiency, renewable energy, and smart technologies expected to benefit. Businesses must adapt by investing in innovative technologies, training staff, and developing new business models to stay competitive. The government is also exploring new growth sectors, including geothermal, biomethane, and nuclear fusion technologies, to position Singapore as a low-carbon hub.

site_title: Who watches the watchers?
summary: A US survey of C-suite executives by PwC and The Conference Board found that boards in Singapore can learn from their findings. Executives praised the boards' understanding of strategy, risks, and shareholder base, but rated their directors' overall performance as "fair" with only 10% indicating "excellent". The majority (90%) believe at least one director should be replaced, citing concerns about long-tenured directors impeding diversity and performance. The survey highlights the need for boards to develop expertise in emerging trends and regulatory changes, particularly in areas like ESG and technology.

site_title: China's pick for next HK chief vows to protect hub status
summary: Hong Kong's leading candidate, John Lee, has pledged to maintain the city's international competitiveness and protect its status as a hub, vowing to strengthen connectivity and uphold values of inclusion and openness. Lee, backed by China, has won Beijing's sole backing for the race, with the next chief executive set to take office on July 1. Concerns have been raised that Beijing plans to prioritize tightening security over rebuilding the city's status as an international financial hub.

site_title: Sharif set to become next Pakistan PM after parliament ousts Khan
summary: Pakistan's Prime Minister Imran Khan was ousted after a no-confidence vote, marking the first time a Pakistani premier has lost office via a vote of no-confidence. Centrist leader Shehbaz Sharif will become the new prime minister, forming a cabinet with the Pakistan Muslim League-N and Pakistan Peoples Party. Khan's exit comes amid rising militancy, inflation, and debt issues. Sharif vowed to put a "balm on the wounds" of the nation, while Khan claims he was the victim of a "regime change" conspiracy.

site_title: S-Reits punching above their weight in the global arena
summary: Singapore Real Estate Investment Trusts (Reits) have shown resilience in the global market, despite rising interest rates. The iEdge S-Reit Index gained 1.3% year-to-date, outperforming the -4.9% average for Global Reits and -4.6% for the S&P 500. S-Reits' diversification in assets and geography, as well as their ability to weather rate hikes, contribute to their resilience. The sector is expected to continue its recovery trajectory as Singapore reopens, with retail Reits and office assets poised for growth.

site_title: Russian bank VTB loses control over European unit
summary: Russia's VTB bank has lost control over its European subsidiary VTB Bank SE after Germany's banking regulator, BaFin, stripped it of voting rights due to EU sanctions over the war in Ukraine. The bank can no longer access its subsidiary's financial assets, but its operations remain unchanged, and clients can still access their deposits. This move follows US sanctions and VTB's exclusion from the Swift banking system. Four of its board members have recently resigned, and the company has stopped taking on new customers since early March.

site_title: AUDUSD in short corrective phase within broader uptrend
summary: The AUDUSD currency pair is in a short corrective phase within a broader uptrend, according to analysts. Despite a recent pullback, the pair remains bullish due to a rising channel and a bull flag formation. A Golden Cross, where the 50-day EMA crosses above the 200 EMA, also confirms the trend reversal. Momentum indicators, such as the RSI and MACD, show bullish momentum. The pair is expected to retest support levels before potentially continuing its upward trajectory.

site_title: Covid cases continue to rise in Shanghai
summary: Covid-19 cases continue to rise in Shanghai, with nearly 25,000 locally transmitted infections reported on Sunday, April 10. The city's lockdown has sharply squeezed food and essential supplies, with supermarkets shut and couriers locked in. Residents are expressing anxiety that other cities may soon be in the same situation, with concern spreading that China's "zero tolerance" policy may lead to more widespread lockdowns. The city is a test bed for China's elimination strategy, which aims to test, trace, and centrally quarantine all Covid-positive people.

site_title: BT Mark to Market: Mapletree sets new standard for REIT sponsors (Ep 18)
summary: Mapletree Investments, the sponsor of Mapletree Commercial Trust and Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust, has set a new standard for REIT sponsors by saving their proposed merger. Despite initial concerns, the combination of the two Reits is seen as not a merger but rather a strategic partnership. This move may raise investor expectations for other REIT sponsors, leading to higher investor scrutiny. Meanwhile, MNACT unitholders are advised to hold on to their units, and investors may view MCT more positively due to the sponsor's support.

site_title: Australian PM seeks second 'miracle' win in May 21 polls
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison has announced the national election for May 21, despite trailing the opposition Labor Party in opinion polling. Morrison hopes to replicate his 2019 "miracle" win, while Labor leader Anthony Albanese focuses on lifting wage growth and easing cost-of-living pressures. The election comes after a 6-week campaign period, with Morrison's government facing criticism over supply shortages and mismanaging the response to flooding. Morrison will frame the vote around the country's strong economic growth and national defence, while Labor targets his handling of the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: After Covid blues, French saxophone maker hits the right note
summary: French saxophone maker Selmer celebrates its 100th birthday with a surge in sales, driven by international demand, particularly in Asia and the US. Founded by Henri Selmer in 1885, the company has been favored by jazz legends such as John Coltrane and Sonny Rollins. Despite facing recruitment difficulties and absenteeism issues due to Covid-19, Selmer aims to expand further in Asia and the US, with a focus on the Chinese market through its new, more affordable Axos series.

site_title: Hotel Properties to book S$29m gain from disposal of stake in 2 JV companies
summary: Hotel Properties Ltd has agreed to sell its 100% stake in two joint venture companies, HPL (Olympia) and Maple Olympia Propco 4 S.à.r.l, for £40.8 million (S$72.4 million). The sale is expected to result in a gain of approximately S$29 million for the group. The transaction, which will be satisfied in cash, does not impact the net tangible asset value per share of Hotel Properties.

site_title: Early signs of cooling housing market seen in some US cities: Redfin
summary: US housing market shows early signs of cooling, with Google searches for homes for sale dropping in cities like Baltimore, Boston, San Francisco, and Los Angeles. Tours of homes for sale in California decreased by 21% and Redfin agents reported fewer requests for homebuying help in cities like San Francisco and Los Angeles. Average interest rates on 30-year-fixed mortgages rose to 4.9%, a 3-year high, amid efforts to curb inflation. Despite this, home prices in cities like Los Angeles remain high, with the average home sold for 5% over its asking price.

site_title: Russian bank VTB loses control over European subsidiary
summary: Germany's banking regulator, BaFin, has stripped Russia's VTB of control over its European subsidiary, VTB Bank SE, due to sanctions over the war in Ukraine. VTB can no longer access its subsidiary's financial assets and its board cannot follow directives from the Russian group. The European entity's activities can continue, but its operations remain unchanged, and clients can still access their deposits. This decision follows VTB's placement on the EU sanctions list and its exclusion from the Swift banking system.

site_title: Thai teen Ratchanon breaks record with win at inaugural Asian Mixed Cup
summary: Thailand's 15-year-old golf sensation Ratchanon Chantananuwat broke a record by winning the inaugural Asian Mixed Cup, becoming the youngest-ever winner of a major Tour. He secured a birdie on the final day to finish 20 under par, beating 19-year-old Kim Joo-hyung by one shot. Ratchanon, who balanced homework with competitions, is the fifth amateur to win on the Asian Tour and the youngest player to win a major tournament, beating Japan's Ryo Ishikawa's 2007 record.

site_title: Renewables, tech could drive Asia IPOs in 2022
summary: Renewable energy and technology sectors are expected to drive Asian initial public offerings (IPOs) in 2022, despite a slow start to the year. Companies in these sectors, such as solar and wind power, are likely to raise capital in countries like Malaysia, Thailand, and Vietnam, with many aiming to raise $200-300 million. Interest in electric vehicles and hydrogen energy is also on the rise, with investors seeking "good and solid stories" in the hydrogen sector. Experts predict growing demand for IPOs in these areas, driven by increasing focus on climate and environmental initiatives.

site_title: Shanghai Covid cases keep rising, food supply problems persist
summary: Shanghai, China reported nearly 25,000 locally transmitted Covid-19 infections on April 10, with 1,006 symptomatic cases and 23,937 asymptomatic. The city, under China's "zero tolerance" policy, remains locked down, affecting food and basic supplies. Residents struggle with security personnel and medical staff, while e-commerce giants and food delivery services seek to ease delivery bottlenecks. Similar lockdowns are feared in other cities, with some already experiencing restrictions, amid concerns about China's worst Covid outbreak since 2019.

site_title: Market volatility a drag on IPOs in Q1; no clarity on horizon
summary: Market volatility has hindered initial public offerings (IPOs) in South-east Asia and globally, with total proceeds from region's IPOs slowing and falling 51% year-on-year in Q1 2022. Asia-Pacific accounted for 78% of global IPO proceeds, with 188 IPOs, but South-east Asian IPOs showed a 32% uptick in listings but 57% decline in proceeds. Experts warn that market volatility, geopolitical tensions, and valuation expectations will continue to impact IPO activity, with Q2 expected to be slow and Q3 potentially seeing a surge in IPOs.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary:
The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for the week ending April 8, 2022, reveals a sluggish market with limited fresh cargo support. The Baltic Dry Index and timecharter average started the week near 1,800 points and $15,000 but remained in negative territory until a marginal improvement on Friday. The market settled at 1,444 points and $11,979, the lowest value since mid-February.

Key indicators, such as the C3 Brazil to Qingdao trade, declined over a dollar, while the C5 West Australia to Qingdao run climbed back to $9.236 on Friday. Panamax rates continued to come under pressure, with South America transatlantic trips fixed on tonnage open Continent/Mediterranean along with some ballaster tonnage.

The Ultramax/Supramax market saw limited activity, with demand from China easing and prompt tonnage availability growing in key areas. Handysize activity was also declining, with most regions seeing falling levels due to various factors.

VLCC rates improved, with the 270,000mt Middle East Gulf/China route rates climbing 9.5 points to close to WS53.5. Suezmax rates recovered dramatically, with the 135,000mt Novorossiysk/Augusta route rocketing 121 points to WS305. Aframax rates rose rapidly, with the 80,000mt Ceyhan/Mediterranean market pushing through the WS200 mark.

site_title: Hong Kong to require rapid Covid tests for students as school resumes
summary: Hong Kong will require all school students to take regular rapid antigen tests after in-person classes resume on April 19 for senior primary school students and May 3 for junior and secondary students. The tests will help authorities get a better picture of overall infections at schools, allowing for more flexible suspension policies. Officials are still ironing out details, but the goal is to gradually relax Covid control measures as the city recovers from its worst outbreak since the pandemic began.

site_title: Hong Kong chief candidate John Lee tops nomination threshold
summary: Hong Kong's chief executive candidate John Lee has secured over 200 nominations, surpassing the required threshold, just a day after launching his campaign. Lee, the city's former chief secretary, has received backing from tycoons and Beijing, but concerns remain about China's potential prioritization of security over rebuilding Hong Kong's international financial hub status. The next chief executive will be selected by approximately 1,500 people on May 8, with the position currently held by Carrie Lam set to become vacant on July 1, marking the halfway point in China's 50-year pledge to preserve Hong Kong's liberal systems.

site_title: Fiji overpower New Zealand to win Singapore Rugby Sevens
summary: Fiji won the Singapore Rugby Sevens, defeating New Zealand 28-17 to claim the World Rugby Sevens Series crown. Fiji dominated the match, leading 21-0 at halftime, and never looked back despite New Zealand's late tries. Fiji's victory marked their first Series title since 2020 and their third in Singapore, following their previous wins in 2006 and 2018. The Pacific island side finished the series with a perfect record, ending New Zealand's perfect run.

images.alt_text: Fiji produced a powerful performance to see off New Zealand 28-17 on Sunday (Apr 10) and clinch the World Rugby Sevens Series crown in Singapore.

site_title: Glass Lewis recommends vote against Goldman Sachs' one-off executive bonuses
summary: Glass Lewis recommends shareholders of Goldman Sachs to vote against one-off executive bonuses for the CEO and COO, citing concerns over their "quantum and structural issues." The proposal will be put to an advisory vote at the bank's annual general meeting on April 28.

site_title: Rising petrol prices fuel uncertainty at oil giant Petrobras
summary: Brazil's state-run oil company Petrobras is in crisis after President Jair Bolsonaro fired CEO Joaquim Silva e Luna, citing unaffordable fuel prices. The move has been widely seen as a response to rising inflation and fuel costs, which Bolsonaro is blamed for by voters. The company's future depends on the outcome of October's elections, with leftist former president Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, a rival of Bolsonaro, vowing to "Brazilianize the fuel price." The firing of Silva e Luna is seen as a sacrificial move to satisfy Bolsonaro's electorate, with the company facing pressure to maintain fuel prices amid international market fluctuations.

site_title: Sharif set to become next Pakistan PM after parliament ousts Khan
summary: Pakistan's parliament voted no-confidence in Prime Minister Imran Khan, dismissing him after a long tenure marked by corruption allegations and economic struggles. Centrist leader Shehbaz Sharif, brother of former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, is set to become the new premier. Sharif will form a cabinet from the Pakistan Muslim League-N and Pakistan Peoples Party, while also including the Jamiatul Ulema-e-Islam-F group. The next election must be held by October 2023, and relations between the PML-N and PPP are expected to fray. Khan has vowed to tap into anti-US sentiment and create problems for the new government.

site_title: Former Citigroup executives seek US$100m for crypto hedge funds
summary: A trio of former Citigroup executives, Alex Kriete, Greg Girasole, and Frank Cavallo, have formed Motus Capital Management to manage $100 million in actively managed hedge funds focused on cryptocurrencies. They will invest their own wealth, avoiding self-custody and limiting assets with exchanges. The funds will target smaller market capitalization tokens, aiming to provide growth and income opportunities for high-net-worth individuals. This is part of a growing trend of ex-Citigroup executives entering the cryptocurrency sector.

site_title: Perception that US is on the wane as the East rises likely to be proven wrong, says PM Lee
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong disagrees with the notion that the US is declining as the East rises, stating that the US still has a bright future despite facing challenges. He notes that the US is one of the most advanced, vibrant, and dynamic economies and societies in the world, with the ability to attract talent and generate new ideas. However, Lee acknowledges that the US must adapt to a shifting global balance, particularly with regards to its relationship with China, which he believes is driven by a sense of mission to become a modern, great nation.

images.alt_text: PM Lee says the question is whether the Pacific region is big enough for countries to be friends with both the US and China, or whether it is big enough to be split down the middle.

site_title: Apple buys UE BizHub Central in Ang Mo Kio for S$55m
summary: Apple has acquired UE BizHub Central in Ang Mo Kio, Singapore for S$55 million from United Engineers, part of Yanlord Land Group. The 4-storey, 7-storey facility has a gross floor area of about 388,000 sq ft. The acquisition allows Apple to expand its presence in Singapore, taking over the remaining space in UE BizHub Central, which was previously occupied by United Engineers.
