site_title: Parliament backs White Paper to improve equality, opportunities for Singapore women after 9.5-hour debate
summary: The Singapore Parliament has unanimously passed a 10-year roadmap to improve equality and opportunities for women, known as the White Paper on Singapore Women's Development. The plan, which was endorsed after a 9.5-hour debate, aims to promote flexible work arrangements, enhance support for parents and caregivers, and change mindsets. Key proposals include mandatory flexible work arrangements, mandatory family care leave, and a shared parental leave scheme. The government also aims to improve digital safety and address family violence. The White Paper's passage marks a significant step towards creating a more inclusive and equitable society in Singapore.

site_title: US imposes sanctions on Russian darknet market and crypto exchange
summary: The US Treasury Department imposed sanctions on Hydra, a prominent Russia-based darknet market site, and Garantex, a cryptocurrency exchange, citing their alleged operation primarily out of Moscow and St. Petersburg. The sanctions, published on April 5, 2022, aim to deter criminals from using these platforms. According to blockchain researchers, approximately 86% of illicit bitcoin received by Russian crypto exchanges in 2019 came from Hydra, described as the world's largest and most prominent darknet market by the Treasury Department.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 1.25% lower on April 6, 2022, following Wall Street's losses due to the Federal Reserve's potential monetary policy tightening. The Hang Seng Index fell to 22,220.21, while the Shanghai Composite Index lost 0.40% to 3,269.43. Mainland Chinese markets were closed on Monday and Tuesday.

site_title: Asia: Stocks skid, bond yields up after hawkish Fed comments
summary: Asian share markets declined on April 6, 2022, amid concerns over the US Federal Reserve's aggressive monetary tightening to combat inflation. US Treasury yields reached multi-year highs, with the Nikkei shedding nearly 2% and South Korean shares falling 0.9%. The comments from Fed Governor Lael Brainard sparked investors to reassess their positions, leading to a downturn in Asian markets.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong's Hang Seng index was down 1.3 per cent, moving away from a 1-month high hit on Monday.

site_title: Short video app born after India's TikTok ban gets US$805m
summary: Indian social content startup VerSe Innovation, the maker of short video app Josh, has received $805 million in funding, its largest venture capital round this year. The funding, led by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board, values the company at $5 billion. Josh has 150 million monthly active users and is billed as the "Instagram for Bharat." The company plans to use the capital to boost user engagement and retention through artificial intelligence and machine learning capabilities. VerSe aims to become profitable within 2-3 years.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened flat on Wednesday, edging up 0.3 points to 1,597.1. Volume reached 150.7 million lots worth RM66.4 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 202 to 99.

site_title: US sanctions on Singapore-based Alexsong a warning to all firms to stay compliant
summary: The US has designated Singapore-based electronics wholesaler Alexsong Pte Ltd as a Specially Designated National (SDN) due to its involvement in providing western technology to Russia's defense sector. The designation is part of a broader US crackdown on sanctions evasion networks and technology companies enabling Russia's war on Ukraine. The US Department of the Treasury's Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) imposed fresh sanctions on 21 entities and 13 people, emphasizing the importance of robust sanctions compliance policies for businesses dealing with international trade.

site_title: India's EV sales seen doubling led by battery-powered scooters
summary: India's electric vehicle (EV) sales are expected to almost double in the current fiscal year, driven by battery-powered scooters and rickshaws, reaching 800,000 units by March 2023. This marks a significant increase from 429,217 units in the previous period. However, India's adoption of EVs lags behind other countries, with only 53% of new automobile sales expected to be electric by 2040, compared to 77% in China. Expensive prices, limited options, and inadequate charging stations are major barriers to adoption.

site_title: China holiday travel slumps after Covid outbreaks: state media
summary: China's 3-day Tomb Sweeping Festival holiday saw a nearly 63% decline in journeys taken, reaching an estimated 53.8 million, down from 159.3 million in 2021 and 58.5 million in 2020. Air travel was severely impacted, with a 87% drop in flights. The decline is attributed to strict testing requirements and lockdowns in 23 cities due to the Omicron variant. Analysts warn that the economic cost of containing Covid-19 is likely to be high, particularly for the tourism sector.

site_title: 'The Northman' aims to tell Viking tale with accuracy and action
summary: Filmmaker Robert Eggers' new epic, "The Northman," is a star-studded revenge tale set in 895 Viking culture, blending action and accuracy. The film stars Alexander Skarsgard as Amleth, who seeks to avenge his father's murder and rescue his mother, following a brutal killing by his uncle and mother. With meticulous planning and attention to detail, the film's violent action scenes and long takes showcase a truthful portrayal of Viking culture and mythology. The movie, released in April, is Eggers' most accurate Viking film yet, made in collaboration with historians and archaeologists.

site_title: Canada to force Google, Facebook to pay news publishers
summary: Canada plans to introduce the Online News Act, a bill that would force tech companies like Google and Facebook to pay local news publishers for content through privately-negotiated deals. The law aims to address the market imbalance as online advertising revenue has drained away to Silicon Valley's digital giants. The Canadian effort follows Australian legislation and US lawmakers' proposals, and is designed to help a struggling Canadian media sector that saw 450 outlets close between 2008 and 2021.

site_title: Crypto mania, financial contagion, and the 'Goldilocks zone'
summary: Crypto mania has taken hold globally, with 6% of US respondents and 16-21% of respondents in Peru, Turkey, the Philippines, and Vietnam investing in cryptocurrencies in the past year. El Salvador has made bitcoin legal tender, despite warnings from the International Monetary Fund. The article warns against "first-version trap" of crypto investments and unbridled speculation, cautioning investors to be aware of financial contagion and animal spirits.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on April 6, 2022, extending US falls as investors awaited US Federal Reserve meeting minutes. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.94% and the Topix index 0.78%. This follows the US market's recent gains, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: FDA pulls authorisation for GSK-Vir's Covid therapy as BA.2 cases rise
summary: The US FDA has withdrawn authorization for GlaxoSmithKline and Vir Biotechnology's antibody therapy, sotrovimab, as a Covid-19 treatment due to its limited effectiveness against the dominant BA.2 sub-variant. Shares in Vir Biotechnology dropped 11.5% after the move. Despite the FDA's decision, the companies plan to submit data for a higher dose of sotrovimab and seek full approval in the second half of the year. Vir Biotechnology still expects $1.1 billion in collaboration revenue and will conduct late-stage trials to assess the drug's effectiveness in immunocompromised patients.

site_title: G-20 wrestles with response if Putin shows up at Bali summit
summary: The G-20 summit, set to take place in Bali, Indonesia in November, is facing uncertainty due to Russia's potential attendance, led by President Vladimir Putin. Officials are exploring scenarios where Putin may be excluded or condemned, with some considering a lower-level delegation or no formal communique. The summit's host, Indonesia, is seeking to remain impartial, but the US and other G-7 nations have imposed sanctions on Russia, making it difficult for them to attend without criticizing Putin. The summit's format and tone are still unclear, with some fearing it could end without a joint statement.

images.alt_text: Russia's war in Ukraine is looming large over a Group of 20 (G-20) summit that's still 7 months off, with officials frantically preparing in case President Vladimir Putin decides to turn up.

site_title: CapitaLand Investment to issue S$400m worth of notes due 2027 at 3.33%
summary: CapitaLand Investment plans to issue S$400 million worth of senior notes at a 3.33% fixed rate due in 2027. The notes were oversubscribed by 80 accounts, with an order book of S$780 million. The funds raised will be used to refinance existing borrowings and finance investments. DBS, HSBC, OCBC Bank, and UOB have been appointed as joint lead managers and bookrunners for the issue. The company's shares ended lower by 1.71% after the announcement.

site_title: World's biggest solar firm sees profits hurt by power hike
summary: Longi Green Energy Technology, the world's largest solar company, reported its profits will be cut by higher power costs in China. Yunnan province, a key manufacturing hub, cancelled preferential electricity prices, increasing costs by 500 million yuan (S$106.8 million) and less than a 3.5% impact on after-tax profits. The decision risks changing Longi's expansion plans in the province. Despite higher power costs, solar installations in China tripled in January and February, and the company expects savings from making larger and thinner wafers.

images.alt_text: Longi Green Energy Technology, the world s largest solar company, said its profits will be cut by higher power costs at one of its key manufacturing hubs in China.

site_title: Tencent-backed UK startup achieves fusion breakthrough
summary: A UK startup backed by Tencent Holdings achieved a breakthrough in fusion energy, using a novel "Big Friendly Gun" approach to generate clean nuclear fuel. First Light Fusion's method could slash the cost of fusion energy by providing cheap fuel, releasing enough energy to power a UK home for 2 years per target. The company's approach is 1,000 times cheaper than traditional methods, and UK regulators have confirmed the achievement, which could make fusion energy a commercially viable option.

site_title: US: Wall Street, tech shares stumble on fears of aggressive Fed
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday, with the Nasdaq posting its largest daily percentage drop in about a month, as Federal Reserve Governor Lael Brainard expressed concerns about aggressive interest rate increases to control inflation. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 280.7 points, and the S&P 500 fell 57.52 points, with tech and growth stocks declining 2.2% and 2.4%, respectively. The Fed's comments have raised concerns about a recession and the potential for a "soft landing."

site_title: Oxley issues third tranche of notes due 2024 at 6.9%
summary: Oxley Holdings has issued S$50 million worth of notes with a 6.9% fixed interest rate due in July 2024, as part of its US$1 billion guaranteed euro medium term note programme. This is the third tranche, consolidated with the first and second tranches issued last year.

site_title: Twitter to start testing long-awaited edit feature in coming months
summary: Twitter will begin testing its long-awaited edit feature in the coming months, with the feature being the most requested for many years. The edit feature will initially be tested within Twitter Blue Labs, the company's premium subscription service, to "learn what works, what doesn't, and what's possible." The feature's launch is expected to take time, with Jay Sullivan citing concerns about misuse without proper controls and transparency. The announcement comes as Elon Musk joins Twitter's board, sparking a broader change in direction for the company.

site_title: UK, US, Australia agree to work on hypersonics under defence pact
summary: Britain, the US, and Australia agreed to cooperate on hypersonic weapons and electronic warfare capabilities as part of the new Aukus defence alliance. The three countries will work together on research and development in the area to expand their options, despite the US not joining an existing hypersonic programme. This move comes amid concerns about European security following Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The Aukus leaders also reaffirmed their commitment to a "free and open Indo-Pacific" and a "free and open international system that respects human rights and the rule of law".

site_title: ADB pares S-E Asia growth outlook on Omicron spread, warns of further risk from China outbreaks
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has pared its full-year GDP forecast for South-East Asia to 4.9% due to the spread of the Omicron variant in early 2022, citing concerns over ongoing Covid-19 outbreaks in China. The ADB forecasts growth to pick up to 5.2% in 2023, with the region's overall economy expected to grow 5.2% in 2022 and 5.3% in 2023. The downgrade mainly affects Thailand, where the forecast was cut from 4% to 3% due to the pandemic's impact on the tourism-reliant economy.

site_title: Hatten Land's new partnership starts operations ahead of schedule
summary: Hatten Land's new partner has delivered 40 of 50 Bitmain Antminer S19J Pro crypto mining rigs ahead of schedule, with all machines now operating smoothly. The partnership, which includes an option to deliver an additional 500 rigs by the end of 2022, is a significant boost to the company's operations. This early delivery is a testament to the partnership's success and sets the stage for Hatten Land's continued growth in the crypto mining industry.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at open tracking Wall Street retreat; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.3% or 8.72 points to 3,436.29 on April 6, 2022, tracking a Wall Street retreat. The US Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite declined 0.8%, 1.3%, and 2.3%, respectively, amid concerns over the Federal Reserve's potential aggressive actions to control inflation. European shares edged higher, while Asian markets, including Tokyo and Hong Kong, opened lower.

images.alt_text: Losers outnumbered gainers 101 to 49, or about 2 securities down for every 1 up, after 55 million securities worth S$82.3 million changed hands.

site_title: Ex-Goldman banker jury asks for wife's testimony in 1MDB case
summary: A jury in the 1MDB conspiracy case against former Goldman Sachs banker Roger Ng has asked to review testimony from his wife, Hwee Bin Lim, who previously testified that a $35.1 million infusion of capital into a shell company was not a kickback for Ng in the 1MDB scheme. Ng faces up to 30 years in prison if convicted on all counts, accused of conspiring to violate US anti-bribery laws and launder money in a plot to steal billions of dollars from the sovereign wealth fund 1Malaysia Development Bhd.

site_title: Oil eases on pandemic worries, strong US dollar
summary: Oil prices eased on Tuesday, pressured by a rising US dollar and growing concerns over new coronavirus cases, but limited by supply concerns due to sanctions on Russia. Brent futures fell 0.8% to $106.64 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell 1.3% to $101.96. A stronger US dollar makes oil more expensive for holders of other currencies, while supply concerns in Opec+ countries and a potential decline in US crude inventories could support prices.

site_title: Value-unlocking still a key theme in the local market despite the pandemic-recovery rally
summary: Value-unlocking initiatives, where companies restructure to unlock the value of their underlying assets, continue to attract investors in the local market despite the pandemic-recovery rally. Recent examples include Japfa, Olam Group, and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, which have delivered significant share price gains after announcing restructuring plans. Analysts believe that such initiatives can lead to a higher overall market value for the group, as investors with different risk appetites can focus on the segments that really interest them. Companies like Sembcorp Industries and CapitaLand Investment have also seen sustained rallies after undergoing similar value-unlocking initiatives.

site_title: Ukraine readies NFT sales as crypto donations top US$60m
summary: Ukraine is launching a web page to sell donated non-fungible tokens (NFTs) to raise funds for the war effort. The platform, set to launch within the week, will feature 300 NFTs, including a CryptoPunk valued at around $200,000, with proceeds going to Ukraine. The sales will be conducted through OpenSea, the largest NFT marketplace. Only a portion of the donated NFTs are valuable, but the initiative aims to demonstrate public support for Ukraine and inspire further donations.

site_title: Inflation may pave the way to a new era of globalisation
summary: Inflation may lead to a new era of globalisation, contrary to concerns that the pandemic and war in Ukraine will end globalisation. The relationship between globalisation and low inflation was first identified by policymakers and academics in the early 20th century, with the global labour market pressuring wages down in rich countries and poorer countries seeking monetary stability. Despite the current inflationary pressures, the past has shown that inflation can drive globalisation, particularly after significant technological advancements and policy changes. A post-conflict future with effective government and globalisation may be on the horizon, offering a glimmer of hope.

site_title: Toronto home prices dip as new listings close the gap with sales
summary: Toronto's average home price dipped 2.6% to C$1.3 million in March, as new listings closed the gap with sales, bringing a slight cooling to the market. Sales fell 30% and new listings declined 12% from last year. The Toronto Regional Real Estate Board's chief market analyst notes that if this trend continues, price growth may moderate. The market remains heavily skewed in favor of sellers, with the benchmark home price rising 35% from last year, and the average sale time decreasing to 11 days.

site_title: Looking ahead with confidence
summary: Singapore Maritime Week 2022 kicked off with a focus on the maritime sector's transformation, innovation, and resilience. The Singapore Ministry of Transport and Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore established a Maritime International Advisory Panel to discuss global trends and industry collaboration. The panel, chaired by Minister S Iswaran, brings together 12 global business leaders to address issues such as decarbonization, supply chain resilience, and the impact of the pandemic on the industry. The panel's work aims to provide insights on how Singapore can strengthen its value proposition to the global maritime industry and supply chains.

site_title: World Bank cuts East Asia's 2022 GDP forecast on Ukraine war
summary: The World Bank has cut its 2022 GDP forecast for East Asia and the Pacific to 5% due to the economic impact of Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The region's growth could slow to 4% if conditions worsen and government policy responses are weaker. China's economy is expected to grow 5% this year, down from a previous estimate of 5.4%. The war is leading to food and fuel price increases, financial volatility, and reduced confidence globally. The region's strong fundamentals and sound policies are expected to help it weather these storms.

site_title: STI up 0.8%, outperforming regional indices
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.8% to 3,445.01, outperforming regional indices, driven by US equities' surge overnight following Elon Musk's Twitter stake announcement. Gainers outnumbered losers 259 to 123, with City Developments being the biggest gainer and Dairy Farm International the biggest loser. Analysts attribute muted Asian market activity to concerns over China's Covid-19 situation and potential knock-on effects on global growth.

site_title: Deutsche Bank predicts US recession in 2023 as Fed boosts rates
summary: Deutsche Bank predicts the US will enter a recession in 2023 due to the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes to combat inflation. The Fed is expected to raise rates by 50 basis points at each of its next three meetings, peaking above 3.5% by mid-2023. Deutsche Bank forecasts a recession, with unemployment rising to 4.9% in 2024, and stocks suffering a 20% decline by summer 2023. The bank's economists also predict a reduction in the US central bank's balance sheet by almost $2 trillion by the end of 2023.

images.alt_text: While Deutsche Bank is among the first major banks to predict a recession, many finance professionals are coming to the view that a downturn is likely as the US Fed tightens credit, according to a recent survey by Bloomberg.

site_title: Your next bottle of vodka could be made from captured carbon
summary: Companies are turning captured carbon dioxide into everyday products, such as vodka, jet fuel, and hand sanitizer, to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. This "carbon capture and utilisation" (CCU) technology uses CO2 to make goods that can be sold to fund the scaling up of carbon capture technologies. Several startups, like Dimensional Energy, aim to make useable fuel from waste carbon and sunlight, while others, like Adaptavate and Econic Technologies, create products like drywall and polymers that can cut emissions from various sectors. However, experts warn that CCU may not be as effective as storing CO2 underground and that its impact on the climate may be limited.

site_title: Over 990 locals, 140 companies to benefit from Capability Transfer Programme: Tan See Leng
summary: Singapore's Capability Transfer Programme (CTP) has benefited over 990 local employees across 20 sectors since its introduction in 2017. The top 3 sectors in terms of local trainees are precision engineering, air transport and logistics. The programme aims to upskill local employees and enhance industry capabilities.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand Investment, Oxley, Yeo Hiap Seng, Jumbo, Hatten Land
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singaporean companies made announcements on April 6, 2022, affecting their securities. CapitaLand Investment issued S$400 million senior notes at 3.33% interest, while Oxley Holdings priced S$50 million notes at 6.9% interest. Yeo Hiap Seng retrenched 32 employees to transform its business, and Jumbo Group opened two new Kok Kee Wanton Noodle stalls. Hatten Land's partner delivered 40 Bitmain Antminer S19J Pro crypto mining rigs, and United Hampshire US Real Estate Investment Trust extended the due-diligence period for a proposed divestment. These developments may impact trading of their securities.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand Investment and Oxley Holdings issue new notes; Yeo Hiap Seng axes 32 employees in Singapore amid changing market trends, higher costs; and more.

site_title: Euro feels weight of French election concerns
summary: The euro weakened against the US dollar on Tuesday due to concerns over the outcome of the French presidential election and potential sanctions against Russia. The euro fell to a one-week low of $1.0956 and a 1-month high of $1.1185 just days earlier. The euro's implied volatility climbed to 3-week highs as traders braced for more sanctions. The Swiss franc and Swedish crown gained against the euro, with falls of 0.2% and 0.4% respectively.

site_title: Lalamove seeks fresh funds at US$10b valuation: sources
summary: Chinese on-demand logistics firm Lalamove is considering raising $500 million in new funds at a valuation of $10 billion. The company is gauging interest from potential investors, seeking to expand its operations globally. This move comes as Lalamove aims to increase its presence in the US market. The company's valuation represents a significant increase from its previous valuation. Lalamove's fundraising plans are seen as a strategic move to further its growth and expansion plans.

site_title: Novel vaccination tech to combat Covid-19, future pandemics
summary: A new novel vaccination technology is being developed to combat Covid-19 and future pandemics, aiming to create "universal vaccines" that can protect against new viruses prospectively. Despite the shift towards endemic living, the threat of another pandemic remains, with companies focusing on therapeutics like Pfizer's Paxlovid and fluvoxamine, a cheap antidepressant, to reduce hospitalization and death in high-risk patients. This technology could bring us closer to the "holy grail" of vaccination, enabling proactive protection rather than reactive treatment.

site_title: Europe: Shares steady with eye on sanctions; French stocks sell off on election angst
summary: European shares edged higher on Tuesday as investors awaited fresh sanctions on Moscow, while France's blue-chip index slumped due to tightening polls for presidential elections. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.2% and France's CAC 40 index lost 1.3% after a poll showed far-right candidate Marine Le Pen capturing 48.5% of voter intentions. The EU proposed new sanctions, including a ban on coal imports, which could impact Russian imports worth 19 billion euros. Utilities and renewables sectors performed well, while PMI surveys showed euro zone business growth boosted by re-opening of economies.

site_title: 'Buy now, pay later' schemes to come under industry code to protect consumers
summary: Singapore's "buy now, pay later" (BNPL) schemes will be subject to an industry code of conduct launched in the second half of the year, aimed at protecting consumers from debt accumulation. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) plans to rely on industry self-regulation for now, with the code set to include safeguards against financial imprudence and over-indebtedness. Features of the code may include minimum age requirements, interest and late fee caps, and payment freezes for missed payments.

site_title: Hedge funds that won big in China's bond meltdown now see risks
summary: A handful of small Chinese hedge funds, managing over $4.2 billion, achieved significant gains of 319%, 104%, and 96% in 2021 under their high-yield strategies, capitalizing on distressed debts issued by troubled property firms and local government financing vehicles. Despite global investors suffering losses, these funds now see risks rising further, prompting them to become more cautious, as China's real estate sector remains stressed.

site_title: Keep calm and carry on
summary: Oil prices, fueled by the Ukraine invasion, are not the primary driver of current market volatility. Instead, supply chain disruptions from COVID-19 lockdowns and new China lockdowns, combined with US interest rate hikes, are key factors. Oil prices are within a historical trading band, and recent rises are not unusual. The S&P 500 index shows a decline in growth and economic activity due to entrenched inflation, setting up potential for a head-and-shoulders trend-reversal pattern.

site_title: Many gig workers support mandatory CPF, citing housing, retirement needs
summary: A significant number of Singapore's ride-hailing and food delivery workers support making mandatory contributions to the Central Provident Fund (CPF), with 55% of submissions indicating support. This contradicts recent private surveys, which found that some workers are worried about reduced cash flow and do not want CPF contributions deducted from earnings. The government advisory committee reviewing better protection for these workers has received over 1,200 submissions, with housing and retirement being the most cited reasons for wanting CPF contributions. If mandatory CPF becomes a reality, platforms will have to contribute as well, and measures will be developed to ensure compliance.

site_title: Alcohol suppliers, distributors rush to meet demand ahead of Apr 19 nightlife reopening
summary: Singapore's nightlife sector is set to reopen on April 19, prompting a surge in demand for alcohol from distributors and businesses. Alcohol suppliers are scrambling to meet the increased demand ahead of the reopening, following the government's announcement to lift the ban on alcohol sale and consumption after 10:30 pm and allow gatherings and dining-in groups of up to 10 people. The move is seen as a significant boost to the sector, which has been restricted since the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Pacific Alliance FTA is finally signed and delivered; here is why it matters
summary: The Pacific Alliance Free Trade Agreement (PASFTA) has been signed and delivered, marking a significant milestone in deepening relations between Singapore and Chile, Colombia, Mexico, and Peru. The agreement provides opportunities for companies to access markets in the region, diversify imports and exports, and strengthen supply chain resilience. Key benefits include increased trade, investment, and collaboration in areas such as the digital economy, green energy, and innovation. The PASFTA also sets the stage for Singapore to become the first associate member of the Pacific Alliance, paving the way for new areas of cooperation and collaboration.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust's proposal to align fee structure
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) has proposed a revised fee structure to align its management costs with its growing portfolio. The new structure, which includes a base fee tied to distributable income, is designed to support the trust's long-term growth and value creation. KIT has reported a 1.6% year-on-year growth in distributable per unit (DPU) for FY 2021, and plans to expand its global reach and talent pool to drive growth. The revised fee structure aims to enhance the trustee-manager's alignment with unitholders' interests and support the trust's continued scalability.

site_title: IBM banks on lingering relevance of mainframes with new model
summary: IBM has unveiled its new mainframe model, z16, which includes new security protocols to protect against quantum computing threats. Despite the rise of cloud computing, mainframes remain relevant, with 56% of IT professionals surveyed saying they are still a predominant part of their infrastructure. The z16 model allows for predictive analytics to be run directly on the machine, providing benefits for applications like real-time fraud detection. With IBM being the only large mainframe manufacturer left, the company is banking on the continued relevance of mainframes as a cash cow.

site_title: DBS initiates GuocoLand with 'buy' on company's strength in property development
summary: DBS Group Research has initiated coverage on GuocoLand with a "buy" call, citing the company's strength in property development and high-end residential projects. The research team sets a target price of S$2.30, representing a 51% potential upside, due to GuocoLand's undervalued price-to-net-asset-value ratio. The company's pipeline of development properties, solid sales, and growing investment portfolio are expected to drive earnings growth, while its hotel business and office upcycle are also seen as positives.

site_title: Amid higher interest rates and lower spending, real returns may prove elusive
summary: Global markets continue to face challenges amid high inflation, rate hikes, and geopolitical risks. Despite rebounding equity markets, European equities remain down year-to-date, and US consumer spending shows signs of weakness. The US Federal Reserve's rate hike cycle is expected to continue, raising recessionary concerns. However, the yield curve's reliability as a recession indicator is compromised, and investors are advised to diversify their portfolios to achieve positive real returns. With average global non-bank institutional bond allocations at historic lows, diversification is crucial in a year dominated by inflation, rate hikes, and geopolitical risks.

site_title: How travel businesses can capitalise on revenge travel
summary: The global pandemic has fueled a surge in travel demand, with "revenge travel" on the rise as people look to book vacations after two years of lockdowns. According to Rakuten Advertising's Asia-Pacific travel network data, click growth for travel has more than doubled year-on-year, and TripAdvisor's Seasonal Travel Index found that over three-quarters of Singaporean travelers are planning their year-end vacations. Travel marketers are capitalizing on this trend by offering unique rewards and incentives, such as cashback and loyalty points, to engage consumers and drive conversion. Affiliate marketing is also emerging as a critical channel to reach and convert potential customers, and social media platforms like TikTok are providing opportunities for travel marketers to showcase social proof and build trust with their audience.

site_title: US reviews LG Energy Solution batteries to ensure adequate recalls
summary: The US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) is reviewing LG Energy Solution batteries to ensure all defective batteries have been recalled by automakers. The review follows recalls issued by Mercedes-Benz, Chrysler, General Motors, and Hyundai Motor due to internal failures in high-voltage vehicle batteries that pose fire risks. The NHTSA will communicate with LG and other companies to ensure thorough safety recalls are conducted, covering 138,324 vehicles. LG Energy Solution has agreed to cooperate with the inquiry.

images.alt_text: The US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) on Tuesday (Apr 5) said it is opening a review to ensure all defective batteries produced by LG Energy Solution have been recalled by automakers.

site_title: Credit investors venture back after worst quarter since 2008
summary: Credit investors are cautiously optimistic as the worst losses since 2008 may be over, with a recent rally in the corporate bond market. Analysts predict less selling in the second quarter, with investment-grade spreads expected to decline over the next 12 months. Despite inflation concerns and the ongoing war in Ukraine, strong balance sheets and low default rates support a positive outlook for credit in developed markets. However, some experts warn of potential technical selling pressure due to risk sentiment and central bank actions.

site_title: Lendlease Foundation awards S$80,000 to leaders of social change
summary: The Lendlease Foundation has awarded S$80,000 to 9 community leaders in Singapore and Malaysia, focusing on causes such as community inclusion, mental health, and climate action. The grants support grassroots initiatives that align with the Foundation's sustainability framework. The recipients include community organisations like Engineering Good, RiverLife, and Soap Cycling, which will use the funds to reduce waste, improve sanitation, and raise awareness about social issues. The initiative follows the launch of the Lendlease Foundation Community Grant Asia in October 2021, and aims to empower local community groups to drive positive social impact.

site_title: Parliament passes Bill that consolidates and expands MAS' financial regulatory powers
summary: Singapore's Parliament has passed an omnibus Bill consolidating and expanding the Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) financial regulatory powers, particularly in the digital token services sector. The bill enhances regulation of digital token service providers for money laundering and terrorist financing risks, covering those outside Singapore if they operate from the country. The new bill gives MAS more powers to impose requirements in technology risk management, raises the maximum penalty for breaches to S$1 million, and provides statutory protection to mediators and employees of dispute resolution schemes.

site_title: Payment performance of local firms improves marginally in Q1: SCCB
summary: The Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau (SCCB) reported a marginal improvement in payment performance among local firms in Q1 2022, with prompt payments increasing to 41.1% and slow payments decreasing to 44.2%. However, slow payments year on year increased from 43.1% in Q1 2021. The construction sector continued to have the highest proportion of payment delays, with 56% of payments delayed in Q1 2022.

site_title: Malaysia's real estate market expected to recover following reopening of borders
summary: Malaysia's real estate market is expected to recover following the reopening of its borders, driven by factors such as the strong Singapore dollar and relatively stable prices. Foreign buyers, particularly from Singapore, are expected to increase their purchases, with the border reopening also signaling a return to pre-pandemic economic activity between the two countries. The reopening is expected to lead to a resumption of trade and travel, boosting economic activity and enabling cross-border lifestyle opportunities.

site_title: Yeo Hiap Seng axes 32 employees in Singapore
summary: Yeo Hiap Seng, a Singapore-based beverage manufacturer, has announced the retrenchment of 32 employees due to a change in its business model to reduce ongoing operating costs. The company cited changing consumer patterns, retail conditions, and cost inflation as reasons for the move. The affected workers represent less than 2% of its total workforce of 1,900. Yeo's will incur a one-off restructuring charge and provide separation packages to the retrenched staff.

site_title: Energy realism and the implications for Singapore
summary: Singapore must reassess its green energy plans following the shift in Western Europe's energy priorities post-Ukraine invasion. Germany's re-evaluation of its energy policies, including extending coal and nuclear power operations, is a warning for Singapore to consider energy security alongside climate change concerns. The country's aggressive carbon tax increases could threaten its competitive edge in the oil refining and petrochemicals industry. With energy reliability, affordability, and security becoming increasingly urgent, Singapore must adopt a more balanced approach to energy policy, balancing environmental stewardship with economic development and energy security.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng unit to acquire minority interest in Shenton Way property for S$2.1m
summary: Chip Eng Seng Corporation plans to acquire a minority stake in the 50-storey AXA Tower at 8 Shenton Way for S$2.1 million. The acquisition will give CEL Shenton, its wholly-owned subsidiary, a 10.5% effective interest in the property. The property, valued at S$1.7 billion, will be redeveloped into a mixed-use commercial and residential development subject to approval. The acquisition is expected to be completed by the end of April and will not have a material impact on Chip Eng Seng's financials.

site_title: TPG nears US$300m deal to buy IHH's education arm
summary: TPG Capital Asia is nearing a US$300 million deal to buy IHH Healthcare's medical education arm, International Medical University. The private equity firm is in advanced talks with IHH, Asia's largest hospital group, to divest the university. A deal could be announced as early as this month, following IHH's efforts to sell the arm since last year.

site_title: United Hampshire US Reit again extends due-diligence period for divestment
summary: United Hampshire US Reit, a real estate investment trust, has extended its due-diligence period for the proposed divestment of two self-storage properties to April 11. This is the third extension granted, following initial delays to March 28 and April 4. The purchaser, Storage Post, will have more time to complete due diligence on the properties worth US$49 million. During this period, Storage Post can terminate the agreement at any time and be refunded the deposit.

site_title: Reebonz Building put on the market for undisclosed sum
summary: The Reebonz Building in Singapore has been put on the market for an undisclosed amount, following the luxury marketplace's creditors' voluntary liquidation last year. The 8-storey building, completed in 2016, features an ancillary office, warehousing, and production spaces, and has a remaining tenure of about 22 years. JLL is the exclusive marketing agent for the sale, which will close on May 5. The property's specifications include an "excellent configured area" with a high ceiling and large floor plate, making it suitable for end-users needing a place to move into and future expansion.

site_title: Zelensky to UN: 'Act immediately' on Russia or 'dissolve yourself altogether'
summary: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky urged the United Nations to "act immediately" or "dissolve itself altogether" during a speech to the UN Security Council, citing Russian atrocities in cities like Bucha. Zelensky showed a graphic video of dead bodies, including children, and likened Russia's actions to terrorism. The UN Secretary-General, Antonio Guterres, also called for an end to the conflict, emphasizing the need for serious negotiations for peace based on the UN Charter.

site_title: Singapore retail sales down 3.4% ending 5-month growth streak
summary: Singapore's retail sales fell 3.4% year-on-year in February, ending a 5-month growth streak, due to lower sales compared to a year ago when sales were boosted by pre-Chinese New Year spending. Most retail segments declined, except for cosmetics, watches, and jewellery. Economists expect retail sales to improve in the coming months as Singapore eases Covid-19 measures and the labour market continues to see improvements. Predicted growth for 2022 ranges from 3.5% to 6%, with some uncertainty due to the ongoing geopolitical crisis in Ukraine.

site_title: As inflation soars, Philippines central bank says it's ready to take pre-emptive action
summary: The Philippines' central bank governor, Benjamin Diokno, stated that the country is prepared to take pre-emptive action against inflation, which has reached the upper end of the official 2-4% target in March. The central bank maintained its key borrowing rate at 2% and projects GDP growth between 7% and 9% for 2022, driven by fiscal management and significant foreign investments. The government aims to emerge from its pandemic-induced slump and has seen a record $10.5 billion in foreign direct investment as of 2021.

site_title: Morrison faces daunting challenges in fourth term quest
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison faces a daunting challenge in his fourth term quest for re-election. Despite generous election-time budgets, including a $200 tax refund for 10 million workers, his coalition's opinion polls continue to decline. Morrison's term has been marred by controversies, including a 2019 vacation cut short due to forest fires in Australia. The country's government debt stands at $1.2 trillion, projected to grow higher. With the federal election set before May 21, Morrison's chances of retaining power seem uncertain.

site_title: Russia turns to China for microchips for in-demand domestic bank cards
summary: Russia is turning to Chinese microchip manufacturers to circumvent western sanctions, which have boosted demand for bank cards linked to the Mir payment system. Western sanctions have cut Russia off from the global financial system, leading to a shortage of microchips. Russia's National Card Payment System has issued over 2 million Mir cards, with total cards outstanding at 116 million. The system is now co-branded with China's UnionPay, and Mir cards are accepted in some countries, including Turkey and Armenia. Russia is seeking new microchip suppliers in China amid the coronavirus pandemic and European supplier sanctions.

site_title: Watchmakers tinker with new materials to draw new buyers at Geneva fair
summary: The 2022 Geneva watch fair showcased timepieces crafted from new materials, targeting a new generation of luxury watch connoisseurs. Brands such as H Moser and Oris introduced lab-made diamonds, recycled plastic, and Vantablack, a super-black coating made from carbon nanotubes. The use of these materials is aimed at providing unique beauty and technology, while also exploring environmental concerns. Luxury brands like Cartier and Tag Heuer also showcased innovative designs, including 3D printing and lab diamonds, which are seen as a way to stay ahead in the luxury market.

site_title: Microsoft hawks Windows 11 as the answer to hybrid workplaces
summary: Microsoft is positioning Windows 11 as the operating system for hybrid workplaces, where employees split time between offices and home. The latest updates aim to improve network security, enhance cloud connectivity, and provide better protection against phishing attacks. Features like Smart App Control and personal data encryption are designed to make it easier to move work between physical computers and the cloud. With some companies already adopting Windows 11, Microsoft expects strong demand for new products that cater to the changing work landscape.

site_title: US services growth improves as ISM's March gauge climbs to 58.3
summary: US service sector growth improved in March, with the Institute for Supply Management's gauge rising to 58.3, the first increase in four months. Employment and orders strengthened, driven by a decline in Covid-19 cases. The service sector's business activity expanded at a faster pace, and 17 industries reported growth. However, respondents noted capacity constraints, logistical challenges, and inflation, with supply and demand imbalances fueling inflation, which reached a four-month high.

site_title: Tiger Woods says 'as of right now' he will play Masters
summary: Tiger Woods plans to play the 86th Masters golf tournament at Augusta National, 14 months after suffering severe right leg injuries in a car crash. As of now, he will participate in a nine-hole practice round on Wednesday and will reassess his readiness after the practice round. Woods, a 15-time major champion, aims to win a sixth Masters title and match Jack Nicklaus' all-time record. He tested his ability to walk the hilly course last week and plans to make his 24th Masters start.

site_title: Manhattan homebuyers see more bidding wars in still-hot market
summary: Manhattan homebuyers are experiencing intense bidding wars in the still-hot market, with 9.3% of completed purchases above the asking price, the highest in 4 years. Luxury listings saw their second-highest rate of bidding wars in 5 years, and competition was intense in the luxury market. The median price of deals closed in the quarter was $1.19 million, up 11% from last year, and it would take 5.8 months to sell all available apartments at the current pace. Demand is expected to remain high, with more apartments anticipated to hit the market in the spring.

site_title: Nato says Russia regrouping to try to take Ukraine's Donbas
summary: NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg says Russia is regrouping to try to take Ukraine's Donbas region in the coming weeks. Russian troops have moved away from Kyiv, re-arming and re-supplying to focus on the east. NATO allies will discuss delivering advanced weapons systems, including anti-tank missiles, to Ukraine. Meanwhile, Russia denies staging civilian deaths in Ukraine, accusing Ukraine of staging fake videos to blame Moscow. The Russian defense ministry also claimed Ukrainian special services are organizing similar events in other cities.

site_title: 6,341 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, 518 patients in hospital
summary: Singapore reported 6,341 new Covid-19 cases on April 5, down from 3,334 the previous day. Hospitalized patients decreased to 518, from 522 the day before, with one reported death. The case numbers are lower than the previous week, reflecting the easing of Covid-19 measures. The country has recorded 1,119,419 Covid-19 cases and 1,284 deaths, with 95% of the eligible population vaccinated and 72% receiving booster shots.

site_title: Fund ideas that capitalise on risks and opportunities in April 2022
summary: Investors have navigated a volatile 2022, influenced by inflation, war, and the pandemic. Despite uncertainty, some opportunities have emerged. Asia is expected to drive dollar asset diversification, while retail investors are forecasted to drive ETF growth in the region. Productivity gains are key to unlocking wealth creation. Markets have risen, and de-dollarization is underway, with shifting safe havens. Amid these developments, investors are being advised to capitalize on risks and opportunities, and to consider diversification strategies to navigate the complex market landscape.

site_title: US trade gap stays close to record as services surplus narrows
summary: The US trade deficit remained close to a record in February, narrowing to US$89.2 billion after a record shortfall in January. The merchandise shortfall shrank, while the services surplus declined due to increased broadcast rights fees for the Olympics. Imports rose 1.3% to a record US$317.8 billion, and exports climbed 1.8% to US$228.6 billion. However, the deficit may temper US export growth due to the ripple effects of Russia's invasion of Ukraine and potential weakening in European demand.

images.alt_text: The February gap in goods and services trade was little changed at US$89.2 billion after a record shortfall in January.

site_title: EU unveils new sanctions on Moscow as Kyiv mayor calls for halt to 'bloody money'
summary: The European Union has proposed new sanctions against Russia, including a ban on coal imports worth 4 billion euros, in response to evidence of civilian killings in a Ukrainian town seized from Russian invaders. The proposed sanctions, which EU member states must approve, would also bar Russian imports worth 9 billion euros and exports to Russia worth 10 billion euros. Kyiv's mayor called for all business ties with Russia to be cut, halting the flow of "bloody money," as Ukraine accuses Russia of genocide and seeks international support for an investigation into the killings.

site_title: GM, Honda unveil plan to jointly build millions of small EVs
summary: General Motors and Honda Motor have unveiled a plan to jointly develop millions of small electric vehicles, leveraging GM's Ultium EV battery technology. The collaboration aims to produce affordable EVs priced below $30,000, targeting North America, South America, and China. The project's first models are expected to be available in 2027, marking a major move towards democratizing electric vehicles. By sharing technology, design, and manufacturing strategies, GM and Honda aim to reduce battery costs and increase sales, deepening their ties as they work together to achieve their respective goals of carbon neutrality and EV adoption.

site_title: Booze suppliers get drunk on orders as nightlife operators rush to reopen
summary: Singapore's nightlife sector is set to fully reopen on April 19, with alcohol sales and consumption allowed after 10:30 pm. Booze suppliers are struggling to meet the surge in demand, with some businesses having only a 4-6 week buffer to restock. Wine suppliers face longer lead times due to supply chain disruptions, and some are expecting shortages until May. Craft breweries are also experiencing increased demand, but some are concerned about meeting the surge in orders, particularly for malts and grains.

site_title: Twitter to name top shareholder Musk to board
summary: Twitter appoints Elon Musk to its board of directors, following his disclosure of a 9.2% stake in the company. Musk, CEO of Tesla, will serve as a Class II director with a term expiring at Twitter's 2024 annual meeting. The move comes after Musk's stake in Twitter was revealed, with the billionaire stating he is a "passionate believer and intense critic" of the service. Twitter shares surged 6% in trading before the announcement. Musk will participate in director benefits arrangements and enter into a standard form of indemnification agreement with the company.

site_title: Online jam builds up as new World Cup ticket sale launched
summary: Huge online queues built up on the FIFA website as a new round of World Cup ticket sales launched in Qatar. Fans worldwide reported waiting over an hour to apply for tickets, with some going to great lengths to secure them. The first round of sales sold over 800,000 of the 3 million available tickets, with prices ranging from $68 to $1,600. The draw for the first round group matches has made the tournament more attractive, with notable matchups like Germany and Spain in Group E.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore gig workers support mandatory CPF contributions, with over 990 locals benefiting from the Capability Transfer Programme. Retail sales fell 3.4% in February, ending a 5-month growth streak, while the STI rose 0.8% on Tuesday. A code of conduct for the "buy now, pay later" industry will be launched in the second half of the year to protect consumer interests.

site_title: Industrial building at Leng Kee area on sale for S$19 million
summary: An industrial building at 6 Kung Chong Road, Leng Kee, is for sale for S$19 million through an expression of interest exercise. The property has a gross area of approximately 15,642 sq ft, with potential to increase to 40,000 sq ft, and a remaining lease of about 33 years. It is approved for light and clean industrial use, near shopping malls and MRT stations, and has no land rent payable. The sale will launch on Wednesday and close on May 18 this year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Tuesday, down 2.13 points to 1,596.79. The market saw 3.873 billion lots worth RM2.365 billion in trading, with gainer-to-loser ratio at 653:308.

site_title: Novel vaccination technologies to combat Covid-19 and future pandemics
summary: Global Covid-19 protocols have shifted towards endemic living, but the threat of future pandemics remains. Despite decades of warning signs, the defence against new viruses has been insufficient. Therapeutics, such as Pfizer's Paxlovid and fluvoxamine, are being prioritized as part of medical countermeasures. Promising data suggests fluvoxamine may significantly reduce hospitalization and death in high-risk Covid-19 patients, offering hope for combatting future pandemics.

site_title: Jumbo opens 2 more Kok Kee Wanton Noodle stalls as safe-management measures ease
summary: Jumbo Group has opened two new Kok Kee Wanton Noodle stalls in Singapore, bringing the total number of outlets to eight. Jumbo acquired a 75% stake in Kok Kee in December 2020. The new stalls were opened in a food court at Lazada One Building along Bras Basah Road and a coffee shop at Bedok North Avenue 3.

site_title: Sinopec's Qingdao LNG terminal receives its first Qatari gas
summary: Sinopec's Qingdao LNG terminal in eastern China has received its first shipment of Qatari gas, marking the start of a 10-year supply deal. The shipment, valued at 2.8 billion cubic meters, is part of an annual supply of 2 million tonnes. The deal was reached with Qatar Petroleum in March last year, with the gas supply set to begin this year. This marks the first Qatari gas supply for the eastern Chinese province.

site_title: New Batman story coming to Spotify podcasts in May, in 9 languages
summary: Spotify is set to release a new Batman podcast, "Batman Unburied," in May, featuring local adaptations in 9 countries, including India, Brazil, and Japan. The podcast follows the alter-ego Bruce Wayne and is part of a multi-year deal between Spotify and AT&T's Warner Bros to bring DC Comics superheroes to narrative podcasts. This marks the first podcast developed under this partnership, which aims to expand Spotify's podcast offerings, now totaling over 3.2 million titles.

site_title: Amazon signs on launch partners for space Internet
summary: Amazon has signed launch contracts with Arianespace, Blue Origin, and United Launch Alliance (ULA) to deploy a constellation of satellites in low Earth orbit for its Project Kuiper internet service. The deals are the largest commercial procurement of launch vehicles in history, with Amazon aiming to provide fast and affordable broadband to tens of millions of customers worldwide. The project, in-house developed by Amazon, will utilize capabilities from its other divisions, such as logistics and AWS cloud computing. The launch bookings are expected to boost the US and European space industry.

site_title: 5 Questions with Coinhako's Liu Yusho
summary: Coinhako founder Liu Yusho shares insights on navigating the crypto market and growing his user base to over 400,000 users. Before starting Coinhako in 2014, Liu worked on various ventures in university and had a keen interest in startups. He emphasizes the importance of creating a product that serves customers' needs and having conviction in one's idea. Liu also advises entrepreneurs to be prepared for challenges and uncertainties, and to learn from industry veterans. He has experienced two crypto winters, but managed to weather the storms and emerge stronger.

site_title: Post-Ukraine invasion: Energy realism and the implications for Singapore
summary: The Russian invasion of Ukraine has prompted a shift in energy policies in Western Europe, with countries like Germany and the UK reevaluating their focus on climate change and prioritizing energy security. Germany has announced plans to extend the operations of its coal and nuclear power plants, and is considering importing liquefied natural gas (LNG) to diversify its energy imports. This shift has implications for Singapore, which must balance its long-term plans for "green" energy with the need to maintain energy security and competitiveness in the region. The article warns that overly aggressive carbon tax increases could threaten Singapore's strategic advantages in the oil refining and petrochemicals industry.

site_title: US: Stocks mixed amid talk of more sanctions on Russia
summary: US stocks were mixed on Tuesday as European officials considered additional sanctions on Russia amid outrage over carnage in Ukraine's Bucha. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.3%, while the S&P 500 added 0.1%. The tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.6%. The Federal Reserve is set to release meeting minutes on Wednesday, which may influence interest rate hikes. Oil prices also edged higher.

site_title: Yeo Hiap Seng axes 32 employees in Singapore amid changing market trends, higher costs
summary: Beverage manufacturer Yeo Hiap Seng has retrenched 32 employees in Singapore as part of its long-term plan to transform its global business amid changing market trends and increasing cost pressures. The company cited consumer pattern changes and retail conditions as reasons for the restructuring. The affected workers, representing less than 2% of its total workforce, will receive separation packages to help them through the transition. Yeo's expects to incur a one-off restructuring charge, which will be finalized later, and is working with unions to provide training and placement support to those affected.

site_title: Asia's US$350b gas buildout intensifies clean energy debate
summary: Asia is investing over $350 billion in new gas infrastructure, including liquefied natural gas terminals, power plants, and pipelines, to reduce reliance on coal and curb emissions. The region aims to avoid burning more coal, but this could slow renewable energy deployments and lock in fossil fuel use for decades. Despite producing half the carbon emissions of coal, gas use must shrink to combat climate change. The UN warns that the world may warm by over 3 degrees Celsius if fossil fuels are not phased out, and Asia's gas expansion is concerning due to its potential for massive growth and impact on global energy markets.

images.alt_text: The region has more than US$350 billion of projects under way to expand liquefied natural gas terminals, gas-burning power plants and pipelines.

site_title: Missing Charles Darwin notebooks returned to Cambridge University
summary: Charles Darwin's two missing notebooks, containing his pioneering ideas on evolution and the famous "Tree of Life" sketch, have been returned to Cambridge University Library after 21 years. The notebooks, which are worth millions of pounds, were found in a pink gift bag with a typed note wishing a Happy Easter to the librarian. The manuscripts are in good condition and will go on display over the summer to allow the public to see them. The university's librarian expressed profound relief at the notebooks' safe return.

images.alt_text: A handout image released by the University of Cambridge Library on April 5, 2022, shows the returned 1837 'Tree of Life' sketch on a page from one of the lost notebooks of British scientist Charles Darwin.

site_title: Australia's central bank opens door to tightening
summary: Australia's central bank, the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA), surprised markets by dropping its "patient" stance on interest rate policy, paving the way for a potential rate hike. The RBA kept the cash rate at 0.1% but noted inflation had picked up and was likely to rise further. The local dollar surged to a nine-month high as markets expect an eventual tightening. Analysts predict core inflation may exceed the RBA's 2-3% target, making it harder to justify low rates.

site_title: EU to propose import ban on Russia coal, chemicals, wood: source
summary: The European Commission plans to propose sweeping sanctions against Russia, including banning imports of coal, wood, chemicals, and other products worth around 9 billion euros per year. The EU will also propose a ban on exports worth 10 billion euros per year, including semiconductors, computers, and technology. Russian vessels and trucks will be prevented from accessing the EU, except for energy products, food, and medicines. The sanctions are intended to further cripple trade with Russia, reducing the value of trade by at least 20 billion euros per year.

site_title: Amid higher interest rates and lower spending, real returns may prove elusive
summary: Global equity markets are still down year to date, with European equities declining 9% due to the war in Ukraine and economic slowdown. However, markets are following a historical pattern, recouping most of their losses since the war started. Asia is expected to drive and benefit from dollar asset diversification, while retail investors are expected to drive massive growth in ETFs in Asia and Europe. Productivity gains are key to unlocking wealth creation, and markets are rising despite economic headwinds, with the S&P 500 reaching a record high.

site_title: Dozens of Sri Lanka lawmakers quit ruling coalition; Finance Minister resigns
summary: At least 41 Sri Lankan lawmakers have quit the ruling coalition, leaving President Gotabaya Rajapaksa's government in a minority in Parliament. Finance Minister Ali Sabry resigned ahead of crucial talks with the International Monetary Fund. The move comes as public unrest surges over the country's worst economic crisis in decades, with shortages of food, fuel, and power cuts. The opposition has called for President Rajapaksa and Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa to step down, with a possible vote of no confidence or snap elections possible.

site_title: Saudi oil buyers in Asia may seek alternatives after price hike
summary: Asian oil buyers may shift to US and Middle Eastern crude on the spot market due to Saudi Arabia's record price hike. The price increase, which is a $9.35 premium above Oman and Dubai prices, has made long-haul flows from the US and Middle Eastern crude more viable. Traders expect buyers to reduce volumes and opt for spot market purchases, citing cost advantages. The move comes after the US announced a strategic reserves release and China's weakening demand outlook due to Covid-19 outbreaks.

site_title: Parliament passes Bill that consolidates and expands MAS' financial regulatory powers
summary: Singapore's parliament passed a bill expanding the Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) financial regulatory powers, focusing on digital token services such as cryptocurrencies. The bill aims to enhance regulation of digital token service providers for money laundering and terrorist financing risks, covering entities outside Singapore if their businesses are created or operate from the country. The bill also gives MAS more powers to impose requirements in technology risk management and raises the maximum penalty for a breach to $1 million. The move aims to balance regulation with the need to support the growth of the digital financial services industry.

site_title: STI up 0.8%, outperforms regional indices
summary: The Singapore market rose 0.8% on Tuesday, outperforming regional indices, driven by gains in US equities following Elon Musk's Twitter stake announcement. The Straits Times Index (STI) climbed to 3,445.01, with property developer City Developments Limited and local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC making gains. Regional markets saw moderate gains, but China's Covid-19 situation and potential lockdowns in China weighed on investor sentiment, according to Oanda senior market analyst Jeffrey Halley.

site_title: Inflation may pave the way to a new era of globalisation
summary: Inflation, driven by pandemic-related fiscal packages and supply chain disruptions, is expected to persist and potentially lead to global instability. Rising food and fuel prices may spark discontent, protests, and revolutions worldwide. The relationship between globalisation and low inflation was initially identified in the early 2000s, with policymakers citing global labour markets and innovation as key factors. The current inflation may mark a shift away from globalisation, with national inflation levels increasing, and policymakers reevaluating their stance on the topic.

site_title: Treasury stops Russia from paying debt through US accounts
summary: The US Treasury has halted dollar debt payments from Russian government accounts at US banks, increasing pressure on Moscow to find alternative funding sources. The move comes as a payment on Russia's sovereign debt was due on Monday and is intended to further ratchet up pressure on Russian President Vladimir Putin to end his invasion of Ukraine. Russia's dollar bonds fell after the announcement, and the country's dollar reserves have plunged to $604.4 billion, the lowest level since last August.

site_title: Morrison faces daunting challenges in fourth term quest
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison faces a daunting challenge in his fourth term quest for re-election, despite a budget filled with giveaways, including a tax refund to 10 million workers. His coalition's opinion polls remain low, and he has accumulated problems throughout his term, including a botched vacation in 2019. Morrison's government debt stands at A$1.2 trillion, projected to grow higher. The federal election must be held before May 21, with Morrison's chances of retaining power uncertain.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end near 2-month high as battery, internet stocks jump
summary: South Korean shares closed near a 2-month high on Tuesday, driven by gains in battery and internet companies, including LG Energy Solution and Samsung SDI, which rose 2.39% and 2.56%, respectively. The benchmark Kospi index closed up 1.3 points, or 0.05%, to 2,759.20. Investors took a wait-and-see stance ahead of US PMI data and Federal Reserve comments, while the won strengthened and bond yields rose.

site_title: Australia: Shares eke out gains on tech strength; RBA stance caps advance
summary: Australian shares ended 0.2% higher on Tuesday, driven by surging oil prices and tech firms tracking Wall Street gains, but gains were capped by the Reserve Bank of Australia's signal of its first interest rate hike in over a decade. The benchmark rose as tech stocks led gains, with local tech stocks advancing 3.1% and energy stocks jumping 2.2%. Despite the RBA's decision, investors will focus on the timing of the rate hike, with the August meeting in focus.

site_title: Crypto mania, financial contagion, and the 'Goldilocks zone'
summary: Cryptocurrency has gained remarkable legitimacy, with 6% of US respondents purchasing or trading in the past year, and higher rates in countries like Peru and the Philippines. However, experts warn of the dangers of speculation, financial contagion, and the potential for a "Goldilocks zone" of confidence and expectations. As the market capitalisation of cryptocurrencies approaches $1.7 trillion, risks of housing debt, economic shock, and contagious panic may lead to a perfect storm. Institutions and governments will play a role in stability, but financial history suggests they may be late to the dance.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust's proposal to align fee structure
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) has proposed a new fee structure that aligns with the interests of unitholders. The proposed Base Fee is tied to distributable income and increases in DPU, reflecting the level of resources required to manage the trust's diverse portfolio. The current fee structure has been criticized for being unsustainable and hindering growth. KIT's CEO, Jopy Chiang, has assured unitholders that the new structure has been carefully deliberated and will support the trust's long-term growth and value creation. The proposed fee structure will be implemented progressively over the financial year.

site_title: SoftBank-backed startup Remote nears US$3b value in funding
summary: Remote Technology, a startup that facilitates international employee hiring, has raised $300 million at a valuation of nearly $3 billion, bringing its total funding to $495 million. The investment was led by SoftBank Vision Fund 2, with existing investors participating. Remote's platform helps businesses manage payroll and benefits for international employees, with notable customers including DoorDash and GitLab. CEO Job van der Voort believes the trend of hiring remote employees internationally will continue, and the company is well-positioned to excel in this category.

site_title: How travel businesses can capitalise on revenge travel
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has sparked a surge in "revenge travel" as people seek to make up for lost time. With vaccination rates improving and borders reopening, travel bookings are increasing, with over double year-on-year click growth in the travel industry. Travel marketers are capitalizing on this trend by offering unique rewards, cashback, and loyalty programs to attract customers. Affiliate marketing is also emerging as a key channel to engage consumers throughout their journey. Social media platforms like TikTok are being used to fuel wanderlust and promote travel-related content, while safety remains a top priority for travelers.

site_title: Fund ideas that capitalise on risks and opportunities in April 2022
summary: Investors can capitalize on risks and opportunities in April 2022 by considering four fund ideas. High oil prices, driven by supply disruptions and under-investment in the sector, may reach US$150, making the Blackrock World Energy Fund a potential choice. Asia remains a diversification option despite volatility, with the Fullerton Lux Funds - Asia Absolute Alpha Fund and the JPMorgan Japan Equity Fund being recommended. Fixed-income strategies, such as short-duration bond funds and unconstrained bond funds, can protect portfolios against rising interest rates. Additionally, Greater China exposure, driven by China's commitment to market stability, is an attractive option, with the UBS (Lux) Equity Funds being recommended.

site_title: Hong Kong: Market closed for holiday
summary: Hong Kong's financial markets are closed on April 5 for the Qingming Festival holiday. This marks a brief pause in market activity amidst ongoing global economic trends. Meanwhile, in other news, the Singapore stock market edged up 0.4% on Thursday, driven by investor positivity despite tariff uncertainty. Additionally, eSIM platform Airalo has raised $220 million in new funding, lifting its valuation past $1 billion.

site_title: Credit investors venture back after worst quarter since 2008
summary: Credit investors are venturing back into the market after a worst quarter since 2008, with some optimistic investors citing strong balance sheet cash positions and record-low default rates as reasons for their optimism. Despite a 7.1% loss in the first quarter, the rally may continue as investors bring some of their money back, with investment-grade spreads expected to decline over 12 months. The war in Ukraine and potential rate hikes by the Federal Reserve may still pose risks, but many analysts believe credit is in a reasonable state to weather the current storm.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei tracks Wall Street higher; caution over corporate outlook caps gains
summary: The Nikkei share average in Tokyo rose 0.19% to close at 27,787.98, tracking overnight gains on Wall Street, but was capped by investor caution over corporate outlook. The Topix index fell 0.23%. Fast Retailing, SoftBank Group, and Tokyo Electron led gains, while insurers and banks led losses. The broader market was influenced by concerns about the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic and rising commodity prices due to the Russia-Ukraine conflict.

site_title: Shanghai lockdown deepens after new surge in asymptomatic Covid cases
summary: Shanghai, China's major financial center, has extended lockdown restrictions after a surge of 13,086 new asymptomatic Covid-19 cases on April 4. The lockdown now covers over 25 million people, with thousands in "central quarantine" facilities. Authorities have deployed 38,000 personnel and are conducting intensive city-wide testing. The government's zero-tolerance approach is under scrutiny, with experts warning of economic costs and concerns about the treatment of those in quarantine. The situation remains critical, with no end to the lockdown in sight.

site_title: Singapore retail sales down 3.4% ending 5-month growth streak
summary: Singapore's retail sales fell 3.4% in February, reversing a 5-month growth streak, due to lower sales compared to a year ago when pre-Chinese New Year spending boosted sales. However, economists expect retail sales to improve in the coming months as Singapore continues to ease Covid-19 measures and as the labour market improves. Despite the decline, some segments like cosmetics, watches, and furniture showed growth, with forecasts suggesting retail sales will expand by 3.5%, 4-6%, or 6% in 2022, depending on the economist.

site_title: Gold eases as dollar holds firm on safe-haven flows
summary: Gold prices eased 0.2% to $1,929.60 per ounce, as the US dollar held firm despite rising prospects of Russian sanctions and interest-rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. The stronger dollar makes gold less attractive, while US Treasury yields climbed to their highest level since 2019. Spot silver fell 0.1% and platinum remained unchanged, while palladium rose 0.7%. The US and Europe plan new sanctions against Russia, and President Zelensky warned of more civilian deaths in Ukraine, fueling market uncertainty.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets steady at open
summary: European stock markets opened steady on Tuesday, April 5, 2022, after Tokyo's close and a 1% increase in oil prices. London's FTSE 100 index opened flat at 7,559.47 points, while the eurozone's DAX and CAC 40 indices remained stable.

site_title: Your next bottle of vodka could be made from captured carbon
summary: Companies are turning captured carbon dioxide into everyday products, such as vodka, hand sanitizer, and building materials, to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Carbon capture technology separates CO2 from other gases and can be stored underground or used to make goods. While some startups, like Dimensional Energy, aim to create fossil-fuel-free aviation fuel, experts argue that replacing everyday goods with versions made from captured carbon may not be effective in reducing emissions. Instead, companies should focus on storing CO2 underground to minimize its impact on the atmosphere.

site_title: Reebonz Building put on the market for undisclosed sum
summary: The Reebonz Building in Singapore, formerly the headquarters of the luxury marketplace Reebonz, has been put on the market for an undisclosed sum. The 8-storey building, completed in 2016, features an ancillary office, warehousing, and production spaces, as well as car-parking facilities. JLL is the exclusive marketing agent for the sale, with a tender closing on May 5. The site has a remaining tenure of 22 years and is zoned "Business 1" for light and clean industrial use.

site_title: The hottest NFT marketplace is mostly users selling to themselves
summary: The LooksRare NFT marketplace, now leading in trading volume, is dominated by users selling tokens to themselves to earn rewards, a practice known as "wash sales." This activity accounts for 95% of the platform's trading volume, with most transactions being self-sold to boost Looks token prices. The platform benefits from transaction fees and helps mask the cooling of demand in the NFT market, with OpenSea's sales volume declining 67% in the last 30 days. Experts consider wash trading a form of market manipulation, and the model is being adopted by other NFT marketplaces.

site_title: Alphabet's Wing to begin biggest US drone-delivery test in Texas
summary: Alphabet's Wing is set to begin the largest US drone-delivery test programme, starting Thursday in the Dallas suburbs. The company has obtained permission from the Federal Aviation Administration to deliver items from a Walgreens store and partner with other companies to deliver products such as ice cream and pet medications. This milestone marks an important step for Wing and drone delivery in the US, with the company having already surpassed 200,000 deliveries earlier this year. The deliveries will be available to people living near Dallas in Frisco and Little Elm.

site_title: IBM banks on lingering relevance of mainframes with new model
summary: IBM unveiled its new mainframe model, z16, emphasizing the continued relevance of the decades-old computing systems despite the shift to public cloud. The new model features improved predictive analytics capabilities and enhanced security protocols to protect against quantum computing threats. Mainframes remain a crucial part of many organizations' IT portfolios, particularly in financial institutions and hybrid cloud environments. IBM is banking on the enduring value of mainframes, with the unit generating $2.9 billion in fourth-quarter revenue. The company is the only large mainframe manufacturer left, with Fujitsu planning to end its mainframe offerings by 2031.

site_title: Metals world agonises over war but keeps buying from Russia
summary: The global metals industry is grappling with the ethics of buying from Russia despite the ongoing war in Ukraine, with some companies opting to disentangle themselves from Russian business and others continuing to fulfill existing contracts.
