London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.4% to 7,566.36 points, while Frankfurt's DAX and Paris's CAC 40 also rose 0.3% and 0.4% respectively.

site_title: Like Lego play, is your investment portfolio built to last?
summary: A well-diversified investment portfolio is likened to building with Lego bricks, with precision and attention to detail crucial for stability. Portfolio construction, like Lego building, should involve combining assets that are not perfectly correlated to lower risk without sacrificing expected returns. A classic 60/40 portfolio for moderate-risk investors delivers on its risk-adjusted returns, according to Morningstar. A passive portfolio approach, anchored by years of scientific research, is key to success, whereas active investing normally does not bring good outcomes over time. Investors should prioritize a well-diversified core portfolio over tactical allocations.

site_title: Oil inches up as supply concerns weigh despite reserves release, Yemen truce
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday as concerns about tight supply persisted despite the release of supplies from strategic reserves and a truce in Yemen. Brent crude futures increased 0.09% to $104.48 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 0.03% to $99.30 a barrel. The truce, brokered by the UN, could temporarily alleviate supply disruptions in the Middle East, but the absence of Russian oil remains a concern. Oil production at the world's No. 2 exporter fell to 11.01 million barrels per day in March, and US energy firms may be reluctant to increase output due to high crude prices.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei inches higher on gains in Wall Street, Asian shares
summary: Japan's Nikkei rose 0.25% to close at 27,736.47, tracking gains in Wall Street and other Asian equity markets, despite losses in chip-related shares. The Topix gained 0.48%. The market was supported by US gains over the weekend, but investors remained cautious due to uncertain US market direction. Shipping companies and oil explorers led gains, while chipmaking equipment maker Tokyo Electron fell 2.66%. The market was restructured into three new markets to attract foreign investors.

site_title: 'Not tenable' for the govt to subsidise electricity costs in Singapore: Tan See Leng
summary: Singapore's government cannot subsidize electricity consumption to keep domestic prices lower than global prices, said Second Minister for Trade and Industry Tan See Leng. The government will instead diversify energy sources to reduce reliance on fuel supply shocks. Plans include increasing solar deployment to 2 gigawatt-peak by 2030 and importing up to 4 gigawatt of low-carbon electricity by 2035. Businesses can manage costs by being more energy efficient, and the government will assist sustainable practices.

site_title: Starbucks announces halt to stock repurchasing programme
summary: Starbucks has suspended its stock repurchasing program, allowing the company to invest more in its people and stores. The move comes amid supply chain challenges, the effects of the pandemic, and heightened tensions. Former CEO Howard Schultz is returning to lead the company for the third time, citing a desire to "design that next Starbucks" with purpose and agency. The suspension will impact the company's ability to buy back shares, which had risen 5% after Schultz's previous appointment as interim CEO.

site_title: Hong Kong leadership contender emerges amid uncertain future
summary: Hong Kong's deputy leader, John Lee, has signaled his intention to contest the city's top job, potentially paving the way for Beijing's approval of a security official as leader. Incumbent leader Carrie Lam has announced she won't seek a second term, citing family considerations. The election, originally scheduled for March, has been postponed due to the Covid-19 outbreak and will now take place on May 8. The election process, overseen by Beijing, has been criticized for lacking democratic representation, with the city's 7.4 million residents having no say in who leads them.

site_title: Indonesia's GoTo gives IPO shares to 600,000 drivers in regional first
summary: GoTo Group, a ride-hailing and delivery app, has given away thousands of shares to its 600,000 drivers as part of its $1.1 billion Indonesian initial public offering (IPO). Drivers who registered between 2010 and 2016 will receive 4,000 shares, while those who registered between 2017 and February will get 1,000 shares. This represents a token amount, but GoTo becomes the first major sharing-economy giant in South-east Asia to include part-time gig workers in its IPO windfall.

images.alt_text: "It's an acknowledgment that our driver-partners are part of our success," chief executive officer Andre Soelistyo said in an interview. "This is something we've wanted to do since the beginning."

site_title: Philippine presidential candidates urge tougher stance on China
summary: Philippine presidential candidates are urging the country to take a tougher stance against China over territorial disputes in the South China Sea. They propose leveraging the 2016 Hague arbitration ruling to establish a code of conduct with China through the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean). Some candidates, like Norberto Gonzales, also suggest shifting Asean's voting system to a majority vote to counter China's influence. The candidates also weighed in on other issues, including Myanmar and climate change, during the Commission on Election's debate.

site_title: Gold muted as dollar, yields firm on strong US jobs data
summary: Gold prices remained flat at US$1,922.43 per ounce on Monday, as a stronger US dollar and rising yields offset support from safe-haven demand due to the Ukraine crisis. Strong US jobs data raised expectations of aggressive interest rate hikes, increasing the opportunity cost of holding non-paying bullion. Spot silver edged 0.1% higher, while platinum and palladium also saw slight changes.

site_title: Two Chinese mRNA Covid vaccines move towards clinical trials
summary: China has approved clinical trials for two mRNA Covid-19 vaccines, SYS6006 by CSPC Pharmaceutical Group and a vaccine by Shanghai-based Stemirna Therapeutics. The vaccines, which can neutralize the Omicron variant, are the first mRNA-based vaccines approved for use in China. The approval follows a nationwide outbreak of the Omicron variant, with Shanghai battling its worst coronavirus outbreak since 2020. This move marks a significant development in China's vaccine development, which has primarily relied on inactivated virus technology.

site_title: Ryanair narrows loss forecast, traffic tops pre-pandemic levels
summary: Ryanair Holdings has narrowed its annual loss forecast to between 350 million euros and 400 million euros, as it sees passenger numbers top pre-pandemic levels for the first time ahead of the Easter holiday period. The airline flew 11.2 million people in March, surpassing pre-pandemic levels, and expects to reach 97 million passengers in fiscal 2022, still below the pre-pandemic peak of 149 million. CEO Michael O'Leary also outlined an optimistic outlook for the next year, targeting at least 1 billion euros in net income.

images.alt_text: In an interview last Thursday (Mar 31), Ryan CEO Michael O'Leary presented an optimistic outlook for the next 12 months, saying that Ryanair will target at least 1 billion euros in net income for the new fiscal year, driven by hedges on 80 per cent of its fuel needs and pent-up demand for travel as Covid curbs are lifted.

site_title: Singapore forms international advisory panel for maritime industry
summary: Singapore has formed an international advisory panel for the maritime industry, comprising 12 global business leaders. The panel, chaired by Transport Minister S Iswaran, aims to discuss trends shaping the maritime sector and supply chains. The panel members include major companies such as Maersk, Boston Consulting Group, and Procter & Gamble. The maritime international advisory panel will meet during Singapore Maritime Week 2022, focusing on collaboration to improve global maritime industry and supply chains, ensuring the flow of essential goods to countries and people in need.

site_title: MPA investigating cause of major bunker fuel contamination at Singapore port
summary: Singapore's Maritime and Port Authority (MPA) is investigating the cause of a major bunker fuel contamination at the city-state's port, affecting 34 vessels from two unnamed suppliers. The contamination, containing up to 2,000 parts per million of chlorinated hydrocarbons, led to a loss of power and propulsion in at least 14 ships. The MPA has contacted the suppliers to stop supplying the contaminated fuel and has warned ships to exercise caution when using it. Further investigations are ongoing, and the agency will take action if there is non-compliance.

site_title: China's BYD ends full combustion engine cars to focus on electric, plug-in hybrids
summary: China's BYD, the country's largest electric vehicle (EV) maker, has ended production of full combustion engine cars and now focuses on electric and plug-in hybrid vehicles. This move is in response to Beijing's pledge to boost green energy consumption to peak carbon emissions by 2030. BYD sold 104,878 units of new energy vehicles in March, with 53,664 pure EV and 50,674 plug-in hybrid cars. The company will continue providing services and spare parts to existing fuel vehicle customers, while smaller efficient engines will be used in plug-in hybrid cars.

site_title: Nearly half of crypto owners first bought digital assets in 2021: survey
summary: A new survey from Gemini found that nearly half of cryptocurrency owners in the US, Latin America, and Asia-Pacific first bought digital assets in 2021. The survey of 30,000 people across 20 countries shows 79% of crypto owners bought for long-term investment potential, and 64% in countries like Indonesia and India reported using crypto as a hedge against inflation. Countries with currency devaluation, like Brazil and Indonesia, have high crypto adoption rates, with 41% of people surveyed owning crypto.

site_title: Cutting fuel duties would 'effectively amount to subsidy on private transport': Lawrence Wong
summary: Finance Minister Lawrence Wong stated that cutting fuel duties or providing road tax rebates would effectively be a subsidy on private transport, benefiting a small but affluent group, and counteracting efforts towards sustainable living. This move would also reduce incentives for switching to more energy-efficient modes of transport. Wong emphasized that the government can provide support to Singaporeans through measures outlined in the Budget, rather than through subsidies.

images.alt_text: "Cutting fuel duties also means that some of the subsidies will flow back in part to producers and suppliers themselves, not just to consumers, as the pump price may not fall as much as the reduction in duty," said Finance Minister Lawrence Wong.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand Investment, SPH, SPH Reit, ALog Trust, Wilton Resources
summary: CapitaLand Investment's development arm won a bid for 2 prime residential sites in China, worth 3.5 billion yuan. Cuscaden Peak's acquisition bid was sanctioned in court. SPH Reit posted a 16.1% higher Q2 distribution, and its shares resumed trading. ALog Trust received a writ of summons for a claim related to damages at its ALog Cold Centre property. Wilton Resources sold 4.78% of its Indonesia-listed stake for S$3.5 million.

site_title: Singapore still considering deployment of nuclear, geothermal energy: Alvin Tan
summary: Singapore is considering the deployment of nuclear and geothermal energy to meet its goal of net-zero emissions by 2050. Minister of State for Trade and Industry Alvin Tan stated that these technologies must meet stringent safety and environmental standards, and the government is supporting research into nuclear policy and science. Geothermal energy is seen as an "attractive source" but conventional systems are not viable in Singapore. New nuclear technologies, such as small modular reactors and generation IV designs, have the potential to be safer and more efficient. The government will carefully study recommendations from the Energy 2050 Committee and calibrate plans accordingly as technologies evolve.

site_title: Wilton Resources pares stake in subsidiary to fund Indonesia project
summary: Wilton Resources has sold 742 million shares in its subsidiary Wilton Makmur Indonesia for S$3.5 million, reducing its stake from 91.34% to 86.56%. The company plans to use the proceeds to fund leaching activities, construction of a mineral processing facility, and general working capital in Indonesia.

site_title: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam says will not seek second term
summary: Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam announced she will not seek a second term, completing her 5-year term on June 30 and ending a 42-year government career. Her decision was reportedly made with family considerations, and she informed Beijing about her intentions in 2021. The city's next leader will be chosen by a 1,500-strong pro-Beijing committee on May 8, with little clarity on who will run. Lam's departure closes the chapter on a controversial 5-year term marked by Beijing's increased control and international isolation.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with a 0.85% gain, rising 187.56 points to 22,227.11, following Beijing's decision to remove a rule preventing US authorities from inspecting Chinese firms traded in New York, easing delisting concerns. Mainland Chinese markets were closed for a holiday.

site_title: Vertex Holdings back in the black with US$530.9m FY2021 profit
summary: Vertex Holdings, a venture capital firm, reported a net profit of US$530.9 million for FY2021, reversing a net loss of US$40.4 million the previous year. The company's total fair value of investments increased by 69.5% to US$2 billion, driven by unrealized gains of US$962.7 million. Revenue jumped 8,173.9% to US$79.3 million, while earnings before interest and taxes grew to US$614 million. Vertex also reported a cash holding of US$249.6 million and issued corporate bonds totaling S$450 million.

site_title: Myanmar military's beer sales tumble after junta boycott
summary: The Myanmar military's beer sales have plummeted after the Japanese brewing giant Kirin announced its exit from the country last month. The military-backed firm, Myanmar Brewery, dominated the market, but a boycott sparked by the coup has led to a significant decline in sales. Rivals Heineken, Carlsberg, and Chang have picked up market share, and establishments that still serve the beer have faced threats and vandalism. The boycott has also been met with resistance in some areas, particularly in rural regions where the brew remains popular.

site_title: Refreshed maritime sector roadmap to grow value add by S$2 billion by 2025
summary: Singapore has refreshed its Industry Transformation Map (ITM) for the sea transport sector, aiming to grow its value-add by S$2 billion by 2025. The updated plan includes developing Tuas Port into the world's largest fully automated container terminal and expanding Singapore's international maritime centre ecosystem. It also seeks to nurture the MarineTech startup ecosystem. The refreshed blueprint was announced by Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat during the opening ceremony of Singapore Maritime Week.

images.alt_text: Tuas Port, slated to be completed in the 2040s, is expected to be the largest fully automated container terminal in the world then.

site_title: Rodrigo wins new artist, Zelensky appeals for help at Grammys
summary: Olivia Rodrigo won the best new artist award at the 64th Grammy Awards, beating out Saweetie, Glass Animals, and others. In a surprise appeal, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky appeared via video to discuss the impact of Russia's invasion of his country, urging artists to support Ukraine through their music. Rodrigo, 19, performed on the Grammys stage while seated on a Mercedes hood and thanked the audience for her biggest dream come true.

site_title: Backed by Australia government, Iluka greenlights A$1b rare earths refinery
summary: Iluka Resources, backed by the Australian government, has greenlit a $1 billion rare earths refinery in Western Australia, set to begin production in 2025. The refinery, expected to cost $1 billion to $1.2 billion, will produce light and heavy rare earths crucial for tech applications. The project is part of a push by the US and allies to diversify critical minerals supply away from China. Iluka shares jumped 9% after the announcement, with the company contributing $200 million in equity towards the construction cost.

site_title: Singapore stocks little changed at Monday's open; STI down 0.01%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened little changed on Monday, down 0.01% or 0.44 point to 3,418.67, after 57.9 million securities worth S$68.8 million changed hands. Gainers outnumbered losers 86 to 42, with Singapore Press Holdings and Sembcorp Marine being actively traded. The STI is on track for a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while European shares rose 0.5% on Friday, driven by commodity-linked and bank stocks.

site_title: Hot stock: Sembmarine up 6.3% amid heavy trading
summary: Sembcorp Marine shares jumped 6.3% on Monday, reaching a high of S$0.102, amid heavy trading. The move comes after the company and Keppel Corporation said they need more time and deliberation to advance their proposed combination. The shares were previously down 4.9% after Sembmarine reported three consecutive years of pre-tax losses. Despite this, the company still meets the financial entry criteria to avoid being placed on the Singapore Exchange's watch list.

site_title: Collective efforts key in driving environmental sustainability outcomes
summary: The International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies warns of the urgent need for collective efforts to address climate change impacts, particularly in the Asia Pacific region, where 57 million people were affected by climate-related disasters in 2021. Governments, private sectors, and companies are stepping up their commitments to tackle climate change, with Singapore aiming to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050. Companies are encouraged to improve employee awareness, adopt renewable energy sources, and collaborate with suppliers to reduce carbon emissions, with Panasonic testing an in-house power generation system combining hydrogen fuel cells and solar panels to achieve carbon neutrality.

site_title: Oiltek International bags RM49.2m in new contracts for year to date
summary: Oiltek International's subsidiary in Malaysia secured RM49.2 million in new contracts for its fiscal year ending Dec 31, 2022. The contracts involve the design and fabrication of two palm oil refinery plants in Indonesia with capacities of 1,500 and 600 metric tonnes per day. The company's order book has reached a "new historical high" of RM198.1 million, with expected fulfillment over the next 18-24 months. The latest contract win marks a significant growth momentum for the company, with plans to maintain its growth momentum in edible and non-edible oil refinery and renewable energy segments.

site_title: China sends military, doctors to Shanghai to test 26m residents for Covid
summary: China has deployed the military and thousands of healthcare workers to Shanghai to conduct COVID-19 tests for all 26 million residents, marking its largest public health response since the initial outbreak in Wuhan in 2019. Over 10,000 healthcare workers have been sent from multiple provinces, with the People's Liberation Army (PLA) dispatching over 4,000 medical personnel to Hubei province earlier. The city has reported 8,581 asymptomatic and 425 symptomatic COVID cases, prompting a 2-stage lockdown and self-testing for residents. China aims to curb the outbreak while sticking to its "dynamic-clearance" policy.

site_title: Lazada's co-founder joins Revolut as its Asia-Pacific general manager
summary: Charles Debonneuil, co-founder of Lazada, has been appointed as the Asia-Pacific general manager of Revolut. Debonneuil, who oversaw Lazada's growth in the region for 6 years, will focus on building local growth teams and developing the company's growth strategy in the Asia-Pacific region. This appointment aims to get new users on board Revolut's mobile payment platform in the region.

site_title: ALog Trust trustee, property manager receive writ of summons for S$8m claim
summary: Ara Logos Logistics Trust's trustee and property manager have received a writ of summons for a claim of approximately S$8 million, including interest and costs, following damages to ALOG Cold Centre. The incident occurred when TheSeafoodCompany occupied the premises. The manager is discussing the claim with its insurers and has engaged legal counsel. The incident occurred at ALOG Cold Centre, a 2-storey cold storage warehouse in Jurong Industrial Estate. Units of ALog Trust closed 0.6% lower on Friday.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB downgrades SPH Reit to 'hold' as recovery likely priced in
summary: CGS-CIMB downgraded SPH Reit to 'hold' from 'add' as the market likely prices in the Reit's recovery, with its target price remaining at S$0.95. The Reit posted a 16.1% on-quarter increase in DPU to 1.44 Singapore cents for the fiscal second quarter, exceeding expectations. Despite this, the research team remains positive on the Reit's recovery moving forward, citing low gearing levels and potential benefits from relaxed Covid-19 restrictions.

site_title: Tesla delivers record vehicles in Q1; output falls as China shutdown weighs
summary: Tesla delivered a record 310,048 vehicles in the first quarter, exceeding analyst estimates, despite production falling due to supply chain disruptions and a China plant shutdown. The company's deliveries increased 68% from the previous year, driven by strong demand for electric vehicles. Despite production declines, Tesla's deliveries were seen as a positive sign, with analysts expecting the company to continue outperforming rivals in sales growth.

site_title: Satellite images show long trench at Ukrainian mass grave site, Maxar says
summary: Satellite images show a 45-foot-long trench at a Ukrainian mass grave site, where Russian forces withdrew from the town of Bucha. The trench was dug into the grounds of a Ukrainian church where bodies were found on the streets. Ukraine accused Russian forces of a "massacre" in the town, one of many recaptured by Ukrainian troops. The discovery comes after Russian forces regrouped for battles in eastern Ukraine.

site_title: Oil's war-driven rise won't fuel a bear market or recession
summary: Oil prices have surged due to Russia's war, but this won't necessarily lead to a global bear market or recession. The economic impact of high oil prices is nuanced, with output and consumption shifting around, rather than being crushed outright. Symbolic bans from the US, UK, and Singapore have limited economic punch, and Russia's oil exports to Europe are significant but not crucial. In fact, high oil prices can promote investment in the oil industry and even benefit renewables, making stocks less likely to be negatively affected.

site_title: Cost of living rises in India as companies pass on higher prices
summary: Indian manufacturers are passing on higher input costs to consumers due to a global supply squeeze and rising energy costs following Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Companies like Unilever, Suzuki Motor, and JSW Steel are raising prices, threatening to hurt demand just as the economy recovered from the pandemic. The cost of living is rising, with inflation remaining a concern for the second year in a row, according to Dabur India's chief financial officer. To mitigate price pressures, Dabur plans calibrated price increases and cost optimization measures.

site_title: NFTs: Are they art or artifice?
summary: Non-fungible tokens (NFTs) are a type of cryptoasset that has gained significant attention, but also raises legal concerns. NFTs are unique digital assets that can be bought, sold, and traded, but their ownership and value are often disputed. The article highlights several issues, including the lack of clear regulations, potential copyright infringement, and tax complexities. NFT buyers may not own the underlying intellectual property, and the original artist may retain ownership. Additionally, the use of fractionalized NFTs, which represent partial ownership, raises further questions about securities laws. The article concludes that new laws are necessary to address the complexities of NFT ownership and ensure fairness and justice in the digital world.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher after US gains
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index opened higher on Monday, tracking US gains, despite volatility in early trade due to Ukraine developments and China lockdowns. The benchmark index rose 0.28% or 78.49 points to 27,744.47, while the Topix index added 0.27% or 5.18 points to 1,949.45. The gains followed US market records, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh levels despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Great resignation isn't slowing and may persist, Randstad says
summary: The Great Resignation shows no signs of easing, according to Randstad's latest Workmonitor report. With a dwindling supply of workers, talented individuals are having more job options, leading to a shift in the job market. Employees are becoming more prepared to quit unhappy jobs, with one-third saying they've left due to personal life issues. Employers must personalize the work experience for each employee, and most employees feel they lack control over their work hours, with 2 in 5 unable to control their hours.

site_title: World's scramble for energy drives Australian exports to record
summary: Australia is poised to benefit from a surge in global energy prices due to the war in Europe and sanctions on Russia. The country's energy exports are expected to reach a record A$425 billion in the fiscal year to June 2022, driven by increased demand for thermal coal and metals such as copper and lithium. However, prices are likely to fall in the following year as global supply lifts and demand growth moderates. The Australian government forecasts growing demand for metals as global electric vehicle sales surge, but warns that higher global interest rates could impact the outlook.

site_title: Fashion startup Shein raising funds at US$100b value: sources
summary: Chinese fast fashion e-commerce startup Shein is reportedly raising funds at a valuation of about US$100 billion, according to people familiar with the matter. The company is in talks with potential investors, including General Atlantic, to raise about US$1 billion. Achieving the US$100 billion mark would make Shein the third most valuable startup in the world. The company has operations in Guangzhou, Singapore, and Los Angeles, and offers over 600,000 items to customers in over 150 countries.

site_title: Climate change could cost US budget US$2t a year by end century: White House
summary: The White House has released its first-ever assessment on the economic impact of climate change, predicting a 7.1% annual revenue loss, equivalent to US$2 trillion a year by the end of the century. The assessment, conducted by the Office of Management and Budget, estimates that climate-related disasters such as floods, wildfires, and droughts could cost the federal budget $25-128 billion annually. The report warns that greenhouse gas emissions will continue to rise, leading to devastating consequences if left unchecked.

site_title: Crypto players' green efforts to combat climate change
summary: The cryptocurrency industry is taking steps to combat climate change through various initiatives, including new technologies for carbon capture and removal. Companies like HyperLinq, Independent Reserve, and Babel Finance are investing in clean mining and carbon removal technologies, with the goal of reducing their carbon footprint. These efforts are expected to increase in the coming years, with industry-wide initiatives and clearer regulations in countries like the US, Canada, and Norway predicted to drive transformation.

site_title: PropNex CEO expects local demand to drive growth
summary: PropNex Realty CEO Ismail Gafoor expects strong local demand to drive growth in the Singapore real estate market in 2022. Despite market concerns and cooling measures, Gafoor predicts nearly matching 2021 volumes in HDB and private resale markets, and a rise in foreign tenants entering the rental market. The company aims to grow its market share by recruiting more agents, with plans to reach 12,000 agents, and expanding into regional markets such as Malaysia, Vietnam, and Indonesia.

site_title: Switzerland's Cold War bunkers back in vogue as Ukraine conflict rages
summary: Switzerland's Cold War-era nuclear fallout shelters, built to protect its 8.6 million residents, have gained renewed attention amid the Ukraine conflict. The shelters, which number nearly 9 million spaces, were initially conceived for nuclear attacks but now serve as a precautionary measure due to the war's proximity and geopolitical tensions. With fears of a potential attack, Swiss authorities have urged households to maintain a week's worth of food and are reviewing available shelter spots, as the country prepares for a possible emergency.

site_title: CapitaLand unit wins bids for prime residential sites in Wuhan, Chengdu for 3.5b yuan
summary: CapitaLand Development has won bids for two prime residential sites in China, totaling 3.49 billion yuan (S$748 million). The sites, in Wuhan and Chengdu, will yield 1,581 homes and are targeted at first-time buyers and upgraders. Construction is set to begin this year, lifting CapitaLand's residential pipeline to 19,139 units.

site_title: Hypergrowth Asian companies need to rethink their people strategies
summary: Hypergrowth Asian companies are facing challenges in scaling their people strategies, which can negatively impact product development and growth. Despite the region's digital economy expanding rapidly, companies often prioritize product over people, leading to a shortage of skilled managers and a lack of contextual knowledge. To overcome this, leaders must adopt a more intentional approach to learning and development, focusing on activating employees' curiosity and cultivating an environment of openness. By prioritizing people strategies, hypergrowth companies can scale sustainably and maintain a competitive edge.

images.alt_text: Practising leaders and managers need to be agile enough to address the rapidly-evolving challenges, be it economic or socio-cultural issues, in a dynamic and changing market like S-E Asia.

site_title: China promotes traditional cures as Pfizer pill alternatives
summary: China is promoting traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) as alternatives to antiviral pills like Pfizer's Paxlovid for treating COVID-19, sending herbal combinations to countries like Hong Kong and Cambodia. TCM practitioners argue that these herbal combinations can be effective against the virus by changing the body's environment, rather than targeting the virus itself. However, critics say there is no scientific evidence to support the efficacy of TCM, and Western medicine explicitly explains how active ingredients work. China has developed its own vaccines and is promoting TCM to elevate its soft-power goals and create a "Sino-centred world".

site_title: Deliveroo, FFTH deliver joy to the underprivileged
summary: Deliveroo and Food from the Heart (FFTH) teamed up for a global community-focused campaign, Full Life, to deliver meals to underprivileged families. From October 2021 to March 2022, Deliveroo employees delivered over 140,000 food items to more than 100 families. The partnership has seen a 60% increase in beneficiaries for FFTH's food pack programmes, highlighting the need for more delivery points. Deliveroo's partnership with FFTH is part of the company's commitment to supporting local communities, particularly during the pandemic.

site_title: Fintech Nium eyes more M&A deals on path to IPO
summary: Fintech Nium is exploring 3-4 potential mergers and acquisitions (M&A) deals, primarily in Latin America, as it moves towards a US initial public offering (IPO). The company, valued at US$2 billion, is looking to acquire existing companies with a clean track record and good management. Nium's M&A focus could boost its revenue, following its successful acquisitions of UK travel payments specialist Ixaris and Wirecard Forex India. The company is targeting the upwardly mobile segment in India with its branded travel cards and aims to launch its own branded travel cards in the region.

site_title: Foo Fighters win 3 Grammys, 1 week after drummer's death
summary: The Foo Fighters won three Grammy Awards on April 3, 2022, just a week after drummer Taylor Hawkins' unexpected death in Bogota. Hawkins' body was found with opioids in his system, but the cause of death remains unclear. Despite his passing, the Foo Fighters celebrated their wins for Best Rock Album, Best Rock Performance, and Best Rock Song, without Hawkins' presence at the ceremony. The band had cancelled all tour dates following Hawkins' death.

images.alt_text: The group won prizes for Best Rock Album, Best Rock Performance and Best Rock Song.

site_title: HRnetGroup's largest shareholder raises stake
summary: HRnetGroup's largest shareholder, Simco, increased its stake in the company to 78.03% after acquiring 4,204,300 shares. HRnetGroup reported record-breaking revenue of S$590.5 million in FY21, with net profit growing 41.1% to S$70.3 million. The company also facilitated 7,794 permanent job placements and placed 54,448 unique contractor headcounts for the year.

site_title: Making change work is harder than change itself
summary: The article discusses the challenges of change in the media industry, specifically in transforming The Business Times into a digital product. The author, Wong Wei Kong, notes that while the media business has changed significantly, there are still potential fault lines between different skill-sets and interests. To overcome these challenges, a clearly articulated common purpose is crucial, requiring a contest over priorities and compromises on resources and public purpose. The author also highlights the tension between journalists' affinity for traditional work and the demands of digital workflows, emphasizing the need to provide purpose and meaning to journalists as they adapt to new platforms and workflows.

site_title: Covid-hit property loans redefaulting: Moody's study
summary: A new study by Moody's Analytics found that at least 13 commercial mortgage-backed securities (CMBS) loans, which had previously gone delinquent due to the 2020 COVID-19 crash, are redefaulting. The main cause is that commercial landlords are struggling to re-lease space due to tenants' uncertainty about their future needs. This may lead to an increase in CMBS delinquency rates in the coming months. Overall, CMBS delinquency rates rose to 7.89% in February from 7.78%.

site_title: Cryptocurrencies: Just how much are they wrecking the environment?
summary: Cryptocurrency mining is energy-intensive, generating significant amounts of electronic waste and carbon emissions. However, proponents argue that the industry's environmental impact is often exaggerated, and that efforts are being made to decarbonize. Industry leaders point out that 40-50% of Bitcoin's energy consumption comes from sustainable sources, and that the mining industry is subsidizing the development of renewable energy. Some cryptocurrencies, such as Ethereum, are transitioning to more energy-efficient consensus models, which could reduce energy usage by 99%. The industry argues that its environmental impact should be framed in context, and that it is not the sole cause of environmental harm.

site_title: Time to reassess throwing our money into black boxes
summary: A growing number of investors are turning to robo-advisers to simplify their investing lives, but experts warn that relying solely on these services can be detrimental to financial security. By allocating funds to diversified portfolios, robo-advisers offer relatively low annual fees and user-friendly apps, but investors must consider their ability and willingness to take risks, as well as the robo-adviser's investment philosophy. A lack of understanding and comfort with risk can lead to premature withdrawals, missing out on potential long-term gains. Investors should instead set their own financial goals and seek guidance from reputable sources.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for April 1, 2022, reveals mixed market trends across various segments. The Capesize market showed green shoots, with the 5TC index closing at $15,460, despite poor Atlantic basin demand. Fuel prices continued to influence voyage rates, with Rotterdam and Singapore bunker prices switching premium and discount positions. The Panamax market underperformed, with limited support for the longer grain transatlantic rounds. In contrast, the Ultramax/Supramax market saw reasonable demand for backhaul cargoes, while the Handysize market gained $23,954 since March 7. The VLCC market improved, with rates rising for the 270,000mt Middle East Gulf/China route. The Suezmax market saw increased demand for tonnage, driving rates up. The Aframax market recovered, with rates rising over 16 points to close to WS150.

site_title: Singapore office S-Reits poised to benefit from positive rental momentum
summary: Singapore's office sector has seen a 2.3% quarterly growth in Grade A office rents, with rents reaching S$10.46 per square foot. This recovery is attributed to the reopening of offices, with up to 75% of office workers allowed to return to their workplaces. Office REITs, including Keppel Reit and CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust, are expected to benefit from this growth, with positive rental momentum anticipated in 2022.

site_title: Pakistan PM calls for Parliament to be dissolved, fresh elections
summary: Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan called for the dissolution of Parliament and fresh elections, citing unacceptable interference in democratic institutions. This came after the national assembly deputy speaker declined to hear a no-confidence motion against Khan's rule. Khan urged the president to form an interim government to facilitate fresh elections. The move is seen as a bid to consolidate his power and stay in office despite growing opposition.

site_title: Bosses normalise annual leave policy as borders, society reopen
summary: Singapore's public sector is rolling back its flexible annual leave policies, reverting to pre-pandemic rules as borders and society reopen. The changes, which were pandemic-era concessions, allow unused annual leave to be carried forward only into the next year, rather than being carried over or encashable. Private businesses are also normalizing their leave policies, with some allowing employees to carry forward more leave but others returning to normal rules. The move is seen as part of Singapore's transition to a "new normal" of living with COVID-19.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust should get its DPU on strong upward trajectory before revising fees
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) unitholders will vote on a fee structure revision proposal at an EGM on April 19. The new fee structure, set to take effect on June 1, may be seen as more about the trustee-manager's profit than aligning interests. Unitholders are advised to ask questions about the revision's justification and whether it is in their interests. The Securities Investors Association (Singapore) is hosting an information session to address concerns.

site_title: BT podcast: Opportunities for investors in Asian bond funds
summary: Asian bonds remain relatively stable and attractive to investors despite global inflation near record highs. Correspondent Howie Lim discusses this with Kheng Siang Ng, head of fixed income and Singapore at State Street Global Advisors. Asian central banks are not expected to follow the Fed's monetary policy, and Asian bonds are doing better than US peers. Investors can look out for themes such as inflation and tightening monetary policy, and opportunities exist within bond funds.

site_title: China builders with bond, trust obligations back in spotlight
summary: China's troubled property sector is under spotlight again as stressed developers face significant payments of US$3.1 billion on dollar and onshore public bonds, and 53.6 billion yuan in trust payments. The sector's high-yield dollar note market lost 19% in the first quarter, and the rate of payment misses is expected to be an all-time high. Embattled developers, including Evergrande, have yet to release audited results for last year, and construction work has resumed at 95% of Evergrande's projects.

site_title: Appeal dismissed for duo who cheated Singapore banks by concealing firms' foreign ownership
summary: A Singapore High Court has dismissed the appeal of two individuals, Andruew Tang You Liang and Koryagin Vadim, who were convicted of conspiracy to deceive two Singapore banks by falsely declaring the beneficial ownership of several firms. The duo, who were sentenced to 4 weeks' and 2 weeks' jail respectively, had argued that Tang was the actual beneficial owner of the companies. However, the court upheld the sentences, citing that the false declarations hindered the banks' checks and harmed their reputation, and that Tang relied on Vadim for instructions and did not have control over the companies' transactions.

site_title: Shanghai asks entire city to self-test for Covid as frustration grows
summary: Shanghai has ordered its 26 million residents to undergo two additional rounds of Covid-19 testing as public frustration grows over the city's lockdown and strict curbs. The city reported 7,788 asymptomatic cases on Sunday, with symptomatic cases rising to 438. The lockdown has disrupted daily life and businesses, with supply chains and ports experiencing congestion. China's approach of "dynamic clearance" requires testing, tracing, and central quarantine of all positive cases, testing the country's ability to curb the spread of the virus.

site_title: China removes key hurdle to allow US full access to audits
summary: China has modified a decade-long rule restricting offshore-listed firms' financial data sharing, potentially allowing US regulators to gain full access to auditing reports of most Chinese companies listed in New York. The revised draft rules will require companies to properly manage confidential information and protect national security. This move may help balance national security concerns with the needs of investors and businesses, and could end a decades-long dispute. The compromise is seen as a reversal by Beijing, which aims to bolster investor confidence and promote overseas listings.

site_title: Ukrainians, Europeans accuse Russians of committing atrocities
summary: Russian forces have been accused of committing atrocities in Ukraine, including killing 300 residents in the town of Bucha, raping and setting alight women, and targeting civilians. Ukraine has retaken control of the capital region, while senior European officials call for an investigation into potential war crimes. Missiles struck near Ukraine's southern port of Odesa, with Russia claiming to have destroyed an oil refinery and facilities used by the Ukrainian military. Talks between Russia and Ukraine to end the 5-week war are set to resume, but a draft deal remains elusive.

site_title: What do you really 'own' when you buy an NFT?
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong has announced that the country's income tax rules will consider NFT transactions. NFTs, or non-fungible tokens, are unique digital keys or property titles backed by blockchain technology. However, the ownership and value of NFTs depend on accompanying licenses that come with the sale. There are three types of licenses: personal-use only, commercial use, and no-copyright. Each license has varying restrictions, and creators must consider what they're offering to buyers. Understanding the implications of each licensing option is crucial for NFT buyers and the value of the project.

site_title: PSA expands presence at Canada's Halifax port with acquisition
summary: PSA International, a Singapore-based port group, has acquired the Fairview Cove terminal at the Port of Halifax in Nova Scotia, Canada, becoming the sole container terminal operator. This acquisition marks PSA's expansion at the Canadian port. The deal was announced on April 2, 2022, after PSA acquired Ceres Halifax, the operator of the terminal, from Japanese shipping company Nippon Yusen Kabushiki Kaisha.

site_title: Nearly 4.2 million Ukrainian refugees flee war
summary: Nearly 4.2 million Ukrainians have fled their country since Russia's invasion on Feb 24, with 4,176,401 reported by the UN in just over 5 weeks. Women and children account for 90% of those who have left, while men aged 18-60 are eligible for military call-up. Internally, 6.48 million people are estimated to be displaced, totaling over 10 million people affected by the conflict, which now accounts for around a quarter of Ukraine's population.

site_title: Strategists turn positive on China assets, citing attractive valuations, policy support
summary: Strategists have shifted their stance on China assets to positive, citing attractive valuations and policy support from the Chinese government. Despite short-term drag from COVID-19 cases and lockdowns, they expect China to outperform Asia and emerging markets in the coming months. Key indicators, such as the Institute of International Finance's note on "unprecedented capital outflows" and EPFR Global's report on steady inflows into China assets, support this optimism. Some strategists, including BlackRock and UBS, have also upgraded their stance on China equities, citing easier policies and depressed valuations.

site_title: Terry Hee, Tan Wei Han win Orleans Masters mixed doubles final for 3rd title in 6 months
summary: Terry Hee and Tan Wei Han won the Orleans Masters mixed doubles final, defeating Indonesia's Rehan Naufal Kusharjanto and Lisa Ayu Kusumawati 21-12, 16-21, 21-13. The Singaporean duo claimed their 3rd title in 6 months and 7th together, earning US$7,110. They will move on to the Korea Open, aiming to climb their world ranking from 86th, after a successful tournament in France.

site_title: Headwinds ahead for Hang Seng Index?
summary: The Hang Seng Index (HSI) experienced a decline of 5.49% in the first quarter of 2022, with the index recovering from its low of 18,200 to near 22,000. The index's performance is expected to be dampened by the ongoing pandemic situation in China and the Russia-Ukraine conflict. The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has identified US-listed ADRs of Chinese companies as not adhering to the Holding Foreign Companies Accountable Act, which may lead to further volatility in the Hong Kong market. A bearish scenario is predicted, with potential resistance levels at 22,400 and 23,800, while a bullish scenario is unlikely due to fundamental factors weighing on sentiments.

site_title: With land border finally reopened, Johor businesses hope for pick-up in 'revenge spending'
summary: Johor businesses are optimistic about a strong pick-up in sales after the land borders between Singapore and Malaysia reopened on April 1. About 33,700 people crossed the borders in the first 17 hours, with estimates of at least 400,000 people expected to use the borders within the first full week. Many retailers and business owners, including those from the Johor Bahru Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry, are hopeful of a "multiplier effect" that could spur the city's economic growth. However, some hotels and businesses have been severely impacted by the border closure and may take time to rebuild their capacity.

site_title: HRnetGroup's largest shareholder raises stake
summary: HRnetGroup's largest shareholder, Simco, increased its stake in the company to 78.03% after acquiring 4.2 million shares. Meanwhile, Olam Group's independent non-executive director, Nihal Kaviratne, acquired 133,100 shares, increasing his direct interest to 0.1%. In other transactions, Amos Group's executive chairman Kyle Shaw increased his deemed interest to 80.77%, while Tai Sin Electric's CEO Bernard Lim Boon Hock acquired 115,300 shares. These transactions highlight the ongoing changes in shareholdings among Singapore-listed companies.

site_title: Speculators' net long bets on US dollar at an 11-week high
summary: Speculators have increased their net long bets on the US dollar to an 11-week high, with a value of $16.11 billion, according to US Commodity Futures Trading Commission data. This is the highest since January 11. The US dollar has strengthened due to rising geopolitical tensions and interest rate hikes by the US Federal Reserve. The Canadian dollar has also weakened, with a 0.3% decline for the week, amid a shift in interest rate differentials favoring the US dollar.

site_title: Stressed China builders face US$11b in April payments
summary: China's stressed property developers face significant repayment challenges, with at least US$3.1 billion of payments due in April. The sector's US dollar and onshore public bonds have seen a pullback, while trust payments amount to S$11.4 billion. China's offshore bond defaults have been solely from the property sector, and the rate of payment misses is set for an all-time high. Concerns about balance-sheet transparency persist, and some embattled developers have yet to release audited results for last year. This adds to the sector's woes, with new-home sales continuing to slump.

site_title: Covid-hit property loans redefaulting: Moody's study
summary: A new study from Moody's Analytics found that at least 13 commercial mortgage-backed securities (CMBS) loans, which had previously been delinquent due to the 2020 COVID-19 crash, have redefaulted between October and March. This is largely due to commercial landlords struggling to re-lease space after tenants were lost during the pandemic, with many still experiencing lower cashflows and uncertain recovery paths. The overall CMBS delinquency rate is expected to increase in the coming months.

site_title: China finds new coronavirus subtype as daily cases exceed 13,000
summary: China reported over 13,000 new Covid-19 infections, with a new subtype of the Omicron variant detected. The subtype, isolated from a mild patient in Dalian city, does not match other coronaviruses in China or those shared globally. Most cases (around 12,000) were asymptomatic. Vice-Premier Sun Chunlan arrived in Shanghai to oversee prevention efforts, ordering officials to curb the outbreak.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: One drunken party away from poverty - alternative investments (Ep 116)
summary: BT Money Hacks explores alternative investments, defining them as assets that are not stocks or bonds. Daryl Ho, senior investment strategist, discusses the rising interest in alternatives, with high net worth individuals (HNWIs) allocating more funds to these investments. However, Ho also highlights the biggest risks of alternatives, including market volatility and liquidity issues. The conversation concludes that while alternatives may be a good option for some, they may not be suitable for all investors, and regular investors should exercise caution before investing in these assets.

site_title: Pentagon commits extra US$300m in security aid to Ukraine
summary: The US Defense Department has committed an additional $300 million in security aid to Ukraine, bringing the total US funding since Russia's invasion in February to $1.9 billion. The package includes laser-guided rocket systems, drones, and armored vehicles to bolster Ukraine's defense capabilities. The US also plans to facilitate the transfer of Soviet-made tanks from allies to Ukraine, allowing it to fire long-range artillery strikes against Russian targets. This move underscores the US commitment to Ukraine's sovereignty and territorial integrity.

site_title: Euro bulls call end to currency rout after ECB's 'regime shift'
summary: The euro has reached a 2-year high after the European Central Bank (ECB) signals a potential "regime shift" with the possibility of raising interest rates to zero by December. The ECB's dovish stance has given way to a more hawkish tone, driving yields higher and eroding negative-yielding debt. Analysts predict further gains for the euro, with some forecasting a floor at $1.10, while others see a grind lower for the currency over the course of the year.

site_title: Shanghai asks entire city to self-test for Covid as frustration grows
summary: Shanghai has ordered its 26 million residents to undergo two additional rounds of Covid-19 testing, with residents required to self-test using antigen kits on Sunday and report positive results. A nucleic acid test will be conducted citywide on Monday. The move aims to eliminate risk points and curb the spread of the epidemic. Public frustration over the city's handling of the surge is growing, with officials emphasizing the need for swift action to contain the outbreak.

site_title: Taiwan says new Covid cases won't affect reopening plans
summary: Taiwan reported 183 new domestic Covid-19 cases, bringing the total to 1,266 cases and 1 death in the first quarter of 2022. Despite the increase, Premier Su Tseng-chang stated that the "new Taiwan model" will allow for gradual reopening, with 99.7% of cases being mild or asymptomatic. Taiwan has maintained strict measures, including mandatory mask-wearing and high vaccination rates, and has not raised its alert level, confident in its ability to control the pandemic. The government plans to continue relaxing quarantine rules for arrivals.

site_title: US home refinancing dives on highest mortgage rates since 2018
summary: US home refinancing applications declined for the second straight week, with the Mortgage Bankers Association's index dropping 14.9% to a 3-year low of 1295.1. The average 30-year fixed mortgage rate surged to 4.8%, its highest level since late 2018, and is up nearly 1 percentage point since early February. Despite this, purchase applications edged up, suggesting housing demand remains strong despite higher borrowing costs.

site_title: Huawei CFO Meng Wanzhou named chairwoman in rotating role
summary: Huawei Technologies has appointed Meng Wanzhou, the company's finance chief, as chairwoman in a rotating role. Meng, the daughter of Huawei founder Ren Zhengfei, will act as the company's top leader for 6 months. She will also remain CFO and deputy chairwoman. Meng was detained in Canada from 2018 to 2021 over alleged attempts by Huawei-linked companies to sell equipment to Iran in breach of US sanctions. The move aims to optimize Huawei's internal governance structure and ensure the company's long-term prospects.

site_title: Visa changes rules for gas stations to avoid US$125 pump limit
summary: Visa is changing its rules for gas stations to allow larger transactions, quadrupling the maximum transaction amount for small-business and commercial cards to $500, effective next month. This change aims to reduce pump shutoffs for customers who face the US$125 limit. The move is part of broader changes by Visa and Mastercard to adjust fees for various transactions, including lower fees for smaller transactions and increased rates for online spending.

site_title: Tesla Shanghai plant to remain closed amid lockdown
summary: Tesla's Shanghai factory will remain closed amid ongoing lockdown restrictions in the area, contrary to earlier reports that it would resume production on April 4. Existing Covid restrictions remain in place, with employees told to stay home and abide by community orders. The factory has been extended in shutdown several times in the past week as Shanghai's 25 million residents face varying forms of lockdown. The closure affects Tesla's production plans, with the eastern half of Shanghai, where the factory is located, still under tight movement restrictions.

site_title: PSA expands presence at Canada's Halifax port
summary: PSA International has expanded its presence at Canada's Halifax port by acquiring Ceres Halifax, which operates the Fairview Cove terminal. The acquisition, completed on April 2, 2022, makes PSA the sole container terminal operator at the port, in addition to its existing Atlantic Hub terminal. This move strengthens PSA's position at the Halifax port, which is a significant hub for trade in the Canadian province of Nova Scotia.

site_title: China says not deliberately circumventing sanctions on Russia
summary: China denies deliberately circumventing sanctions on Russia, stating it's contributing to the global economy by conducting normal trade with Moscow. This comes after the EU told Beijing not to allow Moscow to work around Western sanctions imposed over its invasion of Ukraine. China's director-general of European affairs, Wang Lutong, made the statement during a virtual summit with the EU.

site_title: Europe: Commodities, banks help shares rise amid gas supply worries
summary: European shares rose 0.5% on Friday as commodity-linked and bank stocks gained, outweighing concerns about economic growth and inflation. The Russian threat to cut off gas supplies to Europe was averted, with Moscow saying it would not halt supplies until new payments are due in April. Despite worries about inflation and the war, miners and oil stocks led gains, with the Stoxx 600 index marking its first quarterly loss in 2 years last quarter.

site_title: Oil falls most in 2 years after oil stockpile release
summary: Oil prices plummeted 13% in their biggest weekly drop in two years after the US announced a 1 million-barrel-per-day release of crude oil from its Strategic Petroleum Reserve. Brent crude futures fell 0.3% to $104.39 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 1% to $99.27 a barrel. OPEC+ maintained its output target despite Western pressure, and analysts predict a looming supply shortage, citing Russian sanctions and China's lockdown.

site_title: China assets back in favour amid low valuations, Beijing's vow to support economy
summary: China assets have gained favor among strategists and asset managers due to attractive valuations and the government's commitment to supporting the economy. Despite capital outflows from China assets, particularly in the wake of Russia's invasion of Ukraine, investors are reassessing their exposure. The China government's vow to stabilize markets and implement policies to support growth has been seen as a positive development. Analysts expect China to outperform Asia and emerging markets in the coming months, with some predicting mid-teen percentage returns for the year.

site_title: Sri Lanka declares emergency after violent protests over economic crisis
summary: Sri Lanka's President Gotabaya Rajapaksa declared a nationwide public emergency amid violent protests over the country's economic crisis. Protests turned violent outside the president's residence in Colombo, with police using tear gas and water cannons to disperse crowds. At least 53 people were arrested, and 24 police personnel were injured. The move aims to maintain public order and ensure essential services. The country's economic crisis, characterized by rolling blackouts and fuel shortages, has sparked concerns about the impact on tourism and the economy.

site_title: Pakistan PM calls for Parliament to be dissolved, fresh elections
summary: Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan has called for the dissolution of Parliament and a fresh election, citing unacceptable interference in democratic institutions. Following the national assembly deputy speaker's refusal to hear a no-confidence motion, Khan advised the president to dissolve the assemblies. Khan stated that an interim government should be formed to hold fresh elections, allowing the nation to decide the future.

site_title: Appeal dismissed for duo who cheated Singapore banks by concealing firms' foreign ownership
summary: A Singapore High Court has dismissed the appeal of two individuals, Andruew Tang You Liang and Koryagin Vadim, who were convicted of conspiracy to deceive two banks by falsely declaring foreign ownership of several companies. The court upheld the sentences of 4 weeks' jail for Vadim and 2 weeks' jail for Tang, highlighting that the false declarations hindered bank checks and harmed the reputation of OCBC and Maybank Singapore.

site_title: Hong Kong expands access to Western, Chinese Covid medicines
summary: Hong Kong expands access to Western and Chinese Covid-19 medicines, distributing Pfizer's Paxlovid and Merck's Molnupiravir to doctors at no cost for high-risk patients. The move comes as the city reports a decline in daily coronavirus cases, with 3,709 new cases and 111 deaths on April 3. The expansion aims to combat the ongoing pandemic, which has killed around 8,000 people in the financial hub since late January.

site_title: Gold falls 1% after strong US jobs data, firmer dollar
summary: Gold prices fell 1% after strong US jobs data, driving the dollar higher and increasing bets on a 50-basis-point interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve in May. The data showed a 3.6% unemployment rate and accelerating wages, making gold less appealing for overseas buyers. Despite expectations of a rate hike, some analysts believe gold will remain firm due to ongoing geopolitical tensions and the ongoing Russia-Ukraine conflict.

site_title: The 1% tax that has India's crypto industry predicting chaos
summary: India's government plans to impose a 1% tax deductible at source (TDS) on all digital-asset transfers above a certain size, starting July 1, sparking concerns among the crypto industry that it will lead to a liquidity crunch and accelerate an exodus of crypto companies and workers from the country. The tax, combined with a 30% capital gains charge, threatens to disrupt the market and force high-frequency traders to curtail their trading. Industry executives and experts warn that the TDS will "bleed talent" and push trading off locally-based exchanges, potentially destabilizing the market.

site_title: China tells EU it will pursue Ukraine peace in its own way
summary: China assured the European Union that it will pursue peace in Ukraine, but on its own terms, during a virtual summit with EU leaders. Premier Li Keqiang and President Xi Jinping expressed support for negotiations, but China has refused to condemn Russia's action in Ukraine or call it an invasion. The EU urged China to help end the war and not allow Moscow to circumvent Western sanctions. China has instead forged closer ties with Russia, positioning itself as a global force. The EU and China agreed that the war threatened global security and the global economy.

site_title: Toymaker Mattel expands Mexican plant in 'nearshoring' push
summary: Mattel, the toymaker behind Mega Bloks, is expanding its Mexican plant, its largest operation, as part of its "nearshoring" strategy. The $68.3 million investment will increase the plant's capacity and employ 3,500 workers, shifting production from Asia to Mexico. The move aims to reduce transportation costs and increase competitiveness. Mattel plans to double its investment in the plant over the next five years, citing its proximity to the company's distribution center in the US. This trend of nearshoring is gaining momentum, driven by concerns over extended global supply chains.

site_title: Hong Kong's Carrie Lam says leadership election to go ahead as planned
summary: Hong Kong's chief executive Carrie Lam has confirmed the leadership election will proceed on May 8 as planned, despite media speculation of a potential delay due to the ongoing Covid-19 outbreak. The election, which will be held by a 1,500-member Beijing-backed committee, has sparked uncertainty about the city's future under Chinese rule. Lam declined to confirm whether she would seek a second term, adding to the election's uncertainty, and the nomination period will begin on Sunday.

site_title: An electric car can save you money, but only if you choose the right one
summary: Electric cars can save money, but the cost difference between an EV and a comparable combustion car is crucial. A survey of 1,000 Singaporeans found 72% consider saving money by using electricity instead of petrol as a reason to buy an electric car. A property agent, Christopher Quek, saved almost S$200 a week by switching from a combustion car to an electric BMW iX3. However, rising fuel prices may prompt others to reconsider.

site_title: Thai finance minister revokes licences for two local insurers
summary: Thai Finance Minister Arkhom Termpittayapaisith revoked the insurance licences of two companies, Southeast Insurance Pcl and Thai Insurance Pcl, controlled by billionaire Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi. The firms were in serious financial trouble due to Covid-19 claims and received no further financial support. The government will cover outstanding claims and payments. The revocation won't affect the overall insurance industry in Thailand.

site_title: US issues formal notice of record sale of oil from reserve
summary: The US Energy Department has formally announced a record sale of 1 million barrels of oil per day from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve for 6 months, starting in May, to combat soaring fuel prices amid Russia's war with Ukraine. The sale, the third in 6 months, aims to bridge the supply gap until domestic producers boost output. The reserve, currently at 568.3 million barrels, will see up to 38.5 million barrels sold through July from Texas sites and up to 31.5 million barrels sold from Louisiana sites.

site_title: Australia's largest bank to allow workers to discuss pay
summary: Australia's largest bank, Commonwealth Bank of Australia, has removed secrecy clauses on salaries in its contracts, allowing employees to discuss their pay starting April 11. This move aims to boost pay equity, but employees are advised not to pressure coworkers to discuss the topic. The bank's decision follows a similar move by its rival.

site_title: Australia to ink interim trade deal with India
summary: Australia and India will sign a free trade deal on Saturday, reducing tariffs on over 85% of Australian exports, valued at around A$12.6 billion. The agreement aims to boost exports of products such as coal, wine, and rock lobsters, and is seen as a key step towards a more extensive Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement. The deal is expected to deepen strategic ties between the two countries, particularly in counterbalancing China's growing influence. The agreement comes as Australia's conservative government trails in polls ahead of an election in May.

site_title: Will Smith resigns from film academy, says he's 'heartbroken'
summary: Will Smith has resigned from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, citing his slapping of presenter Chris Rock at the Oscars ceremony as "shocking, painful and inexcusable." He expressed regret for betraying the trust of the Academy and depriving other nominees of their celebration. Smith accepted the best actor award for his role in "King Richard" despite the incident, which occurred after Rock made a joke about his wife, Jada Pinkett Smith. The Academy will continue with disciplinary proceedings, which may lead to additional sanctions.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's directors have endorsed a proposed spin-off of the group's investment segment for a separate listing on the Singapore Exchange's mainboard. The directors believe the spin-off will bring substantial, quantifiable economic benefits to shareholders. They have recommended shareholders vote in favor of the proposal at an upcoming extraordinary general meeting on April 18. The directors concluded that the spin-off's tangible economic benefits are "clearly achievable."

site_title: US: Wall Street gains after good jobs data
summary: US equities rose on Friday after the jobs report showed 431,000 new positions and a 3.6% unemployment rate. The manufacturing sector remains struggling with high inflation. Amazon gained 0.4% after its workers in New York voted to launch the first American union. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite US-EU trade uncertainty.

site_title: Meta no longer requiring Covid-19 booster shots for staff in US offices
summary: Meta, the parent company of Facebook, has dropped its Covid-19 booster shot requirement for US office staff, aligning with CDC guidance. The company previously required boosters for office entry, but now considers them "strongly recommended." The primary vaccination requirement of a 1- or 2-shot series remains in place.

site_title: As World Cup nears, some giants won't be on the plane to Qatar
summary: Six major football teams - Italy, Colombia, Egypt, Nigeria, Sweden, and Chile - will not participate in the 2022 FIFA World Cup in Qatar due to their failure to qualify. Italy lost to North Macedonia in a playoff, Sweden was eliminated after losing to Poland, and Colombia, Chile, Nigeria, and Egypt failed to secure enough points in their qualifying groups. The remaining three spots will be filled after the final round of playoffs in June.

site_title: Private home prices grow at slower pace in Q1 after cooling measures; Q2 could remain relatively subdued
summary: Singapore's private home prices grew 0.4% in Q1 2022, the eighth consecutive quarter, but slowed from the 5% jump in Q4 2021 due to cooling measures and rising interest rates. Demand remains strong, with transaction volumes expected to rise as more projects are launched for sale. Landed properties segment led the price increase, while non-landed properties retreated 0.6%. Analysts project developers will launch 9,000 to 10,000 new private homes in 2022, with prices remaining flat or seeing slight gains of up to 3% in 2022.

site_title: Perfectly timed comeback for Watches And Wonders Geneva
summary: Watches And Wonders Geneva, a luxury timepiece trade show, made its in-person debut at the Palexpo in Geneva after a two-year hiatus due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The event saw a 31.2% increase in timepiece exports, with the Swiss Watch Federation reporting a significant recovery in the industry. The show brought together major watchmakers such as Vacheron Constantin, Franck Muller, and Patek Philippe, showcasing their latest collections. The event marks a return to normalcy for the watch industry, with world travel and border restrictions easing, allowing for increased trade and sales.

site_title: Singtel's ATN to acquire Australia telco infrastructure provider Axicom for A$3.6 billion
summary: Singtel's Australia Tower Network (ATN) has proposed to acquire Axicom, a provider of telecommunications tower infrastructure in Australia, for A$3.6 billion (S$3.7 billion). ATN's shareholders, Singtel and AustralianSuper, believe the acquisition will provide exceptional growth opportunities, resulting in a provider with a national footprint. After the acquisition, Singtel will hold an effective 18% stake in the combined business, while AustralianSuper will hold 82%. The deal aims to improve economies of scale and drive cost efficiencies in the telco sector.

site_title: STI up 0.31%; regional indices close mixed
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.31% to 3,419.11, driven by gains from Dairy Farm International, while regional markets showed mixed performance. In Asia, Japan's Nikkei 225 fell 0.56%, and Korea's Kospi closed 0.7% lower. Analysts expect continued market volatility due to the Russia-Ukraine conflict, with potential catalysts including Russia's threat to cut off gas supplies to Europe.

site_title: Ukraine conflict underscores importance of defence, principled diplomacy: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of defense and principled diplomacy in the face of global conflicts, citing the ongoing Ukraine crisis. Lee stated that Singapore must ensure its own defense capabilities and have the will to protect its home and family. He drew parallels between the Ukrainian people's determination to defend their country and the need for Singaporeans to defend their own nation, highlighting the importance of a strong sense of national identity and willingness to make sacrifices for the greater good.

site_title: How to endure the big decline in bonds
summary: The bond market has experienced its worst start to the year in decades, with investors likely to see losses in their quarterly statements. The decline is attributed to various factors, including rising interest rates and economic uncertainty. To endure this decline, investors can consider diversifying their portfolios, focusing on high-quality bonds with strong credit ratings, and exploring alternative investment options. Additionally, staying informed about market trends and adjusting investment strategies accordingly can help mitigate losses.

site_title: Microsoft's cloud business targeted by EU antitrust regulators
summary: EU antitrust regulators are questioning Microsoft's rivals and customers about its cloud business and licensing deals, potentially leading to a formal investigation. The European Commission has previously fined Microsoft 1.6 billion euros for breaching EU antitrust rules. This move comes after German software provider NextCloud, France's OVHcloud, and two other companies filed complaints about Microsoft's cloud practices. The investigation may renew scrutiny of the US software company's cloud business and licensing deals.

site_title: Can moving the body heal the mind?
summary: Research suggests that exercise can improve mental well-being by reducing anxiety, stress, and depression. Jennifer Heisz, a cognitive neuroscience expert, found that light to moderate exercise, such as walking, cycling, or swimming, can provide immediate relief from anxiety and reduce symptoms over time. High-intensity exercise may not be beneficial for those already experiencing anxiety, and gentle exercise is recommended instead. Exercise has also been shown to reduce symptoms of depression by fighting inflammation and improving mood. Heisz's personal experience with exercise also highlights its potential to help cope with mental health challenges, such as anxiety and obsessive compulsive disorder.

site_title: CGS-CIMB upgrades Japfa to 'add' on listing of China dairy unit
summary: CGS-CIMB upgraded Japfa to "add" from "hold" due to its planned listing of its China dairy unit, which could realize a valuation of up to US$730 million for shareholders. Analyst Tay Wee Kuang estimates Japfa's share price could hit S$0.81, representing a 12.5% potential upside. Japfa's China dairy unit, AustAsia Investment Holdings, is set to list on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange, with eligible shareholders receiving AustAsia shares in proportion to their Japfa holdings.

site_title: The business conference is back. Here's how to make it better
summary: The traditional corporate conference is due for a radical reassessment, prompted by the pandemic's impact on professional life. Most formal presentations should be abolished, as people are often not listening or should not be. Instead, interactive modes like Zoom calls and YouTube videos are preferred. Conference organizers should consider alternative formats, such as speed dating sessions and outside group discussions, and fewer conferences in general. This could include more conferences in desirable locations with outdoor settings. Additionally, improving conference food, such as serving diverse and appetizing options, can enhance the attendee experience.

site_title: Where are your headquarters? They are everywhere!
summary: The concept of corporate headquarters is evolving as the COVID-19 pandemic has shown that many organizations can thrive without traditional office spaces. CEOs are now considering their leaders and people as the true definition of their headquarters, regardless of location. This shift in mindset brings cultural diversity, innovation, and global leadership success. Businesses are reimagining office spaces as hubs for employees to be productive and well-being-focused, rather than solely as physical offices. Leaders must adapt to navigate global complexities and challenges, and companies that support managers to be global leaders will have a competitive edge.

site_title: Border reopenings to fill non-PMET jobs; labour market to stay tight: economists
summary: Singapore's border reopenings may ease manpower pressures, but economists say they will not alleviate the shortage of professionals, managers, executives, and technicians (PMETs). Job vacancies hit an all-time high in 2021, with 44% of newly created positions being PMET roles. Despite falling unemployment rates, economists caution that the high vacancy rate is a "not a healthy sign" due to rising inflation, potentially leading to a wage-price spiral and increased labor costs.

site_title: No Signboard closes its Esplanade outlet as Singapore reopens
summary: No Signboard, a seafood restaurant, will close its Esplanade outlet in Singapore as the country reopens its borders. The decision comes despite easing of COVID-19 restrictions, as the company believes it may take several months for travel to return to pre-pandemic levels. The closure is expected to contribute positively to the company's consolidated net tangible assets and earnings per share. No Signboard will continue to operate its other two outlets, and the closure is seen as a necessary measure to reduce operating costs amidst the current financial situation.

site_title: China's March new home prices up marginally: private survey
summary: China's new home prices rose 0.03% month-over-month in March, matching February's growth, according to a private survey. However, demand remains weak, with 53 of 100 surveyed cities reporting declines in new home prices. The slight increase is attributed to local policy easing steps and reduced Covid-19 restrictions.

site_title: Taking a step back to enjoy life
summary: Marcus Chu, ERA Realty Network's CEO, shares his experience on the importance of physical fitness in maintaining a clear mind. Twenty years ago, his high-stress job led to health issues, but after a visit to an ENT specialist, he committed to changing his habits. He now engages in regular exercise, including trail running, hiking, and cycling, which he believes keeps his mind sharp and lifestyle balanced. Chu's fitness regime is simple yet consistent, allowing him to enjoy life and maintain a work-life balance.

site_title: AGM 2022 - business as usual or time for a reset?
summary: The article discusses the upcoming Annual General Meeting (AGM) in 2022 and how companies can make it more engaging and informative for shareholders. With the pandemic changing the landscape of AGMs, companies are expected to be more prepared and responsive to shareholders' needs. To achieve this, boards should refresh their narrative by sharing lessons learned from the pandemic, highlighting their talent strategy, and discussing long-term value creation.
